site_title: Hedge fund demand is on its way up, JPMorgan survey finds
summary: Institutional investors are flocking to hedge funds this year, with about a third planning to boost allocations, up from 15% in 2018. The industry, which took its biggest annual loss since 2011, is expected to see growth due to investors seeking market-beating returns and diversification. Funds are focusing on Asia and macroeconomic strategies, with nearly half of respondents planning to increase exposure to the region. Despite concerns over crowding, style drift, and transparency, investors remain optimistic about the value propositions offered by hedge funds.

site_title: Yuan, Australian currencies gain on upbeat China factory survey
summary: A surprise improvement in Chinese factory activity, with China's PMI rising to 50.5 in March, supported the yuan and Australian dollar, boosting global investor confidence. The US dollar gained against the yen, while other currencies like the Mexican peso and South African rand also gained. Analysts say policy support is working to underpin the Chinese economy, but growth is unlikely to accelerate. The news provided a boost to emerging market currencies and helped the US dollar rise 0.15% to 110.93 yen.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks climb at open
summary: Hong Kong shares surged over 1% in the opening minutes of Monday, following data showing a pick-up in Chinese manufacturing activity last month. The Hang Seng Index rose 1.14%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased by 0.68% and 0.7%, respectively.

site_title: Making an organic expansion to paediatrics
summary: Singapore O&G's paediatrics segment continues to make losses, but CEO Ivan Lau expects revenue growth within 2-3 years, shifting the segment's contribution to the group's overall revenue mix. Despite operational losses of $487,000 in FY18, Lau believes the segment will grow as it expands its team of doctors and clinics, and considers overseas expansion through joint ventures and acquisitions. The company aims to increase its market share in obstetric care and expand its services in dermatology and cancer-related conditions.

site_title: Australia's new budget seen splashing cash in bid for votes
summary: Australia's new budget, set to be unveiled by Treasurer Josh Frydenberg, is expected to feature increased infrastructure spending, bigger personal tax cuts, and possibly cash handouts to households. The government aims to boost popularity ahead of a federal election by May 18, which opinion polls suggest it will lose. A budget surplus of around A$4 billion is anticipated, allowing for a significant increase in tax cuts, potentially worth A$6 billion. The move is seen as a last-ditch effort to win back votes and retain power, but experts warn that tax cuts may not provide a significant economic boost.

site_title: The bond market shuddered. Now we will find out if that was justified
summary: US Treasury yields dropped to a 15-month low of 2.34% amid fears of a recession, but a week of economic reports may dispel those concerns. The March jobs report and retail spending data will provide insight into the state of the economy, with Fed officials set to speak. Experts predict a soft patch in the first quarter, but no recession, with yields rising if the reports are favorable. The 10-year Treasury yield is expected to end the year at 2.5%, and a rate cut by the Federal Reserve is still unlikely.

site_title: There's no easy deal in 2019, but that's not stopping big M&A
summary: In the first quarter of 2019, nine major mergers and acquisitions (M&A) deals exceeding $10 billion were announced, but closing these transactions proved challenging due to regulatory delays, activist investors, and hostile interlopers. Institutional investors are increasingly vocal about M&A transactions, and dealmakers report that getting deals to close is more difficult than at any time since the financial crisis. Despite this, deal volumes are expected to remain strong, driven by technological disruption, particularly in the technology and financial technology sectors.

site_title: New agency launched with goal to strengthen food security and safety, from farm to fork
summary: The Singapore Food Agency (SFA) was launched on April 1, 2019, with the goal of strengthening food security and safety from farm to fork. The agency, formed by merging experts from three agencies, will address all food-related issues, including production and hygiene. 565 former Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority (AVA) officials, 219 National Environment Agency (NEA) inspectors, and 31 Health Sciences Authority (HSA) food scientists will be transferred to the new agency. The formation aims to consolidate capabilities and signal the government's commitment to food security and safety.

site_title: MSM International proposes 1-for-4 rights issue to raise S$1.5m
summary: MSM International plans to launch a one-for-four rights issue to raise approximately S$1.5 million, mainly to fund general corporate and working capital, as well as business expansion. The renounceable non-underwritten rights issue of up to 22.5 million new shares will be priced at S$0.07 apiece, representing a 30% discount to its previous trading price. The company expects 70% of the proceeds to be used for general corporate and working capital, while 30% will go towards expanding its existing business and new investment opportunities.

site_title: Disney's 'Dumbo' soars, sort of, to top North American ticket sales
summary: Disney's live-action film "Dumbo" took in an estimated US$45 million in North American theaters, falling short of the expected US$50 million opening weekend. The film, directed by Tim Burton and starring Colin Farrell, took in US$71 million overseas. It pushed "Us" down to second place and "Captain Marvel" to third spot, with US$20.5 million in North American ticket sales. The weekend's top 10 films also included "Five Feet Apart," "Unplanned," and "Hotel Mumbai."

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,240.00, up 0.84% on day
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.84% on Monday, reaching 3,240.00, with 483.4 million securities worth S$426.7 million changing hands. Gainers outpaced losers 232 to 107. Key movers included Genting Singapore, Mapletree Logistics Trust, DBS Group Holdings, and OCBC Bank, which all saw gains. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher, following Wall Street
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on April 1, 2019, following gains on Wall Street and a weak yen, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 1.45% to 21,513.15. The broader Topix index also increased 1.4% to 1,613.90.

site_title: World Bank cuts Philippines 2019, 2020 growth outlook
summary: The World Bank cut its economic growth forecasts for the Philippines to 6.4% in 2019 and 6.5% in 2020, citing a delayed budget approval and global trade slowdown. The revised forecast is within the government's 6-7% target for 2019. Domestic consumption is expected to rebound, with inflation projected to return to the central bank's 2-4% target. The reduced growth outlook reflects risks from trade tensions, a strengthening US dollar, and potential borrowing costs for infrastructure projects.

site_title: Bulls stage a strong, decisive comeback
summary: US stocks staged a strong comeback, with the S&P 500 completing its biggest quarterly gains since 2009. Despite concerns over slowing growth and interest rates, the market remains bullish. The US jobs report and Brexit crisis will test the new momentum. Economists predict US growth is slowing but not heading into recession. Interest rates remain a worry, with a potential rate hike possible if the jobs report is strong. The bulls are expected to continue their rally, with the past decade showing that a strong first quarter often leads to a successful year.

site_title: Asia lifted as Wall Street climbs on trade developments, pound sags
summary: Asian stocks rose on Monday, driven by US-China trade talks progress and Wall Street gains, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific index adding 0.35%. Factory activity in China unexpectedly grew in March, suggesting government stimulus measures are having an impact. Stocks in Australia, South Korea, and Japan also climbed. The US and China made progress in trade talks, with Washington describing them as "candid and constructive". The pound fell 0.1% after British lawmakers rejected Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal for a third time.

site_title: Joe Biden responds to kissing incident, says never acted improperly
summary: Former Nevada assemblywoman Lucy Flores accused Joe Biden of inappropriately touching her at a 2014 campaign event, claiming he smelled her hair and delivered a slow kiss to the top of her head. Biden responded, saying he never acted improperly and had offered countless expressions of affection during his public life. Biden stated he would remain a strong advocate for women's rights and ensure equality. Many Democrats, including Senators Amy Klobuchar and Bernie Sanders, expressed respect for Biden's statement, but some, like Senator Dick Durbin, urged taking allegations seriously. A new poll shows Biden as the most palatable candidate among Democrats for the 2020 presidential election.

site_title: Japan business confidence drops in April: BoJ survey
summary: Japan's business confidence among major manufacturers dropped to 12 in the April Tankan report, down from 19 in the previous quarter. The decline was attributed to a slowdown in the Chinese economy and concerns over rising crude oil prices. Economists warn that the US-led trade wars could pose a significant risk to Japan's economy, which has been struggling with deflation. This marks the third consecutive month of declining business confidence in Japan, raising concerns about the country's economic recovery.

site_title: Comedian takes lead in Ukraine presidential vote: exit polls
summary: Ukrainian comedian Volodymyr Zelenskiy took the lead in the country's presidential election, securing 30.6% of the votes in the first round, according to exit polls. Zelenskiy, who has no political experience, defeated incumbent Petro Poroshenko and former Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko, with a runoff election set for April 21. The election outcome reflects Ukraine's growing anti-establishment sentiment and dissatisfaction with the current government. Zelenskiy's campaign has been marked by its use of social media and comedy, and he is expected to face pressure to flesh out his policy agenda in the run-up to the second round.

site_title: US plans end to aid for El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras over migrants
summary: The US is cutting off aid to El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras, collectively known as the "Northern Triangle", due to President Donald Trump's direction. Around $700 million of aid will be affected, with the State Department stating it will engage Congress in the process. The move has been met with criticism from Democrats, who claim it is "immoral" and will exacerbate poverty and migration. Trump claims the countries have not done enough to prevent migration, despite the US providing $500 million in aid.

site_title: Zuckerberg calls for global Internet regulations
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg called for global Internet regulations, recommending rules on hateful content, election integrity, privacy, and data portability. He stated the company seeks overarching regulations to set baselines for prohibited content and minimize harmful content. This move comes as Facebook faces criticism over its handling of online issues.

site_title: Irony of ironies: it is the EU that is now in control of Brexit
summary: The UK's Brexit process has reached an impasse, with the EU now firmly in control. Following the rejection of Parliament's withdrawal motion, the UK must submit a proposal by April 11, which will determine the fate of Brexit. The EU has warned of a potential no-deal Brexit, and UK Prime Minister Theresa May is under pressure to come up with a workable plan. The UK may be forced to hold another referendum, general election, or accept a softer Brexit, with EU leaders set to meet on April 10 to discuss the UK's proposals.

site_title: Most PMET layoffs in 2018 were due to restructuring: Josephine Teo
summary: Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo stated that nearly two-thirds of 2018 PMET layoffs were due to restructuring. A total of 5,400 local PMETs were let go that year, the lowest level since 2014, according to Manpower Ministry data.

site_title: Turks vote in local polls marred by violence
summary: Turkish voters cast ballots in local elections marred by violence, with two party members killed in the country's southeast. President Tayyip Erdogan's ruling AK Party may lose control of capital Ankara and Istanbul, potentially dealing an electoral blow. Economic woes, including a currency crisis, have led some voters to punish Erdogan, who has ruled with an increasingly uncompromising stance for over 16 years. The elections, which began Sunday, have been marred by clashes and violence, with thousands injured and detained.

site_title: StarHub streamlines its 50 entertainment bundles to seven
summary: StarHub has simplified its entertainment bundles to seven, offering English Entertainment Pass, Movies Pass, Asian Entertainment Pass, Malay Entertainment Pass, Indian Entertainment Pass, Filipino Entertainment Pass, and Sports Pass. Customers can switch between passes online at any time. The telco also introduced a no-contract option, removed set-up box rental fees, and provides free multi-screen viewing.

site_title: More women needed for STEM jobs
summary: A Dell official states that stereotypes are the primary factor deterring women from pursuing STEM careers. A 32-year-old science graduate, Han Wen, opted for a non-profit role instead of a STEM job. This highlights the need for more women to enter the sector. No concrete solutions or statistics are provided, but the official emphasizes the role of stereotypes in discouraging women from STEM fields.

site_title: Investor Perman Hadi to grant US$2 million convertible loan to Resources Prima Group
summary: Resources Prima Group, an Indonesian coal miner, has executed an investment agreement with Perman Hadi, a US$2 million convertible loan investor. The loan may be drawn down in tranches and requires approval from the company's directors. Any expenditure exceeding US$50,000 must be approved by the investor. This investment agreement marks a significant development for Resources Prima Group, providing the company with access to additional capital to support its operations and growth plans.

site_title: Restructuring does not stop any probe into Hyflux: SIAS chief
summary: SIAS chief David Gerald clarified that restructuring at debt-ridden Hyflux will not halt ongoing investigations into the company's board and management. Gerald stated that investigations can continue without putting the company in liquidation, contradicting some investor views that restructuring would absolve them of responsibility.

site_title: 14 firms to represent Singapore at Hannover Messe tech show in Germany
summary: Singapore will be represented by 14 companies at the Hannover Messe tech show in Germany from March 31 to April 4. The companies will showcase their advanced manufacturing solutions and Industry 4.0 developments under the Singapore Pavilion. This is the second year Singapore participates in the fair, which attracts over 6,500 exhibitors and 220,000 visitors annually, resulting in 40 project leads for Singapore companies last year.

site_title: SGD bonds looking bright as economic outlook dims
summary: The Singapore dollar bond market is experiencing a rally, driven by investors' risk aversion and dimming economic outlook. Local bonds, particularly government-linked and familiar credits, are in high demand, with some issues seeing significant price increases. Longer tenors, such as the Land Transport Authority's 40-year bond, have also seen strong demand. The rally is attributed to the US Federal Reserve's dovish stance and low interest rates, which have boosted yields in the US dollar market. As a result, Singapore bond yields have fallen, making them more attractive to investors.

site_title: Mystery owner auctions US$26m of wines in HK
summary: A single-owner wine collection of nearly 17,000 bottles, including grand cru Burgundies and first-growth Bordeaux, is set to auction off for up to US$26 million in Hong Kong. The four-day sale features over 275 lots from Domaine de la Romanee-Conti, with top Bordeaux including La Mission Haut-Brion 1945 and Chateau Lafite Rothschild 1961. The collection's provenance and storage history will be easily verifiable, potentially driving up prices, with the most coveted bottles going on sale on Sunday.

site_title: UK pub chain bans mobile phones, laptops and tablets
summary: UK pub chain Samuel Smith's has banned mobile phone, laptop, and tablet use in its 200 venues, citing a desire to promote social conversation. The 261-year-old firm, which operates historic taverns, instructed employees to enforce the ban, citing a need to return to traditional pub behavior. The ban, which went into effect on March 25, aims to encourage customers to engage in face-to-face conversations. This is the latest attempt by the company to influence customer behavior, following a 2017 swearing ban.

site_title: Australia shares up on China data, Wall Street gains; NZ falls
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Monday, driven by strong Chinese data and gains on Wall Street. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached a one-week high of 6,226.20, with miners and financials leading the gains. China's factory activity unexpectedly grew in March, boosting commodity prices. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.4% due to a decline in Restaurant Brands. Investors await the Reserve Bank of Australia's policy meeting and the federal budget, which may include measures to boost the economy.

site_title: Japan's new imperial couple face heavy burden of tradition
summary: Japan's Crown Prince Naruhito, 59, faces the challenge of balancing tradition with modern values as the world's oldest monarchy. He has criticized the rigid lifestyle imposed on royals and warned of the need to remember World War II "correctly." His wife Masako has struggled to adapt to imperial life, and like his father Akihito, he emphasizes the importance of remembering Japan's early 20th-century militarism. The new imperial couple must navigate these complexities while upholding Japan's rich tradition.

site_title: GIC names new COO in management shuffle
summary: GIC appoints Tay Lim Hock as its new COO, succeeding Goh Kok Huat, who is retiring after a decade. Tay will relocate from London, while Arjun Gupta, currently president (Europe), will take on the role. Leslie Teo, chief economist, and Leslie Teo are also retiring, with new appointments to replace them. The changes aim to refresh the bench and prepare new leaders for more responsibilities, according to GIC CEO Lim Chow Kiat.

site_title: Turkey's ruling AKP candidate claims victory in tight Istanbul vote
summary: Turkey's ruling AKP candidate Binali Yildirim claimed victory in the Istanbul mayoral election with 48.71% of votes, narrowly beating his opponent Ekrem Imamoglu with 48.65%. With 98% of ballot boxes counted, the outcome was considered a dead heat. Yildirim expressed gratitude to Istanbul residents for the mandate, following a closely contested election.

summary:

These developments may impact trading of these companies' shares.

site_title: Cell phone 'Tower of Babel' highlights China e-waste problem
summary: A Chinese artist unveiled a sculpture made of discarded mobile phones resembling a cell tower in Beijing to highlight the problem of electronic waste. The sculpture, titled "Tower of Babel," aims to raise awareness about e-waste recycling and its economic value. China's e-waste is projected to reach 15.4 million tonnes by 2020, with environmental group Greenpeace launching an e-waste recycling and reduction campaign in the country. The campaign seeks to reduce mining and environmental damage by recycling valuable metals from old electronic devices.

site_title: HDB resale prices slip 0.3% in Q1: Flash data
summary: HDB resale flat prices in Singapore dropped 0.3% in Q1 2019 compared to the previous quarter, according to HDB flash estimates. The resale price index fell to 131, down from 131.4 in Q4 2018. Final figures will be released on April 26.

site_title: Japan reveals new 'era' name ahead of emperor's abdication
summary: Japan has announced its new imperial era name, "Reiwa", which translates to "harmony" and will begin on May 1 after Emperor Akihito's abdication. The name consists of two characters, "Rei" and "Wa", with meanings related to "order" and "peace". The government will explain the official meaning and English spelling shortly. The new era replaces "Heisei", which defined Akihito's 31-year reign.

site_title: Government officials call for output control at Chinese steel mills
summary: China's steel mills are under pressure to control output due to a supply glut and waning demand. The country's steel production increased 9% in the first two months of 2019, with 149.6 million tonnes produced. This has led to falling profit margins, with nearly a quarter of steel companies reporting losses in January and February. Officials call for steel mills to restrain production in accordance with China's economic development pace. Beijing has also lowered its economic growth target for 2019 to 6.0-6.5%.

site_title: Rakuten says to book 110b yen gain on Lyft investment
summary: Rakuten announced a 110 billion yen (S$1.34 billion) gain in its quarterly earnings due to its investment in Lyft's successful IPO, making it the ride-hailing firm's largest shareholder with a 13% stake. Lyft's shares rose 9% on its market debut, giving the company a market cap of around $22.2 billion. Rakuten's shares have increased 38% this year, driven by investor expectations of returns on its tech investments, including Careem and Pinterest.

site_title: China expects to make first trade in national emissions scheme in 2020
summary: China plans to launch its first trade under the national emission trading scheme in 2020, with coal-fired power utilities expected to participate. The scheme aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by encouraging utilities and manufacturers to reduce emissions through a market mechanism. China has already cut carbon intensity by 45.8% and aims to peak emissions by 2030, meeting its Paris accord commitments. The nationwide ETS will cover 100,000 industrial plants and eight billion tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions annually.

site_title: Q1 uptrend in commodities may be a tough act to follow
summary: The Bloomberg Commodity Index rose 6% in the first quarter, its best quarter in almost three years, driven by supply concerns and optimism over demand. However, the outlook for demand is now running into troubling signs, with China cutting its economic expansion goal and US growth cooling more than forecast. Analysts say commodities demand has yet to fall out of bed and supply concerns won't go away soon, but the uptrend may be a tough act to follow.

site_title: SIA Engineering, NokScoot in 63.7m baht line maintenance joint venture
summary: SIA Engineering Company and NokScoot Airlines Co formed a 63.7 million baht line maintenance joint venture in Thailand, with an initial registration capital of 63.7 million baht. SIA Engineering will hold a 49% stake, while NokScoot will hold a 51% stake. The JV will start operations at Don Mueang International Airport and expand to other key airports. The joint venture is expected to support NokScoot's growing fleet and grow SIA Engineering's international line maintenance network.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks jump on Sino-US trade talks progress, China data
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 1.14% on Monday, boosted by progress in Sino-US trade talks and China's strong factory activity data. China's manufacturing sector unexpectedly returned to growth for the first time in four months in March, indicating government stimulus measures may be gaining traction. Foreigners and institutions were net buyers of Kospi shares, with the won rising 0.18% against the US dollar. The Kospi has risen 6.17% so far this year, and MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan was up 1.05%.

site_title: New tripartite guidelines set out what constitutes wrongful dismissal
summary: New tripartite guidelines have been published outlining examples of wrongful dismissal, including discrimination, avoiding benefits payment, and false reasons. The guidelines provide clear illustrations of what constitutes wrongful dismissal, helping workers and employers navigate disputes. For example, dismissing an employee with notice after three years without paying maternity benefits or providing a legitimate reason is considered wrongful. The guidelines aim to provide clarity and consistency in employment law.

site_title: PM Lee convenes committee to review data security in public sector
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has convened a committee to review data security practices in the public sector following recent data breaches, including a recent lapse involving over 800,000 blood donors' personal information. The committee, chaired by Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean, will examine data collection and protection practices, and develop an action plan to improve data security and response to citizens. The committee will submit its findings and recommendations to the Prime Minister by November 30, 2019.

site_title: Tech startup mobilityX launches all-in-one transport app Zipster
summary: mobilityX, a Singapore-based startup, has launched the beta version of its all-in-one transportation app Zipster, providing access to MRT, buses, private-hire vehicles, shared mobility devices, and car-sharing services. The app aims to integrate journey planning, booking, and payment, allowing users to compare options and arrange trips through one platform. Zipster also features a Zipster card trial and partnerships with major transportation providers, including SMRT and Grab. The launch aligns with Singapore's Land Transport Master Plan 2040, aiming to make transportation more seamless and connected.

site_title: Solar power getting more cost-competitive in Asean
summary: A study by the Asean-German Energy Programme found that solar power can be cost-competitive with conventional energy sources in South-east Asia, particularly in Indonesia, the Philippines, and Thailand. Biomass and hydropower are currently the most cost-competitive renewable power sources, but solar PV's declining costs make it a promising option. The study recommends targeted government support, including subsidies and research grants, to encourage renewable energy development and spur growth. Solar PV has already reached grid parity in Singapore and the Philippines, and could achieve it in Thailand if equipment costs can be reduced.

site_title: Midas to be liquidated after failing to find rescuer; owes 1.9b yuan in loans
summary: Midas Holdings, a Singapore-listed aluminium train components supplier, will undergo liquidation after failing to secure a rescue deal from Hong Kong-listed CRRC Corp. The company owes 1.9 billion yuan (S$383.4 million) in loans, with an unaudited net liability position of S$47.1 million as of end-2018. Midas had previously disputed 779 million yuan of the loans, but will now liquidate its assets to settle debts. The company's subsidiaries, including Jilin Midas Aluminium Industries, will also be liquidated.

site_title: Gold slips as equities gain on trade talk progress, China data
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.1% to $1,290.98/oz, following improved investor appetite for riskier assets amid progress in Sino-US trade talks and better-than-expected Chinese economic data. US gold futures fell 0.3% to $1,294.90/oz. Factory activity in China unexpectedly grew for the first time in four months, suggesting government stimulus measures are taking hold. US President Trump expressed optimism in trade talks with China, while British Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal faced another setback.

site_title: EU agency said to have skipped 737 Max meeting in snub to Boeing
summary: The European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) skipped a meeting with Boeing to review a software update for the 737 Max, sparking concerns about the agency's influence on the review process. The update aims to prevent stall-prevention software from engaging in normal flight. EASA's snub highlights the delicate politics Boeing faces in convincing regulators that the Max is safe, with foreign agencies vowing to conduct their own rigorous analysis. The FAA's reputation has taken a hit, and EASA's determination will play a crucial role in determining the review's duration and complexity.

site_title: Japan to unveil new era name ahead of abdication
summary: Japan is set to unveil a new era name ahead of Emperor Akihito's abdication on April 30, marking the beginning of a new era under Crown Prince Naruhito. The announcement, expected to be made on Monday, will be a significant event in Japan, with special festivities and public celebrations planned. The new era name must adhere to strict guidelines, including being easy to read and write, and not starting with the first letter of any of the last four eras. The selection process involves a nine-member panel, including Nobel Prize-winning scientist Shinya Yamanaka, and is seen as a major event with potential impacts on daily life and the economy.

site_title: Reimagining Singapore's CBD
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) of Singapore has introduced the CBD Incentive Scheme to revitalize the city's Central Business District (CBD). The scheme encourages mixed-use developments, such as residential and hotel projects, to attract a broader pool of residents and transient populations. The URA aims to inject life back into the CBD, making it a more inclusive and vibrant area, with a focus on placemaking and experiential living. The plan is part of Singapore's Draft Master Plan 2019, which aims to enhance the city's status as a talent hub in the region.

site_title: Swiber Holdings signs investment agreement with NY-listed Seaspan, getting up to US$200m shot in the arm
summary: Swiber Holdings has signed an investment agreement with NY-listed Seaspan Corporation, securing up to US$200 million in funding. This deal is a significant step forward in Swiber's restructuring, which has been ongoing for over two years. The agreement modifies terms previously announced in 2018 and marks a positive development for the beleaguered marine engineering group.

site_title: Swiber Holdings signs agreement with Seaspan
summary: Swiber Holdings announced a US$200 million investment from Seaspan Corporation, a New York-listed box ship player, in the marine engineering group's restructuring efforts. This investment is seen as a "significant step forward" for Swiber, which has been in judicial management for over two years. The deal aims to support Swiber's restructuring and development.

site_title: IREIT strengthens position, looks for opportunities
summary: IREIT Global, a Singapore-listed real estate investment trust (REIT), aims to diversify its geographical spread and tenant mix to broaden its scope and build longer-term sources of income. CEO Aymeric Thibord, who has nearly two decades of experience in real estate asset management, wants to diversify the REIT's portfolio beyond its current German focus. Thibord sees diversification as a way to mitigate risks and balance yields, with France and other European markets considered as potential targets. The REIT has a strong track record, with a 7.4% total return in 2019 and a 98.6% occupancy rate.

site_title: Captain of Jass
summary: Jeremy Monteiro, captain of Jazz Association (Singapore), is dedicating half of his time to the non-profit body, which aims to grow the jazz community, develop jazz education, and strengthen cultural ties internationally. The association, now in its fourth year, has recently gained Institution of a Public Character (IPC) certification, making donations tax deductible. It has also secured international performances, including an Outstanding Performance Award at the US Jazz Education Network Conference. Jass plans to engage local communities through cultural ambassadorship and upcoming events, including a fundraising gala and the Lion City Youth Jazz Festival.

site_title: PM Lee convenes panel to conduct review of data security practices across public sector
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has convened a public sector data security review committee to examine data security practices across the entire public service following recent data breaches. The committee, chaired by Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean, will review measures and processes related to data protection and recommend steps to improve the government's protection of data. The committee will submit its findings and recommendations to the Prime Minister by November 30, 2019.

site_title: CEO pay: both an art and a science?
summary: Singapore CEOs face scrutiny over their pay, with some arguing they are overpaid. However, experts say it's a complex issue, with CEOs carrying significant personal risk and responsibility. A fair pay ratio is difficult to define, as it varies across industries and sectors. Instead of focusing on the ratio, companies should prioritize performance-based incentives and tie CEO pay to company value creation. Many CEOs argue that their compensation is tied to results, including profitability and stock price performance, and that a CEO-to-worker pay ratio is not a meaningful metric. Ultimately, a company's decision on CEO pay should be based on its specific circumstances and performance.

site_title: Pound rally forecasts pegged to Brexit deal may be too optimistic
summary: Analysts expect a 5% pound rally on a market-friendly Brexit resolution, but may be too optimistic. The pound could rise towards $1.40 by June, but a more likely outcome is a shallow follow-through after the initial knee-jerk move. A disorderly Brexit exit could prompt a free-fall mode for the pound. Despite the recent drop, the pound remains the best performer among Group-of-10 currencies this year, but remains structurally short in the cash and options markets.

site_title: Chinese airlines post mixed results for 2018
summary: Chinese airlines posted mixed results for 2018, with China Southern Airlines reporting a 3.71% decrease in net profit to 8.82 billion yuan, while China Eastern Airlines' net profit slumped 56.98% to 2.93 billion yuan. In contrast, Air China reported a 1.47% increase in net profit to 7.35 billion yuan. The industry is expected to continue growing, but faces uncertainties due to macro-economic factors, trade relations, oil prices, and exchange rate fluctuations.

site_title: Top tax lawyer Ong Sim Ho to rejoin Drew & Napier
summary: Top tax lawyer Ong Sim Ho is rejoining Drew & Napier's tax and private client services team as an equity partner on April 1, 2019. He will bring over his team of four tax lawyers and transfer his case portfolio to the firm, increasing its strength to 11. This move is seen as a boost to Drew & Napier as Singapore's enhanced tax position makes it a global wealth and investment hub.

site_title: Lower coal use cuts UK emissions to levels last seen in Victorian times
summary: The UK's carbon dioxide emissions fell to levels last seen in the Victorian era, with coal use dropping to 5% of electricity generation in 2018. This marks a 44% reduction since 1990 and is the lowest level since the 1890s. The shift away from coal is attributed to a rise in gas, wind, and solar power, with over half of the country's electricity coming from nuclear and renewables. The UK aims to quit coal for power by 2025, with transport emissions expected to be phased out by 2040.

site_title: Hyflux rebuts statements by SM Investments in SGX filing
summary: Hyflux rebutted statements made by SM Investments in a Singapore Exchange filing, denying allegations of withholding material information. The water treatment firm said SM Investments had not explained how information sought to rely on would necessitate a revision of its assessment of working capital needs. Hyflux disagreed with SM Investments' claims on the allocation in the schemes of arrangements proposed by the company, stating they had agreed on economic parameters prior to the schemes' publication. The firm expressed surprise at SM Investments' "sudden position" and alleged they were seeking to rely on information provided over two months ago.

site_title: Expect another volatile month for markets
summary: Expect another volatile month for markets as recession fears and geopolitical chaos swirl. The US yield curve inversion has stoked recession fears, while ongoing US-China trade negotiations and the UK's Brexit conundrum pose market risks. However, Singapore's real estate investment trusts (Reits) are seen as attractive, with a widening yield gap and high dividend yields. Key data releases include the official purchasing managers index and Q1 URA private home price index, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore likely to leave its exchange-rate based policy unchanged.

site_title: Apple pulls plug on AirPower wireless charging mat
summary: Apple has canceled its AirPower wireless charging mat project, citing engineering challenges. The project, announced in 2017, aimed to wirelessly charge Apple devices, including iPhones, smartwatches, and AirPods. Apple senior vice president Dan Riccio stated that the project will not achieve the company's high standards, and the future of wireless charging remains a priority. The decision marks a setback for Apple's efforts to reduce its reliance on iPhone sales, which are shifting towards digital content and services.

site_title: Teckwah to buy digital graphics print provider for S$13m
summary: Teckwah Industrial Corporation is acquiring digital graphics print provider Profoto Digital Service (PDS) for S$13 million. Profoto Malaysia, a subsidiary of PDS, will be transferred to PDS for a nominal sum. The acquisition will see Teckwah expanding its services and strengthening its presence in the digital graphics print market.

site_title: Korean Air stops serving peanuts after teens' flight disrupted by allergy
summary: Korean Air has stopped serving peanuts as snacks after two teenage brothers were removed from a flight due to a severe peanut allergy. The incident occurred when the airline refused to accommodate the allergy, despite a request to stop serving peanuts around the teens. This decision comes after the airline's history of nut-related scandals, including the infamous "nut rage" case in 2014. The company will remove peanut products and peanut ingredients from in-flight meals in several weeks, citing it as the minimum safety measure for peanut-allergy passengers.

site_title: Troubled Apple supplier Japan Display to seek funding, shares surge
summary: Japan Display, a major Apple supplier, aims to raise up to 110 billion yen in new financing as early as this week. The company, which has been struggling due to a slowdown in iPhone sales and the shift to newer display technologies, plans to issue stocks and bonds to external investors, including a potential investor group led by China Silkroad Investment Capital. This move comes after Japan Display flagged its fifth straight year of net losses in February, with shares surging as much as 16% in early trade.

site_title: Australia plans tougher social media laws for failing to thwart violent content
summary: Australia proposes a new law that could punish social media companies for failing to quickly remove violent content, with executives facing up to three years in prison and fines of 10% of their turnover. The law comes after the Christchurch mosque massacre, where a white supremacist livestreamed the killings on Facebook. The proposed law aims to hold social media companies accountable for their role in spreading violent content, with a task force to be established to tackle the issue. The law is expected to be presented to parliament next week.

site_title: 800,000 blood donors' personal data accessed illegally and possibly stolen; police investigating
summary: Over 800,000 blood donors' personal data was accessed and possibly stolen after a Health Sciences Authority (HSA) vendor, Secur Solutions Group (SSG), improperly uploaded their information to a server. Initially thought to be accessed by a foreign cyber-security expert, further investigation revealed multiple IP addresses accessed the server between October and March. SSG is cooperating with the police and HSA, and the incident is being investigated as a breach of contractual obligations. The HSA's centralised blood bank system remains secure.

site_title: RHT Health Trust appoints Paul Hoahing as CEO of trustee-manager
summary: RHT Health Trust appointed Paul Hoahing as CEO of its trustee-manager, effective April 1, 2019. He replaces Gurpreet Dhillon, who resigned on March 31, 2019. Hoahing has over 10 years of corporate finance experience, previously working at Citic CLSA Singapore and Deutsche Bank AG. The Board of RHT Health Trust's trustee manager expressed confidence in Hoahing's expertise, citing his knowledge of capital markets and corporate finance. He will also hold director positions at THR Infrastructure and THR Services.

site_title: HC Surgical named sole colorectal cancer screening provider for eligible AIA policyholders
summary: HC Surgical Specialists, a Catalist-listed medical services group, has been appointed as the sole colorectal cancer screening provider for eligible AIA Singapore policyholders aged 50 and above. The service, part of AIA Singapore's early detection screening benefit, aims to reduce the number of colorectal cancer cases through colonoscopic excision of asymptomatic benign polyps. The partnership is expected to generate additional recurring revenue for HC Surgical.

site_title: Co-owner of Russia's S7 airline dies in plane crash near Frankfurt
summary: Natalia Fileva, co-owner and chairwoman of Russia's S7 airline, died in a plane crash near Frankfurt on Sunday. A private jet, Epic-Lt, crashed while landing at Egelsbach airport, killing Fileva and the pilot. The jet, carrying two passengers, caught fire after the incident. Fileva was reportedly en route from France.

site_title: Oil prices push higher as supply worries drive gains
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, driven by supply concerns and rising US sanctions on Iran and Venezuela. Brent crude and US West Texas Intermediate futures increased 0.6% and 0.5%, respectively, to US$68.01 and US$60.46 per barrel. Analysts expect future gains to be limited by potential softness in the global economy and US oil production. Despite this, some analysts remain cautiously optimistic on crude oil prices this year, citing Opec's supply cuts and US sanctions as key factors.

site_title: Omani oil minister sees prices staying in US$65-75 range until year-end
summary: Omani Energy Minister Mohammed bin Hamad al-Rumhy expects global oil prices to remain in the $65-75 range until the end of 2019, citing the ongoing Opec+ agreement. The agreement, reached in 2018, aims to reduce oil supply by 1.2 million barrels per day for six months. If Russia were to exit the pact, oil prices could drop. Meanwhile, Oman's official selling price for crude will rise to $66.98 a barrel in May, the highest in five months.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat: Cybersecurity and how to prevent election hacking
summary: Money FM podcast "The Hot Seat: Cybersecurity and how to prevent election hacking" features an interview with F-Secure CEO Samu Konttinen, discussing ways to prevent election hacking. Konttinen shares strategies such as implementing robust security systems, conducting regular audits, and educating voters on cybersecurity best practices. He emphasizes the importance of a multi-layered approach to protect against sophisticated cyber threats. Konttinen's advice aims to empower individuals and organizations to safeguard against election hacking and ensure the integrity of the electoral process.

site_title: China calls on New Zealand to provide 'fair' investment environment
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang called on New Zealand to ensure a fair investment environment during a meeting with Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern. Ardern's government has rejected a Huawei bid to build a 5G mobile network, straining ties between the two countries. Li emphasized the importance of good relations and fair investment opportunities, while Ardern expressed her desire to discuss the decision and upgrade their free trade agreement. The meeting comes amid tensions over human rights issues in China's Xinjiang region and a recent attack on mosques in Christchurch.

site_title: Resurgent India bulls look to RBI to keep market rally going
summary: Indian markets have staged a significant comeback in March, driven by foreign investors returning to the country after tensions with Pakistan eased. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is expected to lower the benchmark repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 6% on April 4, further boosting the market rally. The yield on India's sovereign debt has fallen, attracting $2.4 billion in foreign investment, while Indian stocks have taken in $4.3 billion, making the equity-sensitive rupee the region's best performer over the past month.

site_title: Australia's Woolworths to shut 30 BIG W stores, shares climb
summary: Woolworths Group, Australia's largest supermarket chain, plans to close 30 BIG W stores over three years at a cost of A$270 million. The move aims to improve the chain's profitability amid intense competition from online shopping. Woolworths expects a one-off impairment charge of A$370 million, which will be recorded in its annual results. The company's shares rose 2.2% to an almost nine-month high following the announcement.

site_title: New Silk Road critics are 'prejudiced', China's top diplomat says
summary: China's top diplomat, Yang Jiechi, has defended the Belt and Road Initiative, saying critics are "prejudiced" and misinformed. China has never forced debt on participating countries, contrary to claims, and instead resolves debt difficulties through friendly consultations. Yang cited the lack of debt crises among participating countries, with many escaping the "no development trap". China will hold its second Belt and Road summit in April, with nearly 40 foreign leaders expected to attend, including Russian President Vladimir Putin and Pakistani Prime Minister Imran Khan.

images.alt_text: Speaking to the ruling Communist Party's official People's Daily, Yang Jiechi, who runs the party's foreign affairs committee, said he had noted that some in the international community believed this was a geopolitical tool and would only bring debt traps for participating countries.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange's shipping market report reveals a disappointing week for tanker and dry bulk markets. Capesize rates continued to languish at near historical lows, with the Baltic Capesize Index (BCI) route 5TC dropping to $3,796. The Panamax market saw a spike in transatlantic trades, but the Pacific market remained sluggish. Supramax rates lost ground, with limited support from Asian markets. Handysize rates also declined, with limited activity reported. The tanker market was similarly unimpressive, with VLCC rates continuing to slide. The Baltic Index Council announced changes to its timecharter indices to clarify the inclusion of scrubber-fitted vessels.

site_title: Singapore's first bitcoin trial highlights dangers of algorithmic trading
summary: The Singapore International Commercial Court (SICC) ruled in favor of B2C2, a digital currency trading firm, in a dispute with Quoine, a currency exchange platform. Quoine's software automatically executed trades without human intervention, resulting in a significant loss for B2C2. The court held that Quoine's mistake was not unilateral, as the programmer of B2C2's software did not have actual or constructive knowledge of the mistake. The ruling highlights the dangers of algorithmic trading and the challenges of applying the law to automated systems.

images.alt_text: The court's ruling in the dispute between market maker B2C2 and cryptocurrency exchange operator Quoine raises questions about how to determine a programmer's knowledge of complex algorithms.

site_title: Elton John joins call for boycott of Brunei-owned hotels
summary: British pop legend Elton John and actor George Clooney are calling for a boycott of nine Brunei-owned hotels due to the sultanate's new death-penalty laws for gay sex and adultery. The laws, set to be implemented starting Wednesday, have sparked widespread condemnation from politicians and celebrities worldwide. The boycott aims to send a message that such treatment is unacceptable and to put pressure on Brunei to repeal the laws. Several US lawmakers and celebrities, including former US vice president Joe Biden and actress Jamie Lee Curtis, have expressed support for the boycott.

images.alt_text: The entrance of the luxury hotel Plaza Athenee in Paris, France, 31 March 2019. British musician Elton John has joined US actor George Clooney in his calls to boycott nine luxury hotels in the world, including Le Meurice, that are owned by the Brunei wealth fund Brunei Investment Agency.

site_title: Forex firm TransferWise to sell stake in new fundraising round: sources
summary: TransferWise, a money transfer startup backed by Richard Branson and PayPal co-founders, is seeking to sell a stake in a new fundraising round valued at up to $4 billion. The company aims to raise $300 million, led by Goldman Sachs, as it shakes up the industry with lower border transfer costs. TransferWise has over 4 million customers and transfers $4 billion monthly, with a valuation of $1.6 billion after its last fundraising round in 2017.

images.alt_text: TransferWise, which was formed by Estonian duo Taavet Hinrikus and Kristo Kaarmann (pictured) in 2011, has over 4 million customers and transfers more than US$4 billion a month, according to its website.

site_title: China's factory rebound heralds improvement in global outlook
summary: China's manufacturing purchasing managers index rose to 50.5 in March, the largest increase since 2012, signaling a stabilisation in the world's second-largest economy. This rebound is seen as positive news for global investors, easing concerns about the global outlook. While domestic consumption remains uncertain, the improvement in China's economy is expected to support a stabilisation in the global economy, lifting European and US economies and potentially leading to a global asset price increase.

images.alt_text: China's first official economic gauge for March signalled a stabilisation in the world's second-largest economy, easing one of the biggest worries for the global outlook.

site_title: Missing Boeing 737 Max sensor said to be a focus of Ethiopian crash probe
summary: Ethiopian Airlines crash investigators focus on a malfunctioning sensor in the Boeing 737 Max's anti-stall system, MCAS, which was suspected to have caused the March 10 disaster. Preliminary flight data indicates the nose of the plane was pushed down due to the faulty sensor. A search of the wreckage has failed to locate the part believed to have been involved, with investigators now searching for the key piece of equipment. The finding is similar to a previous accident involving an Indonesian 737 Max.

images.alt_text: Investigators of an Ethiopian Airlines crash have concluded that the same system that malfunctioned in an earlier accident off Indonesia was activated, and they are searching for a key piece of equipment that might explain why, according to people briefed on the probe.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.35 points, or 0.14%, to 1,646.43 on Monday, with a trading volume of 54.3 million lots worth RM24.3 million. Gainers outpaced losers 146 to 30.

site_title: Australian business conditions bounce but confidence sags
summary: Australian business conditions improved in February, driven by gains in sales and profitability, with the National Australia Bank's index of business conditions rising three points to +7. However, confidence weakened, declining two points to zero. Forward-looking indicators showed some improvement, including a rise in forward orders and employment, but remained below average. The labour market remains a strong sector, but economists will continue to monitor the survey closely to assess whether the improvement is temporary or persists.

images.alt_text: A closely-watched measure of Australian business conditions rose in March led by gains in sales and profitability but confidence weakened further to stay below average.

site_title: Red Cross to distribute aid in Venezuela next month
summary: The International Red Cross plans to distribute aid in Venezuela starting mid-April, despite President Maduro's refusal to allow in US food and medical supplies. The organization aims to reach 650,000 people with aid, and its distribution will be impartial and neutral. The US welcomes the announcement, while China's delivery of 65 tons of medical aid to Caracas was seen as a victory for Maduro. The crisis in Venezuela has led to a rise in malnutrition and disease, affecting 7 million people, with the UN reporting that 24% of the population lives in dire need of humanitarian aid.

images.alt_text: Malnutrition and disease are on the rise as living conditions plummet in the oil-producing Latin American nation, which is spiraling ever deeper into economic chaos.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday, STI up 0.6% to 3,232.06
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,232.06, driven by gains in Golden Agri-Resources and other actively traded counters. The rally follows a 5-day streak, ahead of GDP data and US-EU trade talks. Investors appear to be brushing off new Trump threats, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australia PM Morrison seeks to sway voters with last-ditch cash splash
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison is making a last-ditch effort to win over voters ahead of the election with a spending spree in the upcoming budget. The Liberal-National coalition has earmarked A$9 billion for giveaways, despite trailing badly in opinion polls. The government is expected to deliver the nation's first surplus in over a decade, but it's unlikely to win a third term. Labor is vowing to match any government-announced cash handouts and increase spending for schools, hospitals, and renewable energy.

images.alt_text: With an election just weeks away and the government trailing badly in opinion polls, Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison is mounting a last-ditch effort to woo back disaffected voters with a spending spree.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise, clocking best quarter in 4 years
summary: European stocks rose, marking their best quarter in four years, despite a rejected UK Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal. The pan-European STOXX 600 index closed up 0.6% after US-China trade talks showed encouraging signals. The retail sector led gains, with a 20% surge over the last three months. Stocks in France, Germany, and Britain also rose, with Dublin's Brexit-sensitive stocks posting their best day in almost two months. The European labour market remains robust, boosting retail sales.

site_title: Private jets banned from flying out of Algeria for a month
summary: Algeria has banned all private aircraft from taking off or landing until April 30, amid weeks of anti-government protests. The move, announced after the arrest of business tycoon Ali Haddad, aims to prevent prominent individuals from fleeing abroad. The decision comes as ailing President Abdelaziz Bouteflika's mandate ends on April 28 and he has postponed elections due in April. The reason for the ban was not immediately stated, but officials are believed to be targeting individuals who may be attempting to flee the country.

images.alt_text: Algeria, which has been hit by weeks of anti-government protests, on Sunday banned all private aircraft from taking off or landing until the end of the month.

site_title: Honda says 16th US death confirmed in air bag rupture
summary: Honda Motor Co confirmed a 16th US death linked to a faulty Takata air bag inflator, resulting in metal fragments flying after a 2002 Honda Civic crash in Arizona in June 2018. The defect has led to the largest automotive recall in US history, with 56 million inflators recalled in 41.6 million vehicles. 290 injuries worldwide and 19 automakers are recalling over 100 million potentially faulty inflators. Honda had previously recalled the 2002 Civic in 2014, but the repairs were not completed due to an ownership change.

images.alt_text: Honda Motor Co said on Friday it had confirmed a 16th US death has been tied to a faulty Takata air bag inflator.

site_title: Trump says North Korea suffering, doesn't need new sanctions
summary: US President Donald Trump announced he would stop new sanctions on North Korea, citing the country's suffering under its authoritarian leader Kim Jong Un. Trump stated he valued his relationship with Kim and believed additional sanctions were unnecessary at this time. Despite this, senior administration officials vowed to maintain "maximum pressure" on North Korea until it gives up its nuclear program. Trump's decision contrasts with his stance on other US adversaries, such as Iran and Venezuela, where his administration has imposed sanctions.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump on Friday reaffirmed that he would stop new sanctions on North Korea, saying the country was suffering and he valued his relationship with its authoritarian leader Kim Jong Un.

site_title: Feb home loans shrink for first time since 2006
summary: Singapore's housing loans contracted to S$203.8 billion in February, marking the first decline since April 2006. Consumer loans grew 0.5% year-on-year, the slowest since 1991, while business lending rose 0.4% to S$407.4 billion. The private residential housing market is expected to remain subdued due to cooling measures, despite market expectations of US Federal Reserve rate hikes being unwound.

images.alt_text: From a year ago, housing loans in February continued to grow, but at its slowest yet of 1.2 per cent since BT began compiling bank lending data from 1991.

site_title: Trump threatens closure of US-Mexico border next week to stem asylum surge
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened to close the US-Mexico border next week to stem an asylum surge, potentially disrupting millions of legal border crossings and billions of dollars in trade. The move would require 750 border personnel to process asylum seekers, leading to commercial delays and longer wait times. Mexico played down the possibility, saying it would not act on threats. A shutdown could disrupt tourism, commerce, and industry, with potential losses in the billions of dollars.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump on Friday threatened to close the US border with Mexico next week, potentially disrupting millions of legal border crossings and billions of dollars in trade if Mexico does not stop immigrants from reaching the United States.

site_title: 24 director acquisitions filed & 15 stocks conduct buybacks
summary: The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) declined 0.3% over five trading sessions from March 22 to 28, with the total return for 2019 reaching 4.8%. There were 15 share buybacks, totaling S$11.0 million, led by Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation and Hong Fok Corporation. In director and substantial shareholder transactions, 24 director acquisitions were reported, with no disposals, while substantial shareholders filed 18 acquisitions and four disposals. Key transactions included First Sponsor Group's chairman Calvin Ho increasing his stake to 45.22%, and UOB-Kay Hian Holdings chairman Wee Ee Chao increasing his stake to 28.28%.

site_title: Australia to crack down on live-streaming of violent crimes
summary: Australia will introduce new legislation to prevent social media platforms from live-streaming violent crimes, following the Christchurch terror attack. The laws, modelled on existing offences, would impose penalties of up to 10% of a company's annual turnover and potential prison sentences for executives who fail to remove abhorrent material. The new legislation aims to stop social media platforms from being "weaponised" by terrorists and extremists. The laws will be introduced into parliament this week, following criticism of social media companies, including Facebook, for not removing the live-streamed video of the Christchurch attack quickly enough.

images.alt_text: Australia will legislate "tough" new laws to prevent social media platforms from being "weaponised" by terrorists and extremists who may use them to live-stream violent crimes, such as the Christchurch terror attack.

site_title: Moody's delays publishing South Africa ratings review
summary: Moody's delayed publishing a review of South Africa's debt rating, originally scheduled for Friday, without providing a reason or new release date. The rating agency rates South Africa's foreign and local currency debt at 'Baa3' with a stable outlook. The delay comes amid power crisis concerns, which some economists fear could lead to capital flight and a downgrade of the country's sovereign rating. The power crisis is a challenge for President Cyril Ramaphosa ahead of an election. Moody's is the only major rating agency to maintain a stable outlook on South Africa's debt rating.

site_title: With a piece of paper, Trump called on Kim to hand over nuclear weapons
summary: US President Donald Trump handed North Korean leader Kim Jong Un a document on February 28, 2019, calling for the transfer of Pyongyang's nuclear weapons and bomb fuel to the United States. This was the first time Trump explicitly defined denuclearization directly to Kim. The lunch between the two leaders was canceled shortly after, contributing to the collapse of their talks in Hanoi last month. The document may have played a role in the summit's failure, but neither side has publicly explained the reasons behind the collapse.

site_title: Private home price index down 0.6% q-o-q in Q1 2019: URA flash estimate
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority's (URA) flash estimate for Q1 2019 shows a 0.6% decline in private home prices, a larger drop than the 0.1% in Q4 2018. Year-over-year, prices rose 3.2%. Non-landed homes in prime areas fell 2.9% quarter-over-quarter, while landed homes rose 1.1%. Experts attribute the decline to the 2018 cooling measures, but note demand remains resilient. Predictions for the rest of the year include steady prices, with more supply entering the market.

images.alt_text: The Urban Redevelopment Authority's (URA) flash estimate for the first quarter of 2019 shows that its overall price index for private homes fell 0.6 per cent over the preceding quarter. This is a bigger decline than the 0.1 per cent quarter-on-quarter dip in the fourth quarter of 2018.

site_title: Alaska bakes under heat wave linked to climate change
summary: Alaska is experiencing a record-breaking heatwave, with temperatures soaring 25-40°F above normal in the northern half of the state. Cities like Barrow and Wainwright have seen daily record high temperatures, while the Iditarod sled dog race had to be changed due to open water on part of the route. The warming trend is linked to climate change, which has caused a decline in sea ice and Arctic ocean warming. This has affected local communities, wildlife, and the economy, with concerns about the seal population and transportation corridors.

site_title: South Korea's Moon to meet Trump over stalled North Korea talks
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in will meet US President Donald Trump on April 11 to discuss stalled denuclearization talks with North Korea and alliance issues. The meeting comes after a failed summit between Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Hanoi. The talks have stalled due to conflicting demands, with North Korea seeking sanctions relief and the US insisting on denuclearization. The meeting also addresses the cost of US troops in South Korea and North Korea's rebuilding of its missile launch site. Moon's approval ratings have reached a record low due to the stalemate with North Korea.

site_title: USDHKD is on the verge of an impending reversal to the downside
summary: The USDHKD currency pair is on the verge of a reversal to the downside, potentially breaking a 100-pip range trap. This reversal is forecasted due to several catalysts, including a stochastic oscillator reading above 80, indicating an overbought condition, and a strong resistance level at 7.8500. Prices may test the first support level at 7.8426 and potentially decline towards 7.7972 if volatility increases.

site_title: Indonesia March inflation slows to below central bank target
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate slowed to 2.48% in March, below the central bank's target range of 2.5-4.5% for the first time in three years. This marks the weakest pace of increase since late 2009. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) data indicates a slight decrease from the median forecast of 2.5%.

site_title: Corporate big fish must swim smarter, not just faster, to surf startup wave
summary: Corporate big fish must set clear, realistic goals when engaging with startups to avoid "death by pilots," a phenomenon where startups suffer from prolonged, unsuccessful product trials. Experts warn that lack of clear objectives, budget constraints, and changing business priorities can lead to startups being left hanging. To avoid this, corporations should prioritize pragmatism, transparency, and clear communication with startups, and be willing to adjust their approach as needed.

site_title: No-deal Brexit fears rise as parliament sinks May's deal
summary: UK lawmakers rejected Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal for a third time, dealing a significant blow to her government's plans for the country's departure from the European Union. The vote leaves Britain's withdrawal in turmoil, with no clear path forward, and raises concerns about a possible "no-deal" exit that could cause economic chaos. EU leaders will meet on April 10 to discuss Britain's departure, and US President Donald Trump has expressed sympathy with May, but also warned that the US is keen to sign a trade deal with Britain once it leaves the EU.

site_title: Trump takes fresh approach with long-delayed Keystone XL pipeline
summary: US President Donald Trump signed a new permission for TransCanada Corp to build the Keystone XL pipeline, replacing previous permits revoked in 2017. The pipeline, carrying 800,000 barrels of Canadian oil to US Gulf refineries, was blocked by a Montana court in 2019. Trump's move aims to advance US energy security and create jobs, despite environmental concerns. The pipeline's environmental reviews are unclear under the new approval, which follows Trump's "energy dominance" agenda and rolls back environmental regulations.

site_title: Agnes Varda, grande dame of French cinema, dies aged 90
summary: Agnes Varda, a renowned Belgian-born French filmmaker and influential figure in the New Wave movement, died at 90 in Paris. A pioneer of Left Bank Cinema, she made films focusing on ordinary people and women, earning her a reputation as a feminist voice. Varda won an honorary Oscar in 2017 and the Berlin Film Festival's lifetime achievement award. Her final film, "Agnes by Varda," was released before her passing, featuring her discussing her work and spliced extracts from earlier films.

site_title: Ride-hailing company Lyft rises in Wall Street premiere
summary: Lyft shares rose 21% on its Wall Street premiere, raising $2.3 billion in its initial public offering. The ride-hailing company opened at $87.24 and closed at $78.29, up 8.7% from its initial offering price. Despite significant revenue growth, Lyft lost $911 million in 2018 on $2.2 billion in revenues. Analysts predict the company will need to sustain double-digit revenue growth to break even. Lyft's IPO marks a turning point for the ride-hailing business and the "sharing economy," with competitors Uber and Slack also set to go public this year.

site_title: Sim Leisure Group sees 2018 profit more than quadruple to RM6.1m
summary: Sim Leisure Group, a CATALIST-listed theme park operator, reported a 4-fold increase in net profit for fiscal 2018 to RM6.1 million, driven by a surge in revenue from its two Penang theme parks, Escape Waterplay and Escape Adventureplay. Revenue more than doubled to RM21.2 million, with 185,000 visitors in 2018, a 65% increase from the previous year. The company plans to expand into new markets, including China, and expects to open its third theme park in Penang by mid-year.

site_title: China, US scramble to scrutinise details of agreement to end trade war
summary: US and Chinese negotiators are working to finalize an agreement to end the nearly year-long trade war, with a focus on matching English and Chinese-language versions of the text. US officials have complained that Chinese versions have walked back or omitted commitments made by negotiators, leading to discrepancies in the joint wording. The US is demanding China improve treatment of US intellectual property, open up market access, and agree on an enforcement mechanism. Chinese Vice Premier Liu He is due to visit Washington next week to finalize the agreement, which could resolve a conflict that has cast a shadow over the global economy.

site_title: UBS said to be mulling move to 9 Penang Rd
summary: UBS is reportedly considering relocating its Singapore office from One Raffles Quay and Suntec City to 9 Penang Road, a 352,000 sq ft office space development. The move could be one of the biggest office leasing deals in recent years if the entire development is leased. The 9 Penang Road site is located opposite Dhoby Ghaut MRT Station and will also feature 15,000 sq ft of retail space.

images.alt_text: The 10-storey project, coming up on the former Park Mall site, will have about 352,000 sq ft net lettable area of office space and 15,000 sq ft of retail space.

site_title: Oil posts biggest quarterly rise since 2009 on Opec cuts, sanctions
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Friday, posting their biggest quarterly gain since 2009, driven by US sanctions on Iran and Venezuela, as well as Opec-led supply cuts. The May Brent crude oil futures contract rose 57 US cents to settle at US$68.39 a barrel, with the June contract up 48 US cents at US$67.58 a barrel. The quarterly gain was the largest since 2009, overshadowing concerns over a slowing global economy. US sanctions on Iran and Venezuela, combined with Opec's production cuts, have boosted prices this year.

site_title: Resources Prima to seek further extension from SGX for resumption of trading proposal
summary: Resources Prima Group, a CATALIST-listed company, is seeking a six-month extension to submit its resumption of trading proposal (RTP) and to fill a vacancy in its audit and risk management committee. The company had previously been granted an extension until March 28 to meet these deadlines. Trading in the company's shares has been suspended since June 28, 2017, due to financial and business viability issues. Resources Prima aims to restructure the company and turn it around, with management having made progress in addressing concerns from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Must-watch YouTube channels for 5 kinds of cooks
summary: A YouTube creator shares their favorite channels for various types of cooks, including those who struggle with meal planning, pasta enthusiasts, and those who prefer visually appealing recipes. The channels featured are Brothers Green Eats, Pasta Grannies, Jun's Kitchen, Binging with Babish, and Bon Appétit's Gourmet Makes, offering inspiration and entertainment for cooks of all skill levels and preferences.

site_title: US, China report progress in Beijing trade talks
summary: US President Donald Trump reported progress in trade talks with China, stating that the talks were "going very well" but emphasized the need for a "great deal." The two sides made progress on issues such as intellectual property, trade secrets, and currency manipulation, but significant differences remain on enforcement and tariffs. China approved joint ventures for US banks, a step towards meeting US demands for access to China's financial services market. Talks are set to resume next week in Washington, with no timeline for completion.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said on Friday that trade talks with China were going very well, but cautioned that he would not accept anything less than a "great deal" after top US and Chinese trade officials wrapped up two days of negotiations in Beijing.

site_title: US: Trade hopes lift Wall St; S&P 500 notches best quarter since 2009
summary: US stocks closed the first quarter on a strong note, with the S&P 500 posting its best quarterly gain since 2009, rising 13.1% for the quarter. Optimism over trade talks between the US and China, which concluded in Beijing, boosted investor confidence. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 11.2% for the quarter, while the Nasdaq Composite jumped 16.5%. Despite concerns over the economy, including a modest increase in US consumer spending and a decline in quarterly earnings forecasts, the market remained upbeat, with the yield curve turning slightly positive.

site_title: SGX RegCo warns Camsing Healthcare's former independent directors
summary: SGX RegCo has warned three former independent directors of Camsing Healthcare that it will assess their suitability for appointment as a director or executive officer. The regulator has ordered Camsing Healthcare to provide explanations by April 5, 2019, on why they resigned before audit matters were resolved. This move comes after the directors considered their resignation "proper and appropriate." The warning marks an unprecedented move by the regulator.

site_title: The return of a magazine that changed culture
summary: The British magazine "The Face," which was a key cultural awakening for generations of youth, is making a comeback 15 years after its initial folding in 2004. The new iteration, led by editor Stuart Brumfitt, will initially be an Instagram account and website, with its first print issue set to appear in late summer. The magazine's new business model will focus on long-form documentaries, brand content, and e-commerce, blurring the lines between journalism and commerce. The revived publication aims to capitalize on the changing nature of subculture, where young people now communicate through their phones and social media.

site_title: Barr hints at wider release of Mueller report as Democrats fume
summary: Attorney General William Barr plans to send Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report to Congress by mid-April, possibly including damaging information about President Donald Trump, despite stripping out grand jury evidence. Democrats in Congress demand the full report, while Barr suggests he won't remove information critical of Trump or his campaign. Barr will testify before Congress in May, and Democrats threaten to request a court order to release grand jury information. The 400-page report is not publicly known, and Barr's redactions will include information about peripheral third parties.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: AMP Capital sold its 50% stake in AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit) to its joint venture partner AIMS Financial Group. AMP Capital also sold its 10.26% stake in AA Reit to AIMS Financial. TEE International secured two new engineering contracts worth S$22 million. FJ Benjamin secured an exclusive distributorship for Baume & Mercier watches in Singapore and Malaysia for three years.

site_title: Alliance Healthcare planning IPO on Catalist board
summary: Alliance Healthcare Group, a Singapore-based integrated healthcare group, plans to list its shares on the Catalist board through an initial public offering (IPO) in 2019. The IPO aims to fund business expansion, including network growth, acquisitions, and technology investments. The company reported a profit after tax of S$3.48 million in FY2018, up from S$1.74 million the previous year. Proceeds from the IPO will be used to invest in technology systems, expand pharmaceutical services, and pursue growth initiatives. The IPO is sponsored by CIMB Bank Berhad and underwritten by CGS-CIMB Securities.

site_title: Firms 'can do more to support entrepreneurial spirit to retain talent'
summary: A quarter of Asean youth want to become business owners, with only 10% interested in large corporations. To retain talent, corporations must create an environment for "intrapreneurship" with freedom and flexibility, according to experts. Large organizations can support entrepreneurial spirit by fostering innovation and providing resources, such as accelerators or incubators, for young people to experiment and develop their ideas. Corporations can also raise awareness among young people about entrepreneurship and its socio-economic impact.

site_title: US pending home sales fell by more than expected in Feb
summary: US pending home sales fell 1% in February, more than expected, suggesting a sustainable recovery may take time. The index fell 5% from a year earlier, following a 3.3% annual decline. Rising wages and lower mortgage rates are expected to support demand, while the Fed's pledge to remain patient on raising borrowing costs will keep mortgage rates at attractive levels. The data adds to a mixed picture of the US housing market, which has struggled with elevated prices and limited supply.

site_title: White House wants Fed to cut rates: advisor
summary: The White House has urged the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates to protect the US economy, with advisor Larry Kudlow stating that a rate cut is necessary as a "protective measure." Kudlow, citing President Donald Trump's view, believes the Fed's actions were "overdone" after raising rates four times in 2018. This stance contrasts with most economists and institutions, which predict a slump in US growth this year and next. The Fed recently reduced its growth projection to 2.1% for 2019 and 1.9% for 2020.

site_title: A night of martial arts mania in Tokyo
summary: One Championship held its debut event in Japan, "A New Era", at the Ryogoku Kokugikan arena in Tokyo, marking a milestone in the company's global expansion. The event featured 15 matches, including four world championship bouts and a champion-versus-champion match, with fighters from 19 countries competing. Key bouts included Angela Lee's potential first female double world championship bid and Eduard Folayang's rematch against Shinya Aoki.
