The event was a success, with One Championship CEO Chatri Sityodtong announcing plans for four events in Japan in 2020 and potentially scaling up to 12 events annually, as part of the company's massive global expansion.

site_title: New waterfront lifestyle area to open in Sentosa
summary: Sentosa is set to open Siloso Green, a new waterfront lifestyle quarter, by the end of 2019, featuring bars, food trucks, live music, and waterfront accommodation. The area will expand the island's night-time offerings, with about 30% of attractions now open until 9pm or later. The push aims to draw more visitors, particularly locals, and integrate Sentosa with the upcoming Greater Southern Waterfront district. The area will also support plans for residential, commercial, and hospitality development.

site_title: Treasuring your suppliers
summary: A business article emphasizes the importance of recognizing suppliers as valuable sources of learning and earning, rather than just as potential antagonists. It highlights how treating suppliers with respect and fairness can lead to mutually beneficial relationships, similar to those found in personal life. The article cites examples from Marks & Spencer, a company that prioritized paying suppliers immediately and sharing information to build trust and loyalty. The author concludes that recognizing the supplier-customer relationship as a two-way street, where businesses can also be suppliers to each other, can lead to great synergy and long-term success.

site_title: Asia bankers bet on follow-on offerings
summary: Asia's equity market saw a 41% decline in the first quarter, with $49.1 billion in sales, the weakest start in three years. Despite this, bankers expect follow-on offerings from companies that went public last year to boost equity sales. Companies like NIO, iQIYI, and Pinduoduo have already returned to the market, raising funds through convertible bonds. The market is expected to slow down from last year's blockbuster IPOs, but smaller IPOs and follow-on activity may provide a boost to investor confidence.

site_title: H&M stock surges as Q1 profit beats estimates on fewer discounts
summary: H&M reported a Q1 profit of 1.04 billion Swedish kronor, beating estimates of 678 million kronor, thanks to reduced clearance sales. The company's stock surged 16% as investors took advantage of "short squeezes" after years of declining sales. Despite the positive earnings report, CEO Karl-Johan Persson noted the market is still "shaky" and the company is in a "transition period." This is the seventh consecutive quarterly earnings decline for H&M.

site_title: Three key investment themes to be bullish on in 2019
summary: Global equities have rallied 10.2% in 2019, with the MSCI AC World Index on track for a third straight month of gains. Amid the exuberance, three key investment themes are bullish on for 2019: China's Big Four state-owned commercial banks, China's Internet sector, and the US semiconductor industry. Investors can consider ETFs such as the BMO Hong Kong Banks ETF, Invesco China Technology ETF, and VanEck Vectors Semiconductor ETF to tap into these opportunities, with potential upside of 30% for the Big Four banks and 30-40% for the Internet sector and semiconductor industry, respectively.

site_title: Remisier concedes front-running before executing trading instructions from defendant
summary: A Singaporean remisier, Ng Kit Kiat, has conceded that he engaged in front-running while working for a defendant, Quah Su-Ling, in a penny stocks trial. Ng had traded on information before executing orders from Quah, and even placed trades for his wife before fulfilling Quah's requests. The defense has described Ng's actions as the "worst case of front-running possible." The trial, which has already seen a third defendant plead guilty, continues on April 22.

site_title: Patrick Ang succeeds Lee Eng Beng as managing partner at Rajah & Tann S'pore
summary: Patrick Ang, 55, succeeds Lee Eng Beng, 52, as managing partner at Rajah & Tann S'pore, effective March 31. Ang will prioritize training young partners and oversee the firm's move to a new office at Marina One, adopting an open concept to enhance collaboration. He will remain as deputy managing partner and take on the role of vice-chairman of Rajah & Tann Asia, while Lee will remain as senior partner and chairman of Rajah & Tann Asia.

site_title: Look beyond the hype before booking a vacation rental
summary: As the vacation rental industry continues to evolve, experts recommend several ways to determine if a rental is genuine. Look for "Plus" designations on Airbnb, "Premier Partner" badges on HomeAway and VRBO, and pay attention to the tone of the property description. Be wary of stock images, high-dynamic-range photos, and euphemisms like "quaint" or "cosy." Virtual tours and reviews can also provide valuable insights. Additionally, check the location on a satellite map, look for timely responses to negative reviews, and type the property address into a crime-reporting site to ensure the rental is in a safe neighborhood.

site_title: SingPost fined S$300,000 for service lapses in 2018
summary: SingPost has been fined S$300,000 for lapses in service in 2018, with 20 incidents of non-compliance, including lost letters and delayed deliveries. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) cited repeated failures, including nine months of delayed local basic letters and four months of delayed registered mail. SingPost has implemented measures to improve its service standards, including hiring more staff and extending delivery slots. The authority will continue to work with SingPost to improve the quality and reliability of its postal delivery services.

site_title: Grab aims to double workforce to 3,000 by 2020
summary: Grab, a Singapore-based ride-hailing company, plans to double its workforce in Singapore to 3,000 by 2020, with its new headquarters set to be completed by the end of next year. The company will also add 1,000 technology jobs across its research and development centres globally. Grab aims to provide a public transport planner feature in its application, allowing users to plan trips using buses and trains. The firm's CEO, Anthony Tan, stated that ride-hailing is not the ultimate solution to city transport problems, and the company is focusing on serving customers through various modes of transportation.

site_title: BMW M850i xDrive review: Shark attack!
summary: BMW has revived its 8 Series model with the M850i xDrive, a luxurious two-door coupe that boasts a powerful V8 engine and all-wheel drive. The car is designed to rival high-end sports cars and grand tourers, but its high price tag and limited rear seat space may be drawbacks. Despite this, the M850i's muscular elegance, aerodynamic design, and impressive performance capabilities make it a compelling option for luxury car enthusiasts. With a starting price of $595,800, the M850i is a bold statement from BMW, putting the brand back among the luxury segment's top players.

site_title: Markets cheer the return of trade talk news
summary: US-China trade talks resumed in Beijing, sparking optimism among investors, with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin describing a "productive working dinner" with Chinese negotiators. The Singapore market closed 0.29% higher, despite concerns over weak global growth. The Straits Times Index ended flat on the week, with the threat of weak growth remaining a key concern for markets.

site_title: Russia is dumping US dollars to hoard gold
summary: Russia has quadrupled its gold reserves over a decade, with holdings rising by 1 million ounces in February, the most since November. Analysts speculate that de-dollarisation could impact the dollar's desirability, with European countries like Poland and Hungary making substantial gold purchases. Russia's central bank may import more gold to guard against geopolitical risks and US sanctions, despite concerns about affordability. Central bank buying has supported gold prices, but significant increases in Russian purchases would be needed to impact the market.

site_title: Why are US employers hung up on hiring PhDs?
summary: US tech and finance companies are increasingly requiring PhDs for top jobs, overlooking talented workers with master's or bachelor's degrees. This trend may create a segmented labor market and entice more Americans to pursue PhDs, but it also has drawbacks, such as high opportunity costs and potential psychological toll on students. Companies should consider alternative credentials, like industry-focused PhD tracks, to tap into a broader talent pool and avoid overlooking skilled workers.

site_title: SLB's Matthew Ong named president of Association of Catalist Companies
summary: Matthew Ong, executive director and CEO of SLB Development Limited, was elected as the second president of the Association of Catalist Companies (ACC), replacing founding president Phil Rickard. Danny Siaw and Terence Tea were elected vice-presidents, while Leo Peng was named Treasurer. Ong expressed gratitude to Rickard and the founding committee, stating the ACC will continue to advocate for the Catalist community and enhance the platform for its members.

site_title: Singapore market capitalisation dips slightly in March
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a 0.3% decline in March, with the Straits Times Index (STI) total market capitalization falling to S$923.6 billion. The decline was more pronounced among blue chips, with Jardine Matheson Holdings and Jardine Strategic being among the top losers. The companies' poor financial performances, including a 57% profit drop for Jardine Matheson, contributed to the slump. However, some blue-chip gainers, such as DBS Group and CapitaLand, helped to offset the decline.

site_title: PSA chairman Fock Siew Wah retiring, to be replaced by deputy
summary: PSA International's chairman Fock Siew Wah is retiring after 13 years, to be replaced by deputy chairman Peter Voser on April 1. During Fock's tenure, cargo volumes doubled and the company expanded to over 50 terminals globally. Voser, a 60-year-old former Royal Dutch Shell CEO, aims to build PSA's position in the supply chain sector, focusing on sustainability, integrity, and collaboration. Fock will remain as special adviser until July 31, and CEO Tan Chong Meng expressed confidence in Voser's ability to lead the company's growth.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ST Engineering's proposed acquisition of Newtec expands its satellite communications reach into the European broadcast and consumer space. UOB Kay Hian Research maintains a "buy" rating and raises its target price to S$4.40 due to the acquisition's strategic value and expected 5G network launch. The move is seen as more strategic than previous OEM acquisition, MRA System.

site_title: PSA, JTC to get new chairmen on Monday
summary: PSA International and several government bodies have announced personnel changes, effective Monday. Peter Voser will become the new chairman of PSA, replacing Fock Siew Wah, who steps down after 14 years. Tan Chong Meng, PSA's group CEO, will take over as chairman of industrial landlord JTC Corp. The Ministry of Trade and Industry has also shuffled boards, with Tan joining JTC and three new members appointed to its board, as well as new members to the boards of the Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore and the Energy Market Authority.

site_title: China home prices expected to rise as credit conditions improve: poll
summary: China's average residential property prices are forecast to rise 5% in 2019, up sharply from a 0.5% gain expected in the previous survey. Strong underlying demand and relaxation of home purchase restrictions in some cities are expected to support prices, despite sales slowing. Property investment is predicted to rise 7% for the year, driven by improved domestic financing conditions. The resilient property market could provide a cushion for the economy as Beijing works to revive the manufacturing sector and restore consumer confidence.

site_title: SGX RegCo warns Camsing Healthcare's former independent directors
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulatory Co. (SGX RegCo) has warned three former independent directors of Camsing Healthcare, Kenneth Chin, Maurice Tan, and Ong Wei Jin, that they will be assessed for suitability to serve as directors or executive officers. The directors resigned before audit matters were resolved, prompting SGX RegCo to request explanations by April 5. The auditors had flagged various issues for the 2019 financial year.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, exceeding expectations. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to fresh tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, citing an operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing a veteran DBS executive. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) will deepen cooperation on green finance.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.30 points to 1,643.63. Volume was 2.5 billion lots worth RM2.2 billion, with 478 gainers outnumbering 337 losers.

site_title: Global investors may spur change in China's US$13 trillion debt market
summary: Foreign investors are set to significantly impact China's $13 trillion debt market as the country's bonds are included in the Bloomberg Barclays Global Aggregate Index starting April 1. With expected inflows of $100 billion or more, foreign investors will become a major stakeholder in China's financial system, pushing for regulatory reforms. China's financial regulatory structure will need to be upgraded to accommodate the new investors' demands, including readily available hedging tools and transparent registration procedures. This change will challenge Beijing's control over borrowing costs and money flows, and the government's heavy-handed approach to managing the market may spook investors.

site_title: Tianjin Zhong Xin posts net profit of 567.8m yuan for FY2018
summary: Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical Group posted a net profit of 567.8 million yuan for FY2018, up 20% from the previous year. Revenue reached 6.4 billion yuan, driven by new products such as Qingyan Pills and Tezacef. The company declared a proposed dividend of 2.2 yuan for every 10 shares, up from 2.0 yuan in FY2017. Despite external challenges, the company aims to focus on marketing, innovation, and quality improvement in FY2019.

site_title: Is now the time to buy Boeing shares?
summary: Boeing shares have plummeted 13% since the Ethiopian Airline crash on March 10, but the company's history suggests it will recover from the 737 Max crisis. Boeing has overcome similar crises in the past, such as the 1997 production problems and the 2013 Dreamliner battery glitch, and emerged stronger. The company's ability to learn from its mistakes and adapt to changing circumstances will be key to its recovery. With the FAA working on a software fix, and other regulatory bodies potentially certifying the 737 Max themselves, Boeing is poised for a swift recovery and may even emerge stronger than before.

site_title: Rajah & Tann Singapore: Patrick Ang succeeds Lee Eng Beng as managing partner
summary: Patrick Ang succeeds Lee Eng Beng as managing partner of Rajah & Tann Singapore, effective March 31, 2019. Ang will prioritize training and mentoring young partners to take on leadership roles. The firm will also move to a new office at Marina One, adopting a more open concept to promote collaboration and efficiency. Ang, a deputy managing director, has been instrumental in driving key projects and initiatives, and has built a reputation as an eminent insolvency and restructuring lawyer globally.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.3% higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.29% to 3,212.88 on Friday, driven by a 216-165 gain-to-lose ratio. Key movers included Marco Polo Marine (-11.76%) and GSH Corporation (-3.28%), while index stocks like Genting Singapore (+0.97%) and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (+0.67%) also saw gains. The rally marked a 5-day increase ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust to divest Australia facility for A$17.25m
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) announced plans to divest its Australian facility for A$17.25 million, a 13.1% premium to its book value. The sale is expected to be completed by the first half of 2019 and won't impact FLT's net asset value or distribution per unit. The proceeds will be used for funding potential acquisitions, reducing debt, and general corporate purposes. The divestment is part of FLT's proactive asset management and portfolio rebalancing strategies, which will leave the trust with 60 properties in Australia, 17 in Germany, and 5 in the Netherlands.

site_title: 'Please, sir, I want some more': Understanding food producers
summary: The food production industry faces a complex array of issues, from non-discretionary demand to changing consumer tastes and environmental concerns. Despite potential production shortfalls due to climate change, economics, and demographics, investment avenues such as waste technology and innovative production methods exist. Companies must manage stakeholder relationships, recognize customer trends, and adapt to future demands to thrive. A comprehensive framework for analyzing food producers involves examining demand, retail channels, market structure, innovation, and environmental, social, and governance issues. By doing so, companies can ensure sustainability and drive structural demand growth.

site_title: Hyflux saga: Focus needed despite the noise
summary: The Hyflux saga, a troubled water treatment firm, has become mired in confusion due to speculation and efforts by stakeholders to secure the best deal for themselves. Despite widespread speculation, Hyflux has proposed a restructuring plan, and white knight investor SM Investments (SMI) has offered a cash investment of S$400 million. To save the company, stakeholders must focus on ensuring SMI does not walk away from its agreement and that all stakeholders, including small investors, vote in the restructuring plan. If the plan fails, Hyflux may be placed in liquidation, leaving preference, perpetual, and ordinary shareholders with nothing.

site_title: PUB gives Hyflux's Tuaspring till April 30 to cure defaults
summary: Hyflux subsidiary Tuaspring Pte Ltd (TPL) has been given an extension of its default notice period to April 30 by the national water agency PUB, subject to conditions. The extension was granted after TPL requested for more time to cure its defaults, citing financial difficulties. The extension will be rescinded if the rescue deal is terminated or if the court does not sanction any of the schemes of arrangement. PUB has also stated that it will purchase the Tuaspring desalination plant for zero dollars if the defaults are not cured, which could benefit all stakeholders involved.

site_title: CRCT, CapitaLand to divest interests in CapitaMall Wuhu
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) and CapitaLand announced the divestment of their interests in CapitaMall Wuhu to an unrelated third party for 92.7 million yuan (S$18.3 million). The transaction is based on the company's adjusted net asset value, excluding the mall's 193 million yuan valuation as of Dec 31 2018. The divestment is expected to have minimal impact on CRCT's core business and will provide financial flexibility. The sale is part of the companies' asset management strategy to optimise portfolios and enhance returns.

site_title: SingPost fined S$300,000 for service lapses in 2018
summary: SingPost has been fined S$300,000 for failing to meet quality of service standards for local and international mail delivery in 2018, including not delivering 99% of local basic letters within the CBD by the next working day. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) cited 20 incidents of non-compliance, with repeated failures involving lost letters. SingPost has implemented measures to improve service standards, including hiring more postmen and extending delivery slots, and has pledged to conduct an overall review of its operations.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower following Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating loss for H2. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, ahead of Singapore's GDP data release.

site_title: London property slide continues with biggest drop in decade
summary: London's property market continues to decline, with values dropping 3.8% year-on-year in the first quarter, the largest drop since the 2009 financial crisis. The decline is attributed to Brexit uncertainty, which has led to low consumer confidence. Despite this, a shortage of homes, record employment, and low interest rates are preventing a sharper downturn. Nationally, UK property values rose 0.2% in March, with the annual rate of change improving to 0.7% from 0.4%.

site_title: Tee International bags engineering contracts worth S$22m
summary: Tee International secured two new engineering contracts worth S$22 million, bringing its order book to S$506 million. The contracts include fit-out works for a data centre and alteration works to industrial buildings. The group's shares rose 1.7% after the announcement. Eric Phua, group deputy managing director, emphasized the company's commitment to quality works and timely project execution.

site_title: Grab to double Singapore staff to 3,000 in latest expansion
summary: Grab, South-east Asia's largest ride-hailing company, plans to double its staff in Singapore to 3,000 by 2024, as it prepares to move into new headquarters. The company has signed an 11-year lease for a 42,310 sqm building in Singapore, with a five-year renewal option. Grab, which has 6,000 employees globally, is also adding 1,000 technology jobs across its research and development centers in Asia and the US. The move comes after Grab raised $4.5 billion from investors to become a one-stop shop for on-demand services in the region.

site_title: Shinvest Holding flags first half-year loss
summary: Shinvest Holding, a precision manufacturer, expects to report a net loss for the first half of fiscal 2019 due to the disposal of its GD Tech H K stake, increased provision for accounts receivable, and the US-China trade war's impact on the economy. The company will provide more details when it announces its unaudited financial results on April 14.

site_title: JTC awards Tuas industrial site to sole bidder Transmare-Chemie
summary: JTC awards a 4,456 sqm industrial site in Tuas South Link 3 to sole bidder Transmare-Chemie for S$2.05 million, with a 20-year tenure and gross plot ratio of 1.4. The project completion date is 5 years. Another industrial site at Jalan Papan will not be awarded due to a single bid below the reserve price.

site_title: F J Benjamin lands exclusive distributorship for Baume & Mercier watches in Singapore, Malaysia
summary: F J Benjamin Holdings has secured an exclusive distributorship for Baume & Mercier watches in Singapore and Malaysia, effective April 1, for a three-year period with the possibility of a two-year extension. The luxury watch brand, founded in 1830, will be supported by F J Benjamin for daily operations, sales, and marketing. This partnership aims to strengthen Baume & Mercier's brand awareness in the two markets, with Nash Benjamin, CEO of F J Benjamin, expressing delight at the opportunity.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices rise for second month, up 1.3% in Feb
summary: Hong Kong home prices rose 1.3% in February, the second consecutive month, as solid demand eased expectations for a further interest rate hike. The price gain was higher than expected, with property consultancy Knight Frank now forecasting a 5% drop in home prices this year, down from its previous 10% forecast. Analysts disagree on the market's trajectory, with some predicting a 5-7% rise, while others expect a correction. The rebound follows a 28-month price rise streak from August to December last year.

site_title: PUB accedes to Tuaspring's request to extend default notice period
summary: National water agency PUB has agreed to extend the default notice period for Hyflux subsidiary Tuaspring Pte Ltd to April 30, subject to conditions. The extension was requested by Tuaspring to cure its defaults, which PUB initially served on March 5. The decision allows Hyflux to seek financial support from SM Investments, but creditors are still scheduled to vote on the rescue plan on April 5, with SMI's endorsement now uncertain. If defaults are not cured, PUB can take control of the Tuaspring desalination plant for zero dollars.

site_title: Singapore bank lending up 0.2% in Feb: MAS preliminary data
summary: Singapore bank lending increased by 0.2% in February, reversing a slight contraction in January, according to preliminary data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Total lending rose 3.3% year-over-year, stronger than the 3.2% gain in January. Loans stood at S$672 billion in February, up from S$671 billion the previous month.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,218.36, up 0.46%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.46% to 3,218.36, driven by gains from DBS Group Holdings, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank. The Straits Times Index moved up 14.78 points, with 441 million securities changing hands. The rally follows a 0.4% gain on Thursday, despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views. Gainers outnumbered losers 186 to 115, with Netlink NBN Trust and CapitaLand also seeing significant gains. The market is on pace for a positive week ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally as blockbuster quarter draws to close
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday, ending the week on a positive note, despite a downgrade of US growth and concerns over the global economy. Investors focused on the next round of top-level China-US trade talks, with China making concessions on intellectual property. The US 10-year Treasury yield rose, providing stability, and risk assets were supported by a dovish Fed and improving geopolitical sentiment. Markets in Shanghai, Hong Kong, Tokyo, and other cities surged, while the dollar rose against the yen.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start day with a gain
summary: Hong Kong shares opened with a 0.13% gain, rising to 28,812.64 on the Hang Seng Index. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased, adding 0.19% and 0.28% respectively. The gains come as investors focus on China-US trade talks in Beijing, putting an end to a week of positive trading.

site_title: The Brexit day that wasn't leaves Britain counting the cost
summary: Brexit uncertainty continues to mount in the UK, with companies spending millions on preparations that may be rendered obsolete due to the ongoing delay. Companies such as HSBC and GlaxoSmithKline have invested tens of millions of pounds, while smaller businesses like Plastribution Ltd are facing significant costs due to warehouse space shortages. The government is also incurring costs, including £46.6 million to bring vital goods into the UK, despite the lack of a clear departure date. Some businesses, however, are seeing a surge in inquiries and profits from worst-case planning, and the outcome of the vote on Friday may have little impact on trade flow.

site_title: Huawei profit up 25% in 2018 despite US pressure
summary: Huawei reported a 25% increase in net profit to 59.3 billion yuan in 2018, despite US pressure over espionage fears. The company's overall revenue grew 19.5% and its consumer business surged 45%. Despite a 1.3% decline in its carrier business, Huawei remains a leading manufacturer of 5G equipment and a crucial player in the global rollout. The company's rotating chairman, Guo Ping, vowed to "shake off outside distractions" and reiterated that Huawei poses no security risk, while hinting at its market dominance.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 7.03 points to 1,648.36. Volume reached 19.95 million lots worth RM8.47 million, with 120 gainers surpassing 48 losers.

site_title: Indonesia central bank to buy "sizeable amount" of government bonds from market: official
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, plans to buy a "sizeable amount" of government bonds from the market to stabilize the rupiah, which has been affected by concerns over global growth. The rupiah was trading at 14,235 per dollar, little changed, and the yield on Indonesia's 10-year government bond was at 7.683%, its highest in a week. This move aims to support the currency and alleviate market volatility.

site_title: AMP Capital completes sale of AA Reit management rights, stake to AIMS Financial
summary: AMP Capital has completed the sale of its 50% stake in AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit) management rights and 10.26% stake in AA Reit to AIMS Financial Group. The transaction, which includes changes to the Reit's management entities' names, was initially delayed due to a disagreement between the parties. AIMS Financial Group becomes the sole owner of the management companies and holds a 17.88% stake in AA Reit, with AMP Capital retaining a put option to acquire its shares.

site_title: Penny stocks trial: Remisier concedes front-running trading instructions from defendant Quah
summary: A remisier testified in the penny stocks trial, conceding that he received front-running trading instructions from defendant Quah Su-Ling. The remisier, Ng Kit Kiat, stated that market information shared between brokers and clients could artificially inflate share prices. This testimony comes on the fourth day of the joint trial for Quah and John Soh Chee Wen, who face charges of market manipulation and deception.

site_title: Wirecard sues FT over investigative reports
summary: German payments company Wirecard is suing the Financial Times over investigative reports that it claims misrepresented business secrets, leading to billions of dollars in market value loss. Wirecard alleges that the FT's reporting was based on a law firm's probe of whistleblower allegations, which found local staff in Singapore may have committed financial crimes, but not to a material extent. Wirecard seeks a halt to the incorrect use of business secrets and damages, following the FT's revelations that wiped billions off Wirecard's market value.

site_title: Alliance Healthcare Group eyes Catalist listing in Singapore
summary: Alliance Healthcare Group, a Singapore-based integrated healthcare group, plans to list its shares on the Catalist board in 2019 to fund business expansion. The group, led by Barry Thng, aims to expand its network of GP clinics, specialist care services, and medical facilities in Singapore, as well as pursue growth through acquisitions and joint ventures. Proceeds from the IPO will also be used to invest in technology systems and develop a digital medical platform. The company's profit after tax increased to S$3.48 million in FY2018, up from S$1.74 million a year ago.

site_title: US apartment vacancy rate flat at 4.8% in first quarter: Reis
summary: The US apartment vacancy rate remained flat at 4.8% in the first quarter, according to Reis Inc. Only 15 of 79 metros experienced an increase in vacancy, primarily due to high construction exceeding net absorption. National average asking rent and effective rent rose 0.5% from the previous quarter. Net absorption fell 21.6% to 37,159 units, while new construction dropped 40.6% to 33,276 units. Despite low levels, Reis expects this year to see more apartment units added than last year, which saw 254,000 units added.

site_title: Sim Leisure Group sees 2018 profit more than quadruple to RM6.1m
summary: Sim Leisure Group, a Catalist-listed theme park operator, reported a fourfold increase in net profit for fiscal 2018 to RM6.1 million (S$2.0 million) from RM1.3 million the previous year. Revenue rose to RM21.2 million, driven by contributions from its two theme parks in Penang, Escape Waterplay and Escape Adventureplay. The company expects to expand into new markets, including China and other Asean cities, with plans to open its third theme park in Penang and a theme park in Linyi, China.

site_title: UK consumers hold their nerve in Brexit storm: GfK
summary: British consumers maintained their confidence levels in March, with the GfK consumer confidence index holding at -13, despite concerns over Brexit. Strong employment and wage growth helped consumers spend, but business investment was hit by Brexit uncertainty. The European Commission's version of the GfK data showed British consumer morale fell to its lowest level since 2013. Prime Minister Theresa May announced her resignation once a Brexit deal is secured, but the deal's passage remains uncertain.

site_title: URA tenders Tan Quee Lan Street site; postpones one-north Gateway site launch to June
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched the tender for a 99-year leasehold site on Tan Quee Lan Street, with a potential yield of up to 580 residential units. The tender, part of the first half 2019 GLS programme, will close on September 5. In another move, the URA has postponed the launch of the one-north Gateway site to June to review planning parameters and tender conditions. The site's launch was initially scheduled for this month.

site_title: US, China resume trade talks in Beijing after 'productive working dinner'
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer met with Chinese officials in Beijing, marking the first face-to-face talks in weeks. The meeting follows a "productive working dinner" on Thursday and comes as the US seeks to resolve the trade dispute with China. US President Trump has imposed tariffs on $250 billion of Chinese imports, while China has pledged to expand market access for foreign banks and securities companies. Talks are ongoing, with White House adviser Larry Kudlow saying the US may drop some tariffs if a deal is reached.

site_title: Tan Chong Meng named new JTC chairman; more board changes at JTC, CCCS, EMA
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry appointed Tan Chong Meng as the new chairman of JTC Corporation, effective April 1. Dr Loo Choon Yong steps down after a term that ends on March 31. Tan, former executive vice president at Shell Downstream, brings over 20 years of experience in sales, marketing, and operations. Three new members were also appointed to JTC's board, including John Lim Hua Ern and Mok Wei Wei.

site_title: US lawsuit filed against Boeing over Ethiopian Airlines crash
summary: A US federal court lawsuit was filed against Boeing on Thursday, alleging that the company's 737 Max aircraft had a defectively designed automated flight control system. The lawsuit, filed by the family of a Rwandan citizen who died in the March 10 Ethiopian Airlines crash, claims Boeing failed to warn the public, airlines, and pilots of the allegedly erroneous sensors. The crash, which killed 157 people, occurred five months after a Lion Air crash in Indonesia that killed 189 people, leading to the grounding of the 737 Max worldwide.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

A penny stocks trial concluded with an OCBC Securities remisier conceding to front-running trading instructions from a defendant. Grab plans to double its staff in Singapore to 3,000 by next year. Banking data showed a 0.2% increase in lending in February, reversing a contraction in January. SingPost was fined S$300,000 for service lapses in 2018. The Ministry of Trade and Industry appointed Tan Chong Meng as JTC Corporation chairman and made other board changes. Singapore stocks closed 0.3% higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,212.88.

site_title: Vietnam's Q1 GDP growth at 6.79% y-o-y vs 7.45% growth in Q1 last year: govt
summary: Vietnam's Q1 GDP growth slowed to 6.79% y-o-y, down from 7.45% in the same period last year. The processing and manufacturing industry grew 8.63%, while services rose 6.50% and agriculture increased 2.68%. This marks a decrease from last year's 7.08% growth, but still within the government's target of 6.6-6.8% for the year.

site_title: Japan's factory output rises, unemployment stays low
summary: Japan's factory output rose 1.4% in February, a modest increase after a 3.4% dip in January, according to the trade and industry ministry. Unemployment remains at a record low 2.3%, with the jobs-to-applicants ratio at 1.63. While the economy is showing signs of recovery, experts warn that weak exports and a Chinese economic slowdown could impact growth. The government forecasts a rise in March and April, but analysts will closely monitor economic indicators to determine if the economy is on the verge of a downturn.

site_title: Europe: Shares give up gains as banks weigh amid concerns on growth, Brexit
summary: European shares ended lower, despite initial optimism over US-China trade talks, as banks weighed on the market amid concerns over global economic growth and Brexit uncertainty. The Stoxx 600 index fell 0.1%, while Frankfurt's DAX index declined 0.08%. Economic data showing US growth slowed more than expected further weighed on the market. However, healthcare stocks and tech companies like Capgemini rose, and the FTSE 100 gained 0.6% due to a weaker pound.

site_title: Nations must help economic 'roadkill': Buffett
summary: Warren Buffett emphasized the need for wealthy countries to care for those who become "roadkill" in a changing economy. He acknowledged that some workers and companies inevitably become obsolete, but argued that rich countries have an obligation to support those affected. Buffett expressed support for free trade, but noted that its benefits can be detrimental to older workers who cannot retrain or relocate. He praised General Motors' plans to create new jobs, despite criticizing President Trump's reaction to the plant closures.

site_title: Malaysia may seize RM48m from Jho Low's father: Edge report
summary: Malaysia is set to seize approximately RM48 million from bank accounts of Low Hock Peng, father of fugitive financier Jho Low, under the country's anti-money laundering and anti-terrorism financing act. The funds are believed to have originated from 1Malaysia Development Bhd, a state investment company. Authorities have previously seized a mansion linked to the Low family in connection to 1MDB investigations. Low has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing, and his legal team claims the action is a "strategy of harassment and political persecution".

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher tracking rallies in US market
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, tracking rallies in the US market. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 1.06% to 21,256.40, while the Topix index gained 0.86% to 1,596.37. The relatively cheap yen against the dollar also boosted investor sentiment.

site_title: New Singapore registry can protect names of geographically unique products
summary: Singapore has established a new registry to protect the names of geographically unique agricultural products, including cheeses and cured meats. The Registry of Geographical Indications (GI) at the Intellectual Property Office of Singapore will start receiving applications from April 1. This registry aims to provide consumers with information about unique product characteristics and enhance protection for producers and traders of GI products. The move follows the European Union-Singapore Free Trade Agreement and is expected to bring more high-quality wines, spirits, and agricultural products to Singapore's food shelves.

site_title: US performs first kidney transplant from living donor with HIV
summary: US surgeons at Johns Hopkins University successfully performed the world's first kidney transplant from a living HIV-positive donor to another patient with the same virus. The operation took place on Monday and was announced on Thursday, with donor Nina Martinez stating she's feeling good after the surgery. This breakthrough marks a significant medical advancement in organ transplantation for individuals with HIV/AIDS.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday's open; STI up 0.67% to 3,225.01
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.67% to 3,225.01 at open on Friday, following overnight US market gains. The index had a heavy trading volume of 41.2 million securities worth S$126.3 million. Key gainers included DBS Group Holdings (up 0.8%) and OCBC Bank (up 0.6%), while Singtel rose 1% and Genting Singapore fell 1%. The rally marks the fifth consecutive day of gains, ahead of upcoming GDP data.

site_title: Brazil ex-President Temer charged in graft case linked to meatpacker JBS
summary: Former Brazilian President Michel Temer has been formally charged with corruption, accused of using a middleman to procure a bribe from JBS SA, the world's largest meatpacker. The charges stem from a 2017 incident where a JBS executive was caught with a suitcase of cash, and plea-bargain testimony implicated Temer and other politicians. Temer denies the charges and was released after a petition by his lawyers. He faces allegations of running a vast criminal enterprise seeking bribes for public works projects, and his lawyer claims the charges are "devoid of any foundation."

site_title: WTO confirms US failed to fully comply over Boeing subsidies
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) ruled that the US failed to fully comply with a 2012 order to halt subsidies to Boeing, a partial victory for Airbus and the EU. The WTO found billions of dollars in subsidies to Boeing in Washington State and South Carolina to be non-compliant with the 2012 ruling. Both the EU and the US claimed victory, with the EU stating the US had continued to subsidize Boeing despite WTO rulings, while the US denied providing comparable subsidies to Airbus. The WTO has no power to enforce compliance, but can approve retaliatory measures to pressure trade manipulators.

site_title: Ocean heat hits record high: UN
summary: The United Nations reported that ocean heat hit a record high in 2018, further emphasizing the threat of global warming to marine life. The World Meteorological Organization confirmed the last four years as the hottest on record, surpassing previous provisional drafts. This development raises concerns about the impact of climate change on ocean ecosystems.

site_title: Oil near flat, shrugs off Trump calls for Opec to boost output
summary: Oil futures were near flat on Thursday after recovering from a session low following US President Donald Trump's call for Opec to boost crude output. US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures dropped 11 cents to settle at $59.30 a barrel, but later rallied above pre-tweet levels. Trump's tweet urged Opec to increase oil flow due to fragile world markets, but oil prices showed little reaction, shrugging off the call.

site_title: Federal Reserve bank president downplays recession fears, stresses flexible Fed policy
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of New York President John Williams downplayed recession fears, stating the economy is likely to experience 2% GDP growth and continue adding jobs, despite a yield curve inversion signaling investors expect lower interest rates. Williams believes the probability of a recession this year or next year is not elevated relative to any year. The inversion, a historical precursor to recessions, occurred for the first time since 2007, but Williams remains optimistic about the economy's prospects.

site_title: Lyft IPO sets rollout for ride-hailing, sharing economy
summary: Lyft is raising $2.5 billion in its initial public offering (IPO), valuing the company at at least $20 billion. The ride-hailing firm will trade on the Nasdaq exchange under the symbol LYFT, with an expected share price of $72 per share. Lyft aims to play a growing role in the $1 trillion US transport sector, but analysts warn that competition is growing and investment may be risky. The company's IPO comes ahead of a hotly anticipated offering from larger rival Uber and other tech startups.

site_title: Wells Fargo says CEO Tim Sloan to step down 'immediately'
summary: Wells Fargo CEO Tim Sloan is stepping down "effective immediately" due to pressure from critics following a series of lapses by the bank. Sloan, who led the company since 2016, will leave the board and retire on June 30. Interim CEO Allen Parker will oversee an external search for a new chief. Sloan touted reforms, but the bank remains under a Federal Reserve asset cap imposed after a fake accounts scandal. Democratic Senator Elizabeth Warren praised the decision, saying Sloan "should have been fired a long time ago."

site_title: Resources Prima wants another 6-month extension for trading resumption proposal
summary: Resources Prima Group, a CATALIST-listed company, is seeking a six-month extension to submit its resumption of trading proposal (RTP) and to fill a vacancy in its audit and risk management committee. The company had previously been granted an extension until March 28 to submit the proposal. Trading in the company's shares has been suspended since June 28, 2017, due to financial and business viability issues. Resources Prima aims to restructure the company and turn it around, and management has made progress in addressing concerns raised by the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Big steps forward to cultivate better market conduct and boost confidence
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has released a report detailing its enforcement actions against market intermediaries from December 2018 to December 2019, resulting in fines, convictions, and warnings. A recent trial began for the alleged mastermind of a market manipulation scheme that artificially inflated share prices, causing a $8 billion market value loss. The Singapore authorities have taken steps to boost regulatory framework and transparency, including releasing an enforcement report every 18 months, to cultivate better market conduct and confidence in the financial markets.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mind Your Business: EDB's 2019 game plan for Singapore
summary: The Economic Development Board (EDB) of Singapore released its 2019 game plan, aiming to sustain the country as a leading global hub for business and investment. In a podcast discussion, EDB's managing director Chng Kai Fong discussed the strategies, which include investing in key sectors such as biotechnology and digital economy. The EDB plans to promote Singapore's business-friendly environment and enhance its competitiveness globally.

site_title: Ohmyhome enters private property market
summary: Ohmyhome, a Singapore-based property purchase and rental platform, has expanded into the private property market. The company now offers a free platform for buyers and sellers to manage transactions, saving on agent commission. Ohmyhome has facilitated over 2,300 HDB resale transactions since its launch in 2016. The company has introduced a tech-enabled full agent service, and plans to expand to Malaysia in May 2019, its first overseas market. This expansion aims to offer a wider selection of properties to customers and increase its reach.

site_title: Stocks to watch: HPL, Sim Leisure, OneApex, China Kangda, International Cement
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

Several Singapore companies announced new developments that may impact trading on Friday. Hotel Properties Ltd (HPL) entered a joint-venture agreement with Tokyo Tatemono to acquire a hotel and condominium units in Japan. Sim Leisure Group posted a fourfold rise in net profit to RM6.1 million in fiscal 2018, driven by increased revenue from its theme parks. OneApex Ltd acquired a 51% stake in OneWealth Development for S$338,000. China Kangda Food Company reversed a loss to post a net profit of 5.64 million yuan. International Cement Group halted trading pending an announcement of new plant locations.

site_title: Pound falls on Brexit 'labyrinth'
summary: The British pound fell on Thursday due to ongoing Brexit chaos, with sterling dropping over one percent against the dollar and losing ground against the euro. Despite this, London's stock market rose as investors benefited from the weaker currency. British Prime Minister Theresa May will attempt to push through her Brexit plan on Friday after failing to break the deadlock with MPs. Analysts say there is no clear way out of the Brexit impasse, with no-deal prospects resurfacing. Meanwhile, top Chinese and US negotiators held trade talks in Beijing, with hopes for a deal to end the tariffs row.

site_title: May's Brexit resignation pledge fails to garner MPs' support
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May has failed to gain MPs' support for her Brexit compromise withdrawal agreement, despite offering to resign if it passes. Parliament rejected all eight alternative options, and the EU is preparing for a no-deal Brexit. The UK has until April 12 to either pass the deal, request a delay, or exit without a deal. Markets have remained relatively stable, but business leaders are concerned about the impact of a no-deal Brexit, with the British Chamber of Commerce warning of "mass disruption to businesses and communities."

site_title: Shell offers UK customers cheaper power tariffs
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc offers UK customers a fixed-rate power-supply tariff of £970 (S$1,732) a year, undercutting Bulb Energy's deal of £981. This move is part of Shell's rebranding of its UK utility business and aims to provide customers with more flexible, controllable, and cleaner energy options. Shell plans to invest US$2 billion annually in its new-energies division to become the world's biggest power company within 15 years, posing significant competition to traditional utility energy suppliers.

site_title: US: Stocks gain as bond yields stabilise
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.4% to 25,717.46, as 10-year US Treasury yields stabilized after a week of decline. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also advanced 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively. Investors welcomed the stabilization of bond yields, which had raised concerns about slowing economic growth. Trade talks between the US and China resumed in Beijing, with no immediate deal in sight, and the Commerce Department downgraded the US GDP growth estimate for the final quarter of 2018 to 2.2%.

site_title: Fuss-Free Living
summary: A Singaporean family of six has created a minimalist home with a stylish and functional design. The three-storey house, designed by architect Robin Tan, features an open layout, cross-ventilation, and ample storage. The family, who values simplicity and low maintenance, has incorporated natural materials such as wood and marble into the design. The home's weatherproof features and movable screens allow for optimal ventilation and light control. With a focus on functionality and minimal clutter, the family's home is a testament to the power of minimalism in everyday life.

site_title: Venezuela: Maduro regime strips Guaido of public office
summary: Venezuela's Auditor General's office has stripped opposition leader Juan Guaido of the right to hold public office for 15 years, a move aimed at politically sidelining him. This decision follows Guaido's recognition as Venezuela's interim president by the US and 50 other countries. The ruling by Auditor General Elvis Amoroso was announced on state television, marking another effort by President Nicolas Maduro's regime to undermine Guaido's authority. The move is seen as a significant escalation in the ongoing power struggle between the Maduro and Guaido factions.

site_title: Brexit is not really about making Britain imperial again
summary: Brexit is not driven by nostalgia for a lost empire, contrary to popular theory. Polls show that many British voters, especially older generations, remain proud of the empire, but this nostalgia did not play a significant role in the 2016 referendum. Instead, the main reason given by "leave" voters was the principle of taking decisions in the UK. The Brexit vote is more closely linked to growing disillusionment with globalization and the EU, as well as a desire for greater control over the country's politics and economy. Many Brexiteers, such as Jacob Rees-Mogg, advocate for free trade and free markets, rather than imperialist policies.

site_title: Aussie household wealth sees largest decline in seven years
summary: Australia's household wealth declined 2.1% in the final quarter of 2018, the largest drop in seven years, due to a slump in property and stock markets. Land and property values fell for a fourth consecutive quarter, while pension funds were hit by stock market losses. The decline in wealth is pushing up debt ratios, with mortgage debt reaching a four-year high. The Reserve Bank is expected to ease interest rates soon, with money markets pricing in almost two quarter-point cuts. The decline reinforces the need for tax relief and extra spending in the upcoming federal budget.

site_title: South-east Asian galleries set their sights on HK fair
summary: South-east Asian galleries are showcasing their works at Art Basel Hong Kong, highlighting the region's growing presence in the art market. The fair features 240 dealers, including galleries from Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore, demonstrating the diversity of the region. Despite vast geography, the fair aims to bridge gaps between cultures and foster discovery of new movements. The South-east Asian contingent is seen as a significant addition to the fair, challenging the market's perception of the Asian market as solely driven by mainland China.

site_title: China Vanke raises HK$7.8b in share sale
summary: China Vanke Co. sold HK$7.8 billion of shares to pay down overseas debt, marking a 5% discount to the previous day's closing price. The sale, which raised $1.34 billion, highlights the company's strong balance sheet and boosts liquidity. The move is seen as a potential wave of equity raising by Chinese developers amid looming debt maturity and slowing home sales. This is the second major share sale by a Chinese developer this year, following Guangzhou R&F Properties Co. and Beijing Capital Land Ltd. The sale reduces Vanke's net debt to equity to 27%, the lowest among tracked developers.

site_title: UK businesses voice anger at Brexit deadlock
summary: The UK business community is expressing frustration and anger at the Brexit deadlock, with lawmakers accused of letting companies down. Prime Minister Theresa May's twice-rejected Brexit deal is set to be put to a third parliamentary vote on Friday. The British Chambers of Commerce and other business groups have criticized the government for focusing on soundbites rather than substance, and for the uncertainty that has paralyzed investment and cost jobs. A no-deal Brexit is feared, with the car industry warning of "serious damage" and the Mayor of London expressing concern over the impact on Londoners' jobs.

site_title: Going beyond the CBD, in BT Weekend
summary: Singapore's Central Business District is undergoing changes, shifting from a traditional profile of office buildings to a more decentralized and diverse space. Data plays a crucial role in digital transformation, enabling firms to make informed decisions. Despite market fluctuations, undervalued opportunities in China's internet sector and US semiconductor industry are expected to deliver strong returns for investors.

site_title: HK grants licences for 3 virtual banks, 5 more being processed
summary: Hong Kong has granted licenses to three virtual banks, with five more in the processing stage. The move aims to foster fintech development and promote financial inclusion, potentially disrupting traditional banking services. The sector is expected to see significant competition, with analysts estimating around 30% of existing banks' revenue at risk over the next decade, primarily from HSBC, Standard Chartered, Hang Seng Bank, and BOC Hong Kong Holdings.

site_title: Sony to close smartphone plant in China, shift to Thailand
summary: Sony to close its smartphone plant in Beijing, shifting production to its plant in Thailand in a bid to halve costs and turn the business profitable by April 2020. The decision, not related to Sino-US trade frictions, aims to cut costs in the loss-making smartphone business. The move is part of Sony's efforts to revamp its business strategy.

site_title: First Mapletree River Hong Bao hackathon unleashes young, enterprising talents
summary: Mapletree sponsored the first-ever River Hong Bao Hackathon, a Chinese New Year event, which received 29 submissions from the Institutes of Higher Learning. The hackathon aims to unleash young, enterprising talents, marking a significant milestone in the event's 33-year history.

site_title: Heart Of Goal
summary: Richard Mille has added former Chelsea and Ivory Coast striker Didier Drogba to its ambassador lineup. Drogba's Foundation Drogba focuses on promoting peace and providing healthcare and education services in Africa. The non-profit organization has built a pediatric outpatient center, a school, and a vehicle to detect cardiovascular illnesses. Drogba believes that autonomy is key to community development and aims to empower people through his work.

site_title: Relisted International Cement eyes demand in rapidly developing countries
summary: International Cement Group (ICG), formerly Compact Metal Industries, plans to set up more cement plants in Central Asia, Africa, and South-east Asia, particularly in regions benefiting from China's Belt and Road initiatives. ICG considers factors such as access to raw materials, market proximity, and selling prices before entering a market. The company owns and operates the largest cement plant in Tajikistan and is building a second plant in Kazakhstan. ICG expects its revenue and earnings to increase after completing construction and acquisitions, with a projected annual production capacity of 3.4 million MT.

site_title: Ford closes 3 Russian plants as market loses its lustre
summary: Ford Motor Co. is closing three Russian plants, ending its presence in the country's car market, due to declining sales and economic sanctions. The move is part of a broader overhaul of its European operations, with Ford expecting $500 million in charges and significant job losses. Vehicle sales in Russia have roughly halved since 2012, with Ford selling 53,234 vehicles last year. The decision reflects the dismal state of the Russian car market, which was once seen as a key growth market.

site_title: Greek Tragedy Reinvented
summary: Cake Theatre's production "Rubber Girl On The Loose" reimagines the classic Greek tragedy Antigone, with Natalie Hennedige subverting the story to explore power, identity, and womanhood. The play features a unique ensemble cast, including Darlane Litaay, Matthias Engler, and Ghafir Akbar, and will be performed at the Esplanade Theatre Studio from March 28-31, 2019. This production marks another bold experiment by Hennedige, who has previously deconstructed Medea and Hamlet, and promises to upend traditional notions of the original story.

site_title: Home prices in Ireland's capital Dublin are falling again
summary: Home prices in Dublin, Ireland are falling again due to Brexit worries, tougher mortgage lending rules, and rising supply. A five-bedroom Edwardian home in the affluent south side of Dublin is selling for 1.95 million euros, down 20% from its original price of 2.5 million euros. This marks the first time a typical three-bed semi-detached house price has dropped since 2015, with annual price growth slowing to 1.9% in January. The slowdown may also reflect the impact of the UK's exit from the European Union and the central bank's tougher mortgage lending rules.

site_title: New CBD options offer flexibility in medium to long-term
summary: Singapore's CBD Incentive Scheme offers greater flexibility in medium to long-term redevelopment for older buildings, allowing for conversions into hotels, homes, or mixed-use projects. Analysts say the scheme benefits property players like CDL and Hong Leong Holdings, but headwinds, such as high development charges and changing rental market, may deter some owners. The scheme is expected to support rentals and boost office rents, with potential beneficiaries including Reits and private equity funds.

site_title: China pledges to sharply expand financial market access
summary: China has pledged to sharply expand financial market access for foreign banks and investors, including allowing foreign investors to trade Chinese bonds and increasing foreign presence in the banking, securities, and insurance sectors. Premier Li Keqiang announced the plans during the Boao forum, citing a need to prevent a trust deficit between China and the US. China aims to revise its "negative" list of restricted foreign investments and issue more favorable rules for foreign acquisitions of Chinese listed firms, with policies to be implemented this year.

site_title: Big dreams for the long road
summary: Lim Hock Chee, founder of Sheng Siong supermarket chain, has been crowned Businessman of the Year at the Singapore Business Awards. The 57-year-old entrepreneur, who grew up on a pig farm and knew nothing about running a supermarket, has expanded the business to 55 stores, with a 15% share of the market in Singapore. He attributes his success to setting a vision and drawing up an organization chart, which has helped attract quality staff and provide growth opportunities. Lim is also known for his focus on customer service and staff benefits, including free meals, gold coins, and Rolex watches. He emphasizes the importance of taking care of staff and customers, and has even made his personal cellphone number available to customers.

site_title: Singapore sends hawker fare nomination to UN
summary: Singapore has submitted its nomination for hawker fare culture to be inscribed on Unesco's Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage (ICH) of Humanity by the end of next year. The nomination, submitted by three agencies, has received over 850,000 pledges of support, with a 24-member inter-governmental committee set to assess the suitability of Singapore's hawker culture. A successful inscription is seen as a recognition of the years of effort put into perfecting the craft, with many hawkers expressing confidence in the nomination's success.

site_title: Basque Meets Prague
summary: Chefs Aitor Jeronimo Orive and Oldřich Sahajdák collaborate on a four-hands menu at Basque Kitchen by Aitor in Prague, combining modern Czech dishes with Basque recipes. The six-course menu features dishes such as beef tartare and potato pancake, alongside interpretations of Japanese ankimo and Basque classics. The collaboration runs from March 28 to 31, with lunch and dinner menus priced at $180++ per person.

site_title: Deposit insurance coverage rises to S$75,000; gig workers gain insurance policy protection
summary: Singapore's deposit insurance coverage increases to S$75,000 starting April 1, 2019, providing enhanced protection for savers in the event of bank or finance company failure. Insurance policy owners who use their cars or homes for commercial purposes will also be protected. The changes aim to align the deposit insurance coverage with international norms and protect personal assets used for commercial purposes. The enhancements apply to deposits up to S$75,000 and extend protection to personal assets used for commercial purposes, with caps on certain claims.

site_title: Spycam crimes threaten hidden camera industry in South Korea
summary: South Korea's hidden camera industry is facing pressure due to a growing epidemic of "molka" or spycam videos, mostly of women secretly filmed by men in public places. Lawmakers are supporting a bill to require buyers to register with a government database, aiming to curb the trade of such devices. Thousands of gadgets, including household items, have been sold with hidden lenses, and the industry is struggling to recover. The move aims to protect consumers and prevent the spread of these invasive videos.

site_title: Aussie wine sheds vin de table image for finesse and grace
summary: Australia's wine scene is shifting away from bold, full-bodied styles to more refined and elegant wines, mirroring the US's natural wine culture. Producers like Taras Ochota and Gary Mills are creating wines with lighter acidity and less alcohol, appealing to younger drinkers. The focus on viticulture is also increasing, with many winemakers adopting organic and biodynamic practices to produce more resilient and balanced wines. This evolution is evident in regions like the Adelaide Hills and Margaret River, where winemakers like Michael Hill Smith and Vanya Cullen are producing precise and focused wines that showcase the region's unique terroir.

site_title: EU risks trade war with Malaysia over palm oil: Mahathir
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad warns the EU that its policies aiming to reduce palm oil use could lead to a trade war. The EU's decision to phase out palm oil by 2030 is seen as an attempt to protect European alternatives, Mahathir says, calling it "grossly unfair" to impact Malaysia's economy, which relies heavily on palm oil exports. Mahathir also criticizes Goldman Sachs, which faces charges in Malaysia, and suggests the bank could only operate in the country if it pays the requested $7.5 billion.

site_title: Keppel Electric leads power retail rivals to SP Services
summary: Keppel Electric has taken the lead in Singapore's electricity retail market, surpassing rival SP Services, which has seen its market share shrink to 26% in 2019. The National Electricity Market of Singapore report shows that Keppel Electric's market share increased by 0.3 percentage points to 13.9%, while Sembcorp Power jumped to 11.7%. The report attributes Keppel Electric's gains to its customized solutions and focus on reliability and value for end-consumers.

site_title: 10 years of toil pay off
summary: The M1 CONTACT Contemporary Dance Festival celebrates its 10th anniversary with a month-long showcase of over 50 events from June 15 to July 21. Founded by Kuik Swee Boon in 2009, the festival has become a premier platform for contemporary dance in Singapore, featuring works by local and international artists. This year's festival includes restagings of popular pieces, new commissions, and workshops, attracting dance festival directors and novice dancers alike. The festival runs at various locations, with tickets available from Sistic.

site_title: The Truth And Nothing But
summary: Florian Zeller's play "The Truth" is being staged by Singapore Repertory Theatre, a light-hearted farce about two couples hiding their infidelities from each other. The play, described as "entertaining" and "unsettling", follows Michel and Laurence as they become entangled in a complex web of lies and deception. The production will run from April 3 to 20, 2019, at KC Arts Centre - Home of SRT.

site_title: Gunning for Success
summary: Fauré Le Page, a 300-year-old Parisian brand, has opened its first store in Singapore, marking its entry into Southeast Asia. The brand, which originated as a master gunsmith to European courts, has been reinterpreted by artistic director Augustin de Buffévent to give its designs a fresh and modern take. The Singapore store will feature world exclusives and store surprises, showcasing the brand's colourful gunsmith heritage. With nine boutiques globally, Fauré Le Page aims to expand its presence in the region.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: TT International secured Singapore High Court approval for its restructuring scheme, subject to a creditor standstill and extended long stop date. Hotel Properties Limited announced a joint-venture with Tokyo Tatemono Co to acquire a hotel and condominium units in Osaka, Japan. ONEAPEX Limited acquired 51% of shares in fund management firm OneWealth Development for S$338,000. The deals are part of the companies' strategies to expand into new businesses.

site_title: Investigating officer coached witness on statement, says defendant's lawyer
summary: A witness in the ongoing penny stocks trial testified that he was coached by the investigating officer on the statement he gave about alleged mastermind John Soh Chee Wen and co-defendant Quah Su-Ling. Senior Counsel N Sreenivasan questioned the witness, OCBC Securities remisier Ng Kit Kiat, about his statement, which implicated Soh and Quah in unauthorized trades. Ng initially claimed he didn't understand the word "nominees" but later admitted he was coached by the IO on its meaning, which led to him accepting trades as possibly resulting from calls from Soh or Quah.

site_title: Back To The 1920S
summary: The Working Capitol in Keong Saik Road hosts an inaugural 1920s themed flea market on March 30, featuring local brands, personalities, and stylists. The event includes a tikam-tikam board, vintage clothing, and a one-day pop-up cafe with limited edition tea time sets. The market aims to bring camaraderie and fun to the F&B and retail enclave, partnering with The Egg and Keong Saik Bakery. The event runs from 10am to 6pm at 1 Keong Saik Rd.

site_title: UK defends buying £12m New York penthouse for diplomat
summary: The UK has defended its £12 million purchase of a New York penthouse for diplomat Antony Phillipson, calling it a "best possible deal and value for money" to promote Britain's business interests in the city. The penthouse, a full-floor apartment in 50 United Nations Plaza, was bought to support Phillipson's work as trade commissioner for North America. The purchase has sparked criticism, with some accusing the government of wasteful spending during a period of austerity.

site_title: Sheng Siong boss awarded Businessman of the Year
summary: Sheng Siong founder Lim Hock Chee was awarded Businessman of the Year at the Singapore Business Awards for his vision and business acumen in building the supermarket chain into Singapore's third-largest chain with 55 outlets. Lim, 57, received the award alongside other notable business leaders, including OCBC's Samuel Tsien and GGV Capital's Jenny Lee. The awards recognized the leaders' contributions to their respective industries and the government's support for businesses to adapt and transform.

site_title: Weekend Walkabout
summary: Car-free Sunday is set to expand into a full, long weekend format following a successful trial last October. The first event kicks off on Thursday and runs until Sunday in the Civic District and Telok Ayer Conservation Area. Activities include complimentary trishaw rides, old school rock concerts, and discounts on traditional snacks. The event coincides with the Singapore Heritage Festival, featuring a retro vibe and exhibitions on the development of the city south of the Singapore River.

site_title: Completed private apartment prices fall in Feb
summary: Singapore's completed private apartment prices fell 0.5% in February, marking the second consecutive month of decline. The decrease was driven by a 1.5% drop in central region prices, the only region to show a decline. This follows January's 0.2% decline. The Singapore Residential Price Index (SRPI) flash estimates were released by the National University of Singapore.

site_title: Deutsche Bank wary of Commerzbank's loan book in merger
summary: Deutsche Bank is concerned about Commerzbank's loan quality ahead of a potential merger, citing a high risk of loan losses. Commerzbank's loan-loss provisions are expected to rise by at least 23% this year, despite CEO Martin Zielke's claims of a "clean balance sheet" and "high-quality" loan book. A merger would require Deutsche Bank to revalue Commerzbank's assets, potentially leading to a writedown and additional capital requirements. The deal's feasibility is uncertain, with some shareholders skeptical about the impact on existing investors.

site_title: US issues secret approvals to firms for nuclear power work in Saudi Arabia
summary: The US Energy Secretary Rick Perry has secretly approved six companies to sell nuclear power technology and assistance to Saudi Arabia, allowing them to do preliminary work ahead of a potential deal. The approvals, known as Part 810 authorizations, were requested to be kept secret, and several lawmakers have raised concerns about the deal due to the risk of a nuclear arms race in the Middle East. The Trump administration aims to build at least two nuclear power plants in Saudi Arabia, with the winners expected to be announced later this year.

site_title: US dollar rallies as more central banks turn dovish
summary: The US dollar rose 0.4% against a basket of six major currencies, reaching its third day of gains and best level since March 12, as central banks turned dovish amid signs of a slowing global economy. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand announced a possible interest rate cut, joining a growing list of central banks. The euro weakened 0.2% to US$1.1225, while the Swiss franc held near 20-month highs. Analysts attribute the dollar's strength to other currencies struggling, with the eurozone government bond yields tumbling and sterling falling towards US$1.31.

site_title: Line founder named co-chief executive as Japan goes cashless
summary: LINE Corp has named co-founder Shin Jung-ho as co-chief executive officer as the company looks to reignite growth by tapping into Japan's push to go cashless. Shin will focus on making Line's services competitive and promoting innovation, while CEO Takeshi Idezawa will concentrate on management, revenue, and recruitment. The move comes as the company doubles down on payments to underpin other financial offerings and transform into an all-in-one app like WeChat.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore's Master Plan 2019 aims to rejuvenate the central area, allowing office space to be converted to hotel and residential use. This is expected to benefit developers with low gearing, such as CapitaLand and City Developments, and office Reits like CapitaLand Commercial Trust and Keppel Reit. The conversion of office space into hotel rooms or serviced apartments could alleviate the shortage in the hospitality sector. Additionally, ST Engineering is set to acquire 100% of Newtec Group NV, a Belgium-based satellite communications company, which is expected to be earnings accretive from the second year post acquisition.

site_title: Tailor Made
summary: High fashion designers Riccardo Tisci, Virgil Abloh, Kim Jones, Hedi Slimane, and Dries van Noten showcased their takes on suiting in recent collections. Tisci emphasized sophistication with single-breasted blazers, Abloh introduced an all-white suit with relaxed fits, Jones debuted a Tailleur Oblique suit style, Slimane featured slim-cut suits, and Van Noten designed printed suits with oversized silhouettes. These designs blend traditional tailoring with modern streetwear influences to stay relevant in the fashion industry.

site_title: Nomura plans dozens of job cuts in Europe, US
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc plans to cut dozens of jobs across its trading and investment-banking businesses in Europe and the US, with over 100 traders and bankers potentially affected. The move is seen as a struggle to make a profit overseas. The job cuts are part of the brokerage's efforts to restructure and improve its performance.

site_title: Home Affairs
summary: Crate&Barrel is hosting the New Home Fair 2019 on March 30-31 at Orchard Gateway. The event offers decorating consultations, on-site demos, and workshops on various projects, including furniture arrangement, cooking, coffee-making, and crafting. Attendees can bring their own floor plans for a personalized consultation with Crate Styling Centre experts. The fair runs from 12pm to 6pm daily.

site_title: Top execs from Teambuild, CDL, Surbana Jurong and SIT to join BCA board
summary: Top executives from Teambuild, CDL, Surbana Jurong, and SIT will join the Singapore Building and Construction Authority (BCA) board in April. The new board members include Johnny Lim, Sherman Kwek, Wong Heang Fine, and Tan Thiam Soon. Their appointment aims to bring industry expertise to the BCA, which oversees Singapore's construction and building industries.

site_title: Corporate governance: avoiding the groupthink pitfall
summary: A recent change in the Singapore Code of Corporate Governance highlights the importance of avoiding "groupthink," a phenomenon where cohesive teams make bad decisions due to a lack of diversity in views and failure to consider alternative perspectives. Groupthink can lead to biased decision-making, suppressed discussion, and disastrous outcomes, as seen in corporate scandals such as WorldCom and Enron. To combat groupthink, the Code emphasizes the need for a balanced board composition, including independent directors, and encourages leaders to be aware of social and cognitive biases in team functioning.

site_title: Gunning for growth
summary: Centurion Corporation, a Singapore-based company, is diversifying its businesses beyond accommodation. Since its successful entry into the accommodation sector in 2011, the company has expanded into student accommodation, worker accommodation, and other markets, including the UK, Australia, and the US. With a portfolio of 31 operational assets totaling nearly 62,500 beds, Centurion aims to achieve a 50:50 split between worker and student accommodation revenue. The company is also exploring asset enhancement programs, leveraging technology, and considering further diversification, including senior living.

site_title: Gentle On The Skin
summary: Aesop has launched its first Gentle Facial Cleansing Milk, a water-soluble, non-foaming emulsion for daily use by most skin types, particularly sensitive, dry, or fragile skin. The product features lavender stem and sandalwood oils for soothing properties, grape seed oil for makeup removal, and provitamin B5 to calm and soften skin. The Gentle Facial Cleansing Milk is priced at S$45 and available at all Aesop stores and online.

site_title: Sustainability key to Thailand's drive for developed country status
summary: Thailand aims to achieve developed country status by 2037, focusing on sustainability in economic growth and development. The country's vibrant private sector, particularly the financial system, can contribute to long-term growth through innovative business practices and ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) factors.
