The episode is part of a six-episode series supporting Singapore SMEs, running from January to April and available on BT and other platforms.

site_title: Wirecard: Law firm says potential criminal liability for some Singapore staff
summary: A law firm's investigation into Wirecard's Singapore office found potential criminal liability for some staff, but these actions were not material to the German payment company's financial position. Wirecard's shares rallied by up to 30% after the news, following a series of investigative reports alleging fraud and false accounting at the firm's Asia-Pacific office. The law firm, Rajah & Tann, found evidence that crimes could have been committed, but did not find evidence of material wrongdoing.

site_title: South America resists electric vehicles as local fuels remain in favour
summary: South America is resisting the global shift towards electric vehicles, with auto executives prioritizing traditional fuels due to subsidies and local availability. In Brazil and Argentina, executives from Toyota to GM favor ethanol, natural gas, and diesel, citing potential for these fuels in their respective countries. Despite global efforts to promote electric cars, these regions are likely to maintain a protected auto market that favors internal combustion engines for years to come.

site_title: Apple bites into TV, gaming and credit card offerings
summary: Apple launched a streaming television service, Apple TV+, and a digital video game arcade, Apple Arcade, at an event in Cupertino, California. The service features original TV shows and movies, and will be available in over 100 countries. A revamped TV app and paid "channels" from major networks such as HBO and Showtime will also be introduced. Additionally, Apple introduced a credit card and a paid subscription version of its news app, Apple News+. The company aims to generate revenue through subscription services as iPhone sales decline.

site_title: UK Parliament seizes control of Brexit options
summary: The UK Parliament has passed an amendment giving it the power to hold votes on various Brexit options, taking control from Prime Minister Theresa May. The move comes after three junior ministers quit the government to vote against the prime minister's withdrawal deal. The options, non-binding and non-binding, aim to gauge cross-party support for different Brexit scenarios, with the goal of finding a deliverable solution in negotiations with the EU. The EU has extended the Brexit date to April 12, and a general election is seen as a possible outcome if no agreement is reached.

site_title: Xi says EU, China 'advancing together' despite 'suspicions'
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping stated that China and the European Union are "advancing together" despite suspicions, during a press conference in Paris with EU leaders. Xi emphasized the need for positive competition and reciprocity in trade, following a series of bilateral deals on the continent. The EU has expressed concerns over China's massive investments, with leaders calling for an "exemplary relationship" and market access for European businesses. The EU and China also agreed to work together on environmental issues and the Paris climate accord.

site_title: 'Dead malls' set to be common in France: UBS
summary: France's shopping center vacancy rates have reached 11.2%, on track to meet UBS's prediction of 20.6% by 2023. Analysts attribute the rise to local high street closures, Yellow Vest protests, and the growth of online sales. Listed shopping mall owners may face a hit as tenants gain bargaining power, potentially leading to "dead malls." Retailers Carrefour and Maisons du Monde, which operate in suburban shopping centers, are among those affected by the social unrest. The decline of the hypermarket model is expected to accelerate the problem.

site_title: New Zealand green lights 'intrusive' spy ops after mosque attack
summary: New Zealand's intelligence minister has given the green light for "intrusive" spy operations following the Christchurch mosque shootings, which killed 50 people. The decision comes amid criticism that the government's intelligence services failed to detect the white supremacist gunman. Minister Andrew Little has signed powerful surveillance warrants, allowing agencies to monitor up to 40 people, and has denied the country was a "soft target" for the attack. A judicial inquiry into the intelligence services' actions is underway, and Little has expressed confidence in their ability to prevent future attacks.

site_title: Markets brace for new ECB chief after 'Super Mario' steps down
summary: European markets are bracing for the departure of ECB chief Mario Draghi, nicknamed "Super Mario," later this year. Draghi's 8-year term has seen ultra-easy monetary policy, including negative interest rates and massive asset purchases, but economic growth and inflation have weakened. The next ECB chief will face significant challenges, including explaining the effectiveness of unconventional policies and navigating potential recession. Potential candidates include Finnish central bank chief Olli Rehn, former ECB head Francesco Papadia, and ECB board members Benoit Coeure and Erkki Liikanen. Investors value stability and bold communication, and the new chief may need to adopt unorthodox policy steps to address the economic outlook.

site_title: Euro steadies as surveys hint at economic recovery
summary: The euro steadied at around $1.13 after economic surveys showed tentative signs of recovery in the eurozone economy. A stronger-than-forecast German business confidence survey boosted the single currency, but German 10-year bund yields remained below zero, causing alarm among investors. Analysts expect the euro to stabilize at $1.13 and predict a limited downside for the rest of the week.

site_title: Deutsche Bank faces Qatari resistance to Commerzbank deal
summary: Deutsche Bank faces resistance from top Qatari shareholders to its merger plans with Commerzbank, with concerns that a deal could dilute their holdings if the bank needs to raise equity. Qatari investors are seeking concessions, including a bilateral deal in other industries, before backing the merger. The German government supports the deal, but some stakeholders, including Labour representatives and German newspaper editorials, have expressed opposition. Regulatory obstacles, such as balancing Deutsche Bank's US exposure and Commerzbank's Italian bond holdings, must also be addressed before a deal can move forward.

site_title: Congestion pricing in Manhattan close to approval
summary: New York is poised to become the first US city to introduce congestion pricing, with electronic tolls set to be implemented in Manhattan's busiest stretches. The plan aims to raise billions of dollars for subway repairs and modernization. After years of hesitation, state leaders have reached consensus, with the Assembly and Senate, as well as Governor Andrew Cuomo, expressing support. The plan is expected to benefit from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, with potential revenue also allocated to commuter railroads.

site_title: UBS names Asia tech head
summary: UBS has named Patrick Tsang as head of telecommunications, media and technology investment banking for Asia Pacific, replacing Randy Gelber. Tsang, a Hong Kong-based managing director, has been with UBS since 2004. This comes as the bank faces a slump in equity offerings in the region, with a 7% decline in deals over the past 12 months and reduced bonuses for managing directors. UBS' CEO Sergio Ermotti has also announced cost cuts of around $300 million.

site_title: Abe expected to proceed with sales tax hike in Oct despite slowing economy
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is likely to proceed with a scheduled sales tax hike in October despite a slowing economy, according to Kozo Yamamoto, a senior ruling party lawmaker. Yamamoto believes the Bank of Japan's current policy framework is limiting its ability to stimulate the economy, and that aggressive fiscal spending and bond buying are needed. Abe has repeatedly stated that the tax hike will proceed unless a major global shock occurs, and Yamamoto has expressed concerns about the impact of the hike on weak wages and the economy.

site_title: Boeing readies 737 MAX software fix as families wait for crash report
summary: Boeing is providing free software upgrades to airlines operating the 737 MAX, following two deadly crashes that have prompted worldwide grounding. The US Transportation Department has formed an outside panel to review the FAA's aircraft certification programme amid concerns. Boeing is briefing airlines on software and training updates, with over 200 global pilots and experts attending. The crash of an Indonesian Lion Air flight in October killed 189 people, bringing the safety of the 737 MAX into focus. Fixes must still get government approval.

site_title: Cryptocurrency miner Bitmain lets its Hong Kong IPO application lapse
summary: Bitmain Technologies, the world's largest cryptocurrency mining equipment manufacturer, has let its Hong Kong IPO application lapse, six months after it was filed. This move comes as hopes for cryptocurrency companies to go public have faded. The decision marks a significant setback for the company, which had been seeking to raise funds and increase its visibility in the market. The IPO lapse may indicate a decline in investor interest and confidence in the cryptocurrency sector.

site_title: Aramco building global gas business to cut carbon footprint
summary: Saudi Aramco is building a global gas business to reduce its carbon footprint. CEO Amin Nasser announced plans to invest $150 billion over the next decade, increasing output and becoming a gas exporter. The company aims to meet Asia's growing energy needs and convert more crude oil into chemicals. With a low carbon footprint compared to other oil suppliers, Aramco plans to reassure stakeholders of its long-term investments in the energy sector. The move is part of its strategy to diversify and reduce its reliance on oil exports.

site_title: P&G achieves goal of delivering 15b litres of water
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) has achieved its goal of delivering 15 billion litres of clean drinking water to needy people worldwide through its non-profit Children's Safe Drinking Water (CSDW) Program. The company now aims to deliver 25 billion litres, or over 100 billion glasses of water, within the next 5-6 years. This initiative, which began in 2004, has worked with over 150 partners to provide water to families in more than 90 countries, improving health, education, and economic opportunities.

site_title: Sias chief questions PUB on Tuaspring in open letter
summary: Singapore's Securities Investors Association (SIA) chief David Gerald sent an open letter to PUB's CEO Ng Joo Hee, questioning how the Tuaspring Desalination Plant's purchase price was fixed at zero and asking for more time for Hyflux to remedy defaults. PUB had issued a default notice on Tuaspring, which expires on April 5, coinciding with the Hyflux scheme meeting. Gerald proposed that PUB give Hyflux more time to resolve defaults and clarified whether it would acquire just the right to operate or the asset itself if it exercises the default notice.

site_title: CPD framework reviewed to benefit property agents
summary: The Continuing Professional Development (CPD) framework for Singapore's real estate agents has been reviewed to include a more structured approach. Agents will need to complete six credits annually, with four focused on technical knowledge and two on soft skills. The new framework, effective October 1, 2019, aims to enhance the industry's professionalism and competitiveness. The review is part of the Real Estate Industry Transformation Map (ITM) and includes initiatives to streamline property transactions and improve consumer satisfaction, with 85% of consumers reporting increased satisfaction with their property agent's service.

site_title: Hyflux faces arbitration request over desalination plant in Algeria
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-based water treatment company, has received an arbitration request from Algerian Energy Company (AEC) over its desalination plant in Algeria. The request concerns disputes dating back to 2007 and was filed with the International Chamber of Commerce's International Court of Arbitration. Hyflux has a 30% stake in the plant's operator, Almiyah Attilemcania, and will seek advice to enforce its rights. The company has until April 20, 2019, to respond to the request, and is currently seeking legal advice.

site_title: Solid fundamentals, growth drivers make strong case for investing in India
summary: India's strong fundamentals and growth drivers make a case for investing, despite populist rhetoric and potential short-term economic challenges. The country's growth path, established under Prime Minister Narendra Modi's policies since 2014, is well-established and resilient. India's GDP growth is projected to remain robust at 7.5% in 2019 and 7.7% in 2020, driven by favorable demographics, infrastructure investment, and increasing income levels. The author believes there is little scope for radical policy changes, regardless of the election outcome, and sees a gradual improvement in earnings growth and a strong case for investing in India.

site_title: Airbus secures US$35b China deal in new blow to Boeing
summary: Airbus secured a $35 billion jet deal from China, consisting of 290 A320-series and 10 A350 wide-body planes. The deal, announced during President Xi Jinping's state visit to Paris, is a significant blow to Boeing, which has been grounded due to fatal crashes and struggling with a China-US trade war. The order is almost double the value initially touted by French President Emmanuel Macron in 2018 and reflects China's growing demand for aviation. The deal is seen as a strategic move by China to bolster its aviation industry and a message to the US to play nice in trade talks.

site_title: Real-estate players tapping proptech to boost customer experience
summary: Real estate agencies in Singapore are partnering with proptech platforms to enhance customer experience. The Singapore Estate Agents Association (SEAA) is acquiring a 51% stake in SoReal Prop, an online property platform co-founded by ERA Realty, Huttons Asia, and PropNex Realty. This move aims to provide clients with digital services such as property market information, agent network, and on-demand home-cleaning. The partnership is expected to boost the industry's adoption of technology and improve customer engagement.

site_title: McDonald's US$300m tech deal biggest in 20 years
summary: McDonald's has acquired Dynamic Yield Ltd for over $300 million, its largest acquisition in 20 years, to leverage technology and personalize menus in its digital push. The deal will allow restaurants to vary electronic menu boards based on factors like weather and time of day, and suggest add-on items to customers. The technology was tested in the US in 2018 and will be introduced for drive-through menus once the deal closes, with plans to expand globally. The acquisition aims to boost sales and help McDonald's stand out in the competitive restaurant industry.

site_title: JPMorgan asks 300 staff to move if no Brexit deal
summary: JPMorgan is asking 300 London-based staff to sign new contracts requiring them to relocate to EU hubs if there's a no-deal Brexit. The move aims to maintain services for EU clients. The US investment bank is expanding its offices in Frankfurt, Paris, and Luxembourg as part of its Brexit planning.

site_title: It wasn't a day of reckoning for Trump
summary: The Mueller investigation report, released on March 26, 2019, found no evidence of a conspiracy or collusion between President Trump and the Russian government in the 2016 presidential election. Despite numerous indictments and charges against Trump's associates, the report concluded that there was no collusion. The investigation did, however, confirm that Russian nationals interfered in the election through disinformation on social media. The report's findings were largely seen as a victory for President Trump, allowing him to consolidate his base and pursue his policies without the cloud of Russia collusion.

site_title: Golden Mile Complex tender relaunched at S$800m reserve price
summary: EDMUND Tie & Company (ET&Co) has relaunched a tender for the sale of Golden Mile Complex in Singapore, with a reserve price of S$800 million. The current tender exercise will close on April 25, and the property, known for its signature step-terraced building design, could be conserved if a buyer is found.

site_title: No 'quiet' rule at Jakarta's flyover library
summary: A unique library has opened under a Jakarta flyover, offering a reading space for kids despite hazardous traffic conditions. The open-air library, wedged between two lanes of traffic, has become a thriving spot for kids to read and socialize, with no quiet rule in place. The library has gained popularity, but faces opposition from menacing gangsters and choking fumes. The library's success highlights the resourcefulness of communities in finding ways to provide essential services despite challenging environments.

site_title: SPH unveils news tablet app for Chinese news products
summary: SPH unveils a news tablet app offering seamless digital access to Chinese news products, including e-paper editions of Lianhe Zaobao, Lianhe Wanbao, and Shin Min Daily News, with a single subscription. The app will be preloaded on Samsung Tab A tablets retailing at S$398, featuring auto updates with no logins required.

site_title: China video-streaming firm iQIYI hopes to raise US$1b in convertible bonds
summary: iQIYI Inc, a video-streaming firm backed by Baidu, plans to raise US$1.05 billion in convertible bonds, likely the largest such sale by a US-listed Chinese company. This is part of a growing trend of convertible bond sales by newly listed Chinese tech companies seeking growth capital.

site_title: Keeping the same crew on one ship can boost efficiency
summary: A three-year study by Southampton Solent University found that keeping the same crew on one ship, known as "stable" or "back-to-back" manning, can boost efficiency in the shipping industry. Researchers used surveys and interviews to analyze the benefits of stable crewing, which was compared to "fluid" crewing, where crew is allocated to different ships. The study concluded that stable crewing can lead to improved performance, reduced training costs, and enhanced crew morale. The results suggest that this practice can be beneficial for shipping companies.

site_title: Fading star of global commodity trade moves closer to sale
summary: The Tokyo Commodity Exchange (Tocom) is set to be sold to Japan Exchange Group after struggling to maintain its relevance in the global commodity trade. The bourse, once a major player in the early 2000s, has seen its volume and open interest dwindle due to stricter rules against retail investors and the rise of rival exchanges in China. Tocom's demise has coincided with China's growing dominance in raw materials trade, with trading on Shanghai and other exchanges now surpassing Tokyo's. A deal to merge Tocom with the Tokyo Stock Exchange is reportedly imminent.

site_title: Electronics, precision engineering still dragging down factory output
summary: Singapore's factory output rose 0.7% year-on-year in February, driven by a 13.3% surge in biomedical production, but economists remain cautious due to the ongoing impact of the US-China trade war and faltering global electronics demand. The manufacturing sector's performance was led by the pharmaceuticals segment, but the precision engineering cluster continued to decline, with electronics experiencing its third straight month of decline. Economists predict a continued slowdown in the manufacturing sector, with some forecasting a 0.5% decline in factory output for the first quarter of the year.

site_title: EZ-Link launches digital platform for TRUST Programme
summary: EZ-Link launched three new phone applications for the TRUST Programme, a digital platform that digitises processes and improves user-friendliness. The TRUST Programme, launched in 2015, ensures refund of un-utilised amounts in prepaid spa packages if the merchant ceases operations. EZ-Link's new digital platform aims to widen adoption and provide a platform for users to track packages and transactions, contact merchants, and edit contact details on the go. The move is seen as relevant to Singapore's push for a Smart Nation, but may pose challenges for the older generation to adapt to a fully digital payment system.

site_title: The future of payments is inclusive and invisible
summary: The future of payments is evolving into a digital and mobile landscape, becoming "inclusive and invisible." Payments will seamlessly integrate into various transactions, making the process effortless for consumers. This shift is driven by advancements in technology, allowing for a critical but unobtrusive final step in transactions. As a result, the traditional payment system is being transformed, prioritizing convenience and accessibility.

site_title: Stockbrokers must seek new revenue models - or face tough slog ahead
summary: Stockbrokers in Singapore face a challenging future as deregulation, online trading, and scandals have led to a decline in investor confidence and liquidity. The industry has experienced regular cycles of restructuring and consolidation, with smaller players being absorbed by larger bank-backed firms. To survive, stockbrokers must adapt to new revenue models, as the lucrative commission-based system has become unsustainable. With the industry undergoing another restructuring, stockbrokers must innovate to stay afloat and maintain their livelihoods.

site_title: Singapore law firm sees cracks in South-east Asia's credit markets
summary: Singapore law firm Rajah & Tann Singapore LLP warns that South-east Asia's credit markets are experiencing cracks due to struggling companies in troubled industries seeking to repair balance sheets. The slowing Chinese economy and increased risk aversion among alternative capital providers will make it challenging for some companies to meet maturing obligations. The firm has seen an increase in review of security and loan documents and advising on enforcement options, anticipating more distress events.

site_title: DBS and SIA tie-up across various digital platforms
summary: DBS Bank and Singapore Airlines (SIA) have signed a framework agreement to enhance digital capabilities across various platforms, allowing for seamless banking and travel customer experiences. The partnership will introduce flight booking and merchandising capabilities on DBS's platforms, a DBS-SIA Rewards Programme on KrisPay, and expanded payment options for SIA customers using PayNow.

site_title: Keppel, co-investors in deal to buy Shanghai's Yi Fang Tower for 4.6b yuan
summary: Keppel Corp, along with co-investors, has signed a deal to acquire Yi Fang Tower in Shanghai, China for 4.6 billion yuan (S$916 million). The acquisition is expected to be completed in the second quarter of 2019 through Keppel subsidiaries under its asset management and property arms. The tower is a Grade A office and retail mixed-use development with a total gross leasable area of 74,400 square meters. The transaction is not expected to have a material impact on Keppel Corp's earnings.

site_title: Australia's Wesfarmers launches US$1.1b rare earths bid
summary: Australia's Wesfarmers Ltd made a surprise US$1.1 billion offer for Lynas Corp Ltd, a rare earths miner, to gain exposure to new energy materials. However, investors are concerned about Lynas' permitting issues and environmental concerns in Malaysia, causing Wesfarmers shares to fall 3.5% and wiping about A$1.4 billion off its market value. The offer is subject to conditions, including Lynas having relevant operating licences in Malaysia for a "satisfactory period".

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Uni-Asia Group agreed to issue up to 5.42 million shares at S$1.08 each, representing an 11.54% stake in the company. Sinarmas Land invested S$44.7 million in a joint-venture project. Soilbuild Reit secured a two-month moratorium on proceedings against NK Ingredients, which owes S$2.32 million. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: First Sponsor revamps cash call with new rights, bonus issue
summary: First Sponsor Group, a Hong Leong-linked property developer, is proposing a rights issue and bonus issue to raise up to S$399.3 million. Under the rights issue, shareholders will receive one Series 2 convertible security for every seven common shares held, priced at S$1.30 each, with a 3.98% distribution rate. The company aims to use the funds to fund expansion plans, including property development projects and acquisition of properties, and redeem outstanding convertible securities. The proposals are subject to shareholder approval at an annual general meeting on April 24.

site_title: Braddell View's enbloc success may hinge on creative use of site
summary: Singapore's 918-unit Braddell View en bloc sale may hinge on developers' creative use of the site, which has a gross plot ratio of 2.1 and is zoned "residential." The site's large size poses potential risks, but also offers opportunities for innovative projects, such as co-living spaces, retirement housing, and serviced apartments. The aging population in Singapore presents a growing demand for such types of housing, with some developers already successfully launching purpose-built student accommodation projects in overseas markets.

site_title: Joining a Singapore bank a dream for thousands, reality for few
summary: Thousands of fresh graduates and young professionals apply for coveted management associate positions at Singapore banks each year, but only a handful secure the coveted jobs. In 2019, UOB received almost 25,000 applications, while DBS received over 20,000 and OCBC received about 4,000. Only 46 UOB candidates, 20 DBS candidates, and 63 OCBC candidates were selected for the 2019 programs. Banks are adjusting their recruiting strategies to attract the right fit, with DBS introducing specialized programs and using digital marketing to engage with candidates.

site_title: Capital C appoints COO in Singapore
summary: Capital C Corporation, a Singapore-headquartered investment group, has appointed Benny Lim as its chief operating officer (COO) based in Singapore. Lim, with extensive experience in the local corporate market, will lead business strategies, scale up the business, and drive sustainable growth. He previously led business development efforts at Toll Global Logistics, Goodrich Global, and SMRT Corporation. James Cheow, co-founder and CEO of Capital C, said Lim's strong knowledge and experience will steer the firm's growth and success. Lim will formulate and execute business strategies, overseeing daily operations and building relationships with stakeholders and investors.

site_title: Copyright reforms: Europe deals blow to tech giants
summary: The European Parliament adopted copyright reforms, backed by news publishers and the music business, but opposed by tech giants like Google. The reforms, which update EU copyright legislation last updated in 2001, aim to give creators a better return from web platforms. MEPs passed the draft law with 348 votes in favor, 274 against, and 36 abstentions, despite intense lobbying from tech giants and online freedom activists. The reforms include Article 13, which holds platforms responsible for enforcing copyright, and a "neighbouring right" for news media.

site_title: ST Engineering bags first seaport AGV contract
summary: ST Engineering has secured its first contract for autonomous material handling solutions, worth an undisclosed amount, to supply 80 Automated Guided Vehicles (AGVs) to Singapore's container port operator PSA Corporation. The AGVs will be integrated into PSA's next-generation port in Tuas, featuring eco-efficient electric power systems and fully automated transportation of 20-40 ft containers. The contract is expected to have minimal impact on ST Engineering's financials for the current year.

site_title: Foodtech startup Zeemart snags S$7m seed funding
summary: Zeemart, a Singapore-based foodtech startup, has secured S$7 million in seed funding led by Kresna Graha Investama and angel investor Dr Prem Pillay. The funding will be used for product development and expansion into the Indonesian market. Zeemart simplifies procurement for businesses, offering a platform for buyers and suppliers to connect and make data-driven decisions. The startup has 65 staff across four countries and has partnered with prominent clients such as restaurant chains Redbean and Denny's.

site_title: US housing starts fall most since June, missing estimates
summary: US new-home groundbreakings fell 8.7% in February to a 1.16 million annualized rate, missing estimates, with single-family starts slumping the most in four years. Permits also dropped 1.6% to a 1.3 million rate, indicating developers continue to struggle with building affordable properties amid rising costs. Despite lower mortgage rates and faster pay gains, sales have yet to bounce back from last year's slump, with some reports showing mixed results for housing in January.

site_title: Most Asian markets bounce back from losses
summary: Asian markets bounced back from losses on Tuesday, driven by easing concerns over the global economy and a possible US recession. The Straits Times Index in Singapore gained 0.55% to close at 3,200.28, while the Japan market added 2.2% and Australia, South Korea, and Malaysia also ended positively. However, China and Hong Kong markets remained in the consolidation phase, with losses from the previous session. The Singapore bourse saw a trading volume of 1.05 billion securities, with DBS Group Holdings and ComfortDelGro shares advancing, while OCBC Bank and Genting Singapore shares fell.

site_title: US objection over Venezuela threatens to halt WTO trade disputes
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has postponed a regular dispute settlement meeting due to the US refusal to recognize Venezuela's government, citing the country's opposition leader Juan Guaido as the legitimate president. The US objection, along with the WTO's dispute settlement body being blocked by the US, threatens to halt the trade dispute system. This development is the latest challenge to the WTO's functioning, with some diplomats comparing it to the 20-year paralysis of the Conference on Disarmament.

site_title: US consumer confidence retreats in March
summary: US consumer confidence retreated seven points in March to 124.1, defying economists' forecasts for a slight increase. The decline was attributed to volatile financial markets, a partial government shutdown, and a weak February jobs report. Consumer confidence has been softening since last summer, indicating a moderation in economic growth. While business conditions and job outlooks worsened, consumers remain optimistic about the economy's near-term expansion, with some experts labeling the decline as an anomaly.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed flat on Tuesday with a 0.79-point gain to 1,649.94. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index saw 2.5 billion lots worth RM1.8 billion traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 373 to 367.

site_title: Indonesia says low-carbon plan could spur annual GDP growth
summary: Indonesia plans to adopt a low-carbon development initiative, aiming for annual GDP growth of 5.6-6% over 25 years. The plan, developed with the World Resources Institute and international partners, aims to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 43% by 2030 and deliver sustainable economic growth. Strict low-carbon policies will be included in the government's 2020-2024 development plan, focusing on increasing agriculture productivity, improving waste management, and transitioning to renewable energy. This could generate 15.3 million better-paying jobs and save 16 million hectares of forest by 2045.

site_title: Saudi venture fund STV says Uber deal with Careem to help Mid-East ride-hailing firm grow
summary: Saudi Technology Ventures (STV) has partnered with Uber to help Careem, a Middle East ride-hailing firm, expand its customer base and grow the regional economy. STV, backed by Saudi Telecom Co, is a $500 million venture fund that invested in Careem's US$200 million Series F funding round in 2018. This partnership aims to further develop the regional economy through Careem's growth.

site_title: May to meet her lawmakers as resignation talk swirls
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is set to address her Conservative lawmakers on Wednesday, possibly announcing a resignation date, as her Brexit deal remains uncertain. The deal has been twice-rejected by parliament, and lawmakers are divided over the best way forward, with some considering a softer Brexit or staying in the EU's single market. May's chances of getting the votes in parliament depend on the support of the Northern Irish Democratic Unionist Party, which props up her minority government. The meeting with lawmakers comes as parliament has seized control of the Brexit process and lawmakers are calling for a change in strategy.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Theresa May will address her Conservative lawmakers on Wednesday, possibly to announce a resignation date in a last throw of the dice to win support for her twice-rejected Brexit deal in parliament.

site_title: Real estate opportunities in Asean: Colliers white paper
summary: Colliers International's white paper Decoding South East Asia Real Estate: Insights for Owners highlights emerging real estate investment opportunities in Southeast Asia despite a global uncertain outlook. Asean governments are focusing on policy changes and infrastructure development to attract foreign investors, particularly in Indonesia, Malaysia, Myanmar, Thailand, Philippines, and Vietnam. The report finds yields ranging from 4.5% in the Philippines to 10.5% in Myanmar, with opportunities in transit-oriented, industrial, and retail developments.

site_title: Sapphire Corp responds to SGX RegCo queries on full-year financial results
summary: Sapphire Corp maintained that its methodologies for determining trade receivable impairment value are "reasonable" after reviewing queries from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on its full-year financial results. The company attributed higher impairment losses to receipt of termination letters for Sri Lanka projects and adoption of a new accounting standard. Reversals of revenue and unwinding of discount for long-term receivables were also cited as reasons. External auditors reviewed the company's methodologies, and the results were deemed reasonable.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on tech boost
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Tuesday for the first time in five sessions, driven by gains in technology stocks led by Apple Inc. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.52%, the S&P 500 gained 0.51%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.82%. Financials were also lifted by big banks, marking a positive start to the trading week.

images.alt_text: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Tuesday, for the first time in five sessions, as Apple Inc led gains in technology stocks, while financials were lifted by big banks.

site_title: Singapore estate agents group plans to buy 51% stake in online property platform SoReal Prop
summary: The Singapore Estate Agents Association (SEAA) has proposed a 51% acquisition stake in online property platform SoReal Prop, owned by ERA Realty, Huttons Asia, and PropNex Realty. The acquisition aims to enhance capabilities of SEAA's 4,700 members with digital tools, streamlining property transactions. SoReal Prop's technology platform provides a central repository of property data and vetted listings, with a RealAgent app used by 23,000 agents. The move is in line with SEAA's goal to fully digitalize property transactions, offering transparent and fast information for consumers and salespersons.

site_title: Uni-Asia plans placement of up to 5.42m shares at S$1.08 each
summary: Uni-Asia Group has entered into a placement agreement with Maybank Kim Eng Securities to issue up to 5.42 million shares at S$1.08 each, representing a 9.98% discount to the volume-weighted average price. The placement is intended to raise approximately S$5.42 million for investments in potential property or hotel projects. The company hopes to broaden its shareholder base and improve trading liquidity. The shares will represent 11.54% of issued shares to date and 10.34% of enlarged issued shares after the placement.

site_title: The risks faced by babies of older fathers
summary: Researchers have found that babies born to fathers over 40 years old are at a higher risk of premature birth, low birth weight, and health complications, including seizures and gestational diabetes. A study of over 40.5 million births in the US revealed that fathers aged 45 or older had a 14% greater chance of their babies being born prematurely and at low birth weight. The study also linked paternal aging to increased risks of congenital diseases, psychiatric disorders, and developmental disorders. Experts emphasize the need for men to prioritize their reproductive health, particularly their fertility, to minimize these risks.

site_title: High Court grants 2-month moratorium on NK Ingredients: Soilbuild Reit manager
summary: The Singapore High Court granted a 2-month moratorium to NK Ingredients until May 20, 2019, on proceedings against NK Ingredients for failing to pay rent. The moratorium was granted pending a proposal for a scheme of arrangement to creditors. NK Ingredients must make payments of S$100,000 for April rent, and submit financial information and disclose assumptions regarding sales and wages. The company owes S$2.32 million, including rental charges, and has a S$2.56 million security deposit.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers downgraded mm2 Asia to "Hold" due to the recent success of its film "More Than Blue" and a tie-up with Fox Networks Group Asia. The company's core production business is insulated from volatility, but its interim visibility is clouded by the Cathay cinema acquisition. Geo Energy Resources maintained its "Hold" rating despite reporting a Q4 loss, citing a 5.6% forward dividend yield and manageable debt levels. The company is reviewing its coal production quota with Indonesian authorities and may increase production by 10%.

site_title: DBS Bank, SIA ink tie-up across multiple digital platforms
summary: DBS Bank and Singapore Airlines (SIA) signed a Memorandum of Understanding to enhance digital capabilities across multiple platforms, enabling a seamless banking and travel customer experience. The partnership will introduce flight booking and merchandising capabilities on DBS's platforms, a DBS-SIA Rewards Programme on KrisPay, and expanded payment options for SIA customers using PayNow via API technology. The initiatives will be gradually rolled out this year, starting with the DBS Travel Marketplace, offering extensive travel and retail options for travellers.

site_title: Sysma unit bags S$20m Nassim Road bungalow contract
summary: Sysma Holdings has secured a S$20 million contract to build a two-storey bungalow at 54 Nassim Road. The 16-month project is expected to start in April 2019 and will run until August 2020. The company's order book now stands at S$80.9 million. Sysma aims to continue building its order book while maintaining focus on margins and cost, according to its CEO.

site_title: Sinarmas Land enters into JV for total investment of 222.34m yuan
summary: Sinarmas Land Limited has entered into a joint-venture agreement with Rongqiao Group Co and Taicang Rongguan Real Estate Development Co for a total investment of 222.34 million yuan (S$44.7 million) in a residential site in Chengxiang Town, Taicang City, Shanghai. The investment includes 94.03 million yuan in equity and 128.3 million yuan as a long-term shareholder loan. The partnership aims to strengthen Sinarmas Land's property development footprint in China and enhance future earnings derived from China.

site_title: European lawmakers urge end of golden visa schemes, name EU tax havens
summary: European lawmakers urged EU member states to end "golden visa" schemes, which sell citizenship and residency permits to wealthy foreigners, citing concerns over money laundering and tax evasion. The schemes, used by 20 of the 28 EU states, pose a risk to the bloc's economy and security. Lawmakers also named seven EU countries, including Luxembourg and Cyprus, as tax havens. The recommendations are non-binding, but lawmakers called for stricter rules and supervision to combat money laundering and tax evasion, with an estimated 110 billion euros lost annually to laundered proceeds.

images.alt_text: The European Parliament urged EU member states on Tuesday to curb money-laundering in the bloc by ending programmes to sell visa and passports, a step the multi-billion-dollar industry said would cause economic damage.

site_title: Europe: Markets climb at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose 0.2% at the open on Tuesday, despite concerns over the global economic outlook. The FTSE 100 index rose to 7,193.30 points, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also gained ground. In London, MPs voted to take control of the Brexit debate, potentially altering the UK's path forward. Asian equities mostly rose, with investors cautiously optimistic despite growing anxiety over the global economy.

images.alt_text: Europe's main stock markets advanced by about 0.2 per cent at the open on Tuesday, despite ongoing jitters over the global economic outlook.

site_title: Singapore shares add 0.6% on Tuesday on bargain hunting
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) gained 17.36 points, or 0.55%, to close at 3,200.28 on Tuesday, driven by bargain hunting following a previous day's decline. Despite a global economic slowdown and geopolitical risks, investors sought bargains, with 76% of trading volume achieved. Advancers outnumbered decliners 242 to 165, with seven of the STI's 30 constituents ending in the red.

site_title: Xi says trust me, as Europe wrestles with how to handle China
summary: European leaders struggled to establish a unified stance on China amid President Xi Jinping's visit to Paris, where he sought to reassure them of Beijing's intentions. Xi emphasized the need for trust and cooperation, citing a $35 billion jet order from Airbus SE as a sign of goodwill. Despite concerns over China's growing influence and predatory investments, EU leaders expressed a desire for dialogue and cooperation. France's Emmanuel Macron and Germany's Angela Merkel sought to downplay tensions, with Macron describing China as a "strategic competitor" and Merkel highlighting the positive connotation of this term.

images.alt_text: Emmanuel Macron, France's president, centre leaving a meeting with Xi Jinping, China's president, left, and Angela Merkel, Germany's chancellor, at Elysee Palace in Paris, France, on Monday, March 26, 2019.

site_title: Japan's Cabinet approves regulations for gambling resorts
summary: Japan's Cabinet approves regulations for gambling resorts, paving the way for the country's first casinos to open as early as 2024. The regulations, approved after years of wrangling, specify hotel and conference center sizes, casino areas, and advertising restrictions. The move is expected to attract billions of dollars in investment from international companies like MGM Resorts International and Melco Resorts & Entertainment Ltd. The goal is to make Japan an advanced country for tourism, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stating that the casinos will provide a new source of tax revenue.

site_title: Why Asia is home to the world's most dynamic cities
summary: Asia is home to the world's most dynamic cities, with India and China leading the way. According to JLL's City Momentum Index, 15 of the top 20 cities undergoing the fastest economic growth and rapid urbanization are in these two countries. Cities like Bengaluru, Hyderabad, and Xi'an are driving growth with innovation, foreign investment, and infrastructure development. Despite challenges, these cities are expected to continue their trajectory with a focus on smarter, more sustainable development.

images.alt_text: The Bank of East Asia (BEA) Ltd. building, left to right, China World Trade Center Tower III, and the Ping An Insurance Group Co. building stand in the central business district of Beijing, China.

site_title: Sias, SID jointly produce guide on best practices for shareholder meetings
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) and the Singapore Institute of Directors have jointly produced a 24-page guide on best practices for shareholder meetings. The guide covers key points such as shareholder rights, etiquette rules, and open dialogue between directors and shareholders. It suggests best practices for shareholders, board chairmen, and companies, including preparing for meetings, engaging in respectful dialogue, and providing adequate communication channels. The guide aims to enhance transparency and accountability, and improve corporate governance in Singapore.

site_title: EU lawmakers back copyright reforms targeting Google, Facebook
summary: EU lawmakers have endorsed copyright reforms targeting Google and Facebook, requiring the tech giants to pay publishers for news snippets and filter out protected content. The reforms aim to protect the 915 billion euro EU creative industry, which supports 11.65 million jobs. However, Google and the European Consumer Organisation have criticized the reforms, citing concerns over legal uncertainty and potential harm to the free internet. The reforms are now set to be finalized, with the European Commission welcoming the outcome as a balance between creators' rights and online platforms' interests.

images.alt_text: EU lawmakers have endorsed an overhaul of the bloc's two-decade old copyright rules, which will force Google and Facebook Inc to pay publishers for use of news snippets and make them filter out protected content.

site_title: Metro Holdings to issue S$165m worth of 4.3 per cent notes due 2024
summary: Metro Holdings has launched and priced S$165 million in 4.3% notes due 2024, as part of its S$1 billion multicurrency debt issuance program. The notes, with a 5-year maturity, will be used for general corporate purposes, including financing investments and refinancing existing borrowings. DBS Bank and OCBC Bank are the joint lead managers and bookrunners for the Series 002 Notes. The net proceeds will be allocated for various corporate needs.

site_title: Crypto mining giant Bitmain lets Hong Kong IPO application lapse
summary: Bitmain Technologies Ltd, the world's largest cryptocurrency mining chip producer, has let its Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) application lapse, with the application expiring on Tuesday. The Beijing-based company had initially targeted to raise up to $3 billion. In a statement, Bitmain acknowledged the challenges in the cryptocurrency industry, citing its relatively young status and need for regulatory support. The company will reassess its IPO plans in the future.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's factories reported a 0.7% growth in February, driven by the biomedical sector. Meanwhile, Hyflux received an arbitration request for its desalination plant in Algeria, and Keppel co-investors in a deal to buy a Shanghai building for 4.6 billion yuan. Construction company Sysma Holdings secured a S$20 million contract for a bungalow in Singapore. Singapore's top law firm, Rajah & Tann, warned of cracks in South-east Asia's credit markets. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.6% on Tuesday, closing at 3,200.28.

site_title: Messy days ahead as Thai factions jostle to lead next government
summary: Thailand's first election since a coup saw Phalang Pracharat's proxy party secure an unexpected majority of the popular vote, with 7.6 million votes. However, preliminary results showed Pheu Thai, affiliated with ousted premier Thaksin Shinawatra, is set to become the largest party in the lower house. Experts predict a messy negotiation period as both parties claim the right to form a government, with potential disqualifications and disputes over poll irregularities. The Election Commission's release of results in a staggered fashion has raised questions about the integrity of the process, with regional monitor ANFREL describing the initial ballot tabulation as "deeply flawed."

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up more than 2%
summary: Tokyo stocks closed up more than 2% on Tuesday, recovering from previous day's losses, driven by bargain-hunting. The Nikkei 225 index rose 2.15% to 21,428.39, while the Topix index gained 2.57% to 1,617.94. Investors remained cautious due to signs of a possible global economic slowdown and awaited key economic indicators. US stocks ended flat, and the dollar rose slightly against the yen, following news that an investigation into US President Donald Trump's election campaign found no evidence of collusion with Russia.

site_title: Calls at hearing for label on breast implants' risks
summary: Women with breast implant illnesses demanded more information about the risks of textured implants and called for a ban on one associated with anaplastic large cell lymphoma. The FDA's general and plastic surgery devices panel held a public forum to discuss the issue, with experts expressing frustration over the lack of data and the failure of implant makers to complete promised studies. The panel considered further steps to explore the growing scientific evidence, but only a minority seemed to favor banning textured implants, which offer certain surgical advantages. A "black box" warning label was also requested.

site_title: Yoo-hoo! YuuZoo, anybody home??
summary: YuuZoo Network Groups Corp has vacated its Singapore office without settling rent, leaving questions about the company's leadership and solvency. The company's CEO, Mohandas, departed on March 5, and its chief financial officer, Kevin Wang, left in 2018. The remaining directors declined to comment, while the company's non-executive chairman and independent directors are unreachable. YuuZoo has a history of financial struggles, with an unaudited negative working capital of S$15.7 million as of December 2018. The company has secured a three-year, S$30 million funding facility, but its stock has been under suspension since 2018. An investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department is ongoing.

site_title: Goldman Sachs keeps Brexit bets unchanged after UK Parliament takes control
summary: Goldman Sachs maintained its Brexit bets unchanged after the UK Parliament took control, with European economist Adrian Paul suggesting that indicative votes planned for Wednesday may lead to a softer Brexit. Paul stated that options most likely to succeed point towards a "softer Brexit" than the prime minister's current vision. This move comes as the UK continues its exit from the European Union, with the country facing a fresh blow to its economy.

site_title: Saudi Aramco building global gas business to cut carbon footprint
summary: Saudi Aramco, the world's largest oil producer, is expanding its global gas business to reduce its carbon footprint. The company aims to build an energy bridge between Saudi Arabia and China, increasing oil and gas output, and converting more crude into chemicals. With $150 billion in investment needed over the next decade, Aramco plans to become a gas exporter. The move is part of a strategy to free up more crude oil to export or turn into chemicals, with the goal of reassuring stakeholders that oil and gas will remain vital to world energy for decades.

site_title: Forget German, easy money sounds better in Italian
summary: In Germany, low interest rates are causing frustration among citizens, with many feeling they're not getting a return on their savings. In contrast, countries like Italy and Spain, with weaker economies, seem to welcome easy money, with Italians prioritizing home ownership and viewing real estate as a store of value. Research suggests culture and language play a significant role in attitudes towards financial risk, with German-speakers being more likely to be penny pinchers and those speaking Italian or French being more willing to take risks.

site_title: Canada grants asylum to woman who sheltered Snowden in Hong Kong
summary: Canada granted asylum to Vanessa Rodel, a 42-year-old woman who sheltered Edward Snowden in Hong Kong in 2013. Rodel, accompanied by her daughter, arrived in Canada with permanent residency, citing gratitude for the safety and freedom. The asylum was granted in January but kept secret for security reasons. Snowden, who now lives in Russia, expressed thanks to those who helped him, including Rodel, and urged Canada to grant asylum to others who aided him.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end slightly up
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.15% to close at 28,566.91, following a previous day's decline. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index fell 1.51% and 2.18% respectively. Investors remain cautious due to global economic concerns.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong ended slightly higher Tuesday following the previous day's battering but investors moved uneasily as they fret over the state of the global economy.

site_title: Uber buys rival Careem in US$3.1b deal to dominate ride-hailing in Middle East
summary: Uber has acquired Middle East rival Careem in a US$3.1 billion deal, gaining dominance in the competitive ride-hailing market ahead of a potential initial public offering. The acquisition includes US$1.4 billion in cash and US$1.7 billion in convertible notes, valued at US$55 per share. This deal marks Uber's victory after a series of overseas divestments and ends nearly a year of negotiations between the two companies. The acquisition gives Uber full ownership of Careem, expanding its presence in the Middle East.

site_title: Asiana Airlines reveals wider loss after auditor's red flags, shares plunge
summary: Asiana Airlines revised its 2018 financial statements, revealing a wider annual loss of 196 billion won after auditors raised concerns about its financial statements. The airline reduced its operating profit to 28.2 billion won from 88.7 billion won and increased its net loss to 196 billion won from 105 billion won. The company also reported that its debt was over six times its equity. The airline's shares plummeted 18% after the announcement.

site_title: Goldman joins chorus warning against yield curve panic
summary: Goldman Sachs has joined other experts in warning against panic over the US yield curve inversion, which has historically predicted recessions. The curve's inversion is not as severe as in past recessions, and dynamics outside the US, such as global economic factors, are contributing to the decline in 10-year Treasury yields. Goldman strategists note that American credit spreads are not indicating stress, and the inversion does not necessarily signal an imminent recession within the next 18 months. The experts advise caution and against overreacting to the yield curve inversion.

site_title: Australia shares edge up as fears on US economy weaken; NZ gains
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% to 6130.6 points, boosted by mining shares and a climb in US Treasury yields, which reduced recession fears. The 10-year US Treasury yield rose to 2.43%, following sharp falls and an inversion of the yield curve. Gains were led by BHP Group and Rio Tinto, while Wesfarmers Ltd fell 3.5% due to a bid for Lynas Corp. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.6% to 9574.8.

site_title: Student housing startup Oxfordcaps nabs S$11m in Series A funding led by Times Internet
summary: Singapore-based student housing firm Oxfordcaps has secured S$11 million in Series A funding led by Times Internet. The new capital will be used for expansion into 10 Indian cities, standardizing its product, and investing in technology, particularly Internet of things and deep learning architectures. Oxfordcaps aims to provide a customized living experience for "Gen Z" students in education hubs across India. The company plans to grow its operations in cities such as Delhi, Bengaluru, and Ahmedabad.

site_title: Airbus wins China order for 300 jets as Xi visits France
summary: Airbus signed a deal worth tens of billions of dollars to sell 300 aircraft to China, including 290 A320-family jets and 10 A350 wide-body jets, during Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to France. The deal, valued at around 30 billion euros, matches a China record held by US rival Boeing and comes as the grounding of Boeing's 737 MAX has left uncertainty over major jet orders. French President Emmanuel Macron hailed the deal as a significant step forward and an excellent signal in the current context of US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rebound as foreigners turn net buyers; won rises
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.18% to 2,148.80 points, driven by foreigners turning net buyers after a sharp decline in the previous session. The won edged higher against the dollar and the benchmark bond yield rose. Foreigners bought 40.2 billion won worth of shares, while individuals bought 154.5 billion won worth of shares. The Kospi has risen 5.28% so far this year, despite falling 1.5% in the previous 30 trading sessions.

site_title: Investment group Capital C Corp appoints COO in Singapore
summary: Capital C Corp, a Singapore-headquartered investment group, has appointed Benny Lim as its chief operating officer (COO) based in Singapore. Lim, with extensive experience in the local corporate market, will advise the company on expanding into fintech and emerging technologies. He will lead business strategy formulation, scaling, and daily operations, and build relationships with key stakeholders and investors. Lim's background includes roles at Toll Global Logistics, Goodrich Global, and SMRT Corporation, with a Master's in International Management and a Bachelor's in Business from Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology.

site_title: Jet chairman Goyal steps down as banks move in with rescue plan
summary: Jet Airways Chairman Naresh Goyal steps down as part of a rescue plan led by state-run banks to save the airline from bankruptcy. The banks will seize control and take a majority stake in the airline after failing to convince potential investors, including Etihad Airways. The move aims to avoid thousands of job losses ahead of a general election in India. Goyal's departure could reignite investor interest, but experts say the next steps, including infusing equity capital and selecting a new board, are more critical.

site_title: Ocado lands partnership deal with Australia's Coles
summary: Ocado, a British online supermarket pioneer, has signed a partnership deal with Australia's Coles Group, its fifth major overseas deal in less than 18 months. The partnership will see Ocado's technology and software develop Coles Online's grocery business in Australia, with two robotic distribution centres to be built in Sydney and Melbourne within four years. Coles shares rose 3.1% following the announcement, and Ocado expects the deal to create significant long-term value to the business.

site_title: China's economy will just about escape deflation in 2019: survey
summary: China's economy is expected to narrowly avoid deflation in 2019, with producer prices projected to grow 0.3% this year, down from a previous forecast of 0.8%. This outlook is due to weak demand and declining industrial profits, leading to increased pressure on company debt repayments and fiscal revenues. The People's Bank of China is unlikely to cut interest rates this year, instead focusing on targeted fiscal stimulus to address the issue. Producer prices are forecast to contract in the second half of the year and remain negative until early 2020.

site_title: Singapore factories post modest 0.7% growth in February
summary: Singapore's factory output grew 0.7% in February, beating expectations of a decline, driven by a 13.3% increase in biomedical manufacturing. The biomedical sector's growth was fueled by an expansion of 17.9% in the production of active pharmaceutical ingredients. However, other sectors such as precision engineering and electronics declined, with the electronics cluster experiencing its third straight month of decline.

site_title: SPH unveils news tablet app for Chinese news products
summary: SPH unveiled a news tablet app providing seamless digital access to its Chinese news products with a single subscription. The app is preloaded on the latest Samsung Tab A tablet, available for S$398, and subscribers can get it for free with a two-year package or top up S$14.90 per month for existing subscribers.

site_title: UBS to name Tsang as Asia tech head, replacing Gelber
summary: UBS has named Patrick Tsang as head of telecommunications, media and technology investment banking for Asia Pacific, replacing Randy Gelber who is leaving for other opportunities. Tsang, a Hong Kong-based managing director, has been with UBS since 2004 and will oversee the Asian Pacific region's tech investment banking business.

site_title: Fading star of global commodity trade moves closer to sale
summary: The Tokyo Commodity Exchange (Tocom) is nearing a sale to Japan Exchange Group, marking its decline as a global commodity hub. Once a major player in the early 2000s, Tocom's volume and open interest have dwindled due to stricter rules against retail investor solicitation and competition from Chinese exchanges. The bourse's demise was cemented in 2005, when retail investors withdrew liquidity, making prices for rubber and platinum global benchmarks. Tocom's sale is a testament to its loss of relevance in the global commodity trade.

site_title: Mencast to sell Tuas property at S$13.5m to repay debt
summary: Mencast Holdings plans to sell its 7 Tuas View Circuit property for S$13.5 million to repay debt, with the option valid until April 8. The sale price is lower than the property's valuation but higher than a forced-sale valuation. Mencast expects to receive S$13.3 million and recognize a net gain of S$5.1 million. The proceeds will be used to repay bank borrowings and discharge the mortgage, reducing interest payable. The sale is subject to JTC approval and shareholder approval.

site_title: China will open further to foreign investment: premier
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang reaffirmed Beijing's pledge to further open up to foreign investment, assuring executives of intellectual property rights protection and no forced technology transfers. Li met with global business executives, including those from Daimler, IBM, and BMW, at the China Development Forum. China aims to provide a more open and transparent business environment, with the government targeting economic growth of 6-6.5% this year. The US and China are in final stages of negotiating a major economic policy agreement amid concerns over intellectual property theft and forced technology transfers.

site_title: 'Abenomics' architect predicts Japan to go ahead with sales tax hike
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is likely to proceed with a scheduled sales tax hike in October, despite slowing global demand and soft wage growth, according to Kozo Yamamoto, a senior ruling party lawmaker. Yamamoto opposes the tax hike, citing weak wages, but believes Abe will push forward due to political considerations. He advocates for aggressive fiscal spending and more aggressive bond buying by the Bank of Japan to stimulate the economy, which he believes is under its current policy framework.

site_title: 'Dead malls' will soon be a fixture in France, UBS predicts
summary: UBS predicts that a fifth of shops in French shopping centers will be empty by 2023, reaching 20.6% vacancy rate. Current vacancies are 11.2%, and rising, with local high streets and Yellow Vest protests contributing to the problem. Online sales growth and store openings will compound the issue, potentially harming listed shopping mall owners. The social unrest is likely to accelerate the decline of the hypermarket model, with structural challenges cited as reasons for Carrefour's debt downgrade.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 1.33 points to 1,647.82, with 46.73 million lots traded at RM13.14 million.

site_title: Formula One divided as Brexit threat zooms into view
summary: Formula One teams in the UK are concerned about the implications of Brexit, with seven of the 10 teams based in Britain. If Britain leaves the EU without a withdrawal agreement, teams fear logistical nightmares due to customs delays, visa issues, and taxes that could damage the industry. However, F1 motorsport boss Ross Brawn is more optimistic, saying plans are in place and teams are resourceful and flexible. Some teams, including Mercedes and McLaren, have warned of potential disruptions, while others, like Racing Point, are more relaxed, awaiting the final shape of any deal.

site_title: Nasa cancels first all-female spacewalk over spacesuit sizes
summary: NASA has cancelled its first all-female spacewalk due to a lack of medium-sized spacesuit torsos, which are needed for the two astronauts, Anne McClain and Christina Koch. The mission will proceed with Koch and Nick Hague instead, with Koch and McClain performing a separate spacewalk at a later date. The cancellation highlights the challenges of accommodating diverse body types in space suits, but NASA officials say it's not a setback and that an all-female spacewalk is likely to happen in the future.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,208.37, up 0.8% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed afternoon trading on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 25.45 points, or 0.8%, to 3,208.37. Gainers outnumbered losers 184 to 131, with SingHaiyi gaining 5.4% and Sino Grandness up 3.3%. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally.

site_title: Heal me with plants
summary: A horticultural therapist at NYU Langone's Rusk Rehabilitation center in Manhattan is using plants to help patients recover from surgery and other medical conditions. The activity, which involves arranging plants, watering, and caring for them, has been shown to reduce stress and improve moods. Horticultural therapy, a niche profession, has been used in hospitals and other settings for decades to promote mindfulness, distract from pain, and improve overall well-being. While research on its effectiveness is limited, many patients report benefits, including increased motivation and a sense of connection to nature.

site_title: China's Xi meets top EU leaders to strengthen ties
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping met with top European leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron, German Chancellor Angela Merkel, and EU Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker, in Paris to strengthen ties and discuss "points of convergence" between the two trading giants. The meeting comes ahead of an EU-China summit in Brussels next month and follows a day after Xi signed deals with France worth over $40 billion, including a massive aircraft contract. The leaders discussed building a "new global governance" and a "strong Europe-China partnership" based on multilateralism and fair trade.

site_title: McDonald's US$300m tech deal is its largest in 20 years
summary: McDonald's is acquiring Dynamic Yield Ltd. for over $300 million, its largest deal in 20 years. The technology company will help McDonald's personalize menus in its digital push, varying items based on factors like weather and time of day. CEO Steve Easterbrook sees technology as crucial to boosting sales and creating personalized customer experiences. The deal will allow McDonald's to expand its use of Dynamic Yield's technology, including drive-thru menus and international markets, marking a significant shift towards leveraging technology for growth.

site_title: SIA flight from Mumbai escorted safely to Changi Airport after mid-air bomb hoax
summary: A Singapore Airlines (SIA) flight from Mumbai to Singapore was escorted safely back to Changi Airport after a mid-air bomb hoax was reported. The pilot alerted authorities at 5:48 am, and the plane landed at 8 am after a search found no suspicious items. All passengers, except for a woman and a child, disembarked safely and underwent security screening. The woman and child were held back for questioning by police, who are investigating the incident. The airline confirmed the threat and cooperated with authorities, while the last such incident involving a Singapore carrier occurred in April 2018.

site_title: StanChart CEO says fears of China growth slowdown, trade war are receding
summary: Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters expressed confidence in China's economic growth, citing modest actions to re-stimulate the economy. He stated that fears over a slowdown in China's growth and the impact of the Sino-US trade tensions are "receding a bit." This comes as the eight-month trade war between the US and China continues, with the US imposing duties on $250 billion worth of Chinese imports and China retaliating with tariffs on $110 billion worth of US goods. Winters' comments come as Standard Chartered plans to double returns and dividends in three years despite a slowdown in emerging markets.

site_title: Ex-coaches among 12 to plead not guilty in US college admissions scandal
summary: Twelve individuals, including former coaches from USC and Georgetown, pleaded not guilty to charges in the largest US college admissions scandal, which involved a $25 million racketeering conspiracy. The defendants, including Gordon Ernst and Jorge Salcedo, allegedly took part in a scheme to bribe coaches for fake athletic prospects to secure spots at elite universities. The US Education Department has opened an investigation into eight universities linked to the scandal, and others, including actresses Lori Loughlin and Felicity Huffman, have also been charged.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank Kim Eng downgrades mm2 Asia to 'hold' with market optimism priced in
summary: Maybank Kim Eng downgrades its recommendation of mm2 Asia to "hold" due to market optimism over the success of its produced movie, More Than Blue, and upcoming partnerships with Fox Networks Group Asia. The target price remains S$0.34. The brokerage notes that mm2's core production business is insulated from volatility, but faces risks from changing viewer habits towards streaming platforms and its high leverage due to the Cathay cinema acquisition deal in 2017. Despite these risks, Maybank Kim Eng views mm2's content-production business favourably.

site_title: Cathay to acquire Hong Kong's only budget carrier, SCMP reports
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd has agreed to acquire Hong Kong Express Airways Ltd, the only budget carrier in Hong Kong, to expand into the no-frills market. The acquisition is part of Cathay's three-year transformation program to turn its fortunes around amid increasing competition. Demand on some of Cathay's routes has shifted to budget carriers, and the Asia Pacific region is expected to see the largest increase in air traffic worldwide. Financial terms of the acquisition are not disclosed.

site_title: Newly minted fintech unicorn Airwallex raises US$100m in Series C round
summary: Airwallex, a global payments fintech startup, has raised US$100 million in Series C funding, valuing the company at over US$1 billion. The funding round was led by DST Global and includes returning investors like Sequoia Capital China, Tencent, and Hillhouse Capital. The funds will be used to expand Airwallex's international collection and payment products, supporting global expansion into the US, UK/Europe, and South-east Asia. With over US$200 million in total capital raised, Airwallex aims to empower marketplaces, online sellers, and SMEs to grow their businesses globally.

site_title: First Sponsor proposes rights issue, bonus issue to raise up to S$399.3m
summary: First Sponsor Group, a Hong Leong-linked property developer, has withdrawn its initial application for a rights issue and is now proposing a new plan to raise up to S$399.3 million. The company will issue up to 113.7 million free detachable warrants and a bonus issue of up to 79.6 million warrants, with the proceeds used to fund expansion plans and redeem outstanding convertible securities. The proposal is subject to shareholder approval at an annual general meeting on April 24.

site_title: Hyflux receives arbitration request for desalination plant in Algeria
summary: Hyflux, a troubled water treatment company, has received an arbitration request from Algerian Energy Company (AEC) over a desalination plant in Algeria, dating back to 2007 agreements. The request concerns disputes surrounding several agreements related to the plant, which supplies water to the state-owned national water company and the national oil company. Hyflux will file an answer to the request by April 20, 2019, and is seeking legal advice to protect its rights. The company's financial impact on the current financial year is uncertain due to its ongoing reorganisation process.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise but traders on edge over global outlook
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, with Tokyo leading gains, as investors sought relief from Monday's losses. The mixed lead from Wall Street and safe-haven flows contributed to the recovery. A yield curve inversion, a sign of recession concerns, also weighed on investors. In Britain, lawmakers voted to take control of the Brexit debate, potentially changing the course of the country's departure from the EU. Despite uncertainty, the sterling slightly increased, with investors still hopeful for a no-deal Brexit.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly up after deep losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly up on Tuesday, following a day of heavy losses, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.54% to 28,677.76. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also gained, with the Shanghai Composite Index rising 0.48% to 3,057.56 and the Shenzhen Composite Index adding 0.44% to 1,683.75. Despite the slight increase, investors remain cautious due to concerns about the global economy.

site_title: Australia: Shares checked by growth woes, Wesfarmers slides on M&A; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.1% on Tuesday, weighed down by lingering concerns about a global economic slowdown and Wesfarmers' $1.50 billion bid for Lynas Corp, which sank 3.8%. Iron ore miners Fortescue and BHP rose on concerns about supply, while gold stocks continued their rally. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.2% as Spark New Zealand surged 2.6%.

site_title: Asiana Airlines says auditor approves accounts; shares tumble
summary: Asiana Airlines' auditor has approved its 2018 financial statements, reversing a previous refusal due to lack of information on leased aircraft maintenance and affiliate stake valuations. The airline's shares plummeted 17.5% and Kumho Industrial's shares fell 25.5% upon resumption of trading. The approval comes after Asiana provided additional information, addressing the auditor's concerns.

site_title: Behind the niceties of Chinese leader's visit, France is wary
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron welcomed Chinese President Xi Jinping, despite concerns over China's growing influence in Europe. Macron reiterated the need for a unified European response to China's global infrastructure project, known as "One Belt One Road." France has not signed on to the project, unlike Italy, and Macron emphasized that he was speaking on behalf of Europe. Macron and Xi signed commercial and governmental treaties worth billions of euros, but Macron also expressed concerns over human rights in China and the need for reciprocity in trade and investment.

site_title: California avocados voluntarily recalled for possible health risk
summary: A California avocado grower, Henry Avocado Corporation, has voluntarily recalled its products from six states due to possible contamination with Listeria bacteria. The recall affects California-harvested avocados shipped to Arizona, Florida, New Hampshire, North Carolina, and Wisconsin. No illnesses have been reported, but the company took the measure "out of an abundance of caution." The avocados, both conventionally grown and organic, were recalled after environmental samples tested positive for Listeria monocytogenes, a bacteria that can cause severe illness in vulnerable populations. Consumers are advised to discard or return recalled avocados for a refund.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars bounce, bonds take a breather
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars experienced a rebound against the US dollar, with the Aussie rising to US$0.7121 and the kiwi dollar reaching US$0.6917. This comes as markets anticipate potential stimulus from major central banks, including the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Federal Reserve. Bonds also took a breather, with Australian 10-year debt futures just off a record high, and yields on three-year paper below 1.5%. Analysts expect further rallies in bonds due to low inflation expectations, and the Reserve Bank of Australia remains resistant to pressure for a rate cut.

site_title: UK lawmakers vote to take control of Brexit process
summary: British lawmakers voted to take control of the Brexit process, passing an amendment by 329-302 to provide time for indicative votes on Brexit options. The move aims to break the parliamentary deadlock. The amendment changes parliamentary rules, allowing for a vote on the motion and its passage. This development comes as the UK's Brexit process remains stagnant, with the country facing a fresh blow to its economy.

site_title: Keppel, co-investors in deal to buy Shanghai's Yi Fang Tower for 4.6b yuan
summary: Keppel Corp has signed a deal to acquire Yi Fang Tower in Shanghai, China for 4.6 billion yuan (S$916 million) through its subsidiaries. The transaction follows a shareholders' agreement made on March 25 and is expected to be completed in the second quarter of 2019. North Bund Keppel, a joint venture company, will hold a paid-up capital of around US$302 million, with co-investors holding 42.1% and 29.8% stakes. The acquisition is not expected to impact Keppel Corp's earnings per share and net tangible asset per share.

site_title: Lawyer Avenatti arrested, accused of fraud and of extorting Nike
summary: Lawyer Michael Avenatti, known for representing adult film star Stormy Daniels, was arrested on charges of trying to extort $20 million from Nike and embezzling a client's money. Avenatti devised a scheme to threaten Nike's reputation, claiming the company was involved in a basketball bribery scandal, and demanded millions of dollars unless the company agreed to pay him. He faces up to 97 years in prison if convicted on the four extortion-related charges filed in New York and up to 50 years in prison on the California embezzlement charge.
