Nearly a third of its 1,373 passengers and crew were airlifted to safety by helicopter. The ship was escorted by tugboats and eventually arrived at the port of Molde under its own steam, marking a successful rescue operation. The incident highlighted the risks of navigating stormy seas in the region.

site_title: 10-year US yields fall further below 3-month bills
summary: US 10-year treasury yields fell below three-month rates, an inversion that has signaled economic recession in the past. This is the first inversion since mid-2007. Chicago Federal Reserve Bank President Charles Evans suggested the US central bank should pause and adopt a cautious stance, despite the economy remaining strong.

site_title: ASTI Holdings to release FY2018 results by March 31
summary: ASTI Holdings has been granted an extension to release its FY2018 financial statements by March 31, due to the recent acquisition of Yumei Technologies and its subsidiaries by its associate Advanced Systems Automation (ASA). ASA sought an extension to review accounting adjustments and ensure the acquired companies' financial statements comply with Singapore Financial Reporting Standards. As ASA is an associate of the group, ASTI will take into account its investment in ASA through the equity method in its own financial statements.

site_title: Oman oil minister says excited to be part of Sri Lanka oil refinery project
summary: Oman's oil minister Mohammed bin Hamad al-Rumhy expressed excitement about being part of a Sri Lanka oil refinery project, contrary to previous denials of investment. The $3.85 billion refinery, near a Chinese port, will be the island's largest foreign direct investment. Oman's oil ministry had initially agreed to take a 30% stake, with other countries also investing in the project. Sri Lanka's Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe stated that the project will establish Hambantota as a multinational investment zone, amid a regional competition for influence.

site_title: OCBC's Bank of Singapore hires veteran banker as market head for Greater China
summary: Bank of Singapore, a private banking subsidiary of OCBC Bank, has hired veteran banker Richard Hu as its market head for the Greater China region. Hu, with over 20 years of experience, will lead a team of relationship managers to develop and strengthen client relationships. The region is of strategic importance, with assets under management from the Greater China region posting the highest growth among BOS's core markets in 2018. Hu joins from Avenue Asset Management, where he built a team and started several funds.

site_title: Thai baht rises, stocks outperform as election points to pro-army win
summary: Thailand's baht strengthened as unofficial election results showed a likely win for a pro-army party, seen as likely to continue economic reforms. Thai stocks, however, were weighed down by concerns about a US recession, but outperformed other global markets. The Palang Pracharat party, backing junta chief Prayuth Chan-ocha, is expected to have enough seats for him to remain prime minister, with results to be officially announced on Monday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tumble at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted over 2% in early trading on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index sinking 2.10% to 28,501.37. This followed a decline in the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index. Investors are concerned about the global economy, driving the market downturn.

site_title: National Wages Council seeks public feedback on wage, employment-related issues
summary: The National Wages Council in Singapore is seeking public feedback on wages and employment-related issues to inform its annual guidelines. The council, chaired by DBS chairman Peter Seah, will consider factors such as economic performance, inflation, and productivity growth. Last year's guidelines raised the basic monthly pay threshold to S$1,300 and recommended one-off bonuses for companies with productivity gains. The council will meet in April and May to develop the guidelines, with feedback due by April 15. This is the first time the council has proposed bonuses for companies with productivity gains.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 14.52 points to 1,652.14. Losers beat gainers 41 to 10, with a total of 28.73 million lots traded worth RM4.71 million.

site_title: Chinese-backed fintech poised to offer online advisory service for Singapore retail investors
summary: Pivot Fintech, backed by China's Pintec Technology and FWD Group, has secured a capital markets services licence from Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore to offer online advisory services to retail investors. Pivot designs asset allocation solutions using machine learning, with model portfolios built on exchange-traded funds matched to each investor's risk profile. The fintech aims to support financial inclusiveness through constructive disruption, with plans to expand services in South-east Asia. Pintec will support Pivot's digital wealth management technology services, aiming to offer them throughout the region.

site_title: Aspial buys back S$3.8m 5.05% notes due 2019 in S$20m repurchase plan
summary: ASPIAL Corporation has repurchased S$3.8 million in aggregate 5.05% notes due 2019 under a S$20 million repurchase plan. The notes were issued as part of a S$700 million multi-currency debt issuance programme. DBS Bank is the buyback agent for this exercise. The repurchased notes will be cancelled in accordance with the terms and conditions of the notes.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop on US recession fears, New Zealand also falls
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares fell on Monday as investors fled risk-sensitive assets amid concerns of a looming US recession. The Australian S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 1.2%, while the New Zealand S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.5%. The decline was attributed to US Treasury yields dropping below three-month bill yields, prompting a sell-off on Wall Street. Safe-haven assets, such as gold stocks, gained as investors sought refuge from the economic uncertainty.

site_title: Britain's May to meet ministers amid reported moves to oust her
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May will chair a potentially volatile cabinet meeting amid reports of a coup by colleagues over her handling of Brexit. The meeting comes as lawmakers prepare to vote on whether to force through "indicative votes" to gauge support for various Brexit options. May must decide whether to ask MPs to vote again on her divorce deal, which they have already overwhelmingly rejected twice. The European Union has set a deadline of April 12 for Britain to win MPs' backing for the agreement or find a viable alternative.

site_title: US dollar off six-week lows vs yen, little response to Mueller report
summary: The US dollar rebounded from a six-week low against the yen, rising 0.2% to 110.13 yen, after a degree of calm returned to the market amid fears of a US recession. The dollar had fallen to its lowest level since February 11 after weak US manufacturing data and an inverted yield curve, which historically signals a recession. The US dollar index was unchanged at 96.651, while the euro and Australian dollar remained steady. The Mueller report found no evidence of collusion between President Trump's campaign team and Russia, but had limited market impact.

site_title: Fix to MCAS anti-stall software in 737 Max ready to go: industry sources
summary: A fix to the MCAS anti-stall software on the Boeing 737 Max 8 is ready to be rolled out, addressing the issue suspected to be linked to the deaths of 189 people in the Lion Air crash in Indonesia. The upgrade is set to be presented to US airlines American, SouthWest, and United, but its approval by the Federal Aviation Agency is still pending. The fix aims to enhance the system's stability and prevent similar incidents.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sabana Reit, Sino Grandness, ASTI Holdings, New Silkroutes
summary: Sabana Reit's sale of a Tuas industrial building is delayed due to purchaser Kim Soon Lee (Lim) Heavy Transport not obtaining approvals from JTC. Sino Grandness Food Industry Group raises S$6.8 million through a placement to repay debts and strengthen finances. ASTI Holdings secures an extension to release its financial statements, which will be out by March 31. New Silkroutes Group halts trading pending an announcement.

site_title: Bayer CEO says his team retains backing of supervisory board: report
summary: Bayer's CEO Werner Baumann has stated that his team retains the backing of the supervisory board, despite increased pressure from the US over glyphosate-based Roundup weed killer causing cancer. The company's shares have fallen 33% over the past year due to thousands of lawsuits. Baumann defended the acquisition of Monsanto, saying it's a "good idea," and stated that the company has a clear strategy to develop three divisions: pharmaceuticals, crop science, and consumer health. He also denied the possibility of a break-up, citing a clear strategy and attractive markets.

site_title: Penny scandal: Trial of alleged masterminds begins
summary: Singapore prosecutors have opened the trial of alleged masterminds John Soh Chee Wen and Quah Su-Ling for their roles in a massive stock manipulation scheme. The pair, accused of masterminding the collapse of the penny stock crash in October 2013, face 178 charges related to creating false markets and deceiving financial institutions. The trial will involve 26 witnesses and key evidence, including a spreadsheet and telecommunication data, to prove the pair's involvement in "wash trading" and manipulating the share prices of Blumont Group, Asiasons Capital, and LionGold Corp.

site_title: 'Urgent' to release full Mueller report, documents: Pelosi
summary: Top congressional Democrats, including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, urged the public release of the full Mueller report on Russian interference in the 2016 US election. They stated that the report does not exonerate President Donald Trump, contradicting his claim of exoneration. The Democrats also questioned Attorney General Bill Barr's impartiality and the credibility of his summary of the report. The full report and underlying documentation must be released without further delay to ensure transparency and accountability.

images.alt_text: "The fact that Special Counsel (Robert) Mueller's report does not exonerate the president on a charge as serious as obstruction of justice demonstrates how urgent it is that the full report and underlying documentation be made public without any further delay," House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said in a joint statement.

site_title: China has a lot of financial opening up to do, says central bank
summary: China's central bank Governor Yi Gang stated that the country's financial markets are underdeveloped and need increased access to the rest of the world. The bank plans to provide more hedging tools to help investors manage risks in 2019. Officials have pledged to open up more of the economy to foreign companies and ensure a level playing field with domestic firms. The government aims to bring in foreign expertise and capital to address slowing economic growth and high debt levels.

images.alt_text: The openness of China's financial markets to the rest of the world isn't high, so there's a lot of room for increased access, according to People's Bank of China Governor Yi Gang.

site_title: Britain's financial sector has gloomiest outlook since 2008 crisis: survey
summary: Britain's financial sector has its gloomiest outlook since the 2008 crisis, according to a survey by the Confederation of British Industry and PwC. Optimism has fallen at its fastest rate, with business volumes also declining at their fastest rate since 2012. The investment management industry saw the sharpest fall in growth, while employment across financial services fell at the quickest pace in four years due to job cuts in the banking sector. Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit withdrawal agreement faces a divided parliament, contributing to the sector's concerns.

images.alt_text: Optimism about the business outlook among Britain's financial services firms has fallen at its fastest rate since the 2008 financial crisis amid concerns about Britain's exit from the European Union, a survey showed on Monday.

site_title: Uber to buy Middle Eastern rival Careem: report
summary: Uber is set to acquire Middle Eastern rival Careem for $3.1 billion, with Uber paying $1.4 billion in cash and the rest in convertible notes. The deal comes as Uber prepares for its initial public offering, expected next month, which could value the company at $100 billion. Careem boasts over 1 million drivers and 30 million users across 90 cities, primarily in the Middle East. The acquisition is expected to be announced Tuesday, following a report by Bloomberg.

images.alt_text: Uber is set to buy its Middle Eastern rival Careem for US$3.1 billion, financial news agency Bloomberg reported on Sunday.

site_title: UK fintech Revolut hires Uber Eats' Eddie Lee to run its Asia-Pacific ops
summary: UK fintech Revolut has appointed Eddie Lee, former head of regional operations and head of strategy for Uber Eats' Asia-Pacific operations, as its new Asia-Pacific regional operations director. Lee will focus on Revolut's expansion plans in Singapore, Australia, and Japan, and building up its teams in the region. The company plans to launch in Singapore in the coming weeks, with over 150,000 individuals on wait lists for its services in Asia-Pacific and North America. Revolut aims to deliver an exceptional customer experience while maintaining regulatory compliance, despite recent allegations of toxic work culture and regulatory non-compliance.

site_title: US stock futures sitting out Trump's celebration of Mueller report
summary: US stock futures remained unchanged following the release of the Mueller report, which found no evidence of collusion with Russia in the 2016 presidential campaign. Attorney General William Barr stated that Special Counsel Robert Mueller did not exonerate President Trump on obstruction of justice, but did not find enough evidence to pursue the charge. Investors expressed mixed reactions, with some viewing the news as a market positive, while others believed it would have a fleeting impact. The stock market has been volatile due to other factors, including the trade war with China and slowing global growth.

images.alt_text: For investors with a lot on their minds, the decision to forgo an obstruction case against President Donald Trump meant deescalation in a drama that has been capable of breeding volatility in equities.

site_title: Almost 400 people rescued from stricken cruise liner off Norway
summary: Rescue services successfully airlifted 397 people to safety from the stricken Viking Sky cruise liner off the coast of Norway on Sunday morning. The ship, carrying 1,373 passengers and crew, sent out a mayday signal on Saturday due to engine trouble. Seventeen injured passengers were taken to hospital, while others suffered minor cuts and bruises. The ship has restarted three of its four engines and is being towed to the nearby port of Molde. The rescue operation, which continued through the night, was hindered by stormy weather but improved conditions on Sunday allowed for the airlift and towing.

site_title: Oil prices slide on concerns of sharp economic slowdown
summary: Oil prices slid due to concerns of a sharp economic slowdown, outweighing supply disruptions from Opec's production cuts and US sanctions on Iran and Venezuela. Brent crude oil futures dropped 0.4% to $66.79 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate futures fell 0.6% to $58.68 per barrel. Analysts cited rising inflation expectations and revised downward growth and earnings estimates as factors contributing to the decline.

images.alt_text: Oil prices kicked off the week's trading with losses as concerns of a sharp economic slowdown outweighed supply disruptions from Opec's production cutbacks and US sanctions on Iran and Venezuela

site_title: Russia probe 'an illegal takedown that failed:' Trump
summary: President Donald Trump called the 2-year Russia probe "an illegal takedown that failed" and claimed complete exoneration, despite former FBI director Robert Mueller's report stating that the investigation "does not exonerate" him. The report found no evidence of Trump's collusion with Russian agents, but Mueller's conclusion was that the investigation did not prove a crime. Trump's campaign manager called him "completely and fully vindicated," but opposition Democrats are demanding a full release of the report.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump slammed the two-year probe into his links with Russia as "an illegal takedown that failed" on Sunday, and said he had been completely cleared by the results.

site_title: Key findings of the Mueller report
summary: US Attorney General Bill Barr released a summary of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report, which found conclusive evidence that Russia interfered in the 2016 presidential election through disinformation and hacking. Mueller's investigation did not establish a conspiracy between the Trump campaign and Russia, but Barr noted that the special counsel did not draw a conclusion on obstruction of justice. Trump's former advisors and associates, including Flynn, Cohen, and Manafort, are among the 34 individuals already indicted by Mueller, but Barr said the report does not recommend further indictments.

images.alt_text: US Attorney General Bill Barr released a summary Sunday of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's long-awaited report into allegations that Donald Trump's campaign colluded with Russia in the 2016 presidental election.

site_title: Australia's NAB ends 'introducer' referral payments after public criticism
summary: Australia's National Australia Bank (NAB) has ended its 'introducer' referral payments program after public criticism and a government-backed inquiry found widespread wrongdoing. The program, which brought in over $24 billion in home loans from 2013 to 2016, was criticized for leading to unsuitable loans and defaults. NAB's interim CEO said the move aims to regain customer trust, but consumer groups argue it came too late, with some Australians being duped into unaffordable loans. The decision follows a Royal Commission's findings of misconduct among NAB bankers.

images.alt_text: Australia's National Australia Bank (NAB) said on Monday it would end a profitable system of bonuses for referrals that was criticised by an independent inquiry.

site_title: Sino Grandness to raise S$6.8m in S$0.04 per share placement
summary: Sino Grandness Food Industry Group has entered into a placement agreement with JW Capital Group to raise approximately S$6.8 million by issuing 170 million new shares at S$0.04 per share, representing a 6.98% discount to its volume weighted average price. The placement is subject to certain conditions, including in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange, and is aimed at repaying outstanding sums and strengthening the company's financial and working capital.

site_title: Aussie banks may cut lending rates as funding costs fall
summary: Australia's biggest banks may lower lending rates as their funding costs decrease, with the benchmark bank-bill swap rate falling close to 40 basis points from a 2018 high. The decrease in funding costs could help banks regain public goodwill and pass on savings to consumers, potentially easing pressure on the central bank to ease monetary policy. A fall in consumer lending rates would be timely for the A$1.9 trillion economy, which slowed sharply in the second half of 2018.

site_title: China vows lower tariffs ahead of US trade talks
summary: China has vowed to lower tariffs ahead of US trade talks, with Vice-Premier Han Zheng stating the country will continue to reduce tariffs and create a favorable environment for foreign businesses. China will also strengthen intellectual property rights and reduce restricted areas for foreign investment. The move comes ahead of US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer's visit to Beijing for new trade talks, offering a hint of optimism for a potential trade agreement between the two nations.

site_title: Citi fires eight Hong Kong traders after review finds misconduct: sources
summary: Citi has fired eight Hong Kong traders and suspended three others after an internal probe found misconduct in their dealings with clients, including inaccuracies in disclosure related to principal trades. The US bank stated it was fully compliant with local regulations and introduced enhanced controls to ensure transparency. The actions were taken following a review of cash equities execution in Hong Kong. Citi's clients were notified, and a team was established to minimize disruption.

site_title: Stable earnings seen for retail Reits despite F&B woes
summary: Singapore's retail real estate investment trusts (Reits) are expected to maintain stable earnings despite challenges in the food and beverage (F&B) sector. F&B firms face increasing operating costs and competition, potentially affecting rental reversions for Reits. However, larger mall operators with scale and diverse tenant mix can navigate challenges. Innovative strategies, such as adopting activity-based tenants and using F&B spaces as fulfillment centers, have enabled established players to grow and remain resilient. This may limit the impact of F&B woes on Reit earnings.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down more than 2% on slowdown fears
summary: Tokyo stocks opened down 2% on Monday due to fears of a global economic slowdown. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 460.36 points to 21,166.98, while the Topix index fell 32.97 points to 1,584.14. This follows a decline in US stocks, which has led to concerns about a potential global economic downturn.

site_title: Under the Influence of a 'Super Bloom'
summary: A record-breaking "super bloom" of California poppies in the Temescal Mountains near Lake Elsinore, California, has drawn hundreds of thousands of visitors, causing traffic congestion and strain on local resources. The influx of smartphone-equipped tourists, including social media influencers, has led to concerns about the impact on the environment and local residents. The city has struggled to manage the crowds, with officials eventually surrendering control and increasing shuttle prices. The economic impact is still unknown, but some local businesses have reported increased revenue, while others have suffered losses due to the traffic and disruption.

images.alt_text: A super bloom of wild poppies blankets the hills of Walker Canyon on March 22, 2019 near Lake Elsinore, California. Heavier than normal winter rains in California have caused a super bloom of wildflowers in various locales of the state.

site_title: Euro area's floundering economy looks set to get fiscal boost
summary: The euro area economy is expected to receive a fiscal boost from government spending, providing relief from the economic crisis. The European Central Bank has limited room to intervene, and trade protectionism is adding to the challenges. This move is seen as a positive development for the economy, which has been battling headwinds.

site_title: Sabana Reit's Tuas property sale called off
summary: Sabana Reit's sale of a Tuas industrial building to Kim Soon Lee (Lim) Heavy Transport has been called off due to the purchaser's failure to obtain necessary approvals from JTC. The sale was proposed at S$11.18 million, 52% below the property's book value. The Reit had expected the sale to be completed by December 31, aiming to improve performance and occupancy. The buyer has refused to extend the stop date, leaving the divestment on hold for now.

site_title: Technology could ease pain of rising costs on F&B earnings
summary: Singapore's listed food & beverage companies face rising costs due to stringent foreign worker quotas, which could impact earnings. Most companies are close to the 40% service sector dependency ratio ceiling, forcing them to replace or displace foreigners with technology or locals. This could lead to higher wage costs and short-term depreciation. However, technology could ease the pain of rising costs, making the impact more manageable.

site_title: oBike investor and local startup Anywheel make play for Mobike
summary: Two Costa Rican brothers, Oscar Moises Chaves and Samuel Chaves, lead investment firm OSS Inversiones, which has proposed to acquire Mobike's global operations outside China, partnering with local bike-sharing startup Anywheel to manage Mobike's Singapore operations. Mobike, backed by Tencent Holdings and Meituan Dianping, has been laying off staff and considering pulling out of the international market. The brothers aim to gain Mobike's data and tech platform to fulfill their global ambitions for micro-mobility, and believe they can succeed where others have failed by working closely with regulators and focusing on safety and longer ride trips.

site_title: A bad year for the South Korean won may be about to get worse
summary: South Korea's won has been the worst-performing Asian currency this year, and data this week may further exacerbate its decline. Industrial production slowed to a four-month low in January, and consumer confidence numbers for March are expected to show a similar trend. This may prompt bets that the Bank of Korea will cut interest rates for the first time in three years, potentially leading to a stronger dollar-won currency pair and a test of the July 2017 high. The won has fallen 1.3% this year.

site_title: Geopolitics, trade to guide markets this week
summary: US-China trade talks will take place this week, with US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin leading a delegation to Beijing for two-day negotiations. The talks come amid concerns over US economic weakness, but the Federal Reserve's dovish stance on interest rates may ease pressure on companies and the economy.

site_title: Erdogan says those who buy FX expecting lira to fall will pay "heavy price"
summary: Turkish President Erdogan warned that those who buy foreign currencies expecting the lira to fall will face a "heavy price" after the country's currency tumbled 4% against the US dollar on Friday, its largest one-day fall since a currency crisis in August. Erdogan said finance ministry officials are working to address the issue, while the central bank reported a record high in forex deposits and funds held by Turkish locals. Erdogan also threatened to punish those behind "manipulative impositions" in the foreign exchange market, without specifying who his comments were aimed at.

images.alt_text: Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan said on Sunday those in the finance sector who buy foreign currencies on the expectation that the lira will fall will pay "a very heavy price", adding the finance ministry is carrying out work on this.

site_title: Qatar unveils enhanced Economy Class, 7 new destinations
summary: Qatar Airways has unveiled its enhanced economy class, featuring 19-degree recline seating, additional legroom, and faster broadband. The airline's new inflight dining experience, "Quisine," offers retail-style tableware and a wider variety of food choices. Seven new destinations were also announced, including Portugal, Malta, and Turkey, with direct services starting in June for Malta. The airline's business class, Qsuite, won awards for its double-bed feature and sliding panels, and will now be complemented by the enhanced economy class.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Monday's open; STI down 1.5% to 3,163.80
summary: Singapore stocks declined 1.5% at Monday's open, closing at 3,163.80 due to a weak start. Losers outnumbered gainers 141 to 27, with Rex International Holding and CapitaLand Commercial Trust experiencing significant declines. DBS Group Holdings and Singtel also fell, down 1.9% and 1.0% respectively. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 48.3 points to its new low.

site_title: Facebook, Google face steeper privacy fines under Australia plan
summary: Australia plans to increase fines for tech giants Facebook and Google for violating privacy laws. The measures aim to strengthen disclosure policies and empower the country's privacy regulator to crack down on data misuse. The new rules will impose tougher penalties for breaches, with the goal of safeguarding personal information. The Australian government believes the changes are necessary to protect citizens' data and maintain trust in the digital economy.

site_title: Forcing drugmakers to disclose drug prices on TV ads may cause sticker shock
summary: The Trump administration is moving forward with a proposal to require drug companies to disclose prices in TV ads, despite objections from companies and broadcasters. The goal is to reduce list prices by exposing high costs to public scrutiny. However, drugmakers argue that most consumers pay less than list prices, making the disclosures misleading. The White House believes the rule change will incentivize manufacturers to lower prices, which could be politically popular.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat: Victor Mah, president of the ASEAN Coffee Federation & SG Coffee Association
summary: Victor Mah, president of the ASEAN Coffee Federation & SG Coffee Association, was featured on the Money FM podcast "The Hot Seat". Mah discussed the challenges facing the coffee industry in ASEAN, including rising costs and competition from large coffee chains. He also highlighted the importance of supporting local coffee farmers and promoting sustainable coffee production practices. Mah emphasized the need for a more integrated approach to address the industry's challenges and opportunities.

site_title: Brexit up in the air as May faces possible coup by senior ministers
summary: Prime Minister Theresa May faces a possible coup by senior ministers who have agreed that she should stand down, citing her handling of Brexit. The plot, involving 11 unidentified ministers, puts the UK's exit from the European Union in disarray. With nearly three years since the 2016 referendum, the country's Brexit status remains unclear, and parliament prepares to take control. The development adds to the uncertainty and tension in British politics, raising concerns about the future of Brexit.

site_title: Houston oil spillage disaster, chemical fire sicken thousands
summary: A chemical fire at Intercontinental Terminals Co's storage facility in Houston has contaminated the Houston Ship Channel, creating a cloud of cancer-causing benzene. The US Coast Guard has forbidden vessel traffic on the affected stretch of the channel. Toxic ingredients, firefighting foam, and dirty water flowed into the channel, posing a threat to ship crew. The incident is one of the worst Gulf Coast chemical disasters in over a decade, with thousands potentially affected.

site_title: New streaming TV service part of Apple's reinvention
summary: Apple is launching a new streaming television service, part of a broader reinvention effort, amid sluggish smartphone sales. The service will feature Hollywood stars and is expected to diversify the company's offerings. Additionally, Apple is likely to launch a subscription news service to further expand its presence in the entertainment and media sectors. This move aims to boost growth and compete in a rapidly changing market.

site_title: Miners halt output as 2 cyclones batter Australia
summary: Global miners BHP Group and Glencore Plc halted output at energy and metals operations due to two cyclones battering Australia. Cyclone Veronica affected LNG and iron-ore export operations off Western Australia, while cyclone Trevor made landfall in the north. The cyclones, which are common in the region, forced ships to leave ports and workers to flee the area, causing disruptions to mining operations. This is the first time two cyclones have simultaneously approached Australia since 2015.

site_title: Freshworks launches Asean hub in Singapore
summary: Freshworks, a US-based software firm, has launched its first regional hub in Singapore to engage the Asean market, where it sees double-digit year-on-year growth in sales. The hub will allow the company to ramp up brand awareness, increase its network of partner resources, and meet accelerating customer demand. With the addition, Freshworks now has nine global offices across four continents and plans to hire a 10-15 member team in Singapore. The company aims to deepen its presence in the region, which is supported by the Singapore Economic Development Board.

site_title: Treasure sells 272 units on launch weekend
summary: Singapore's largest condominium, Treasure at Tampines, sold 272 units over its launch weekend, accounting for 12% of the 2,203 units and 56% of the 490 units launched. The average sale price was S$1,280 per sq ft, considered a "credible" performance by experts. Developers attribute the success to competitive pricing, attractive location, and good accessibility. The sales performance is expected to influence home prices in Tampines this year and next, with experts highlighting the importance of reasonable pricing relative to location and product.

images.alt_text: Singapore's largest condominium Treasure at Tampines moved 272 units at an average S$1,280 per sq ft (psf) over its launch weekend.

site_title: Playing a role in helping both the young and old
summary: More than 3,000 financial services practitioners in Singapore participated in the inaugural IFPAS run, commemorating the 50th anniversary of the Insurance and Financial Practitioners Association of Singapore. The event aimed to raise funds for children and adults with special needs. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing flagged off the 5km run, which was part of the association's efforts to promote inclusivity and support for individuals with special needs.

site_title: Under threat May holds Brexit crisis talks
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May held crisis talks with Conservative colleagues amid reports her leadership is under threat. The talks, held at her country residence Chequers, come as May faces opposition from Brexiteer MPs, including Jacob Rees-Mogg and Boris Johnson, who may seek to replace her. May must decide whether to ask lawmakers to vote again on her unpopular EU divorce deal, which they have already rejected twice. The UK's Brexit deadline is set for May 22, and May's deal may not pass in the coming weeks, leading to a no-deal Brexit or a request for another extension.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Theresa May held crisis talks on Sunday with Conservative colleagues as she tries to plot a path through a pivotal week in the Brexit process amid reports her leadership is under imminent threat.

site_title: Opec and the Fed are in the same uncertain boat
summary: Opec and the Federal Reserve are facing uncertain economic outlooks, making policy setting challenging. Opec nations must decide on production levels to balance global supply and demand, while the Fed adjusts interest rates to achieve low and stable inflation and full employment. The Opec+ committee has delayed its decision until June, citing uncertainty on US trade deals with China and the impact of Russia's promised output cuts. The Fed may envy Opec's flexibility, but both institutions are confronted by murky forecasts, complicating their decisions.

site_title: Brexit housing fears linger in London but regions remain resilient
summary: London's Brexit-inspired property decline has yet to significantly impact other UK regions. Data from Acadata shows rising price growth in Yorkshire and Humber (2.9%), East Midlands (4.4%), and north-west (3.4%), contrasting with London's 1.6% fall. Real estate agents in northern England remain optimistic, citing a national divide in the market. Despite Brexit uncertainty, the majority of major UK urban areas continue to experience rising property markets.

site_title: Kuok Group plans mall and 480 apartments on Pasir Ris site
summary: A joint venture between Allgreen Properties and Kerry Properties, backed by the Kuok Group, has won a bid to develop a 480-unit residential project and a mall on a 1.02 million sq ft site in Pasir Ris, Singapore. The winning bid of nearly S$700 million works out to S$684.48 per square foot per plot ratio. The project will be integrated with public transport services, amenities, and a town plaza, offering a seamless connection to residents. The development is expected to be completed within eight years.

site_title: CSE Global on acquisition trail
summary: CSE Global, a mainboard-listed systems integrator, is looking for acquisition opportunities in North America's shale basins, Singapore's Smart Nation drive, and the telecommunications industry in Australia. CEO Lim Boon Kheng stated that the company has organic growth in Singapore, Australia, and the US, but wants to expand faster. New orders increased 0.6% to S$384.2 million in 2018, with an order backlog of S$181 million, up 3.5% from the previous year.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the tanker and dry bulk market for the week of March 17, 2019. Key points include:

Capesize ships endured heavy losses, with negative sentiment gaining pace. Cyclone Veronica prompted port closures in Australia, affecting miner routes and freight rates. 
Vale announced the return of operations at the Brucutu mine in 72 hours, boosting the Atlantic basin. 
Physical spot rates declined, but forward rates saw a bump in value across the curve. 
Panamax ships saw a solid improvement in the Atlantic market, with rates rising due to first-half April activity from East Coast South America. 
Supramax ships gained ground, with improved rates seen from key areas. 
Handysize ships had a positive week, with strong demand in East Coast South America. 
Tanker market rates were under pressure, with VLCC rates slipping below WS 60.

site_title: Gold gains as growth concerns dent risk appetite
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,313.07 per ounce, with the metal up nearly 1% for the week, its best weekly gain in nearly two months. Weak economic data from the euro zone and US Federal Reserve's slowdown comments fueled fears of a global slowdown, reducing risk appetite and boosting gold. Analysts attribute the rise to lower interest rates and reduced opportunity cost of holding non-yielding gold.

site_title: Buying your first home in the US? Save, and save some more
summary: US first-time homebuyers face significant challenges due to housing prices outpacing wage growth. To save for a downpayment, some individuals are tapping into retirement savings, home equity lines of credit, or working long hours. The downpayment alone can be hundreds of thousands of dollars, particularly in New York City. As a result, many are forced to make tough financial decisions, highlighting the difficulties of achieving homeownership in the US, especially in high-cost cities like NYC.

site_title: Visual discovery startup Pinterest files for public offering: filing
summary: Pinterest, a visual discovery startup with 250 million users, filed for a public share offering, seeking a valuation of $12 billion. The San Francisco-based company will trade under the symbol PINS on the New York Stock Exchange. Pinterest connects users with interests in food, fashion, travel, and lifestyle, with the goal of providing inspiration for daily activities and major life events. The filing marks the latest venture-backed startup to hit Wall Street, following in the footsteps of other tech companies.

site_title: Nominations open for 18th EY Entrepreneur Of The Year awards
summary: Nominations are open for the 18th EY Entrepreneur Of The Year awards in Singapore, with a theme of "Unstoppable - innovate, disrupt, transform". The awards will be held from April 30 to honor entrepreneurs across six criteria. The winner will represent Singapore at the EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year awards in Monaco next year. The EY Family Business Award of Excellence will also be conferred for the seventh year, with a focus on balancing business and family issues.

site_title: Indonesia's underground rail network opens, making 34-year dream a reality
summary: Indonesia's underground rail network has officially opened in Jakarta, marking a 34-year dream a reality. The project, initiated by President Joko Widodo in 2013, aims to ease congestion in the city, costing US$5 billion annually. The network, part of the North-South line, connects 13 stations along 16 kilometers, expected to move 170,000 passengers daily. The government has also secured a loan for the second phase, with plans to expand to an East-West line and other areas, aiming to reduce traffic gridlock in the densely populated city.

site_title: Muslims return to Christchurch mosque as NZ works to move on
summary: Muslims returned to Christchurch's Al Noor mosque on Saturday for the first time since a white supremacist attacked the mosque, killing 50 people. The mosque was handed back to the local Muslim community after police investigations and security measures were put in place. Only small groups were allowed on the grounds initially, with 15 people at a time. The mosque is expected to reopen fully, but no timeline has been set. The attacks have shocked New Zealand, a country known for its tolerance, and the country came to a standstill to mark one week since the massacre.

site_title: 23 director acquisitions filed and 12 stocks conduct buybacks
summary: Over 12 primary-listed stocks conducted share buybacks, totaling S$11.1 million, from March 15 to March 21. This follows the S$15.2 million for the preceding five sessions. Meanwhile, 23 director acquisitions and 2 disposals were filed, with substantial shareholders filing 24 acquisitions and 8 disposals. Key transactions include TEE International's managing director disposing of 20 million shares, UOB-Kay Hian Holdings' chairman increasing his stake, and Straits Trading's executive chairman acquiring 700,000 shares.

site_title: Pro-army party takes lead in Thai election
summary: In Thailand's first election since a 2014 coup, the pro-army party Phalang Pracharat took a lead in the popular vote with nearly half a million more votes than the pro-democracy party Pheu Thai after 91% of ballots were tallied. The Phalang Pracharat party, which wants junta chief Prayut Chan-o-cha to return as premier, gained over 7.3 million votes. The election's outcome is seen as a significant shift from the past 15 years, where pro-Thaksin parties have dominated politics.

site_title: Measles outbreak infects three workers at Hong Kong's airport
summary: A measles outbreak has infected three workers at Hong Kong's airport, according to a government statement. The trio developed a rash last week, prompting a health talk and measles mop-up vaccinations for close work contacts. The outbreak follows a man who developed full-blown symptoms of measles after boarding a Cathay Pacific Airways flight from Hong Kong to Tokyo at the beginning of the month. The incident highlights the potential risk of measles transmission in crowded areas like airports.

site_title: Brexit up in the air as May faces possible plot, parliament tries to grab control
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May faces a possible plot by ministers to topple her amid Brexit chaos. Despite reports of a "coup" by senior ministers, May insists she remains in charge. Parliament is set to debate a motion on Monday, potentially proposing changes to May's Brexit plan, including a public vote on the deal. If May's deal fails, parliament may try to find an alternative, including a referendum, revocation of Article 50, or an election. The UK has until April 12 to offer a new plan or decide to leave the EU without a treaty.

site_title: Feedback shows broad support for Budget 2019
summary: Singaporeans largely supported Budget 2019 measures, with 84% agreeing that transforming industries and deepening workers' capabilities will improve job opportunities. 83% also supported helping SMEs improve innovation and productivity. The majority (76%) welcomed the Merdeka Generation Package, while 76% supported the Bicentennial Bonus and 60% supported allocating 30% of the national budget for defence needs.

site_title: Southwest sending team to review Boeing 737 MAX upgrade while parking jets
summary: Southwest Airlines is sending a team to review Boeing's 737 MAX software upgrade, a step towards regulatory approval. The upgrade is aimed at addressing similarities between the crashes of Ethiopian Airlines and Lion Air. Southwest will park its 34 MAX jets at a California facility while reviewing the software, and American Airlines also plans to test the upgrade this weekend. The US Federal Aviation Administration must approve the changes, a process that could take weeks or longer, amid a 14% decline in Boeing shares since the Ethiopian crash.

site_title: US dollar sinks vs yen as US Treasury curve flashes warning
summary: The US dollar fell against the Japanese yen due to dismal US manufacturing data, while rising against the euro amid concerns about Europe's economy. The yield curve inversion, a leading indicator of recession, occurred for the first time since 2007, with Treasury bond yields signaling growing fears of a recession. The yen rose to a nearly six-week high, driven by safe-haven flows, while the euro and pound also declined against the dollar.

site_title: Junta chief croons, ousted PM says "we will win" in Thai election battle
summary: Thailand's general election, set for Sunday, pits a military-backed government against opposition parties led by former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, who claims his affiliated parties will win. Junta leader Prayuth Chan-ocha campaigned for his position, promising to "save the country, save the monarchy." Thaksin, in exile, urged supporters to vote, saying "we will win for sure." Critics argue the new constitution gives the junta significant influence over the next government, making the election a high-stakes contest between democracy and military rule.

site_title: Fed rate hike, rate cut both 'on the table': Bostic
summary: US Federal Reserve President Raphael Bostic stated that interest rates could rise or fall this year, contradicting the Fed's dovish stance. This comes as 11 Fed policymakers anticipate no rate increases, down from 2 in December. Bostic emphasized the Fed's patience does not rule out rate hikes and that it aims to support economic expansion and inflation near 2%. A key Treasury market inversion occurred, signaling recession, and long-term rates fell below short-term ones, further fueling market uncertainty.

site_title: Personal data of 2.3m disaster victims was released by FEMA: report
summary: The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) shared sensitive personal data of over 2.3 million disaster victims with a contractor, exposing them to potential identity theft and fraud. The data included financial information and was released in 2017 for survivors of California wildfires and Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria. FEMA acknowledged the error and took corrective action, scrubbing the data from its networks, but investigators warned that the disaster survivors involved are at increased risk of identity theft and fraud.

site_title: S'pore's largest condo Treasure at Tampines moves 272 units at launch
summary: Singapore's largest condominium, Treasure at Tampines, sold 272 units at an average price of S$1,280 per sq ft, exceeding initial expectations. The 99-year leasehold development, with 2,203 units, was launched after a preview event drew 7,000 visitors. Developer Sim Lian attributes the success to the project's well-located site and competitive pricing, citing a six-month high in UK homebuyer demand as a positive indicator.

site_title: Why Netflix won't be part of Apple TV
summary: Apple is set to unveil a media bundle offering access to magazines, newspapers, music, and original shows and films. The bundle is likely to include content from major studios and networks, potentially threatening Netflix's dominance in the streaming industry. Netflix has opted out of the bundle, citing a desire to maintain control over its brand and data. The move highlights the competitive battle for digital video distribution, with Apple's vast device infrastructure and potential for cross-promotions with other services like CBS and HBO. The bundle's release raises questions about the future of content distribution and the role of tech giants in the entertainment industry.

site_title: Thailand's junta-linked party in the lead after nearly all ballots counted
summary: Thailand's junta-linked party, Phalang Pracharat, is leading in the popular vote with nearly all ballots counted, ahead of pro-democracy rivals in the first election since a 2014 coup. The party gained over 7.3 million votes, while the upstart Future Forward party secured 4.31 million votes. The Democrat Party won with around 3 million votes, and its leader, former Thai Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva, has resigned. The election results will be announced on Monday at 10 am, with the military government's influence evident in the outcome.

site_title: French government gets tough on 'yellow vests'
summary: The French government has vowed a "zero tolerance" approach to anti-government protests by the "yellow vests" after major riots in Paris last week. Police have banned protesters from key areas, including the Champs-Elysees, and redeployed soldiers to guard public buildings. The government faces criticism for its handling of the protests, with opposition leaders accusing them of playing with fire. Despite a decline in protest numbers, the protesters remain determined, citing 40 years of being "beaten psychologically and financially" by successive governments.

site_title: Sabana Reit's Tuas industrial building sale off the table
summary: Sabana Reit's sale of a Tuas industrial building to Kim Soon Lee (Lim) Heavy Transport has been put on hold after the buyer failed to obtain necessary approvals from JTC. The sale was proposed in September 2018 for S$11.18 million, 52% below the property's book value. The divestment aimed to improve performance and deliver cost efficiencies, but the buyer has refused to extend the long-stop date, leaving the sale on hold.

site_title: Europe: Shares deepen losses on slew of dismal PMIs
summary: European stocks deepened losses, closing near session lows, due to weak manufacturing data and fears of a global slowdown. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index declined 1.2% to take weekly losses to 1.3%, its steepest this year. Dismal data from the US and Europe, including a slowdown in German manufacturing and French business activity, exacerbated concerns of a recession. The euro zone-wide flash PMI showed businesses performed worse than expected, with banks, auto, and chemicals sectors down over 2%.

site_title: US: Wall Street tumbles on global economic slowdown fears
summary: US stocks plummeted on Friday, with all three major indexes posting their largest one-day percentage declines since January 3, amid fears of a global economic slowdown. Weak factory data from the US and Europe led to an inversion of US Treasury yields, fuelling concerns of a recession. The Dow fell 1.77%, the S&P 500 lost 1.90%, and the Nasdaq dropped 2.5%. Investors remain cautious, with the CBOE Volatility Index jumping the most in two months.

site_title: Some Boeing 737 MAX orders in jeopardy, US pilots try software fix
summary: Indonesian airline Garuda plans to cancel a $6 billion order for Boeing 737 MAX jets due to concerns about safety following two fatal crashes, with some passengers expressing fear of boarding the plane. US pilots prepare to test Boeing's planned software upgrade for an anti-stall system, while regulators and investigators continue to review data from the crashes, which killed 346 people. Boeing is expected to make the safety feature standard on all 737 MAX planes, but the upgrade needs regulatory approval and could take weeks or months.

site_title: Empowering employees to be creative
summary: Business leaders must create a culture of innovation by providing a clear purpose, resources, and freedom to experiment. A culture of equality and collaboration is also essential, as it fosters a mindset of experimentation and encourages employees to speak up and share their thoughts. Innovation leaders must empower employees with the right tools and trust them to make decisions, while also being open to failure and experimentation. Organisations must also make innovation a part of their overall business strategy and celebrate both successes and failures. By doing so, businesses can unlock the full potential of their employees and drive growth and innovation.

site_title: Oil falls most in three weeks on global slowdown fears
summary: Oil prices dropped 1.6% on Friday, the largest decline in three weeks, amid fears of a global slowdown and disappointing economic data from Germany and France. The US treasury yield curve inverted for the first time since 2007, signaling a potential recession. Oil prices had been supported by supply cuts and disruptions in Venezuela and Iran, but concerns over slowing growth and the US-China trade dispute capped rallies. WTI settled at $59.04 a barrel, while Brent settled at $67.03 a barrel.

site_title: USDJPY still moving along upward trend-line
summary: The US Dollar (USD) has been on an upward trend against the Japanese Yen (JPY) since January 2019, with the USDJPY pair reaching 111.50, a 6.93% increase from its lowest point. The upward trend was driven by the Bank of Japan's expansion of its bond buying program, but was halted by the dovish stance of the US Federal Reserve after its March 21 meeting, which signaled no interest rate hikes for the year. The USDJPY is now moving along an upward trend-line, with key supports at 110.00 and 109.00.

site_title: UK's Theresa May hints she might not bring Brexit deal back for third parliament vote next week
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May hinted she may not bring her Brexit deal back to parliament for a third vote next week if it lacks sufficient support. Her deal has been rejected twice, and an EU summit granted an extension to Britain's departure. May wrote in a letter that if the deal is rejected again, she may ask for another extension before April 12, which would involve holding European Parliament elections. This would give her more time to pass the deal, but also raises concerns about the UK's departure from the EU.

site_title: China factory blast death toll jumps to 64, man rescued after 40 hours
summary: A chemical plant explosion in China's Yancheng city has resulted in a death toll of 64, with 28 people still missing. Rescuers found a survivor after 40 hours, and over 600 people have received medical treatment, including 34 critically injured and 60 seriously injured. Authorities have taken an unspecified number of people into police custody and are investigating the cause of the accident, which was at a facility owned by Tianjiayi Chemical, with a history of environmental regulation violations.

site_title: Sovereign funds placed record amount in 2018 venture capital deals: report
summary: Sovereign wealth funds invested a record amount in venture capital deals in 2018, with 84 deals in 77 rounds, up from 14 in the previous five-year period. This surge in investments aims to get early exposure to emerging companies like Airbnb and Uber. The increase in venture capital rounds is attributed to sovereign wealth funds seeking to diversify their portfolios and capitalize on growth opportunities.

site_title: Singapore shares end slow week on muted note
summary: Singapore shares ended the week on a muted note due to global market concerns, particularly the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates unchanged and signal no further increases for the rest of the year. Despite a minor Wall Street rally, Asian markets barely moved, with investors focusing on upcoming US-China trade talks.

site_title: Fed nominee Moore calls December's rate hike a 'substantial mistake'
summary: Federal Reserve nominee Stephen Moore criticized the Fed's December interest-rate hike, calling it a "substantial mistake." He expressed his willingness to work with Chairman Jerome Powell to ensure the US economy continues to expand, despite concerns about deflation and the impact of global growth on the US economy. Moore, an economist at the Heritage Foundation, supports President Trump's economic policies and believes the US can achieve 3-4% growth for the next 5-6 years.

site_title: ERA Realty launches S$1m grant to attract new talent
summary: ERA Realty Network has launched a S$1 million startup grant to attract new talent in the real estate industry. New agents pay S$100 for administrative and materials fees, instead of the usual S$1,127. The grant covers joining fees and renewal fees for the first year, providing a significant incentive for those looking to start a career in real estate sales.

site_title: Trump taps a strident Powell critic for spot on Fed board
summary: US President Donald Trump nominated Stephen Moore, a conservative economic commentator and critic of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, to join the Fed board, a move seen as unconventional and potentially contentious. Moore, who has clashed with Powell and expressed support for Trump's policies, aims to bring an independent voice to the Fed and work closely with Powell to promote economic growth. The nomination, which would require Senate approval, is likely to face criticism from Senate Democrats and some conservative economists, who question Moore's qualifications and views on monetary policy.

site_title: Pangolin Investment says exit offer for Challenger is too low
summary: Pangolin Investment Management advises minority shareholders of Challenger Technologies to reject Digileap Capital's S$0.56 per-share exit offer, calling it "derisory" and undervalued. The investment firm believes Challenger should be valued by its cash flow to shareholders, rather than historical metrics. This move comes at an upcoming extraordinary general meeting, where minority shareholders will have a say in the company's future.

site_title: Switching jobs? Think of it as moving your investments
summary: A job switch can be seen as a career investment, but it should only be made if it strengthens one's portfolio. Experts advise job seekers to thoroughly research opportunities, including talking to the incumbent, checking reviews, and researching turnover rates. Impulse decisions or acting on desperation can lead to mistakes. Instead, job seekers should weigh the pros and cons, consider their career goals, and think critically about the potential impact on their career. Ultimately, making an informed decision is key to a successful job switch.

site_title: Investor pessimism: is the world outlook getting worse?
summary: Investor pessimism is on the rise, fueled by negative news about the world. However, despite this, the global economy has made significant progress in the past 50 years, including the eradication of smallpox and a 99.99% reduction in plane crash fatalities. GDP per capita continues to increase, with even troubled countries like Afghanistan experiencing growth. Despite the US-China trade war and Brexit, the global economy is expected to continue its upward march, with professional investors citing favorable credit conditions and lower systemic risk. A long-term optimistic outlook is justified, and investors who adopt this perspective are more likely to be successful.

site_title: Sembcorp to supply solar power to YCH's warehouses in Asia
summary: Sembcorp Industries has agreed to supply solar power to YCH Group's warehouses across Asia, following the successful completion of a rooftop solar farm at YCH's Supply Chain City flagship building in Singapore. The partnership will power YCH's facilities in China, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam. This initiative aims to reduce the companies' carbon footprint and promote sustainable energy practices in the region.

site_title: Why Tencent missed the mark on profit by most in a decade
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd posted a 32% decline in fourth-quarter net income to 14.2 billion yuan, missing estimates by 32%. The slump was attributed to increased spending on content, cloud computing, and financial technology, as well as share issues and impairments. The company's gaming division showed signs of recovery, with sales exceeding expectations. Tencent's shares rose 1.2% in Hong Kong, and the company plans to introduce new revenue categories to reflect its growing diversity. The company's CEO, Pony Ma, believes China's Internet sector has entered a new phase, driven by the "industrial Internet".

site_title: Trump's son-in-law Kushner cooperating with US House probe: source
summary: President Donald Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner is cooperating with a US House Judiciary Committee probe into Trump and possible obstruction of justice and abuse of power. Kushner submitted documents in response to a wave of document requests. In contrast, Trump adviser Roger Stone's lawyer cited his right to avoid self-incrimination under the Fifth Amendment. The Justice Department has completed a report by Special Counsel Robert Mueller into Trump and Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election. The Mueller report's contents are expected to be released soon.

site_title: HDB awards white site in Pasir Ris Central to Allgreen Properties, Kerry Properties tie-up
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) awarded a 99-year leasehold plot in Pasir Ris Central to a joint venture between Allgreen Properties and Kerry Properties, with a winning bid of nearly S$700 million. The bid works out to S$684.48 per square foot per plot ratio. The dual envelope concept and price revenue tender closed on Dec 14, 2018, attracting three bids.

site_title: Curb the greed
summary: A recent business paper highlights the dangers of greed and excessive self-interest in driving market excesses and global crises. Examples include Valeant Pharmaceuticals' price hikes and South Korea's chaebol families exploiting corporate opportunities for personal gain. McKinsey & Company's secretive hedge fund, which invests in companies it advises, raises questions about potential conflicts of interest. The paper concludes that while some level of greed is necessary for human progress, excessive greed can lead to suffering and unfair market practices, and calls for greater regulation and accountability to curb these negative consequences.

site_title: Reits
summary: Key real estate news includes rising US mortgage rates, with a five-week decline ending, and a Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore expected to test demand for prime projects above $3,000 psf. Manhattan rents have hit another record, with more increases anticipated. In the UK, homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high, and New World is selling China property assets after securing a loan deal. WeWork has secured new tenants and filled more space at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore after its bankruptcy. These developments indicate shifting market trends and investor sentiment.

site_title: PSA's 2018 profit dips 2.3% to S$1.2b on higher depreciation, finance costs
summary: PSA International, a major container operator, reported a 2.3% dip in net profit to S$1.2 billion in 2018 due to higher depreciation and finance costs. Revenue rose 3% to S$4.09 billion. The decline was despite a jump in revenue.

site_title: Galaxy of wonder
summary: The Samsung Galaxy S10 retains its top spot as the best Android smartphone, offering a formidable feature set. The phone boasts a bright and accurate screen, a snappy performance, and robust hardware. The three-camera setup delivers great photos, especially in good lighting, while the video recording capabilities are impressive, with smooth and well-lit footage. However, some minor niggles include low-light photo issues and a "watercolour effect." Overall, the S10+ is a top choice for those seeking the best Android phone, despite some minor drawbacks.

site_title: Deutsche Bank's bosses get bonuses for first time in 4 years
summary: Deutsche Bank's management board members received their first bonuses in four years, with CEO Christian Sewing earning 7 million euros. The bank's overall bonus pool decreased 14% to 1.9 billion euros, attributed to a reduction in headcount. Sewing led the bank to its first profit in four years and is heading merger talks with Commerzbank. His 2018 pay was higher than some European CEOs, but lower than Credit Suisse's Tidjane Thiam. The move comes as the bank discusses a potential merger with Commerzbank.

site_title: Watches are the new bitcoin
summary: Vintage watches have become a sought-after investment opportunity, with prices for rare timepieces from brands like Rolex, Omega, and Patek Philippe doubling in some cases over just a couple of years. These collectors view watches as a stylish and valuable asset, similar to bitcoin, and are driving up demand in the market. As the watch collecting community continues to grow, experts are warning of a potential bubble, but the long-term value of these timepieces remains to be seen. The market is closely monitoring the trend, with time telling whether watches will follow in bitcoin's footsteps.

site_title: Australia's property stocks are ignoring the housing slump
summary: Australian property stocks have defied the nation's housing slump, rallying to their highest level in almost three years. The S&P/ASX 200 A-Reit Index has risen 13% this year, driven by diversified revenue streams, demand for offices, and low bond yields. Top performers include Charter Hall Group, Goodman Group, and Mirvac Group, which have benefited from a strong economy and the shift to online shopping. Despite the downturn in housing prices, the index's top stocks have outperformed, with some analysts warning that the sector may be a "value trap."

site_title: Lazada, Mastercard in 5-year partnership to develop e-commerce ecosystem in S-E Asia
summary: Lazada, backed by Alibaba, has partnered with Mastercard for a 5-year collaboration to develop an e-commerce ecosystem in South-east Asia. The partnership aims to enhance Lazada's services, increase consumer confidence, and promote digital payments through reward schemes. Lazada will also access Mastercard's sponsorship platforms and become an anchor merchant for new Mastercard solutions in select markets. Mastercard's data-driven insights will help Lazada drive e-commerce growth in the region's growing internet-savvy and mobile consumer base.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3 points to 1,666.66. Volume reached 2.8 billion lots worth RM2.1 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 470 to 377.

site_title: Boustead Projects inks JV deal to develop aerospace, high-tech park in Subang
summary: Boustead Projects has entered into a joint-venture agreement with Malaysia Airports Holdings to develop an aerospace and high-tech park in Subang, Malaysia. The joint venture, BPMA Subang, will hold 70% of the equity interest, with Malaysia Airports Holdings holding 30%. The park will be developed on approximately 34.66 acres of land and leased to aerospace corporations. Boustead Projects' subsidiary, BP Aerotech, will carry out the development work. The completed park will be a major hub for the aerospace industry in Malaysia.

site_title: Malaysia anti-graft regulator unfreezes Jawala's bank accounts
summary: Malaysia's anti-graft regulator has unfrozen the bank accounts of Jawala, a Catalist-listed company, with balances of at least RM16.5 million. The decision follows an order by the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission to release the seized properties to Jawala's subsidiary, under Section 60(1) of the Anti-Money Laundering Act. Jawala's regulatory filing stated that CIMB Bank received the order on March 21, allowing the company to access its frozen funds.

site_title: Julien Royer to open restaurant in Hong Kong
summary: French chef Julien Royer, known for his two Michelin-starred Singapore restaurant Odette, is set to open a fine-dining restaurant in Hong Kong called Louise in June. The restaurant will be located in the PMQ building in Sheung Wan, replacing Aberdeen Street Social, which will close on April 1. Royer is collaborating with Hong Kong restaurateur Yenn Wong of the Jia Group on the new venture.

site_title: Top Glove's Q2 profit dips 2.9% to RM105.8m on soaring finance costs
summary: Top Glove's Q2 net profit decreased 2.9% to RM105.8 million due to soaring finance costs, which rose to RM19.9 million from RM2.7 million previously. Despite a 21% revenue increase to RM1.16 billion, the company's bottom line was impacted by higher finance costs and tax expenses. The company issued US$200 million of exchangeable bonds to reduce interest costs and is optimistic about the industry outlook, expecting a 10% annual growth in glove demand.

site_title: ERA rolls out S$1m startup grant to attract new real estate agents
summary: ERA Realty Network has launched a S$1 million startup grant to help new real estate agents join the industry. The grant reduces the joining fees for new agents from S$1,127 to S$100, covering administrative and materials costs, as well as a S$100 subsidy for skills-based training. ERA aims to attract new talent in the face of global economic uncertainty and a weak labor market.

site_title: Tribe Accelerator forges tie-ups with BMW Group Asia, Intel, Nielsen
summary: Tribe Accelerator, a Singapore government-supported blockchain accelerator, has formed strategic relationships with BMW Group Asia, Intel, and Nielsen for knowledge sharing. The accelerator is part of Trive Ventures, a South-east Asia-focused venture capital firm. This partnership includes a global demo tour in Singapore, Seoul, San Francisco, and Shanghai. Tribe Accelerator has previously announced partnerships with Enterprise Singapore and PwC Singapore's Venture Hub, further solidifying its industry connections.

images.alt_text: Tribe Accelerator has formed strategic relationships with BMW Group Asia, Intel Corporation and Nielsen for knowledge sharing at the accelerator's organised industry engagements.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: DBS Equity Research has maintained a "Buy" rating on Frasers Property, citing the company's controlling stake in PGIM Real Estate Asia Retail Fund, which provides an attractive future pipeline for Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) to acquire and bulk up its presence in Singapore. The research team estimates that PGIM's earnings could make up 8-9% of Frasers Property's FY2018 earnings, and potential divestments of non-core assets could provide a near-term earnings lift. Frasers Property's valuation remains attractive, with a 0.7 times price/net asset value and a 5% dividend yield.

site_title: Telemedicine startups confront limits of diagnosis over video
summary: Singapore's telemedicine startups face challenges in diagnosing patients remotely, with doctors expressing concerns about the limitations of video consultations. To mitigate risks, many platforms select experienced doctors, use specialists, and refer patients to physical clinics when necessary. About 10-27% of patients are redirected to clinics due to doctor discomfort or grey areas in diagnosis. Startups aim to expand their chronic patient base and specialist doctors, with some planning to launch specialist modules. Despite limitations, experts believe remote physical examinations with technologies like digital stethoscopes and pulse oximeters may become more prevalent in the future, enabling more conditions to be treated via telemedicine.

images.alt_text: Left: Siaw Tung Yeng, CEO and founder, MaNaDr, says it brings in only doctors with at least a decade of experience. Right: Snehal Patel, CEO and co-founder of MyDoc, says its pool of doctors are told never to compromise on patient safety.

Left: Kevin Kok, COO of Doctor Anywhere, believes treating patients with chronic problems will be a key revenue driver. Centre: Christina Low, CEO and co-founder of HiDoc, has specialists on its platform, but plans to take in GPs down the road. Right: Bryan Koh, CEO and founder of WhiteCoat, says running a physical clinic as well leads to better care.

site_title: Too early to tell if it's deja vu
summary: The 2019 Formula One season opener in Australia sparked memories of the 2018 event, but rule changes aimed at increasing overtaking opportunities may add spice to this year's season. The simpler front wing design, intended to reduce the sport's reliance on aerodynamic complexity, could lead to more passing opportunities and a more exciting racing experience. However, it remains too early to determine the full impact of these rule changes.

images.alt_text: Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel (left) and Red Bull's Max Verstappen in action at Turn 2 during the F1 Australian Grand Prix in Melbourne on March 17.
Mercedes' Finnish driver Valtteri Bottas upstaged team-mate Lewis Hamilton to record a memorable victory in Australia.

site_title: Li Ka-Shing's son stumbles in year since father's retirement
summary: Li Ka-shing's son, Victor Li, 54, is struggling to follow in his father's footsteps after taking over CK Hutchison Holdings Ltd. in March 2018. The company's stock price has dropped 16% in the past year, and investors are skeptical about Victor's ability to replicate his father's success. Despite some redevelopments of existing properties in Hong Kong, Victor's attempts to make deals abroad have been unsuccessful, including a failed bid for APA Group and a withdrawal from a hostile takeover of MEG Energy Corp. The company's board of directors remains largely composed of old-timers, with an average age of over 73.

site_title: Housing a magnet for money launderers in Toronto: study
summary: A new study by Transparency International Canada found that Toronto's housing market has become a magnet for money laundering due to anonymous property ownership, weak regulation, and lax enforcement. Since 2008, $28.4 billion worth of housing was acquired in the Toronto region through private entities with anonymous owners. The study calls for more measures to shed light on anonymous ownership, including requiring disclosure of beneficial owners for property transfers. The Toronto government has already implemented measures, but more needs to be done to combat money laundering in the market.

site_title: Living to 100, and enjoying it
summary: A growing number of Singaporeans are living beyond 100 years old, with the life expectancy rate reaching 83.1 years in 2017. However, many are afraid of living to 100 due to financial and health concerns. Experts suggest that a mindset shift is needed to embrace the possibilities of a multi-stage life, where individuals can take breaks to pursue passions and rejuvenate themselves. Companies like Prudential Singapore are also removing retirement ages to keep talented employees, encouraging active ageing and longer careers. By taking proactive steps to manage health and finances, individuals can make living to 100 a positive experience.

images.alt_text: An increasing number of people are leading fulfilling lives into their 80s and 90s. Taking proactive and preventive steps to manage one's health, such as getting regular exercise and going for regular health screenings can also help people live longer years in good health.

site_title: New takes on the Old Fashioned
summary: The Old Fashioned, a classic cocktail, has been reimagined at Jigger & Pony group's Flagship bar, with a fresh spin on the traditional recipe. The bar offers three new takes on the classic drink, including a bespoke variation, alongside a classic rendition. Principal bartender Shigeru Nakamura emphasizes the importance of a clear story or inspiration behind each cocktail, ensuring that guests can "get it" and be excited to try the drink. The bar boasts a range of 200 whiskies, with featured flights every month, catering to whiskey enthusiasts.

site_title: PSA International 2018 net profit falls 2.3%
summary: PSA International's net profit fell 2.3% to S$1.2 billion in 2018 due to higher depreciation and finance costs. Revenue increased 3% to S$4.09 billion, despite slower global container trade growth. Container volumes rose 9.1% to 81 million TEUs, with flagship terminals in Singapore contributing 36.31 million TEUs. The company's balance sheet remains strong, with a gross debt equity ratio of 0.48 times. Despite the decline, PSA concluded 2018 on a "firm footing."

site_title: Garuda cancels order for 49 Boeing 737 Max jets after crashes
summary: Indonesia's national carrier Garuda has canceled a multi-billion-dollar order for 49 Boeing 737 Max 8 jets following two fatal crashes involving the plane. This appears to be the first formal cancellation for the model, with the possibility of more to come. Garuda had received one of the planes and paid Boeing around $26 million, but will now return the plane. The airline's decision comes after two crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia, casting a spotlight on the safety certification process and shaking confidence in the plane.

images.alt_text: Garuda has so far paid Boeing about US$26 million and says it would consider switching to a new version of the jet.

site_title: Oil slips further from 2019 highs on trade worries
summary: Oil prices fell further from 2019 highs on Friday due to US-China trade talks uncertainty, but received support from Opec supply cuts and US sanctions on Iran and Venezuela. Brent crude futures were at $67.11 per barrel, down 75 US cents from their last close, while US West Texas Intermediate futures were at $59.40 per barrel, down 58 US cents. Despite concerns over fuel consumption, supply cuts and sanctions are expected to keep prices bullish in the near term.

site_title: Back to the future: cassettes launch comeback tour
summary: Cassette tapes, once thought to be obsolete, have made a comeback in the music industry. Major record labels like Ariana Grande and Justin Bieber are releasing music on tape, and demand is on the rise. However, a global shortage of music-quality magnetic tape has led to a shortage of production facilities. Two companies, National Audio Company in the US and Mulann in France, have stepped in to meet the demand, manufacturing 18 million cassettes last year. The niche revival is driven by audiophiles seeking a tangible music experience, with sales of cassette tapes in the US growing by 23% in 2018.

images.alt_text: Audio cassettes made with magnetic stripes in the production plant of Mulann, in Avranches, northwestern France, under the trademark Recording The Masters.
Wasted magnetic strips (above) are used to make audio cassettes in the production plant of Mulann.

site_title: Blockchains & cryptos: To regulate or not to regulate
summary: Regulators are calling for more effective guidelines and rules to enhance investor protection in the rapidly evolving blockchain and cryptocurrency markets.
