Despite the benefits of blockchain technology, concerns over the anonymity and lack of oversight in cryptocurrencies have led to growing pressure for regulations. The meteoric volatility of blockchain-backed cryptocurrencies has also raised concerns about illicit trading and financial transactions. Regulators are faced with the challenge of creating a holistic and forward-looking regulatory framework that balances the potential benefits of blockchain technology with the need to protect investors and prevent financial crimes.

images.alt_text: Although regulations on certain crypto-related activities exist, efforts have been uneven and observers are casting doubts about these cryptos because of the frequency and severity of relevant frauds.

site_title: Gold prices supported as US Fed policy takes dovish shift
summary: US Federal Reserve officials have declared zero interest rate hikes for 2019 and ended its balance sheet normalization program from October 19, shifting its monetary policy direction to slower economic growth and market uncertainties. This dovish shift has supported gold prices, which continue to trade within a tight range as investors weigh competing influences in risk assets and global growth worries. Despite a positive consensus for Q1 2019, the precious metal remains vulnerable to market fluctuations, with key support levels at US$1,302.00 and resistance at US$1,325.00.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Sembcorp Industries partnered with YCH Group to supply warehouses with solar power. The Singapore Exchange queried Hong Fok's share price, while former Citibank relationship manager Zheng Xuemei's prohibition orders were halved to one year. AEM Holdings received S$174 million in sales orders for FY2019. Transcorp Holdings stated the S$6 million deposit for a cancelled China project is fully guaranteed. Malaysia's anti-graft panel ordered the release of monies in Jawala's frozen bank accounts, and the STI ended flat on Friday.

site_title: Top Glove Q2 profit dips 3% to RM105.8m on finance costs
summary: Top Glove, a Malaysia-based rubber glove maker, reported a 3% dip in Q2 profit to RM105.8 million due to increased finance costs. Despite a 21% revenue increase to RM1.16 billion, the company's net profit was lower than the same period last year. Finance costs rose 7.3 times to RM19.9 million, impacting the bottom line. The company's earnings per share decreased slightly, and it did not recommend a dividend for the quarter. Despite a challenging business environment, Top Glove's executive chairman remains optimistic about the industry outlook.

site_title: Keppel O&M unit finalises semi rig construction contract from Awilco Drilling
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine's (Keppel O&M) unit has finalized a $425 million contract with Awilco Drilling for the construction of a mid-water semi-submersible drilling rig for harsh environment use. The rig, built to Moss Maritime's CS60 ECO MW design, is scheduled for completion in the first quarter of 2022 and will operate in depths of up to 1,500 meters in north-west Europe. The contract is a repeat order for Keppel O&M, and the company's shares decreased 0.5% following the announcement.

site_title: The Hyflux story so far
summary: Hyflux's Tuaspring water desalination project was initially expected to be a springboard for the company, but it ultimately proved to be its toughest project. The project was financed through a S$6.8 million initial public offering in 2001. However, the business model floundered, and the project's challenges were exacerbated by the company's financial struggles. The article marks a significant turning point in Hyflux's history, highlighting the company's struggles in the integrated water and power project segment.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close marginally higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed marginally higher on Friday, driven by Wall Street rallies, but a stronger yen limited gains. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.09% to 21,627.34, while the Topix index increased 0.17% to 1,617.11.

site_title: Sembcorp looking to supply YCH Group's warehouses in Asia with solar power
summary: Sembcorp Industries has partnered with YCH Group to supply solar power to the logistics company's warehouses across Asia. A 2.8 megawatt peak solar farm at YCH's Supply Chain City flagship building has been completed, generating over 3,400 megawatt hours of green power annually. The project aims to reduce carbon footprint and provide cheaper electricity to YCH's clients, while also enhancing the sustainability of Supply Chain City.

site_title: Camsing Healthcare, Top Glove call for trading halt ahead of announcements
summary: Camsing Healthcare and Top Glove Corp have requested trading halts ahead of announcements. Camsing Healthcare's executive chairman, Lo Ching, filed a regulatory notice, while Top Glove Corp halted trading at 12:30pm to release its Q2 financial results. The companies' shares were trading at S$1.07 and S$1.47, respectively, before the halts. The exact nature of the announcements is not specified.

site_title: US: Wall Street falls at open on global growth worries
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 117.86 points, or 0.45%, to 25,844.65. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened lower, with declines of 10.36 and 38.70 points, respectively. The downturn was fueled by downbeat European data and lingering concerns about a slowing global economy following the Federal Reserve's dovish turn earlier in the week.

site_title: China trade deal likely; automakers can avoid tariffs with US plants says Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that trade negotiations with China are progressing, with a final agreement likely, and companies can avoid tariffs by building factories in the US. He expressed optimism about the deal, saying "the deal will probably happen" and China needs it "very badly." Trump also announced plans to keep a 25% tariff on European light trucks unless companies build factories in the US, and stated that he would not agree to zero tariffs for cars, but might consider it for certain products.

site_title: China's auto, internet giants set up 9.76b yuan fund to invest in ride-sharing industry
summary: China's major automobile and internet companies, including Chongqing Changan Automobile, Alibaba, and Tencent, have set up a 9.76 billion yuan joint venture to invest in the ride-sharing industry, focusing on new energy vehicles. The joint venture will be led by Changan, Dongfeng, and FAW, with Alibaba and Tencent's investment units holding smaller stakes. The company will establish a ride-sharing firm, excluding other business operations, and invest in new energy vehicles. This move aims to tap into the growing ride-sharing market in China.

images.alt_text: China's major automobile and internet companies, including Chongqing Changan Automobile, Alibaba and Tencent, are setting up a 9.76 billion yuan (S$1.97 billion) joint venture to invest in ride-sharing industry, Chongqing Changan Automobile said on Friday.

site_title: US should stay engaged in South-east Asia: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the importance of the US staying engaged in South-east Asia, citing geopolitical and geostrategic interests. Despite rising competition between the US and China, Chan suggested that both countries can complement each other in infrastructure development. He also stated that Singapore will evaluate all technologies, including those from Huawei, based on safety, security, and commercial viability. Chan's comments come amid ongoing trade talks between the US and China, and he expressed optimism for a stable global trading system if the two nations resolve their differences.

site_title: True to one's roots
summary: Kärcher, a German cleaning technology company, attributes its success to its family-owned nature and culture of innovation. Founded in 1935 by Alfred Kärcher, the company has maintained its headquarters in the small town of Winnenden near Stuttgart since 1939. Under CEO Hartmut Otto Jenner, Kärcher has expanded globally, with over 12,300 employees across 67 countries. The company's stability is ensured by its family-owned nature, with shareholders staying stable and ownership remaining within the Kärcher family. This approach allows for long-term planning and loyalty among employees, with over 90% of staff agreeing that the company's family-owned nature is important. Kärcher prioritizes innovation, with 1,000 employees involved in research and development, and has a formal innovation process in place. The company is also exploring digital technologies, such as data intelligence and decentralized control of manufacturing processes.

site_title: Li Ka-shing's son stumbles in first year since father's retirement
summary: Hong Kong's CK Hutchison Holdings Ltd, a flagship firm of billionaire Li Ka-shing, has seen its stock price drop 16% since Victor Li took over as CEO in March 2018, following his father's retirement. Despite a 11% increase in profit, Victor Li's attempts to put his stamp on the company have been marred by setbacks abroad, including failed high-profile deals. The younger Li has focused on redeveloping Hong Kong properties, but investors still doubt his ability to match his father's success, with some describing him as the "follow-up act" to a legendary figure.

images.alt_text: Even as CK Hutchison's profit has jumped, Mr Li's attempt to put his stamp on the group's future has led to some setbacks abroad, with the group retreating from several high-profile deals.

site_title: Indonesia's Garuda cancels 49-plane Boeing 737 order after crashes
summary: Indonesia's national carrier Garuda has canceled its order for 49 Boeing 737 Max 8 jets after two fatal crashes involving the plane. The decision was made due to a loss of trust among passengers in Indonesia. Garuda had already received one of the planes, worth $26 million, and is considering returning it or switching to another model. The move is thought to be the first formal cancellation for the 737 Max 8.

site_title: Tribe Accelerator adds tie-ups with BMW Group Asia, Intel and Nielsen
summary: Tribe Accelerator has formed strategic partnerships with BMW Group Asia, Intel Corporation, and Nielsen to enhance industry engagement and knowledge sharing. The accelerator will participate in a global demo tour and host masterclasses and mentoring sessions with the partners. BMW will share best practices in mobility and blockchain integration, Intel will provide blockchain technology guidance, and Nielsen will offer a "sandbox" for testing new technologies. The partnerships aim to accelerate the adoption of blockchain solutions and support innovation in the industry.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,212.19, down 0.01% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Friday at 3,212.19, down 0.01% on the day, with the Straits Times Index losing 1.46 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 152 to 147, with 446.3 million shares worth S$447.7 million exchanged hands. Notable movers included AEM Holdings gaining 4.2%, while CapitaLand and SGX fell 1.4% each.

site_title: Singapore shares end flat on Friday, but up 0.3% on the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended flat on Friday, closing at 3,212.10, but up 0.3% on the week. Trading volumes were high, with 825.53 million securities traded. Decliners outnumbered advancers 198 to 181, and 16 of the STI's 30 constituents fell. AEM Holdings gained 4.2% after receiving S$174 million in sales orders, while Hong Fok rose 4.3% after addressing "unusual price movements" in its shares.

site_title: Fitch cuts Singtel outlook to 'negative' on Bharti rights issue, weaker growth
summary: Fitch Ratings has cut Singtel's long-term default outlook to "negative" due to planned rights subscription in Indian associate Bharti Airtel and weaker earnings growth in tough markets. The outlook downgrade was also influenced by Singtel's expected increase in funds from operations-adjusted net leverage, which may surpass the two-time threshold for a ratings downgrade. Despite this, Singtel's senior unsecured rating remains at "A+" from Fitch, while Moody's has an "A1" rating with a warning of "weak credit metrics".

site_title: Two-year prohibition orders against former Citi relationship manager halved upon appeal
summary: Former Citibank relationship manager Zheng Xuemei's two-year prohibition orders have been reduced to one year by the Monetary Authority of Singapore. The orders, issued in 2018, prohibited her from performing regulated activities and providing financial advisory services due to her false statements to a client. Zheng appealed, and after a hearing by an Appeal Advisory Committee, Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam reduced the orders. The decision was made after considering the appeal and taking into account the evidence presented.

site_title: Hope is not an investment thesis
summary: Investors' perceptions of market trends have shifted, with a dovish stance from the US Federal Reserve, a possible resolution to the US-China trade war, and an end to the longest government shutdown contributing to hope in 2019. However, these factors may not have materialized, as markets have experienced volatility. The article suggests that investors suffer from recency bias, remembering recent events better than earlier ones, and are also influenced by non-material information. This has led to a mixed assessment of whether investors were too pessimistic in 2018 or too optimistic in 2019.

site_title: Australia shares up, aided by financials and healthcare; NZ at record high
summary: Australian shares rose 0.45% on Friday, led by financial and healthcare stocks, following a rally on Wall Street after the US Federal Reserve abandoned rate hike projections due to signs of a slowing US economy. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,195.2, a 0.3% gain for the week.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks steady as institutions book profits; won down
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index ended flat on Friday due to institutions taking profits from a sharp rise in Samsung Electronics shares the previous day. The won weakened, while the benchmark bond yield rose. Foreigners bought 245.6 billion won worth of shares, while local institutions sold 305.7 billion won worth. The won was quoted at 1,130.1 per dollar, down 0.21% from its previous close. The Kospi has risen 7.15% so far this year.

site_title: Good afternoon, good night, goodness me: Fury over South Korean presidential greeting
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in faced criticism for using the incorrect Malaysian greeting "selamat sore" (good afternoon) instead of "selamat malam" (good night) during a press conference and dinner. The mistake triggered a diplomatic row, with opposition lawmakers and newspapers calling it a "diplomatic disaster." Foreign Minister Kang Kyung-wha apologized to Parliament, stating that the ministry made a "painful mistake," but an aide for the Malaysian prime minister's office defended the greeting's usage in Malaysia, saying it was "happy and amused" by the comment.

site_title: Traffic-choked Jakarta battles epic gridlock with new MRT
summary: Jakarta, Indonesia, has inaugurated its first mass rapid-transit (MRT) system, a $1.1 billion project aimed at alleviating the city's severe traffic congestion. The 16km line will reduce travel time between central and southern Jakarta from 2 hours to 30 minutes. While the new line is expected to cut carbon emissions and economic losses, experts caution that changing the city's culture and attitudes towards public transportation will take time. The system is part of a broader infrastructure push to boost Indonesia's fortunes and support President Joko Widodo's re-election bid.

site_title: Credit Suisse CEO gets a 30% pay hike for completing turnaround
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Tidjane Thiam received a 30% pay hike to 12.7 million Swiss francs for delivering the bank's first annual profit in four years. The increase was partly to compensate for a 2017 pay cut. Despite the bank's trading losses, Thiam's pay was boosted by the return to profitability. The bank's overall bonus pool remained unchanged, but top performers received larger awards. Thiam's tenure has seen the stock decline over 50%, with the global-markets business posting a larger-than-expected loss.

site_title: Jump in Hong Fok's share price prompts SGX query
summary: Singaporean property developer Hong Fok's share price jumped 6.42% on Friday morning after a Singapore Exchange (SGX) query about recent "unusual price movements". The company confirmed it had not disclosed any new information and was aware of no unannounced events that could explain the price change. Hong Fok has also repurchased its own shares in March, following a dividend announcement and financial statement release in February. The company maintains compliance with SGX listing rules.

site_title: US warns China meddling in Hong Kong hurting business confidence
summary: The US State Department warned China's increased meddling in Hong Kong has strained international business confidence, citing incidents like the expulsion of a Financial Times editor, jailing of democracy activists, and proposed extradition laws. The US report, under the 1992 Hong Kong Policy Act, expressed concerns about China's tightening grip on Hong Kong's freedoms, which could impact the city's special trade status and economic ties with the US. The US urges China and Hong Kong to maintain the "one country, two systems" arrangement to preserve Hong Kong's autonomy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 6.35 points to 1,670.01. The market saw 86.86 million lots traded worth RM45.67 million, with 165 gainers outnumbering 44 losers.

site_title: Asia: Shares hit 6½-month high on tech hopes, US data
summary: Asian shares rose to a 6½-month high on Friday, driven by upbeat US data and optimism in the tech sector, which lifted Wall Street stocks and calmed some of the jitters sparked by the Federal Reserve's cautious outlook. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite hit five-month highs, with Apple leading the tech sector's advance. The US dollar jumped back after a surprise drop, and the euro traded flat on the day. The Fed's dovish stance has sparked expectations of a rate cut, and investors are awaiting US-China trade talks next week.

site_title: Six dead as car hits crowd in China, police kill driver
summary: A car rammed into a crowd in central China's Zaoyang City, killing six people and injuring seven others. The driver, fatally shot by police, was a "vengeful repeat offender" with daggers in his car. This incident is the latest in a series of similar attacks in China, following incidents in Hunan Province last September and Liaoning Province in November.

site_title: US should stay engaged in South-east Asia: Chan Chun Sing in Washington
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the importance of the US staying engaged in South-east Asia, citing economic and geostrategic interests. Despite rising competition between the US and China, Chan noted that Singapore would prioritize commercial viability over geopolitical concerns. He also highlighted the potential for cooperation between the US and China in infrastructure development, stating that "there will be occasions they'll be able to complement each other." Chan's visit coincided with the US seeking a trade deal with China, and he expressed optimism for a positive outcome, noting that a stable global trading system is crucial for economic development.

site_title: Death toll from east China factory blast jumps to 44: state media
summary: A massive explosion at a chemical plant in eastern China's Jiangsu province has raised the death toll to 44, with 90 others seriously injured. The blast triggered a 2.2-magnitude earthquake and damaged nearby buildings and homes. The cause of the explosion is still unknown, but an investigation is underway.

site_title: Ex-FBI chief Comey has 'no idea' of Mueller conclusion
summary: Former FBI Director James Comey stated in a New York Times op-ed that he has "no idea" of the conclusion of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation, as long as it was conducted properly. Comey expressed his concern for a functioning justice system, rather than the specific outcome of the investigation. He also declined to join calls for Trump's impeachment, citing a desire to avoid further division in the US society. Comey's comments come amid anticipation of the Mueller report's imminent release, which may address allegations of obstruction of justice surrounding Trump's firing of Comey in 2017.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher encouraged by US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by US rallies, despite a stronger yen weighing on the market. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.16% or 33.81 points to 21,642.73, while the Topix index gained 0.08% or 0.91 points to 1,615.30.

site_title: Japan's February consumer inflation slows, stays distant from BOJ's goal
summary: Japan's core consumer prices rose 0.7% in February, slowing from the previous month and remaining below the Bank of Japan's 2% target. This slowdown underscores the fragile nature of Japan's economic recovery due to escalating Sino-U.S. trade frictions and slowing Chinese growth. The data also suggests the impact of these trade tensions on exports and business sentiment.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday's open; STI up 0.19% to 3,219.77
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.19% to 3,219.77 at Friday's open, driven by gains from AEM Holdings and Jardine Strategic Holdings. Gainers outnumbered losers 98 to 33, with 41.6 million securities changing hands. Active index stocks, including DBS Group Holdings, also saw increases. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day streak of gains.

site_title: Pound stabilises but struggles to rally after Brexit delay deal
summary: The British pound stabilized on Friday after a Brexit delay deal, with a deadline set for April 12 for Prime Minister Theresa May to pass her divorce agreement through parliament. The EU warned that a negative vote would lead to a no-deal Brexit, but the pound remains under pressure due to uncertainty. Sterling recovered from a low of US$1.3004, but analysts remain cautious, citing concerns over a no-deal Brexit. The Bank of England expressed concern over the impact of a no-deal Brexit on businesses, while equity markets mostly rose on positive lead from Wall Street.

site_title: Levi Strauss shares surge 31% in stock market return
summary: Levi Strauss & Co shares surged 31% in their debut, reaching a market value of $8.7 billion, driven by strong investor appetite and the popularity of denim styles. The 165-year-old US company's return to the public market comes as stocks near all-time highs. CEO Chip Bergh expressed humility about the stock's performance, stating the company's focus is on long-term business success rather than short-term market fluctuations.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with further gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.35% on Friday, tracking a healthy lead from Wall Street, where investors reacted positively to the Federal Reserve's dovish outlook for interest rates. The Hang Seng Index closed at 29,173.33, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index remained flat. The gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and came as traders brushed off new US President Trump's threats to extend stocks rally.

site_title: World's cheapest mortgage may be around the corner in Denmark
summary: Denmark is set to introduce a 30-year mortgage with a fixed interest rate of 1% for homeowners, making it potentially the world's cheapest mortgage. This move is expected to be comparable to the rates paid by the governments of Switzerland and Germany. The Danish mortgage market, which finances home loans through the world's largest covered-bond market, has historically been considered one of the safest.

site_title: Deep Dive

The 47mm, 161g watch features a micro-sandblasted brown ceramic disc on the bezel and a naturally patinating bronze case. site_title: Japan finance minister says economy recovering, sales tax hike to go ahead
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso stated that the economy is in a moderate recovery and plans to proceed with a national sales tax hike in October. He expressed support for the US Federal Reserve's decision to pause interest rate hikes, citing it as a positive move for the US economy. Aso's comments came after a cabinet meeting, where no changes to the sales tax plan were announced.

site_title: Trump: US should 'fully recognise' Israeli sovereignty over Golan Heights
summary: US President Donald Trump announced the US should "fully recognise" Israeli sovereignty over the Golan Heights, a strategic area seized from Syria, in a major pre-election gift to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. The move was welcomed by Netanyahu and Republican Senator Lindsey Graham, who is pushing for Congress to recognise Israeli control over the Golan. The decision comes ahead of the expected unveiling of a White House plan for Israeli-Palestinian peace, which Palestinian leaders say will be biased in favour of Israel.

site_title: British cannot close off fishing waters post Brexit: France
summary: French Minister of Agriculture Didier Guillaume stated it's "not possible" for Britain to close its waters to French and EU fishermen post-Brexit, as it would be "unacceptable" and "not what we want." site_title: Transcorp says S$6m deposit for cancelled China project MOU is 'fully guaranteed'
summary: TRANSCORP Holdings has stated that its S$6 million deposit for a cancelled China project is "fully guaranteed". The deposit was made in good faith, and Transcorp is not seeking additional assurances beyond a full guarantee.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Camsing Healthcare, Sevak, HRNetGroup, AEM Holdings

Moore, a conservative economist and long-time Trump supporter, and Cain, a former presidential candidate, are being evaluated for the two vacant spots on the board. site_title: OCBC Pay Anyone on food ordering app Waitrr

Wirecard generated 2.1 billion euros in sales last year and has been drawn into a London lawsuit over a disputed Indian business purchase. The company has not commented on the allegations.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares follow Wall Street rally

site_title: Tesla chief Musk calls on workers to help deliver cars

Tsai, who is transiting through Hawaii on her way home from a visit to Pacific island nations, has been criticized by China for her actions. Tensions between China and Taiwan remain high, with China seeking to assert its sovereignty over the island.

site_title: As worries about populism in Europe rise, investors bet on stock market volatility
summary: Investors are betting on heightened European stock market volatility ahead of May's European Parliament elections, driven by concerns about rising populism. site_title: Hundreds charged or jailed in Brazil's 'Car Wash' probe
summary: Hundreds of people in Brazil have been charged or jailed in the 'Car Wash' anti-corruption investigation, which began in 2014. 155 people, including former president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, have been convicted, while hundreds more have been charged. The investigation has uncovered a vast graft operation involving state oil firm Petrobras and major construction companies. Ex-president Michel Temer was arrested on corruption allegations, and public confidence in the system has been severely damaged. However, a recent Supreme Court ruling has raised concerns about securing further convictions of politicians.

summary: China's State Development & Investment Corp (SDIC) has vowed to stop investing in new coal-fired plants, joining a global shift away from the polluting fossil fuel. Despite this, large investors and lenders are moving away from coal, with some banks pledging to stop providing capital for coal plants. The move is seen as globally significant, as it's the first Chinese domestic financier to announce a total withdrawal from coal investments.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip as banks slide, London shares jump

Analysts attributed the London surge to the pound's slump and commodity stocks outperforming. site_title: Deutsche Bank CEO sees strong case for Commerzbank merger: source
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO Christian Sewing believes a merger with Commerzbank is a strong case, despite potential job cuts and skepticism from investors. The merger would merge Germany's two largest banks, but its feasibility remains uncertain.

site_title: Singapore, US to jointly promote infrastructure development in Asia
summary: Singapore and the US have signed an agreement to promote infrastructure development and investment in Asia, complementing China's Belt and Road Initiative. The agreement will facilitate information sharing, deal facilitation, and capacity building in sectors such as energy, transportation, and urban development. Analyst Phil Flynn noted the market's hesitation at high levels, citing a bearish outlook from President Trump's tariff moves. Despite the decline, oil prices remain near their 2019 peak.

summary: Frasers Property and its real estate investment trust arm, Frasers Centrepoint Trust, are increasing their stakes in the PGIM Real Estate Asia Retail Fund. site_title: Apple's new paid subscription news service to feature WSJ
summary: Apple is launching a paid subscription news service featuring The Wall Street Journal, with a monthly fee of $10. site_title: Four in 10 Britons worried, angry about Brexit: survey
summary: Around 4 in 10 British adults feel powerless, angry, or worried about Brexit, according to a Mental Health Foundation survey. The survey was conducted among 1,823 British adults and reflects the ongoing impact of Brexit on the nation's mental health.

site_title: Sakura Madness

site_title: New technique may overcome infertility in childhood cancer survivors
summary: Scientists have developed a new technique to potentially overcome infertility in childhood cancer survivors. This approach could help the 30% of prepubescent boys who become sterile due to toxic cancer treatments. Researchers hope this technique could provide a solution for men diagnosed with cancer in childhood, allowing them to have children in the future.

site_title: Boeing 737 Max to get new warning light: industry source

site_title: Japan convenience stores pressed to rethink 24-7 model amid labour crunch

MMT advocates claim that the government can print money to finance its spending, but experts argue that this approach ignores supply-side constraints and risks undermining long-term growth and financial stability.

summary: Singapore is witnessing a surge in plant-based protein options, with several restaurants and eateries embracing lab-produced "meats" such as Impossible Foods' 'bleeding' burger and Beyond Burger. Eight restaurants, including Michelin-starred and celebrity chef-led eateries, have endorsed these products, while supermarkets have started stocking them up. The trend is attributed to the environmental benefits of plant-based diets, with a recent study suggesting that a predominantly plant-based diet can mitigate climate change and confer health benefits. As the market continues to grow, chefs and restaurateurs are embracing the versatility of plant-based meats, with some even using them as a new ingredient in fine dining settings.

site_title: Hyphens inks MOU with A*Star's A*ccelerate
summary: Hyphens Pharma International Limited signed a 5-year commercialization agreement with A*Star's A*ccelerate to develop products targeting eczema, acne, and pigmentary disorders. The partnership aims to launch its first product within two years, following successful research collaborations between the two organizations since 2014. The agreement builds on prior partnerships and enhances the relationship between Hyphens and A*Star, with the goal of improving skin health through encapsulation and sebum control.

site_title: Old World Charm in San Sebastian
summary: San Sebastian, a coastal town in Spain's Basque region, is renowned for its rich history, stunning natural beauty, and exceptional culinary scene. The city, which boasts a compact size and picturesque location, has been a summer retreat for Spanish royals and hosts the annual San Sebastian International Film Festival. With its origins dating back 5,000 years, San Sebastian has evolved from a monastery to a fishing village and later a strategic military stronghold. The city's famous pintxos bars, seafood restaurants, and txokos (all-male eating clubs) showcase the region's strong food culture. However, over-tourism has led to concerns among locals, making the best time to visit the spring and autumn.

site_title: Oil stays above US$60 on US storage drawdown, Opec+ output cuts
summary: Oil prices remain above US$60 a barrel after the largest US storage drawdown since July, with crude inventories declining to 439.5 million barrels last week. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) and its partners have implemented output cuts, while supply disruptions in Venezuela and Iran have also contributed to the price increase. Analysts expect prices to stay buoyed by growing demand and supply picture, but a US$65 breakeven is unlikely in the near term.

site_title: Fed dims economic outlook, predicts no rate hikes this year
summary: The Federal Reserve announced a surprise dimming of its economic outlook, predicting no interest rate hikes in 2019. The decision was made due to a slowdown in the US economy, with household and business spending expected to drop off. The median federal funds rate forecast for 2019 was lowered to 2.4% from 2.9% in December. Although the Fed expects no rate hikes this year, it still anticipates an increase in the key policy interest rate in 2020.

site_title: One year on, Skoda chalks up record sales and is launching mobile app for drivers
summary: Skoda has achieved record sales in Singapore, selling 587 cars between March 2018 and February 2019. The brand has outperformed rivals such as Ford, Seat, and Opel, and has received numerous awards for its cars. Managing Director Ricky Tay attributes the success to Skoda's focus on value and quality, and notes that the brand complements Volkswagen, its corporate parent. To further engage customers, Skoda is launching a mobile app that will allow owners to book services, access roadside assistance, and enjoy exclusive privileges.

site_title: Red-hot Beto could end up with blue party's veto
summary: Beto O'Rourke, a 46-year-old former Texas Congressman, has garnered significant attention and "Betomania" among Democrats for his presidential nomination. His media coverage, including a Vanity Fair magazine cover, has made him a national celebrity. However, his popularity may be short-lived as the Democratic party may ultimately veto his nomination due to concerns about his electability and lack of experience.

site_title: Aglianico in its own right
summary: Aglianico, an Italian red wine grape, has made significant progress in recent years, but remains underappreciated. A blind tasting of 20 aglianico wines from Campania and Basilicata regions revealed similarities and differences between the two, with Taurasi wines generally showing more structure and aging potential. The tasting confirmed aglianico's versatility, with wines ranging from elegant to burly and tannic. The top wines included a 2011 Taurasi Riserva from Mastroberardino and a 2014 Aglianico del Vulture from Bisceglia, both offering great value and complexity.

site_title: Norwegian kroner surges as rates expected to rise again
summary: Norway's krone surged after the central bank raised interest rates, signaling further tightening to support the strengthening domestic economy. The decision, which was expected, contrasts with a dovish shift by most central banks, including the European Central Bank. The krone's surge is a rare example of a currency rising in response to hawkish monetary policy.

site_title: Better engagement, but virtual AGMs also come with some risks
summary: Singapore is set to adopt virtual Annual General Meetings (AGMs) starting this year, with the aim of increasing shareholder engagement and accessibility. The digital approach is expected to provide greater convenience and wider participation, particularly among the new generation of digital native investors. However, experts also warn that virtual AGMs may exclude those uncomfortable with technology, allow firms to filter out inconvenient questions, and compromise the closed-door nature of AGMs. To mitigate these risks, experts recommend requiring shareholder consent for virtual-only AGMs and implementing hybrid options that allow both physical and online attendance.

site_title: HK property tycoon released from jail heads home for dim sum
summary: Hong Kong property tycoon Thomas Kwok, 67, was released from Stanley Prison after serving 3 years of a 5-year sentence for good behavior. He was granted early release and immediately headed home to order dim sum, stating "I have already ordered dim sum." This marks the end of his time in jail, allowing him to return to his life outside of prison.

site_title: Skanska to miss construction margin target this year and next
summary: Swedish builder Skanska warns it will miss its target for an operating margin of 3.5% in its construction business for this year and next due to weak profitability and project writedowns in Poland and the US. Skanska is restructuring its construction division as a result.

site_title: Boeing faces growing pressure in Washington over 737 Max crashes
summary: The Boeing 737 Max faces growing pressure in Washington over two crashes that killed 346 people, with the FBI investigating the FAA's oversight of Boeing's certification. The US Justice Department is also examining the FAA's oversight. Regulators in Europe and Canada want to verify the jet's safety themselves, rather than relying on US vetting. Boeing has promised to update its automatic flight software, but faces scrutiny over its handling of the crisis, including allegations of promoting Boeing while in office. The grounding of over 350 Max aircraft and the halt of nearly 5,000 deliveries worth $500 billion continue.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The High Court has appointed Yit Chee Wah of FTI Consulting as a judicial manager for Chinese shipbuilding firm JES International following its application in February. Trading in JES's shares has been suspended since March 2015.

site_title: Eurozone bond yields fall as markets cheer halt in US rate hikes
summary: Eurozone government bond yields fell as the US Federal Reserve abandoned projections for any rate hikes this year due to an economic slowdown. US 10-year Treasury yields plummeted to a 14-month low of 2.51%, while German benchmark 10-year bond yields dropped to 0.048%, matching two-year lows. Analysts see this as a signal the end of the rate hiking cycle, with eurozone bond yields also tumbling 2-3 bps on the day.

site_title: Siemens to explore gas turbine deal with Asian partner
summary: Siemens AG is exploring a potential combination of its large gas turbine business with an Asian partner, including Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd. The talks are ongoing and options include a full or partial sale, or a joint venture. The business, worth around 3.2 billion euros, has been considered for sale since last June due to the global market for fossil power-plant technology collapsing. Antitrust issues could play a role in any deal-making.

site_title: Two Singapore consortia to develop, trial driverless road cleaning vehicles
summary: Two Singapore consortia, Nanyang Technological University and ST Engineering Land Systems, have been awarded research and development projects by the National Environment Agency and the Ministry of Transport to develop and trial driverless road cleaning vehicles. The projects aim to improve productivity, reduce reliance on manpower, and increase environmental friendliness in road cleaning operations. The trials, expected to begin in 2020, will test the safety features and efficiency of the autonomous environmental service vehicles (AESVs) in a controlled environment before moving to public roads.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) is upgraded to a buy rating with a target price of S$1.61, driven by China's rising disposable income and potential asset recycling efforts. Starhill Global Reit is also maintained as a buy, citing its long master lease extensions and oversupply of retail malls in Kuala Lumpur. Key risks include a slowing Chinese economy and negative rental reversions, but the sector's top picks are expected to benefit from turnaround in overseas and Singapore office portfolios.

site_title: TB can be eradicated by 2045 with proper funding: experts
summary: An international team of experts predicts that tuberculosis can be eradicated by 2045 with proper funding, which would require a quadrupling of current research funding to around $3 billion per year. The disease, which causes over 1.6 million deaths annually, can be prevented and treated if caught early. Experts say that better screening, treatments, and public awareness are needed to reduce cases, and that reducing deaths to less than 200,000 per year would cost around $10 billion annually.

site_title: Oxley appoints agents for sale of hotels
summary: Oxley Holdings has appointed CBRE, Jones Lang LaSalle Property Consultants, and JLL Hotels & Hospitality Group as agents for the sale of its Mercure and Novotel Hotels on Stevens Road. This comes after the company previously called off the sale of the properties. The agents will be responsible for sourcing, marketing, evaluating, negotiating, and securing a purchaser for the hotels.

site_title: Fed's prolonged pause opens door for Asia's central banks to cut
summary: The Federal Reserve's decision to pause interest rate hikes has created an opportunity for Asian central banks to cut rates, driven by subdued inflation and slowing economic growth. Central banks in Indonesia and the Philippines are expected to keep policy on hold, while others, including China, Taiwan, and South Korea, may also maintain rates. Analysts predict a shift towards domestic concerns and a potential dovish turn, with the yuan's recent strength contributing to a currency rally across emerging Asia.

site_title: The three-wheeler that could make your car obsolete
summary: Adiva, a Taiwanese brand, is set to launch its AD1 Electric scooter in Singapore next year. The three-wheeled, battery-powered scooter has a 32 horsepower electric motor, 7 kilowatt-hour lithium ion battery, and can travel 120-150km on a single charge. With lower fuel costs and increasing support for electric vehicles in Singapore, Adiva believes the scooter could be popular in the city-state and potentially become a regional leader. The company's distributor plans to assess the scooter's market viability before launching it.

site_title: SICC aims to raise awareness of the circular economy
summary: The Singapore International Chamber of Commerce (SICC) has identified raising awareness of the circular economy, promoting collaborative innovation, and fighting ageism as its three focus areas for 2019. The chamber aims to encourage businesses to cut waste and promote environmental sustainability, and hopes to make Singapore a hub for the circular economy in Asia. The SICC will organize quarterly events to raise awareness and collaborate with member companies to brainstorm measures to encourage businesses to think differently.

site_title: Tembusu Partners launching several funds totalling 1b yuan
summary: Singapore-based Tembusu Partners is launching several investment funds totaling 1 billion yuan (S$205.6 million) as it seeks to increase investments in China, in line with Beijing's efforts to liberalize the economy and promote innovation. Former CapitaLand CEO Lim Ming Yan has been appointed as chairman of its China advisory board. This move is part of Tembusu's expansion into the Chinese market, where the private equity firm aims to capitalize on the growing demand for investments in the country.

site_title: Singapore is Revolut's first stop in its Asia push
summary: Revolut, a European fintech company, is launching in Singapore, its first Asian stop, after fine-tuning its product. The startup aims to target 100,000 users in Singapore within a year, despite facing challenges from incumbent banks. Regulated as a remittance business by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, Revolut will offer a debit card with multi-currency accounts and free ATM withdrawals. The company plans to grow staff numbers to 20 and move to a new office in Singapore, with future plans to expand to Japan, Australia, and other markets.

site_title: Gadgets light up Xiaomi's future
summary: Xiaomi reports a 53% jump in 2018 sales to 175 billion yuan, defying the global smartphone slump. The company swung to a full-year net profit of 13.5 billion yuan, driven by a 40% surge in smartphone sales. International sales now account for 40% of the total, with Xiaomi making progress in Western Europe and India. The company's forays into TVs, washing machines, and other internet of things products also show promising growth, with a 44 billion yuan annual sales haul.

site_title: Mortgage bond buyers not worried by Australia's housing slump
summary: Mortgage bond buyers remain optimistic about Australia's housing market slump, citing strong employment and low interest rates. Despite a record 0.75% arrears rate, investors see no systemic threat, with some adding holdings of senior "AAA" rated residential mortgage-backed securities. The Reserve Bank of Australia has shifted to a neutral policy stance, and the government warns of potential economic impact, but buyers are undeterred. New issuance of residential mortgage-backed securities is expected, with some investors viewing the market as a "defensive" play amid rising volatility.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of Australia has shifted to a neutral policy stance as the property downturn weighs on household spending and dampens growth.

site_title: Mazda CX-5 review: A class act
summary: The Mazda CX-5 2.5L Super Luxury has been praised for its refinement and luxury features, despite not having a premium badge. The updated 2019 model boasts a range of changes, including rear seatbelt indicators, G-Vectoring Control, and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. The top-of-the-line Super Luxury model features plush amenities like digital speedometers, 360-degree cameras, and ventilated front seats. While the 2.5L models attract a pollution surcharge, the CX-5 remains a more affordable option compared to luxury rivals like the Lexus NX.

images.alt_text: The CX-5 still comes with two engine choices (2.0 and 2.5 litres), with two levels of trim for each. All four models now have Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, which are practically must-haves in this day and age. Plug your smartphone in and the Mazda's entertainment system becomes an extension of it, and given how your phone is an extension of you, it's tough to see why anyone would countenance buying a car without that sort of connectivity.

site_title: Oxley appoints agents for sale of Mercure, Novotel Hotels
summary: Oxley Holdings has appointed CBRE, Jones Lang LaSalle Property Consultants, and JLL Hotels & Hospitality Group as exclusive agents for the sale of its Mercure and Novotel Hotels on Stevens Road. The appointment, set to expire in six months, follows initial interest from potential buyers. Oxley Holdings executive chairman and CEO Ching Chiat Kwong stated that the developer has received strong interest from enquirers. The agents will be tasked with sourcing, marketing, evaluating, negotiating, and securing a purchaser for the hotels.

site_title: Central America struggles with deadly beetles, crop losses
summary: A deadly southern pine beetle, known as the gorgojo, has reappeared in Honduras, threatening agriculture and water sources in Central America. The beetle, which destroyed over half a million hectares of conifers between 2013 and 2017, is linked to droughts brought on by El Nino, a climatic phenomenon that can exacerbate crop losses and water shortages. The region is already facing a dry spell, with countries such as El Salvador and Guatemala reporting crop losses and water shortages, and the UN Food and Agriculture Organization has announced a project to protect households most at risk from drought.

images.alt_text: A worker cutting pine trees affected by the southern pine beetle in Valle de Angeles. The Central American region faces a severe drought that is causing crop losses and drastic rationing of water for human consumption.

site_title: Fed's pause on rate hikes cheers markets
summary: The Singapore stock market ended the day with a 0.2% gain, closing at 3,213.65, despite concerns over global growth and US-China trade. The US Federal Reserve's decision to pause rate hikes was a positive factor, but worries about US growth and trade tensions weighed on investor sentiment. Oil prices hit a five-month high, and the US dollar weakened, contributing to gains in agri-business counters. Notable gainers included Chuan Hup Holdings and Challenger Technologies, while Genting Singapore rose 3% on stable revenue and limited growth avenues.

site_title: Google's new gaming service will let game makers use rival clouds
summary: Google's new gaming service, Stadia, will allow game makers to use rival clouds, potentially limiting the company's revenue. The service, launching this year, will enable high-quality video games to be played in a browser, with player settings and data residing on Google's servers. However, game publishers can also use other public and private cloud services, which may impact streaming quality. Stadia will follow content guidelines similar to the ESRB, excluding adult-only content, and will offer parental controls to address game addiction concerns.

site_title: Chefs' Specials
summary: Chef Sam Chablani has introduced an artisanal treat, Addict Kombu Butter, made with butter, kombu, and sea salt. The 10-day preparation process yields only 50-70 jars per batch, making it exclusive and addictive. The butter is suitable for cooking and as a spread on warm bread, and is particularly recommended with roasted fish, mussels, and prawns. Chablani, who launched his platform Fresh And Fun, has developed healthy and preservative-free recipes, including healthy sous vide meats and Bonz Tea.

images.alt_text: Kausmo Hot Sauce and Apple Butter Sauce.

site_title: David Yarrow
summary: Photographer David Yarrow, 48, left his hedge fund manager position to pursue fine art photography five years ago. He is now one of the world's most successful photographers, known for his striking black-and-white wildlife photos auctioned for $75,000-$110,000. Yarrow travels extensively to capture rare animals in their natural habitats, including emperor penguins in Antarctica and Kenya's wild elephant Lugard. His work features supermodels like Cindy Crawford and Cara Delevingne.

images.alt_text: "We use chicken quite a bit to attract wolves - I've had chicken wrapped around my head once, so that the wolf would come right towards me, because I wanted to get his eyes looking at me." - David Yarrow.

site_title: New Pakistan PM pushing for reforms
summary: Pakistan's new Prime Minister Imran Khan is pushing for wide-ranging economic, social, and political reforms, aiming to transform the country into a progressive society. The government has introduced austerity measures and implemented various initiatives, including institutional reforms, e-governance, anti-corruption drives, and poverty alleviation programs. Key reforms include a revised school curriculum, online services, and a liberal visa regime. The government is also working on projects to protect religious and heritage sites, promote tourism, and develop special economic zones. The Green Pakistan project aims to plant 10 billion trees over five years to mitigate climate change.

images.alt_text: Mr Rahman says the scope of the CPEC between China and Pakistan has been extended to agriculture, tourism, health, educational linkages and people to people contacts.

site_title: Bistro food with a star touch
summary: Cheek Bistro, a revamped eatery by chef Rishi Naleendra, has maintained its casual yet upscale comfort food atmosphere despite losing its Michelin star. The new menu offers a curated selection of snacks, sharing plates, and main courses, with dishes such as smoked tomato granita, warm waffles, cured trout, and sticky lamb ribs. Prices can be high, but the quality and flavors of the food are on par with the original Cheek by Jowl. The kitchen team, led by head chef Jay Teo, will continue to run operations while the Naleendras await their new fine-dining space.

images.alt_text: Cheek restaurant's menu is smallish but well-curated, covering snacks to smallish sharing plates to main courses such as a 200gm hunk of Rangers Valley rib eye charred on the outside and fittingly medium-rare on the inside; goat's cheese parfait dessert (above), with just a whisper of funkiness and intense berries; and beautiful warm, crisp-fluffy waffles, that are perfectly baked.

The revamped bistro by chef Rishi Naleendra (above) and his wife Manuela Toniolo is a little more upscale than you expect - although it's designed to be casual, comfort food without the fine touches and tasting menus of before.

site_title: Canada's millennials get government funding to buy homes
summary: Canada's government plans to spend up to C$1.25 billion over three years to provide equity funding for first-time homebuyers, aiming to make housing more affordable for millennials. The "First-Time Home Buyer Incentive" will offer up to 10% funding for new homes and 5% for existing homes, targeting low- to middle-income buyers. The move is expected to boost sales and prices, with estimates suggesting a 2-5% increase in sales and a similar rise in prices by the end of 2020.

images.alt_text: Though prices and sales slumped in most cities in 2018, prices are still up 64 per cent in Vancouver (above) over the past five years, topping C$1 million on average, and up 56 per cent in Toronto over the same period, Canadian Real Estate Association data showed.

site_title: The most important sport you've never heard of
summary: Formula E, a battery-powered racing series, is considered the future of electric vehicles. Jaguar Racing's participation in the series has led to the development of electric car technologies that will be used in production cars. The sport's focus on energy conservation and efficiency has made it a cost-effective way for manufacturers to develop EVs, with Jaguar's return on investment being significantly higher than building World Endurance prototypes. Several major manufacturers, including Audi, BMW, and Porsche, are joining the series, and they plan to electrify their entire model lines, with some aiming for over 30% of total sales to be EVs by 2025.

site_title: Philippine stock soars on Qatari fund's bet
summary: The Philippine stock of Premiere Horizon Alliance Corp has more than tripled this year, driven by a Qatari fund's bet on the company's tourism estate project in Palawan. The fund, Sama Global Investment, is set to lend over US$280 million to Premiere, tripling its capital and market value. The project, which includes hotels, golf courses, and malls, aims to generate US$248 million in revenue. Premiere's CEO, Augusto Serafica Jr, sees the deal as "game-changing" and plans to sell 15% of the company to attract institutional investors.

images.alt_text: Premiere's Palawan plan includes 5 hotels, a golf course and 3 malls. These could generate US$248m in revenue from lot sales and memberships, plus an annual US$86m income from hotels and leasing.

site_title: HRNetGroup to set up Taiwan branch
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED HRNetGroup has incorporated RecruitFirst (Taiwan) Pte Ltd to set up a Taiwan branch offering flexible staffing and human resource outsourcing services. The new subsidiary has an initial share capital of S$700,000 and is expected to be restructured with capital injections from co-owners. The move is part of HRNetGroup's efforts to expand its recruitment services business and is considered ordinary. The deal is not expected to have a material financial impact on the current financial year.

site_title: EU summit readies for Brexit in May - or next week
summary: EU leaders will meet with UK Prime Minister Theresa May to discuss a possible Brexit delay, with a 2-month extension to organize an orderly exit expected. If May fails to win parliamentary backing, Britain could face a potentially disruptive exit from the EU next Friday. EU leaders are divided on the issue, with some preferring a mid-May exit and others considering a longer extension conditional on a positive vote in the House of Commons. The fate of the Brexit deal hangs in the balance, with May opposing further postponement and EU leaders warning of the risks of a no-deal Brexit.

site_title: Value of China's metal e-waste to double to US$24b by 2030 - Greenpeace
summary: China's e-waste value to double to US$24 billion by 2030, according to Greenpeace. The potential value of recyclable metals in discarded mobile phones, laptops, and desktop computers is expected to rise due to increasing consumption levels and a growing need for environmental improvement. The report, conducted with the China Association of Electronics for Technology Development, forecasts the value to be around US$23.96 billion by 2030, up from 66.4 billion yuan in 2018 and 81 billion yuan in 2020.

site_title: Testing Jaguar's I-Pace in the harshest possible way
summary: Jaguar's I-Pace, a high-performance electric vehicle, successfully tested at Sepang International Circuit in Malaysia, a challenging environment due to its size, weight, and high temperatures. Despite these factors, the I-Pace delivered instant torque and impressive handling, thanks to its electric motors and low-mounted battery pack. The vehicle's silence also reduced driver fatigue and made it easier to meet noise regulations. Racing driver Simon Evans praised the I-Pace's performance, saying it's a "ball on the racetrack" and a step forward for sustainable motorsports.

images.alt_text: "When you put down the power, it's really instant, you just feel it go, and that's very good from a performance perspective," says racing driver Simon Evans (above), the older brother of Formula E driver Mitch Evans.

site_title: The next financial crisis may be worse than that of 2008
summary: The next global economic recession is expected to be more severe than the 2008 crisis, with excessively high global debt levels, asset price bubbles, and mispricing of credit market risk. The global debt-to-GDP level has reached 250%, with many borrowers of dubious creditworthiness. The US is particularly vulnerable, with low interest rates and a bloated budget deficit, making it difficult for policymakers to respond effectively. A coordinated global policy response is necessary, but the US administration's "America First" policy may hinder cooperation.

site_title: As G20 chair, Japan is placed to resurrect free trade - but faces challenges
summary: Japan, as the G20 chair, is expected to promote free trade as its top priority, emphasizing the importance of a multilateral rules-based trading order. The country will likely stress that protectionist policies are self-defeating and advocate for global policy coordination to settle structural impediments. This agenda reflects Japan's long-standing commitment to free trade, which has been a regular item on the G20 agenda. However, challenges lie ahead, as Japan faces opposition from countries that prioritize protectionism and bilateral trade deals.

site_title: Pound slides as Britain's MPs dice with deal or no-deal
summary: The UK is in a critical phase of Brexit negotiations, with European Council chief Donald Tusk warning that a no-deal Brexit is a possibility unless Parliament backs a compromise deal. The pound has slid against the US dollar and euro, and the stock market is jittery. Tusk has proposed a proviso that Parliament must back the deal, and the UK government is expected to face a fresh vote on the withdrawal deal early next week. The outcome could lead to customs chaos, business uncertainty, and potential inflationary recession if a deal is not reached.

site_title: BMW X7 review: More than a little Xtra
summary: The BMW X7 is a large, luxurious SUV that rivals the Range Rover and Mercedes-Benz GLS. With its 5,151mm length and 2,000mm width, the X7 offers ample space for passengers and cargo. Its air suspension and electrically manipulated seats provide exceptional ride comfort. The X7's 340 horsepower xDrive40i model is available in Singapore, boasting impressive performance and handling capabilities. As a premium product, the X7 is priced at S$440,000, with potential for higher-end variants like the M50i.

images.alt_text: BMW's X7 feels like it's crawling when it's running. And run, it does. Rear axle steering makes the big BMW surprisingly wieldy.

site_title: KKR eyes Asia real estate market with US$1.5b investment fund
summary: KKR is raising its first Asia-focused real estate fund with a target investment of US$1.5 billion, as it deepens its portfolio in the region. The firm, which has already committed US$250 million, is moving towards first-close in Q2. This investment comes as private equity firms expand beyond traditional model of buying and selling companies, and follows a year in which US$18.6 billion was raised in 26 Asia-focused real estate funds, the highest since 2008.

site_title: Australia's jobless rate falls to near 8-year low
summary: Australia's jobless rate fell to 4.9% in February, the lowest since June 2011, as 4,600 new jobs were created, mostly in part-time work. The country's employment growth rate is 2.3% annually, faster than population growth. The Australian dollar rose 0.6% due to the strong labor market data, which may deter the Reserve Bank of Australia from cutting interest rates. The employment report supports the central bank's expectation of a long-awaited pick-up in wage growth and inflation.

site_title: BOE keeps rates on hold as businesses brace for no-deal Brexit
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) maintained interest rates at 0.75% on Thursday, despite a no-deal Brexit looming, citing that most businesses feel ready for the economic shock. The BOE stated that rates could move in either direction if a no-deal Brexit occurs, as a sharp fall in the pound could generate inflation pressure. A survey of 300 companies showed 80% feel ready for a no-deal Brexit, but still expect output, employment, and investment to be significantly weaker in the next 12 months.

site_title: Pine Capital seeks trading suspension amid allegations of lapses, conflict of interest
summary: Pine Capital Group, a Catalist-listed investment firm, has recommended a trading suspension of its shares due to allegations of potential conflict of interest and lapses in internal control. The allegations stem from its sole operating subsidiary, Advance Capital Partners Asset Management Private Limited (ACPAM), following a notice of termination of the management agreement. The board has appointed an independent reviewer to investigate the allegations and will make further announcements as necessary. The trading suspension comes after the resignation of Pine Capital's interim CEO and executive chairman due to a requisition letter by shareholders.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Key developments include Lazada's efforts to boost seller and brand growth, Tembusu Partners' 1 billion yuan investment in China, and Frasers Property's stake in a PGIM Real Estate Asia Retail Fund. Government agencies' compromised logins were also put up for sale online by hackers. Singapore shares rose 0.2% on the Straits Times Index, while international news includes Vietnam's surprise at US tariff announcement, and China's GDP growth expected to slow. Additionally, Citigroup sets a mid-2026 target for the MSCI global equity index.

site_title: Volkswagen charges ahead with EU battery alliance
summary: Volkswagen is forming an EU battery alliance with Northvolt and other firms to develop batteries for electric cars. The European Battery Union (EBU) aims to cover the entire value chain, from raw materials to recycling. The alliance will apply for funding from the German economy ministry to support research and development. The initiative aims to secure Germany's position in the battery technology market, with the economy minister promising €1 billion in support. Other companies, including BASF, BMW, and Peugeot, have expressed interest in the funding.

site_title: US: Wall St falls at open after Fed's abrupt dovish turn
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Thursday after the Federal Reserve announced it would not raise interest rates this year and expects a slowdown in the economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.22%, the S&P 500 fell 0.16%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.30%. The unexpected dovish turn by the Fed sent Wall Street lower, marking a sudden reversal from previous expectations of rate hikes.

site_title: Asia coffee-sales in Vietnam slow on low prices, supply rises in Indonesia
summary: Vietnam's coffee sales are slowing due to low prices, with farmers selling 60-70% of their 2018-19 crop year beans. Prices have dropped to 31,900-33,300 dong (US$1.38-US$1.44) per kg, making it difficult for farmers to cover production costs. In contrast, Indonesia's supply rose 10-15% from last week, driven by a mini harvest in the southern part of Sumatra, which reached the market earlier than expected.

site_title: Deutsche Bank vows more wealth management hires to reverse flows
summary: Deutsche Bank has vowed to hire more wealth management staff to reverse declining revenue and flows. New European wealth management head Claudio de Sanctis announced the plan, which includes hiring from rival banks such as Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse. The bank has reduced regional managers to six from 14 and aims to boost profitability and asset flows in Europe. Despite the efforts, wealth management revenue at UBS is down 9% this quarter, and Deutsche Bank's clients pulled a net 4.4 billion euros last year. The bank's goal is to become a leading pan-European wealth manager.

site_title: PUB says Salim-Medco should not use it as excuse to pull plug on Hyflux deal
summary: National water agency PUB urged Salim-Medco to not use PUB's actions as an excuse to pull out of its investment agreement with Hyflux. PUB clarified that if Hyflux subsidiary Tuaspring Pte Ltd defaults by April 5, PUB will only take control of the desalination plant, not the power plant, at zero cost to Hyflux. PUB is willing to waive compensation for the desalination plant due to Tuaspring's financial position, which could increase chances of Hyflux's successful restructuring.

site_title: 3 Camsing Healthcare independent directors resign over audit concerns
summary: Three independent directors of Mainboard-listed Camsing Healthcare have resigned due to audit concerns, citing unresolved differences in opinion and matters raised by auditors. The directors, Kenneth Chin, Maurice Tan, and Ong Wei Jin, had all been independent directors since November 2015. Their resignations, effective March 20, come as the auditors have raised questions that need to be addressed to allow the audit to continue. The company's shares closed unchanged at S$1.07 on the day of the announcements.

site_title: Lazada ramps up efforts to boost seller and brand growth
summary: Lazada, an Alibaba-backed e-commerce firm, has launched initiatives to boost seller and brand growth on its 7th anniversary. New solutions include improved business dashboards and live-streams, games, and near-real-time information to direct traffic to sellers' storefronts and enhance decision-making. These efforts aim to accelerate growth and resolve pain points in marketing, branding, and sales for merchants.

site_title: India's economic data under a cloud
summary: India's economic data is shrouded in controversy, with a blackout of key statistics and alleged "political interference" by the government. A group of 108 economists and social scientists has urged the government to restore integrity and access to data, citing the lack of transparency and credibility. The government's economic growth rates have been questioned, with some estimates showing significantly faster growth rates that contradict macro-aggregates. The blackout has worsened India's economic woes, including a 45-year high unemployment rate and declining exports. The professors warn that the damage to India's image and statistical reputation is at stake.

site_title: Tencent profit misses estimates as games slip, costs swell
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd reported a 32% decline in quarterly net income to 14.2 billion yuan due to a gaming slowdown and increased costs. Revenue surpassed estimates at 84.9 billion yuan, but costs surged 43% from a year earlier. Despite a decline in gaming revenue, the company's social media platform WeChat maintained 1.1 billion monthly active users. Tencent plans to invest in core infrastructure and frontier technologies to drive growth, despite a dark period for the company.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended lower Thursday after US President Donald Trump warned tariffs on Chinese imports could remain in place after any agreement is reached, fueling concerns about ongoing trade talks. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.85%, closing at 29,071.56, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.35%. The decline reverses early gains, as investors weigh the impact of Trump's comments on the trade talks.

site_title: Living in Harmony
summary: Two co-living spaces, KēSa House and lyf Funan, are set to open in Singapore. KēSa House, owned by 8M Real Estate, offers flexible-living options with 60 rooms and communal spaces, including a kitchen, lounge, and terrace. lyf Funan, managed by The Ascott Limited, features 279 apartments with communal spaces, including a social kitchen, lounge, and gym. Both spaces cater to young professionals and business travelers, and target the growing demand for co-living options in Singapore. The co-living concept aims to provide a sense of community and belonging for residents.

site_title: Smart Entertainment makes partial offer for Sevak
summary: Smart Entertainment, an IT solutions company, has made a partial offer for Sevak, a Singapore Exchange-listed firm, with a 12.51% stake. The offer, valued at S$4 per share, represents a 25% premium to the closing price. The offer aims to gain majority shareholding for statutory control, allowing for better business control. The offeror and its concert parties currently own 38.49% of Sevak's shares, and the acquisition would increase their stake to 51%. The offer is conditional on approval from 50% of shareholders and valid acceptances of 1.48 million shares.

site_title: Duo nabbed for spy cams live-streaming from S Korean motel rooms
summary: South Korean police arrested two men for using spy cameras in motel rooms to secretly film and live-stream videos of 1,600 guests, earning approximately 7 million won (S$8,358) over three months. The illicit filming has surged with the increasing use of mobile devices, following a scandal involving singer Jung Joon-young who was accused of sharing secretly taken videos. The arrest highlights the growing issue of illegal surveillance in South Korea.

site_title: Rediscovering the Prado
summary: The Prado Museum in Madrid, Spain, is celebrating its 200th anniversary with a yearlong celebration. The museum, founded in 1819, is one of the world's great repositories of Western art, featuring works from the 16th and 17th centuries, including masterpieces by Spanish painters such as Goya, Velázquez, and El Greco. The museum has organized various events, including free admission days and special exhibitions. Visitors can explore the museum's 120 galleries, including the Italian Renaissance and Flemish galleries, featuring works by artists such as Raphael, Titian, and Rubens. The museum's largest masterpiece, its neoclassical building, is being restored and will be unveiled later this year.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall more than expected
summary: US weekly jobless claims fell 9,000 to 221,000 for the week ended March 16, beating economists' expectations. The four-week moving average rose 1,000 to 225,000, indicating still strong labor market conditions despite a slowdown in job growth. The unemployment rate remains 3.8%, and annual wage growth was the strongest since 2009. The Federal Reserve held interest rates steady, citing a strong labor market but slowing economic growth.

site_title: EU leaders close ranks ahead of Xi visit, EU-China summit
summary: EU leaders are set to discuss a more defensive strategy towards China during a summit dinner in Brussels, marking a shift towards a more assertive and competitive mindset. The move comes as the EU weighs its options amid a new US-China rivalry. The EU has been criticized for its lack of reciprocity in allowing Chinese business access, and the summit is seen as a response to this issue. EU diplomats are seeking to find a middle path between economic and security concerns, signaling a potential end to unfettered access for Chinese businesses in Europe.

site_title: Hong Kong property tycoon released from jail and heads home for dim sum
summary: Hong Kong property tycoon Thomas Kwok was released from jail after serving 3 years of a 5-year sentence for conspiring to bribe a former official. He was granted early release for good behavior and plans to rest before possibly returning to work. Kwok, 67, has a net worth of $12.4 billion and has no immediate plans to resume his role at Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd. He expressed a desire to study how to incorporate technology into the business and visit other countries.

site_title: Tembusu Partners to boost China presence with 1b yuan investment funds
summary: Singapore-based Tembusu Partners is launching 1 billion yuan (S$205.6 million) investment funds in China, aiming to boost its presence in the country. The move aligns with China's efforts to liberalize its economy and promote innovation. Tembusu secured a Qualified Foreign Limited Partner (QFLP) status, allowing for streamlined regulatory approvals and taxation. The funds will be invested in tech, infrastructure, healthcare, and tourism projects, with access to deal flow through a strategic partnership with the Guizhou government. This expansion is expected to bridge investment communities between China, South-east Asia, and the global market.

site_title: Singapore shares end 0.2% higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended Thursday 0.2% higher, closing at 3,213.65 points. The gain was attributed to a dovish Federal Reserve's decision not to raise interest rates this year, which led to a softer US dollar and oil prices reaching a five-month high. DBS Group Holdings was the top gainer, rising 0.2% to S$25.39, while OCBC Bank fell 0.8% to S$11.18. Despite global growth concerns, the mixed results reflected the market's resilience.

site_title: Europe: No Fed boost for European stocks as banks fall; chipmakers shine
summary: European stock markets opened lower on Thursday, with the pan-European STOXX 600 index dipping 0.3% due to a decline in bank stocks. Despite the US Federal Reserve abandoning further interest rate hikes, European banks fell 1% amid a shift in expectations. Semiconductor makers, however, rose 2% after Micron Technology's upbeat outlook. London's FTSE 100 index bucked the trend, gaining 0.3%, while sterling rose from Britain's EU deadline uncertainty.

site_title: EU leaders to discuss stronger shield against Chinese influence
summary: EU leaders will discuss a stronger shield against Chinese influence during a summit dinner in Brussels, marking a shift towards a more "assertive and competitive mindset" in EU-China relations. The EU seeks to set deadlines for China to make good on trade and investment pledges, amid concerns over China's slowness to open its economy and unfair trade practices. EU leaders will also consider implementing technical measures to address these issues, despite individual member states' varying views on China.

site_title: Judicial manager appointed for JES International
summary: A judicial manager, Yit Chee Wah of FTI Consulting, has been appointed for JES International, a Chinese shipbuilding and engineering firm, following its application for judicial management in February. The High Court appointed Yit to manage the company's affairs, business, and property. Judicial management is a temporary rescue procedure to help the company survive or realize its assets. Trading in JES's shares has been suspended since March 4, 2015.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end sharply lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares ended sharply lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 20.55 points to 1,663.66. Losers outnumbered gainers 547 to 302, with a total trading volume of 3 billion lots worth RM2.1 billion.

site_title: Hot stock: Chuan Hup shares up 12% following proposed special dividend
summary: Chuan Hup Holdings' shares rose 11.9% to 37.5 cents on Thursday after the company proposed a special dividend of nine Singapore cents per share following its planned disposal of its 76.7% stake in PCI Limited, a printed circuit board assembly and user interface panels producer, to American private equity firm Platinum Equity Advisor for S$1.33 per share.

site_title: Google's new gaming service will let game makers use rival clouds, exec says
summary: Google's Stadia gaming service will allow game makers to use rival clouds, such as Amazon, for certain tools, according to Google executive Phil Harrison. Game publishers must follow content guidelines similar to the ESRB, which exclude adult-only content. The service aims to make high-quality video games accessible in an internet browser, with player settings and data residing on Google servers. Hosting data elsewhere may result in slower loading times or lower streaming quality. Stadia seeks to grow a significant games market and advance computing technology.

site_title: May pleads with EU for time to save her Brexit plan
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is set to plead with EU leaders for a three-month delay in Brexit, aiming to secure a deal that has been twice rejected by her parliament. With the UK's departure from the EU looming in just eight days, May's European colleagues are losing faith in her ability to ratify a withdrawal agreement. EU Council President Donald Tusk has suggested that a short extension may be possible, but conditional on a positive vote in the House of Commons.

site_title: Frasers Property and FCT to raise stakes in PGIM Real Estate Asia Retail Fund
