summary: Frasers Property and its affiliated real estate investment trust FCT are increasing their stakes in the PGIM Real Estate Asia Retail Fund. Frasers Property acquired a 29.99% stake for S$601.5 million, while FCT's stake rose to 18.8% through a S$33.5 million investment. The investments are in line with Frasers Property's strategy to grow recurring income sources, particularly in suburban retail properties in Singapore.

site_title: Asean restaurant associations to share ideas, help members enter regional markets
summary: Restaurant associations from six Asean countries have formed an alliance to share ideas and promote the growth of the food and beverage industry. The alliance, signed at Restaurant Asia 2019, aims to expand offerings into regional markets and promote best practices. The move is expected to benefit over 400 members with 700 brands and 3,600 food outlets. The partnership seeks to capitalize on the region's growing 650 million population, with a focus on achieving larger scale, higher value-add, and greater profitability.

site_title: Getting the best out of digitally-empowered employees
summary: A Manpower Group report reveals that 56% of Singaporean employers struggle to fill open positions, with technical roles being particularly in-demand. Asia Pacific is expected to face a talent deficit of 47 million workers by 2030, with unrealised output valued at $4.2 trillion. To get the best out of digitally empowered employees, businesses must invest in digital change, deliver a technology-powered employee experience, and encourage employee ownership. These efforts can lead to improved productivity, employee satisfaction, and ultimately, business growth.

images.alt_text: Employees, many of whom are used to top-notch technology experiences in their private lives, are disillusioned with the talent management processes that many companies continue to use.

site_title: Modi or Gandhi? Indian mystics split over poll outcome
summary: Indian mystics are split over the outcome of the country's general election, with some predicting a victory for Prime Minister Narendra Modi and others believing opposition leader Rahul Gandhi will win. Clairvoyant Larra Shah and astrologer Raj Kumar Sharma have differing opinions, with Shah attributing Modi's predicted victory to his "extremely powerful aura" and Sharma citing the alignment of planets in favour of Congress. The election, which will see 900 million voters cast ballots in April and May, is expected to be highly contested, with both parties forecasting a reduced majority.

site_title: Yamada Green Resources unit pledges factory, building for credit facility
summary: Yamada Green Resources subsidiary Fujian Wangsheng Industrial Co has pledged its factory and office building in China as security for a 50 million yuan (S$10.1 million) credit facility granted by China Everbright Bank from February 26, 2019, to February 25, 2022. The facility has not been drawn down as of March 21, 2019, and is not expected to impact the group's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the financial year ended June 30, 2019.

site_title: Two Singapore consortia to develop, trial driverless road cleaning vehicles
summary: Singapore's National Environment Agency (NEA) and Ministry of Transport (MOT) have awarded research and development projects to two consortia to develop and trial driverless road cleaning vehicles. The projects, set to begin in 2020, aim to improve productivity, reduce reliance on manpower, and enhance safety in road cleaning operations. The consortia, comprising Nanyang Technological University and ST Engineering Land Systems, will develop and test autonomous environmental service vehicles (AESVs) over 18 months, with trials to begin in 2020.

site_title: Canned air and water-spraying drones: how Asia deals with smog
summary: Asia's air pollution crisis has prompted authorities to deploy water-dispersing drones and outdoor air purifiers to improve air quality. In response, companies are selling products such as canned air, lung-purifying teas, and oxygen cocktails, despite a lack of scientific evidence supporting their effectiveness. The World Health Organisation notes that 92% of the Asia Pacific population is exposed to air pollution posing a significant health risk. Authorities have also resorted to spraying water and cloud seeding, with mixed results, in an attempt to mitigate the effects of haze.

images.alt_text: According to the World Health Organisation, 92 per cent of the population in the Asia Pacific region are exposed to levels of air pollution that pose a significant risk to their health, according to UN Environment.

site_title: Australian jobless rate hits near 8-year low, tempering rate cut bets
summary: Australia's jobless rate fell to 4.9% in February, the lowest since June 2011, as 4,600 net new jobs were created, mainly through part-time work. The data tempered expectations of a Reserve Bank of Australia interest rate cut, with the Australian dollar rising 0.6% to US$0.7155. The country's employment growth rate remains strong at 2.3% per annum, but the participation rate fell to 65.6% due to fewer people seeking work.

images.alt_text: Australia's jobless rate fell to a near eight-year low in February as a bumper run in employment extended, sending the local dollar sharply higher on expectations the country's central bank won't cut interest rates any time soon.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,207.24, down 0.01% on day
summary: Singapore stocks opened weaker on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index slipping 0.01% to 3,207.24 as trading resumed. Despite 523.8 million securities worth S$460.2 million changing hands, the index was influenced by a 7.0% decline in Keppel Infrastructure Trust and a 3.7% increase in Rex International Holding. The market remained positive, with active index stocks like CapitaLand and DBS Group Holdings rising 0.9% and 0.3% respectively.

site_title: Singapore, US to cooperate in promoting infrastructure development in Asia
summary: Singapore and the US have signed an agreement to promote infrastructure development and investment in Asia, complementing the Belt and Road Initiative and a trilateral partnership with Australia and Japan. The partnership aims to attract private investment and provide more options for infrastructure financing in the region, addressing the estimated $210 billion annual infrastructure needs of Southeast Asian countries. Singapore's Infrastructure Asia agency and the US Overseas Private Investment Corporation will work together on information sharing, deal facilitation, and capacity building schemes in sectors such as energy and transportation.

site_title: Asia: Shares up on accommodative Federal Reserve; growth concerns linger
summary: Asia's shares rose 0.5% on Thursday after the US Federal Reserve took a more accommodative stance, but concerns over US-China trade talks and slowing global growth capped gains. Chinese blue chips were flat, while Seoul's Kospi added 1% after regulators announced plans to cut the stock transaction tax. US President Trump warned that Washington may leave tariffs on Chinese goods for a "substantial period" to ensure Beijing's compliance. Despite the Fed's dovish shift, investors remain cautious due to weak earnings outlooks.

site_title: From tree killing beetles to crop disease: Central America's struggles with drought
summary: Central America is struggling with drought, exacerbated by El Nino, which is causing crop failures and water shortages. The southern pine beetle, also known as the gorgojo, is reappearing in large numbers, destroying coniferous trees and threatening agriculture. Honduras, El Salvador, and Guatemala are among the countries affected, with some experiencing water shortages and crop losses. The World Food Program has warned of the potential for widespread famine, and the UN Food and Agriculture Organization has launched a project to promote sustainable farming practices and educate rural populations on drought management.

images.alt_text: An area of woods affected by the southern pine beetle 30 km north of Tegucigalpa, Honduras. The Honduran government Saturday declared the country in emergency due to the destruction of more than 700,000 hectares of pines by a southern pine beetle plague that caused a US$266 million loss so far.

site_title: New Zealand bans sale of assault, semi-automatic rifles
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced an immediate ban on the sale of assault rifles and semi-automatics in response to the Christchurch terror attack that killed 50 people. The ban includes high-capacity magazines and devices similar to bump stocks. A buyback scheme will cost between NZ$100 million and NZ$200 million, with those who keep the guns after an amnesty period facing fines of up to US$4,000 and three years' in jail. Ardern expressed confidence that the vast majority of New Zealanders will support the change.

site_title: Micron sees memory chip recovery coming later in year, shares rise
summary: Micron Technology Inc reported a quarterly profit that beat estimates as cost controls offset falling demand and prices, sending its shares up nearly 5%. The company expects a recovery in the memory chip market to begin in the fourth quarter, despite a global semiconductor industry glut triggered by waning smartphone demand. Micron trimmed its spending plans and idled factory lines to maintain profits and a share buyback plan. The company generated nearly $1 billion in free cash flow and a profit of $1.71 per share, excluding items, for its fiscal second quarter.

images.alt_text: US chipmaker Micron Technology Inc on Wednesday said it sees a recovery in the memory chip market coming and reported a quarterly profit that beat estimates as cost controls helped offset falling demand and prices, sending its shares up nearly 5 per cent.

site_title: Closing time? Japan convenience stores pressed to end 24-7 model amid labour crunch
summary: Japan's 24-hour convenience stores, known as "combini," are struggling to stay open around the clock due to a severe labor shortage. Franchise owners, including 7-Eleven, are under pressure to end the 24-7 model as they face increased costs and difficulties in hiring employees. The industry, valued at $100 billion, is also facing challenges from an aging population, slow economic growth, and new competitors like Amazon Prime. Some owners have begun testing shorter hours, and analysts predict the sector may be saturated, leading to consolidation and innovation.

site_title: A tale of two Delhis: Deadly air exposes rich poor divide
summary: New Delhi's deadly air pollution has exposed a stark divide between the rich and the poor, with the affluent enjoying cleaner air in upscale areas and the poor, like rickshaw driver Ramavtar Singh, forced to breathe toxic smog. Air pollution kills over one million Indians annually, and the city regularly exceeds WHO limits, causing chronic sickness and early death. Experts call for green spaces and air purifiers in public areas, but the poor, who can't afford these luxuries, are left to suffer in a toxic environment.

images.alt_text: For the well-heeled in New Delhi, eating out means enjoying a gourmet spread amid sprawling green spaces but the poor must deal with dust and toxic fumes from vehicles zipping past rickety roadside food stalls in the world's most polluted major city.

site_title: Lippo Karawaci gets pre-funding of US$280m for rights subscription
summary: Lippo Karawaci, an Indonesian real estate developer, received $280 million in advance subscription payments for a $730 million rights issue. The pre-funded amount is non-interest bearing and non-refundable, with shareholders exercising at 235 rupiah per share. The funds will be used to reduce debt and meet near-term financial obligations. The company's CEO, John Riady, said the completion marks an important step in the funding program, strengthening the company's commitment to strategic transformation. The rights issue is subject to shareholder approval and regulatory approvals.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise in early trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose in early trade on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.16% to 29,369.33, driven by dovish comments from the Federal Reserve and a lack of interest rate hikes this year. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, adding 0.11% and 0.07% respectively. The gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a rise in US stocks despite tariff uncertainty and mixed Fed views.

site_title: Australia housing slump isn't worrying mortgage bond buyers
summary: Australia's worst property market slump in a generation has not deterred mortgage bond buyers, with top-performing credit funds adding holdings of senior mortgage-backed securities amid strong employment and low interest rates. Despite a record 0.75% arrears rate, experts believe borrowers can meet debt servicing commitments, and new residential mortgage-backed securities worth A$1.45 billion are expected to price this month. This has led to oversubscription and competitive spreads, indicating demand for these assets remains strong.

images.alt_text: Australia's worst property market slump in a generation has the central bank and government worried.

site_title: Pyongyang sanctions workarounds failing to soften impact
summary: North Korea's efforts to circumvent UN sanctions, including the use of ship-to-ship transfers and vessel identity fraud, have failed to significantly soften the impact of the sanctions. Despite the sophistication of these tactics, the sanctions remain effective, with exports to China plummeting by over 90% and the US maintaining leverage over the North's nuclear program. Analysts say the sanctions are a crucial factor in bringing Kim Jong Un to the negotiating table, and without them, the US would lose leverage, making relief from the restrictions "doomed to fail" for Kim's economic goals.

site_title: UK firms expect to give 2.5% basic pay rise this year: XpertHR
summary: UK firms expect a 2.5% basic pay rise this year, matching the 2018 rate, amidst a strong job market with low unemployment. This follows a 3.5% wage growth at the end of last year, the highest in a decade. Some employers may delay pay rises until after the UK's Brexit plans become clearer.

site_title: GovTech, MOH among govt agencies with compromised logins on sale online
summary: Hackers have sold compromised login credentials from government agencies in Singapore, including the Government Technology Agency (GovTech), Ministry of Education, and Ministry of Health, on the dark web. The credentials, valued at over S$600,000, include 50,000 government email addresses and more than 19,000 payment cards from banks. The breach was not from government systems, but from personal use of government email addresses. Hackers are using the compromised accounts for cybercrime and espionage, with Singapore drawing increasing attention from financially motivated hackers.

site_title: South Korea to cut stock transaction tax this year
summary: South Korea's finance ministry and market regulator plan to cut the tax rate for stock trading this year. The tax rate for major Kospi and junior Kosdaq markets will be reduced by 0.05% to 0.10% and 0.25%, respectively, while the Konex market tax will be cut by 0.2% to 0.1%. The combined tax for Kospi transactions will remain at 0.25%. The move aims to support domestic equity markets and startup firms.

site_title: Xiaomi beats profit view, sees more global expansion
summary: Xiaomi Corp reported a 27% increase in revenue to 44.4 billion yuan in its fourth-quarter, exceeding analyst estimates. The company's net profit more than tripled to 1.85 billion yuan, surpassing the average estimate of 1.7 billion yuan. This marks a stronger-than-expected performance, with Xiaomi expanding its global presence.

site_title: Going 'Under': Europe's first underwater restaurant opens in Norway
summary: Europe's first underwater restaurant, "Under," opened in Norway, attracting over 7,000 customers booked for dining among fish. Designed by Snoehetta, the restaurant features a large concrete tube submerged in the North Sea, with a 40-guest dining area and a gigantic transparent window. A 7-course meal can cost up to $579 per person, with the goal of increasing hotel bookings. The restaurant, located on Norway's southern tip, is the first of its kind in Europe and aims to create a unique underwater dining experience.

images.alt_text: Aerial view shows a restaurant named Under, that is semi-submerged beneath the waters of the North Atlantic in Lindesnes near Kristiansand, some 400 km south west of Oslo.

site_title: Italian driver hijacks, torches school bus carrying dozens of children
summary: Italian police rescued 51 children taken hostage by their school bus driver, Ousseynou Sy, who set the bus on fire in protest of migrant deaths in the Mediterranean. The 30-minute ordeal ended when one child called for help, prompting police to intervene. No one was seriously injured, but the driver suffered burns. Sy, a 47-year-old Italian citizen of Senegalese origin, had planned the hijacking over several days, seeking to draw attention to his anti-migrant views. He had previously been convicted of driving while drunk and sexually assaulting a minor.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.43 points to 1,687.64. The market saw a 116-34 gainers-to-losers ratio. Volume reached 73.91 million lots worth RM19.03 million.

site_title: US dollar trampled as Federal Reserve sparks stampede into bonds
summary: The US dollar experienced significant losses after the Federal Reserve announced it would not raise interest rates in 2019, sparking a stampede into bonds and a decline in benchmark Treasury yields. The dollar fell to 110.47 yen, while the euro reached a seven-week peak, and investors now expect rate cuts later this year, with fund futures implying around 11 basis points of easing by December. This dovish shift in Fed policy has limited dollar upside, with other central banks also adopting accommodative stances, but the dollar may not depreciate significantly due to soft economic growth outlooks elsewhere.

site_title: Devin Nunes sued a parody cow, and it conquered Twitter
summary: Rep. Devin Nunes, R-Calif., sued a parody Twitter account @DevinCow, which was pretending to be an imaginary cow he owned, for $250 million. The parody account gained 466,000 followers in just two days, surpassing Nunes' actual account with 395,000 followers. The rapid growth of the parody account highlights the blurred lines between politics and humor on social media. Nunes' lawsuit was likely an attempt to silence the account, but it instead drew more attention to it.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Japan's financial markets are closed on Thursday due to a public holiday. In contrast, Singapore's stocks continued their 5-day rally, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. US markets also saw gains, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions. Meanwhile, eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in funding, lifting its valuation to over $1 billion.

site_title: South Korean watchdog cuts fine on Qualcomm after decade-old legal battle
summary: South Korea's antitrust regulator reduced a decade-old penalty on US chipmaker Qualcomm Inc to $200 million, a 18% decrease from the original $273 billion won. The fine was imposed in 2009 for abusing its market power in CDMA modem and radio frequency chips used in handsets from Samsung Electronics Co Ltd and LG Electronics Inc. The reduction comes after the Supreme Court overturned a lower court ruling against Qualcomm in January.

site_title: Federal Reserve now expects no US interest rate hikes in 2019
summary: The Federal Reserve announced on March 20, 2019, that it does not expect to raise the benchmark lending rate again in 2019, a surprise move indicating the US economy is slowing. The decision comes after the central bankers previously expected to raise rates three times in 2019. Chairman Jerome Powell stated that the outlook for jobs and inflation may not warrant a change in policy for some time. This shift in outlook is seen as a sign of a weakening economy.

site_title: Brazil central bank holds rates steady despite slowdown
summary: Brazil's central bank held interest rates steady at 6.5% in its first meeting under new chief Roberto Campos Neto, in line with market expectations. Rates have been at a historic low for a year and the bank showed no indication of cutting them soon despite slowing growth. This decision follows President Jair Bolsonaro's pro-business agenda to revive the country's economy, which has been slowing down. The unanimous decision underscores the bank's cautious approach to monetary policy amid economic uncertainty.

site_title: China nears aircraft order from Africa in rare advance overseas
summary: China's Comac nears an order from Africa's Africa World Airlines Ltd, a rare advance overseas for the state-owned company. The airline may agree to buy two Comac ARJ21 regional jets, boosting China-Africa trade relations. This order would be a significant step for Comac, which has mostly sold its planes to domestic buyers. The move is part of China's Belt & Road Initiative, aimed at expanding its influence in Africa.

site_title: Australia shares end flat, mining gains offset weak financials; NZ up
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Thursday, with mining stocks offsetting losses in financials due to the US Federal Reserve's decision to abandon further rate hikes in 2019. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.03% to 6,167.2, despite financial stocks falling 0.3% and US financials experiencing a sharp selloff. Mining stocks, however, jumped 1.3-2.6% on news of iron price increases and oil price gains, with BHP Group and Rio Tinto rising 1.3% and 1.5% respectively.

site_title: Nissan cuts China sales outlook as car market sputters
summary: Nissan Motor Co. is cutting its future target for China car sales by about 8% due to signs of an extended downturn in the world's biggest car market. The revised target for 2022 is 2.39 million vehicles, down from the previous target of 2.59 million. The move is part of a shift by new CEO Hiroto Saikawa to prioritize profitability over growth in sales volume, with no major new Nissan models planned for the China market through 2021. The cut in sales targets comes amid concerns over the impact of trade tensions and declining car sales in China.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Thursday's open; STI up 0.24% to 3,215.29
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.24% to 3,215.29, driven by a 65-40 gain-to-lose ratio of securities traded. Key gainers included Rex International Holding (1.2%) and Thai Beverage Public Co (0.6%). The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: US oil prices rise above US$60/barrel on tightening supply
summary: US crude oil prices rose to a 4-month high above $60 a barrel, driven by a large drop in domestic oil supplies and strong export and refining demand. The US Energy Information Administration reported a 9.6 million-barrel drawdown in crude inventories, the largest since July 2018. Despite gains, concerns over the ongoing US-China trade war and potential economic slowdown capped prices.

site_title: Lazada ramps up efforts to boost seller and brand growth
summary: Lazada has announced a series of products and services to boost seller and brand growth. The firm launched new solutions and an improved business dashboard to help direct traffic to sellers' storefronts and generate near real-time information. LazMall brands and sellers will also participate in curated campaigns and access new tech tools such as in-app live streaming and customizable storefronts. The initiatives were announced in conjunction with Lazada's seventh anniversary celebration and formalized partnerships with 12 global lifestyle, tech, and fashion companies. The goal is to help brands and sellers become more nimble in digitizing their businesses.

site_title: Morgan Stanley takes top spot in ranking of commodities banks
summary: Morgan Stanley topped the ranking of commodities banks, generating the most revenue from commodities in 2018, according to Coalition's data. This marks a significant rise for the bank, which previously tied for first place with JPMorgan in 2017. The top 12 global investment banks' commodities businesses generated $3.6 billion in revenues, a 45% increase from 2017. This increase follows a long period of declining revenues due to stricter regulation and poor sector performance.

site_title: Britain's May says still 'determined' to deliver Brexit
summary: Britain's Prime Minister Theresa May remains "determined" to deliver Brexit, despite a request for a three-month delay to the country's departure from the European Union. May has negotiated a deal that has already been rejected twice by British lawmakers, but plans to put it to another vote. The UK's economy has faced a fresh blow, shrinking for the second month in a row.

site_title: Hong Kong freezes assets linked to stock's mysterious 8,500% rally
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission has ordered brokerages to freeze client assets linked to China Ding Yi Feng Holdings Ltd, a company whose 8,500% stock rally has raised suspicions of market manipulation. The regulator has been investigating suspicious trading since mid-2018, citing an "irrationally high" share price. The company, valued at 95 times net assets, has cooperated with regulators, but the SFC has not named any owners of the frozen assets, which account for 38% of issued shares.

site_title: Trump says Mueller investigation report should be made public
summary: President Donald Trump stated that the Mueller investigation report on his campaign's possible collusion with Russia in the 2016 election should be made public. Trump questioned the grounds for the nearly two-year-old investigation, which also examines whether he criminally obstructed the probe. He suggested that the report, currently classified as confidential, should be revealed to the public, despite concerns over potential confidential data and top-secret information.

site_title: AT&T CEO says China's Huawei hinders carriers from shifting suppliers for 5G
summary: AT&T CEO Randall Stephenson stated that China's Huawei hinders European carriers from shifting suppliers for 5G due to interoperability issues. If a carrier has already deployed Huawei for 4G, they are "stuck" with Huawei for 5G. Stephenson also expressed concern about the US government's explanation of security risks associated with Huawei, suggesting they could do better. Despite US warnings, Huawei denies its technology poses a security risk, and European carriers are considering alternative suppliers, with Chancellor Angela Merkel stating that bidders in Germany's 5G auction will need to meet certain requirements.

site_title: Acting Pentagon chief Shanahan investigated over Boeing bias
summary: Acting US Defense Secretary Patrick Shanahan is being investigated by the Pentagon's inspector general for alleged bias in acquisitions favoring Boeing, his former employer. The investigation was initiated after a government watchdog group cited media reports alleging Shanahan disparaged Lockheed Martin's F-35 fighter in favor of Boeing's F-15X. Shanahan has welcomed the probe and maintains his commitment to upholding ethics rules, but the investigation raises questions about potential conflicts of interest. The investigation's outcome is unclear, with Shanahan's future as acting defense secretary uncertain.

site_title: Tuberculosis can be eradicated by 2045: experts
summary: An international team of experts predicts that tuberculosis can be eradicated by 2045 if it receives proper funding. The disease, which is preventable and treatable if caught early, causes over 1.6 million deaths annually. To achieve this goal, experts emphasize the need for better screening, treatments, and public awareness to reduce the 10 million cases recorded each year. The immense economic and social costs of inaction highlight the urgency of addressing this chronic lung disease.

images.alt_text: The world can eradicate tuberculosis by 2045 if the fight against the killer disease is properly funded, an international team of experts said Wednesday.

site_title: Trump: China tariffs may remain for 'substantial period'
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that US tariffs on Chinese imports may remain in place for a "substantial period" amid ongoing trade talks. Despite recent optimism, American officials are pushing for profound changes to Chinese industrial policy. The tariffs, imposed over $360 billion in goods trade, have weighed on manufacturing sectors in both countries. Talks between the US and China are set to continue in Beijing next week, with Beijing expressing willingness to increase purchases of American commodities, but analysts say they will resist demands that could weaken the communist party's hold on power.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said on Wednesday that US tariffs on Chinese imports could remain in place for a "substantial period," dampening hopes that a new trade agreement would see them lifted soon.

site_title: Pound weakens as May's faces resistance for three-month Brexit extension
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May's request for a three-month Brexit extension faced resistance from the European Union, causing the pound to weaken. Sterling fell to a low of US$1.3147 as investors worried about the EU opposing the extension request. France threatened to reject the request unless May can guarantee her departure plans will pass parliament. The pound remains volatile, with markets pricing out the chances of a no-deal Brexit but uncertain about how and when Britain will leave the EU.

site_title: Singapore hopeful for China-backed Asia trade pact this year
summary: Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing expressed hope that the Asia-wide trade pact, the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), could be sealed by the end of the year. RCEP, backed by China and excluding the US, would be the world's largest trading pact, covering nearly half the world's population. The pact has been delayed due to sticking points over market access and India's resistance to opening its borders to duty-free Chinese goods. A clearer picture is expected to emerge in May after elections in four RCEP member countries.

images.alt_text: On a visit to Washington, Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing said that a clearer picture would emerge on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) in May after elections in four countries that are part of it - India, Australia, Indonesia and Thailand.

site_title: IEV Holdings' former VP files wrongful dismissal claim in Malaysia
summary: A former vice-president of operations and commercial at IEV Holdings, Justin Yong, has filed a wrongful dismissal claim against the company in Malaysia's Department of Industrial Relations. Yong, 46, was served a notice of retrenchment on Dec 21, 2018, and given compensation in lieu of his three-month notice period. A reconciliation talk on Jan 23 did not result in a settlement, and the matter has been referred to the Minister of Human Resources of Malaysia.

site_title: Malaysia's biggest state fund sees strong revival for stocks
summary: Malaysia's largest state fund, Permodalan Nasional Bhd, expects a strong rebound in the Asian laggard's stocks as foreign investors return, drawn by the nation's strong fundamentals. This comes after a significant exodus of overseas investors in 2018, with $2.9 billion pulled from local equities. The country's election victory in May has clouded investors' outlook, but CEO Abdul Rahman Ahmad believes there's potential for "significant upside" when foreigners return.

images.alt_text: The biggest exodus of overseas investors from Malaysian equities since 2015 is spurring bets for a strong rebound in the Asian laggard.

site_title: Pine Labs buys India gift card solutions provider Qwikcilver for US$110m
summary: Pine Labs has acquired Indian gift card solutions provider Qwikcilver for US$110 million. Qwikcilver services nine out of 10 gift cards in India and manages US$1.5 billion in annual gross transactions. The acquisition combines Pine Labs' merchant-focused technology with Qwikcilver's brand-focused software-as-a-service platform, aiming to scale up Pine Labs' gift solutions business. Kumar Sudarsan, co-founder of Qwikcilver, will join Pine Labs' leadership team after the transaction closes.

site_title: Boeing 737 crisis deals blow to Norwegian's low-cost transatlantic routes
summary: Norwegian Air Shuttle, a low-cost carrier, is facing significant financial strain due to the global grounding of the Boeing 737 Max, which has exposed its reliance on the plane. The airline has had to scrap flights and switch to bigger aircraft, increasing costs and reducing competitiveness. The grounding is costing Norwegian around $2.37 million per day, with potential long-term effects on its valuation and competitiveness in the market. The airline has already raised funds through a rights issue and has been slowing its capacity growth.

site_title: Dutch PM to lose Senate majority as populists surge: exit poll
summary: Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte is set to lose his majority in parliament's upper house after an upstart anti-EU party, Forum for Democracy, surged in provincial elections, according to an exit poll. The party, led by Thierry Baudet, is now the second-largest in the senate, potentially forcing Rutte's coalition to rely on other parties to pass laws. The elections come ahead of crucial European elections in May and have been influenced by recent attacks and right-wing rhetoric. Rutte's coalition is expected to lose 7 seats in the senate, down from 38 to 31.

images.alt_text: Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte is set to lose his majority in parliament's upper house after an upstart anti-EU party surged in Wednesday's provincial elections, according to an exit poll.

site_title: Regional hubs - an alternative to city living
summary: Singapore's regional hubs, such as Tampines, Jurong, and Punggol, are expected to gain popularity as the concept of live, work, and play evolves. The idea of regional hubs dates back to 1971, with a strategic land use plan guiding Singapore's real estate development. The growth of regional hubs mirrors that of other gateway cities worldwide, driven by convenient public transport. By 2030, Singapore aims for 85% of public transport journeys to be completed within 60 minutes, supporting the growth of regional hubs. These areas will offer a mix of work, living, and leisure spaces, attracting anchor tenants and a skilled workforce.

site_title: Car COE prices rise on likely quota dip ahead
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices rose in the latest tender, with premiums for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp increasing 1.3% to S$26,659. COE prices for larger vehicles rose 6.6% to S$39,401, and open category COEs increased 9% to S$41,000. Market experts attribute the rise to a anticipated smaller supply of COEs in the upcoming quarter, driven by lower vehicle deregistrations and a higher demand for larger vehicles.

site_title: South Korean oil suppliers settle US bid-rigging charges
summary: South Korean oil suppliers S-Oil Corp and Hyundai Oilbank have agreed to settle US bid-rigging charges, pleading guilty to criminal charges and paying a total of $127 million in fines. The Justice Department alleged the companies participated in a bid-rigging scheme that led to over $100 million in overcharges to the US military. This settlement is part of a US Justice Department crackdown on companies defrauding the US government on military contracts. Seven defendants are also named in the indictment.

site_title: Manhattan Resources: Higher trade, other payables from longer credit terms, accrued expenses
summary: Manhattan Resources reported a S$6.7 million increase in trade and other payables for fiscal year 2018, mainly due to longer trade credit terms and accrued expenses. The company secured "longer trade credit terms with zero finance costs" from suppliers, ranging from 60 to 120 days, to align with its cash management strategy amid economic uncertainties. This was attributed to its subsidiaries obtaining "longer trade credit terms with zero finance costs" from key suppliers in shipping and power segments.

site_title: Europe's first underwater restaurant opens
summary: Europe's first underwater restaurant, Under, opened in Baaly, Norway, on March 20, 2019. Designed by Snoehetta, the restaurant is a large concrete tube submerged in the North Sea, offering a 40-guest dining area with a 7.5-meter transparent window to the ocean. The 18-course meal costs up to 3,700 crowns (S$580) per head, and the goal is to attract 12,000 guests annually, with the hope of half of them staying overnight at the nearby hotel.

site_title: PODCAST: Health Check Season 1: Can coffee or tea increase your risk of cancer?
summary: A podcast series, "Health Check," discusses the potential link between coffee and tea consumption and cancer risk. Dr. Wong Seng Weng, a medical oncologist, answers questions on safe coffee consumption amounts and cooling time to reduce cancer risk, specifically for oesophageal cancer. Experts conclude that moderate coffee consumption, up to 3-4 cups daily, may not significantly increase cancer risk, but hot beverages should be cooled for a certain period to minimize the risk. The podcast aims to provide healthier living tips and debunk myths.

site_title: Strategies to thrive in an uncertain property market
summary: Singapore's property market is expected to stabilize in 2019 amidst the ongoing cooling measures. Developers have taken a cautious approach, launching new projects with a focus on sensitive pricing and creative concepts. Strategies to stand out include curating an optimal unit mix and size, offering unique products such as "co-living" concepts and large-format units. Innovative marketing campaigns, including social media and immersive experiences, can also attract buyers. The market is expected to see over 17,000 new launches, with a take-up rate of around 1.0 times, and price growth of 3% for the full year.

site_title: Colours brighten awareness of Down Syndrome
summary: OCBC volunteers and 25 students from MINDS-Woodlands Garden School celebrated World Down Syndrome Day with colourful activities, including mismatched socks and pinwheel decorations, to raise awareness about the condition. People with Down Syndrome have 23 pairs of chromosomes with an extra copy of chromosome 21, leading to trisomy 21. The event aimed to promote inclusion and everyday activities for individuals with special needs.

site_title: Europe: Stocks break 5-day rally; Bayer, BMW weigh on DAX
summary: European stocks fell 0.9% on Wednesday, snapping a five-session gain, as Bayer's 9% slump and BMW's 4.9% drop weighed on the Stoxx 600 index. The decline was also driven by US President Donald Trump's comments on tariffs, which raised Brexit uncertainty and impacted German stocks. The European Union resisted British Prime Minister Theresa May's plea for a Brexit delay, and the FTSE 100 declined 0.5% amid concerns about UK economic damage.

site_title: Boeing faces growing pressure in Washington over 737 Max crashes
summary: Boeing faces growing pressure in Washington over the 737 Max crashes, with regulators in Europe and Canada seeking to verify the jet's safety before clearing it to fly. Investigations into the Ethiopian and Indonesian crashes suggest an automated system may be involved, and pilots' struggles to override it are being scrutinized. The US Justice Department is investigating the FAA's oversight of Boeing, and the Pentagon is looking into allegations of unethical behavior by a former Boeing executive. Over 350 Max aircraft are grounded worldwide, with deliveries on hold worth over $500 billion.

images.alt_text: The world's biggest planemaker Boeing faced growing obstacles on Wednesday to returning its grounded 737 Max fleet to the skies, while details emerged of an Indonesian crash with potential similarities to the Ethiopian disaster.

site_title: Nissan cuts China sales outlook by 8% as car market sputters
summary: Nissan is cutting its China sales forecast by 8% to 2.39 million vehicles in 2022, signaling an extended downturn in the world's biggest car market. The move follows a weak passenger vehicle sales decline of 6% in 2018 and ongoing trade tensions with the US. Nissan and its joint venture partner Dongfeng Motor Corp will no longer meet their previous target of 2.59 million vehicles, citing a lack of new models. The decision reflects a shift in strategy, prioritizing profitability over growth, as the market faces intense competition and regulatory pressures.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Property, ST Engineering, Cache Logistics Trust, Challenger, BM Mobility
summary: Frasers Property acquired a 29.99% stake in PGIM Real Estate AsiaRetail Fund for S$601.5 million. ST Engineering signed a memorandum of understanding with BYD to develop autonomous bus platforms. The ST Engineering autonomous vehicle kit will be integrated onto BYD buses. Shares of Frasers Property closed up 1.2% and ST Engineering shares closed down 0.79%.

site_title: Thousands of firings expected after Disney closes Fox deal
summary: Disney completed its $71 billion acquisition of 21st Century Fox's entertainment assets, taking over a portfolio including 20th Century Fox, FX, and National Geographic. The deal, which includes 15,400 Fox employees, aims to achieve $2 billion in cost savings, leading to thousands of firings in the film and TV business. The acquisition will allow Disney to expand its streaming services, including ESPN+ and Hulu, and increase its presence in the entertainment industry, but will also result in significant job losses.

site_title: Raffles United gets in-principle SGX nod, major shareholder's undertaking for rights issue
summary: Raffles United Holdings has received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange to list up to 234 million new shares under a one-for-one rights issue, priced at S$0.05 each. The rights issue aims to raise between S$7.6 million and S$11.6 million of net proceeds, mainly to repay bank borrowings and finance working capital. Major shareholder Amanda Marie Teo has given an irrevocable undertaking to fully subscribe for her entitlement of 153.9 million rights shares, which would increase her stake in the company to 79.4%.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 end negative after dovish Fed decision
summary: US stocks ended a volatile session mostly negative on Wednesday after a dovish Federal Reserve signaled no interest rate hikes in 2019. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.6% to 25,745.67, while the S&P 500 fell 0.3% to 2,824.23. Despite the initial rally, investors rethought the Fed's dovish stance, citing concerns about the global economic outlook and the possibility of a US economic slowdown. Large banks suffered losses, while tech companies rose, with Apple and Facebook advancing 0.9% and 2.4% respectively.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Transcorp will hold its delayed annual general meeting on March 22, granted a time extension by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority of Singapore. Cache Logistics Trust plans to acquire a warehouse in Victoria, Australia for A$41.2 million. BM Mobility is in talks to raise US$500,000 in redeemable notes to fund its electric scooter-sharing business. ST Engineering and BYD signed an MOU to develop autonomous bus platforms, part of a consortium to pilot autonomous buses in Singapore.

site_title: Food for thought when it comes to reducing food waste on planes
summary: Sats, a major in-flight catering service provider, has announced plans to reduce food waste on planes by extending the shelf life of cooked meals and using pasteurisation and sterilisation technology. The company aims to produce meals that can last up to 24 months, eliminating the need for refrigeration. Airlines and passengers can also contribute to reducing waste by pre-selecting meals and consuming only what is necessary. This initiative is expected to significantly reduce the estimated 5.7 million tonnes of food waste generated by airlines worldwide in 2017.

site_title: Sydney apartment market poses financial stability risks: RBA
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) warns that Sydney's oversupplied apartment market poses financial stability risks, with a sharp rise in supply potentially exacerbating declines in housing prices. The city added over 80,000 apartments, increasing its housing stock by 5%, and could impact households and developers' finances. The RBA has dropped a tightening bias, keeping interest rates unchanged, as tumbling property prices slow economic growth, and markets expect a possible interest rate cut by year's end.

site_title: Foreign investors net buyers of Asian bonds in Feb
summary: Foreign investors turned net buyers of Asian bonds in February, purchasing a net $1.95 billion worth of bonds. The majority of the funds flowed into Indonesian bonds, while Malaysian bonds saw a $1.12 billion inflow. However, Indian bonds saw significant outflows of $844 million due to rising tensions. Thai and South Korean bonds also faced outflows of $486 million and $171 million, respectively, amid political uncertainty and economic concerns. The flows were largely driven by expectations of monetary policy easing and election outcomes in various countries.

site_title: Will 'Amazon Effect' mean a boost for warehouses?
summary: The "Amazon Effect" on warehouses in Singapore may not be as significant as expected. Total warehouse space in Singapore doubled from 4.9 million sq m in 1998 to 10.7 million sq m in 2018, but most e-commerce players, such as online platforms and logistics providers, require minimal warehouse space. In fact, demand for warehouse space was already expanding from 2014 to 2017, driven by other factors, and fell in 2018. The high correlation between new supply and demand for warehouse space suggests that e-commerce growth does not necessarily lead to increased demand for warehouse space.

site_title: Fund sees opportunity in India's real estate turmoil
summary: Indiabulls Group's real estate fund has shifted its focus to office buildings due to India's residential property market turmoil and cash squeeze faced by developers after a non-bank finance company went bankrupt. The fund is buying pre-leased commercial buildings at a yield of 8.5-9% and plans to hold them for five years. This opportunity arises from sluggish residential sales and developers struggling to repay debts, with the fund seeing returns of 20-22% in hybrid deals previously. The fund's CEO, Ambar Maheshwari, says the market is in favor of commercial deals, offering "fantastic deals" due to the crisis.

site_title: Foreign investors, tourism fuel a Greek revival
summary: Greece is experiencing a housing boom fueled by foreign investors and tourism, with property prices recovering from a 40% plunge. The country's golden visa program, which offers a five-year renewable visa for a minimum €250,000 investment, has attracted thousands of Chinese and other non-European Union investors. As a result, local homeowners are selling to tourists, leading to a shortage of affordable housing for average Greeks. The influx of new residents is also changing neighborhoods, with many families being priced out of working-class areas.

site_title: More room at the inn
summary: Singaporeans are increasingly opting for staycations, with local hotels reporting a surge in bookings. To stay competitive, hotels are undergoing revamps. In other news, a wildlife photographer turned full-time photographer shares his success story, and a feature explores the future of plant-based burgers. The article also touches on upcoming co-living spaces and the rise of superheroes in media.

site_title: Oceanus Group completes purchase of majority stake in video marketing firm AP Media
summary: Oceanus Group has completed the purchase of a 51% stake in video marketing firm AP Media for approximately S$400,000, funded by the group's internal resources. The acquisition aligns with Oceanus Group's business plans to bolster its marketing capabilities. Former AP Media owner Tan Guan Cheong retains 49% of the remaining shares, and the deal does not impact Oceanus Group's net tangible assets or earnings per share. The acquisition is expected to contribute to overall profitability from third-party marketing services.

site_title: Frasers Property cashes out its half share of Melbourne office for A$326.2m
summary: Frasers Property has sold its 50% stake in Melbourne's 2 Southbank Boulevard office tower for A$326.2 million, following its repositioning and recent leasing of 22,000 square meters of space. The sale is part of the company's capital management program. Separately, Frasers Property secured a green club loan for its Singapore retail mall, Northpoint City South Wing, with a five-year term of S$785 million.

site_title: Finding right partners, regulation key concerns of fintech startups
summary: Fintech startups, dubbed "challenger banks," are gaining ground over traditional banks, with some achieving significant investments and expansion plans. However, they face challenges in finding the right partners and navigating complex regulations. Experts warn that traditional banks will struggle to compete if they don't create digital propositions within the next couple of years. Challenger banks, such as Revolut and TransferWise, are racing to go international, but are hindered by regulatory hurdles and the need to secure suitable partnerships.

site_title: Terminated hotel deal a setback for Oxley's deleveraging plans
summary: Oxley Holdings, a Singapore-based property developer, has terminated a deal to sell two Stevens Road hotels worth S$950 million, dealing a setback to its deleveraging plans. The company had aimed to reduce its gearing to 1 time debt-to-equity by the end of the year. The failed deal, which was due to be completed by February 28, has caused Oxley's shares to slide 3% and raised concerns about the company's ability to meet its debt repayment targets, including S$450 million of retail bonds maturing in 2019 and 2020.

site_title: The Fed should buy recession insurance
summary: The US Federal Reserve should consider buying "recession insurance" to mitigate the risk of a global downturn, which has fallen to about one in four. With limited policy room to cut interest rates, the Fed may struggle to stabilize the economy in the event of a recession. The Fed has three options: raising interest rates, cutting rates, or leaving them unchanged with a clear plan to combat a recession. However, the Fed is not taking proactive steps to address this risk, which could lead to bigger problems later.

site_title: Fed expected to hold interest rates steady
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to hold interest rates steady, downgrading its projections for the number of rate hikes for the rest of the year. The Fed will also release details of a plan to end the monthly reduction of its massive balance sheet, which has been shrinking by up to $50 billion since 2017. Investors anticipate a single interest rate hike for the year, down from two, and expect the balance sheet to be reduced further, potentially reaching a size of $3.75 trillion by October.

images.alt_text: The US central bank has signalled a patient approach to increasing borrowing costs, drawing an end to a gradual, three-year cycle of monetary tightening.

site_title: Brexit: May to request short extension
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May will request a short delay to Brexit, seeking EU leaders' approval for a short extension at a Brussels summit on Thursday and Friday. The request comes after her failure to get a deal ratified by parliament, leaving the UK's divorce from the European Union in turmoil. A short delay is seen as a compromise between May's request and opposition from pro-Brexit lawmakers, who fear a longer delay could mean Brexit never happens.

site_title: Choices after an en bloc windfall
summary: Following Singapore's 2016-2018 en bloc windfall, beneficiaries have diverse choices for their proceeds, ranging from trading up or down, investing in another property, the financial market, or stashing cash. Beneficiaries with higher payouts (S$3-5 million) can afford to buy new units in the same location or upgrade to larger homes, while those with lower payouts (below S$2 million) have limited options. The ageing population and cooling measures have influenced decisions, with some opting for resale properties or investing in non-residential properties.

images.alt_text: JadeScape (above), the new 99-year leasehold development on the subject site, sold 1,647 sq ft units at around S$2.8 million after its launch in September 2018.

For beneficiaries, buying back a new replacement home in the same location can be challenging. For example, the typical en bloc proceeds for a 1,668 sq ft unit in Shunfu Ville (above) was about S$1.78 million, while a roughly similar floor area unit in Tresalveo, a relatively newer freehold development nearby would cost about S$2.3 million, based on a transaction in August 2017.

Seniors, who may make up a fair proportion of residents in many en bloc projects, may prefer to save more of their proceeds for retirement. In the case of former HUDC estates such as Florence Regency (above), a good number of beneficiaries chose HDB resale flats, leaving them with a fair amount of cash savings.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Two Singapore-based companies received positive analyst reviews: Dairy Farm International and NetLink NBN Trust. Dairy Farm's supermarket division faces challenges, but long-term investors may accumulate the stock at its low. The company has made significant changes and is working to right-size the business. NetLink NBN Trust's long-term growth opportunities are highlighted due to potential demand for 5G infrastructure and Singtel's non-core asset plans. Analysts see these developments as opportunities to accumulate these shares.

site_title: Finally, a workplace that is all about you
summary: A smart office is being designed to prioritize employees' needs, featuring tailored workspaces, healthier buildings, predictive technologies, and curated experiences. These workplaces aim to boost productivity, mental health, and overall well-being. With the rise of remote work, technology enables employees to choose from various work settings, and smart technologies like artificial intelligence and the Internet of Things learn users' habits to support their needs. Curated experiences, including social and fitness activities, are also being implemented to create an enjoyable work environment, ultimately attracting and retaining top talent.

site_title: Gates joins Bezos in the two-member centibillionaires club
summary: Bill Gates has joined Jeff Bezos in the exclusive club of centibillionaires, with both billionaires surpassing the $100 billion threshold. Gates' fortune has increased to $100 billion, while Bezos' has reached $145.6 billion. This marks a widening wealth gap in the US, where the top individuals are accumulating riches at an accelerated rate. Gates plans to give away at least half of his wealth, while Bezos may face a potential fortune reduction due to his divorce from wife Mackenzie.

images.alt_text: Microsoft Corp co-founder Bill Gates (left) , once the world's richest person, has again eclipsed the US$100 billion threshold, joining Amazon.com Inc's Jeff Bezos in the exclusive club, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

site_title: See your future home in virtual reality
summary: Proptech is transforming the real estate industry in Singapore by enabling more efficient and effective transactions. Online platforms have become the norm for property search, allowing agents to remotely present properties and transaction details to clients. Virtual and augmented reality technologies are also being used to enhance the homebuying process, providing immersive experiences and improving customer engagement. The adoption of proptech has increased transparency and reduced red tape, benefiting consumers and agents alike. As technology continues to evolve, agencies and agents will need to adapt and develop new skills to stay ahead, but the human touch and first-hand insights will remain essential.

site_title: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD
summary: The Cryptic Crossword puzzle, published on March 20, 2019, had its solution revealed. The answers included various terms and phrases, with some related to politics, law, and culture. Notable answers included "Montgomery" (Across 1), "Ides" (Across 6), "Oscar" (Across 10), and "Sardinia" (Across 12). The solution also included words like "Preamble" (Down 9) and "Idealist" (Down 16).

site_title: Towards better urban water management
summary: Urban cities are facing unprecedented growth and water scarcity, with Asia expected to be home to megacities with 10 million inhabitants or more by 2030. The public and private sectors must work together to incorporate green infrastructure, develop green buildings, and leverage digitalization in water processes. A "green-grey" approach combining natural land and human-engineered systems can effectively manage stormwater and reduce pollution. Green buildings can also be designed to reduce water consumption, while digitalization can optimize water management systems, predict changes in demand, and reduce water leakage.

images.alt_text: Singapore's highly developed, engineered water systems have provided a reliable supply of clean water for its residents as well as its industries over the years.

site_title: CLSA's CEO joins chair in resigning as parent CITIC tightens control
summary: CLSA Ltd's CEO, Jonathan Slone, has resigned alongside chairman Tang Zhenyi, who stepped down two weeks prior. The departures are attributed to CITIC Securities Co Ltd's efforts to revamp CLSA's operations. CITIC, CLSA's parent, is tightening its control over the Asia-focused broker, which was acquired in 2013. The resignations may signal a change in strategy at CLSA, which has been expanding its investment banking services to capture market share from global banks. CITIC's new chairman, Zhang Youjun, will oversee CLSA's operations.

site_title: Instagram moves into e-commerce with shopping button
summary: Instagram has introduced a shopping feature, allowing users to purchase products directly from posts by selected brands. The "checkout" button, launched in a beta version in the US, allows shoppers to select options and pay without leaving the app. Brands participating in the feature include Adidas, Burberry, and Warby Parker. The move into e-commerce is seen as a potential lucrative opportunity for the social media platform. However, concerns remain about trusting information to a Facebook-owned service.

site_title: Lendlease mulling retail Reit listing on SGX: report
summary: Lendlease Group, an Australia-listed developer, is reportedly considering listing a real estate investment trust (Reit) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to raise up to US$500 million. The company manages over A$34 billion of funds globally and has significant retail projects in Singapore, including Parkway Parade and Paya Lebar Quarter. A potential deal would add to recent speculation about Reit listings on SGX, following ARA Asset Management's recent rumors of a spin-off.

site_title: Trump picks Delta veteran to head federal aviation agency
summary: President Trump nominated Stephen Dickson, a former Delta Air Lines executive, to head the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) amid scrutiny over the agency's approval of the Boeing 737 Max following two deadly crashes. Dickson, a 27-year Delta veteran, will be nominated for a five-year term. His nomination comes as the FAA faces criticism over its safety certification process and response to the crashes. Dickson's background as a former Air Force officer and F-15 fighter pilot is being highlighted by supporters, who say he is passionate about safety.

site_title: SGReit's new leases bring reassurances, but credit outlook takes a hit
summary: Starhill Global Reit (SGReit) has secured new long-term master leases for two of its Malaysian malls, providing reassurance to equity analysts. However, this development has raised concerns about the trust's creditworthiness, with S&P Global Ratings revising its outlook to "negative" from "stable" due to expected financial leverage to increase. Despite this, DBS Group Research has issued a "buy" call on the trust, citing potential long-term benefits from the leases and asset-enhancement initiatives.

site_title: Executive condominiums still good value
summary: Executive condominiums (ECs) remain a good value in Singapore, despite low supply and increasing prices. Only 5 EC units were unsold at the end of 2018, and the next launch, Sumang Walk, is expected later this year. EC prices have increased due to high demand and limited supply, with some units selling for over S$1,000 psf. Despite restrictions on resale and eligibility criteria, ECs offer a subsidized housing option for eligible buyers, with up to S$30,000 in CPF grants available. ECs are priced at a discount to private condominiums and offer a similar living environment, making them an attractive option for local families.

site_title: Challenger Technologies aims to delist with S$0.56-a-share offer
summary: Challenger Technologies, a Singapore-based electronic retailer, aims to delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) with a cash exit offer price of S$0.56 per share. The offeror, a partnership between the Loo family and Dymon Asia Private Equity, has received undertakings from four Loo family members to vote in favor of the delisting resolution. The exit offer represents a premium of 15.1% over the volume-weighted average price and 110.1% over the firm's net tangible asset value. The proposed delisting is conditional on SGX's approval and a resolution at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Singapore market dips on US, China issues
summary: The Singapore stock market declined by 0.4% to close at 3,207.66, following muted trading ahead of the US Federal Reserve policy decision. Despite 11 out of 30 constituents ending the day in the black, the Straits Times Index (STI) fell as much as 0.7% due to renewed US-China tensions. Investors were on the sidelines, awaiting the Fed's decision, with some expecting a dovish move.

site_title: Ongoing makeover adding value to Beach Road's commercial markets
summary: The Beach Road/Ophir-Rochor Corridor is undergoing a significant makeover, transforming it into a hotspot for work-live-play. Recent projects, including South Beach, DUO, and Guoco Midtown, have increased office stock by 13% and boosted rents by 20-16%. The area is attracting major multinational companies, with occupancy rates exceeding 97%. Upcoming developments, including residential projects and the Kampong Bugis waterfront community, will further enhance the area's vibrancy. Investor demand is rising, with institutional investors seeking assets in the vicinity, driven by its potential for growth and decentralization.

site_title: Will Salim-Medco walk away from Hyflux deal?
summary: Indonesian billionaire Anthoni Salim's Medco team may walk away from a proposed rescue deal for Hyflux, citing unremedied operational and financial defaults. The deal, which would have provided cash to Hyflux to keep its Tuaspring plant running, is now in jeopardy due to PUB's demands. Salim-Medco's short-term plan aims to re-establish Hyflux as a technology leader in water treatment and expand its power business, but analysts question the viability of the plant. Tuaspring's losses persist, and PUB is unwilling to renegotiate its water contract. A bailout is unlikely, and Hyflux's future remains uncertain.

site_title: Japan's regional land prices rise for first time since property bubble burst in 1990s
summary: Japan's regional land prices rose 0.4% for the first time since 1992, according to land ministry data, as the country's economy gradually recovers under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. The average price of land outside Tokyo, Osaka, and Nagoya increased, driven by falling unemployment, higher pay, and demand for hotels and retail space. Overall, Japan's land prices rose 1.2% for a fourth straight year, with gains mostly limited to bigger provincial cities. The easy supply of cheap property loans poses a risk of localised property bubbles.

site_title: Goh Hin Calm gets 3 years for role in trading conspiracy
summary: Former Ipco International interim CEO Goh Hin Calm was sentenced to three years in jail for his role in a penny stock trading conspiracy in 2013. The scheme artificially inflated the share prices of Blumont Group, Asiasons Capital, and LionGold Corp, resulting in a market value loss of S$8 billion. Goh pleaded guilty to abetting and was the first to face sentencing, with the possibility of testifying against co-conspirators Quah Su-Ling and John Soh Chee Wen in their joint trial.

site_title: Vacation nation: Hotel investment in Singapore to get a boost in 2019
summary: Singapore's hotel investment is expected to see a boost in 2019, with a projected US$9.5 billion in transaction volume, a 15% increase from last year. The country's tourism board reported a record 18.5 million tourist arrivals in 2018, with 6% more tourists visiting hotels last year. The opening of Jewel Changi Airport and plans to revamp Orchard Road are expected to attract more visitors. With limited supply and growing demand, investors are looking to capitalize on the improved performance of hotels, particularly mid-market and limited-service hotels.

images.alt_text: Hotel Indigo Singapore Katong (above), which leans heavily into the Peranakan influences of its surrounding neighbourhood, is one example of how hoteliers can go beyond just providing a room for their target travellers.
The reopening of historic Raffles Hotel (above) this year comes amid a rise in luxury travel and growth in the high-end market.

site_title: Tokyo downgrades view of economy as US-China trade war affects exports, output
summary: Japan's government downgraded its assessment of the economy for the first time in three years, citing a US-China trade war's impact on exports and industrial output. The Cabinet Office stated the economy is in gradual recovery, but with signs of weakness. This downgrade follows a global economic slowdown and ongoing trade tensions affecting major economies.

site_title: MAS out to identify cases of tardy corporate disclosure
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has released its first enforcement report, focusing on penalties and censures imposed on financial institutions and individuals for infractions between July 2017 and December 2018. A total of S$16.8 million in financial penalties and settlements were imposed, with 42 institutions and 223 warnings issued. MAS will review corporate disclosure, financial advisers, and brokerages' internal controls to strengthen timely and adequate disclosure. The enforcement department will also use an augmented intelligence tool, Project Apollo, to detect and pursue cases of market manipulation.

site_title: Looking for the pot of gold in Asia's rainbow
summary: Ireland's Minister for Business, Enterprise and Innovation Heather Humphreys, has emphasized the country's opportunity to expand its global exports, particularly to Asia-Pacific markets, as the UK prepares to leave the European Union. Humphreys met with Singaporean Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations S Iswaran to discuss potential collaborations and investments in sectors like healthcare, fintech, and engineering. Ireland aims to grow non-British exports by 50% by next year, with a focus on Singapore and the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Boulevard 88 sells 20 units during previews, mostly four-bedroom units
summary: Boulevard 88, a high-end freehold project in Singapore's prime district 10, has sold 20 of its 25 units during previews, with most sales coming from four-bedroom apartments. The units sold for a total of over S$160 million, averaging S$3,550 per square foot. The development is within walking distance of Orchard MRT Station and the future Orchard Boulevard Station.

site_title: Some local, foreign firms eyeing Malaysia Airlines: Dr M
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced that the country is studying options for buying Malaysia Airlines Bhd, as the airline faces financial troubles. Local and foreign firms have expressed interest in acquiring the national carrier. The government is considering its options, but no decision has been made yet.

site_title: StanChart pumps US$2.5b into consolidated local unit
summary: Standard Chartered Bank is injecting US$2.5 billion in common equity tier 1 (CET1) capital into its locally-incorporated unit as part of a business transfer, increasing the total capital position by approximately three times. The CET1 ratio of the combined entity will remain above 11%, exceeding regulatory requirements. This move aims to strengthen the bank's financial position and position itself for future growth.

site_title: Measures needed to ensure a vibrant equity market
summary: Singapore's equity market faces challenges, with low retail participation and low capital raised through IPOs. The market has seen a decline in listings, with 742 companies listed as of 2019, down from 782 in 2010. A vibrant market is crucial for SMEs to access capital for growth and for the country to maintain its role as a leading financial hub. To address these issues, measures such as deploying pension funds, improving corporate governance, and enhancing equity research are needed. A concerted effort among stakeholders is required to reinstate confidence in the market.

site_title: Exhibition turns up trove of looted Nazi art in Louvre
summary: A new exhibition at the Louvre in Paris has uncovered a trove of looted Nazi art, including works by Eugène Delacroix and Léon Forain, taken from a Jewish family nearly wiped out by the Nazis. The exhibition, about the booming art market in Paris during World War II, highlights the collaborationist French Vichy authorities' role in looting and selling Jewish art. The discovery aims to make amends for the unresolved wrongs of the Nazis and restore the works to their rightful owners.

site_title: MAS scores, sets benchmark for others
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) released its first-ever enforcement report, providing insight into how it polices the financial markets. The report covers the period from July 2017 to December 2018 and outlines statistics on review and investigation times, enforcement outcomes, and ongoing investigations. MAS prioritizes market abuse, financial services misconduct, and money laundering control breaches, and has vowed to continue publishing the report every 18 months. The report aims to improve accountability and trust in Singapore's financial markets, and experts praise the move, calling for greater transparency from other regulatory agencies.

site_title: Freshworks takes on Asean on the back of rapid expansion
summary: Freshworks, a software-as-a-service firm, has launched its first regional hub in Singapore to engage the ASEAN market, with a focus on increasing brand awareness and adoption. The company aims to capitalize on the region's double-digit year-on-year growth. Sidharth Malik, chief revenue officer, sees Singapore as a key office to cover the entire ASEAN market.

site_title: New unisex toilets for transgender fans in Germany
summary: Germany's football association, the DFB, is launching new measures to improve the stadium experience for transgender fans, including unisex toilet facilities. The move follows the introduction of a third official gender category in German law last year. The DFB has partnered with the group Queer Football Fan Clubs to provide a complaint-free experience for all visitors. The measures aim to address the challenges faced by transgender fans when using male or female toilets, which may be misinterpreted by fellow supporters.

site_title: Brazil leader's US visit showcases global rise of populism
summary: Brazil's President Jair Bolsonaro's recent visit to the US, meeting with Donald Trump, highlights the global rise of populism. Academic research suggests 2 billion people are now governed by populist leaders, a two-decade rise that began with the global financial crisis. Populism has spread across the world, with key differences in Europe and South America, and is fueled by economic downturn, austerity, and social media. The rise of populism is unlikely to peak, with long-standing discontent and youth unemployment continuing to drive unrest.

site_title: Mass-personalisation and collaboration leading the way for retailers
summary: Retailers are shifting their focus from selling products to creating personalized experiences and mass-personalization. This includes immersive technologies, co-creation, and collaborative spaces. Retailers like SK-II, Tung Lok, and NomadX are incorporating digital and physical elements to engage shoppers. The survey found 37.8% of retailers prefer creating customized products, and 35.1% prefer in-store cafes and pop-up events. To overcome high rental expenses and attract millennials, retailers are collaborating and creating social destinations, such as ICONSIAM and Jewel Changi Airport, which offer unique experiences and community spaces.

images.alt_text: Jewel Changi Airport, which will be opening this year, is looking to be the talk of the online community. Boasting the world's tallest indoor waterfall of 40 metres - Rain Vortex, Forest Valley, a huge five-storey garden housing Singapore's largest indoor collections of plants, as well as a 14,000 sq m Canopy Park, the developent will be an attraction to behold for both locals and tourists alike.
The newly launched Design Orchard will give brands and products with a Singapore identity a platform to a larger audience and widen the diversity of retail options for shoppers.

NomadX, Singapore's first "phygital" (physical and digital) store at Plaza Singapura offers a glimpse of what is to come, with major retailers, start-ups and online stores offering experiential spot offers.
Leveraging technology, habitat by honestbee offers a multi-sensory experience which also aims to help customers save time with features such as cashless auto-checkout and auto-collection systems.

site_title: Trump calls top aide Kellyanne Conway's spouse 'husband from hell' in Twitter brawl
summary: US President Donald Trump called George Conway, Kellyanne Conway's husband, a "husband from hell" in a Twitter brawl, escalating their feud. Conway, a lawyer, had previously suggested Trump was mentally unfit for office. Trump denied getting Conway a job and accused him of being jealous of his wife's success. Conway dismissed the suggestion of a book or movie deal and stated he's not fearful of his personal safety. The White House declined to comment on the incident.

site_title: Plant-protein startups vie to tap China's hungry market
summary: Plant-protein startups are entering China's booming food market, aiming to tap into the country's growing demand for sustainable and environmentally friendly alternatives to traditional meat. Companies like Impossible Foods, JUST, and Beyond Meat are expanding into China, backed by top billionaires, with products such as pea-stuffed burgers, cell-grown fish, and mung bean faux eggs. The market is predicted to reach US$6.4 billion by 2023, with Asia being the fastest-growing region.

images.alt_text: Impossible Foods, which makes burgers out of soy, has said plant-based meat will eliminate the need for animals in the food chain and make the global food system sustainable.

site_title: Pfizer buys stake in French gene therapy firm Vivet
summary: Pfizer Inc acquired a 15% stake in Vivet Therapeutics, a French gene therapy firm, for approximately US$51 million. The deal grants Pfizer an exclusive option to fully acquire Vivet, which is developing a gene therapy for Wilson disease. This move aims to tap the potential of gene therapies to dramatically improve or even cure diseases. Pfizer has paid up to US$635.8 million in clinical, regulatory milestone payments, and analysts expect gene therapies to charge over US$1 million.

site_title: Dollar rises on trade war angst before Fed meeting
summary: The US dollar rose on Wednesday due to growing trade war tensions between the US and China, attracting safe-haven bids. However, gains were limited as investors await the Federal Reserve's policy meeting later in the day. Volatility in foreign exchange markets has decreased due to a dovish shift by major central banks, including the US Federal Reserve. The dollar's slight increase is a response to the uncertainty and caution expected from the Fed meeting.

site_title: Power shift to Asia offers opportunity and challenge to German companies
summary: The balance of power is shifting towards Asia, with the US no longer the sole dominant force in global trade. Europe is struggling with internal challenges and a lack of a uniform foreign economic policy. This shift has created opportunities for German companies to expand into the Asian market, but also poses challenges such as navigating complex regional dynamics and competing with Asian economies. As the Asian Century begins, companies must adapt to these changes to remain competitive.

site_title: Things to look out for when buying a home
summary: When buying a home, consider the potential for higher returns, but be aware that expensive properties may not guarantee higher returns. Data from the Urban Redevelopment Authority shows that non-landed prices in suburban districts may appreciate more due to improved transportation options. In contrast, developments in the Rest of Central Region and Outside Central Region have recorded higher appreciation due to government initiatives. Buyers should also consider factors like mortgage rates, which have recently increased after five weeks of declines. A thorough analysis of the market and location is essential for making an informed decision.

site_title: Asian business sentiment near 3-year low as trade war drags
summary: Asian business confidence nears a three-year low due to ongoing US-China trade tensions, according to a Thomson Reuters/INSEAD survey. The survey found the Asian Business Sentiment Index remained flat in the first quarter, marking its lowest level since the September quarter of 2018. This decline is attributed to uncertainty and a wait-and-see mode among companies, affecting a global economy already on a downward path.

site_title: Tele-match kickstarts 6th instalment of LEAD
summary: UBS Singapore and CampVision organized a tele-match event for the sixth instalment of the LEAD mentoring programme, promoting trust and team spirit among 150 youths from seven secondary schools.
