The six-month programme focuses on self-leadership, communication, and achieving life goals, with over 1,000 youths having participated since 2014. The event aimed to build adaptability, resilience, and a positive mindset, with UBS staff volunteers playing a vital role in building lasting relationships with the youths. This marks the 150th youths that has been impacted by the LEAD program.

images.alt_text: UBS Singapore volunteers and CampVision participants played games that promoted trust and team spirit.

site_title: Tencent may bid for US$3b Temasek stake in AS Watson
summary: Chinese internet giant Tencent Holdings is considering a bid for a 10% stake in AS Watson Group, a global retailer, worth around US$3 billion. Tencent may team up with investment funds for the offer, which has also drawn interest from Alibaba Group. Temasek Holdings, a Singapore state investment company, is considering selling its 25% stake in AS Watson after receiving preliminary interest. No final decisions have been made, and valuation differences could make reaching a deal difficult. Temasek may still decide to keep the stake.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close down, ending four-day rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed down 0.49% on Wednesday, snapping a four-day winning streak, amid anticipation of the Federal Reserve policy meeting. The Hang Seng Index fell to 29,320.97, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The market downturn comes ahead of the Fed's decision, which may influence investor sentiment.

site_title: Saudis seek US$20b in investments for landmark
summary: Saudi Arabia is seeking up to $20 billion in investments for its planned landmark tourism destination in Al-Ula by 2035. The project aims to diversify the country's economy away from oil, following decades of reclusion. A global investor roadshow will be held before the end of the year.

site_title: China mulls excluding Boeing 737 Max from US trade deal
summary: China is considering excluding Boeing's 737 Max from a potential US trade deal due to safety concerns following the Ethiopian Airlines crash that grounded the aircraft worldwide. The 737 Max was initially featured on a draft list of American products China would buy to reduce its trade surplus with the US. China's decision comes amid growing scrutiny of Boeing's safety record and the need to balance trade agreements with safety concerns.

site_title: US top court undermines Google settlement in internet privacy case
summary: The US Supreme Court has cast doubt on a $8.5 million Google settlement in an internet privacy case, directing a lower court to review the eligibility of plaintiffs who accused Google of wrongdoing. The justices threw out a ruling that upheld the settlement, citing concerns about whether the plaintiffs were harmed by Google and had the necessary legal standing. The court's decision could potentially undermine the settlement and lead to further litigation.

site_title: Singapore's data centre market at a crossroads
summary: Singapore's data centre market has grown to 400 megawatts, making it a hub for local and global players. The growth began in the early 2000s with the construction of telecommunication infrastructure to support the dot.com wave. Singapore's data centre operators favor the city-state due to its high data speeds and sub-sea fibre network, which routes 99% of the world's internet traffic. However, regional rivals are on the rise, posing a challenge to Singapore's dominance in the Asia-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: The merits of Singapore as a data centre hub accounts for major players like Facebook setting up in Singapore, despite the high land costs and lack of hinterland or secondary market.

site_title: The Flintstone House, a home so odd it was declared a public nuisance
summary: The town of Hillsborough, California, has sued the owner of the Flintstone House, a unique property featuring oversized dinosaur statues and a "Yabba Dabba Doo" sign, to force its removal. The town claims the property is a public nuisance, seeking to avoid becoming the next Bedrock. The lawsuit aims to restore the property's original appearance, which is believed to be more in line with the town's aesthetic standards. The outcome of the lawsuit is uncertain, but the town's efforts reflect a desire to maintain a more traditional and subdued appearance in the community.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat as investors await Fed outlook
summary: US stock markets opened flat on Wednesday as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's monetary policy outlook for the year. The S&P 500, Nasdaq, and Dow Jones Industrial Average were little changed, with the S&P 500 opening 1.23 points lower. Investors remain cautious due to ongoing trade worries and uncertainty surrounding the Fed's outlook. Despite this, markets have recently reached fresh records.

site_title: Japanese Olympic Committee was step behind when dealing with Takeda charges
summary: Japanese Olympic Committee President Tsunekazu Takeda has announced his decision to step down at the end of his current term, citing a change in the International Olympic Committee's stance on his alleged misconduct. Takeda's departure comes amid concerns that the issue could tarnish the image of the Olympic Games. He will resign as JOC president in June and as an IOC member, leaving a reorganisation of the JOC to prepare for the 2020 Tokyo Olympics and Paralympics.

site_title: Emerging trends in HDB market
summary: The HDB resale market ended 2018 on a positive note, with 23,099 transactions, the highest in six years. Demand surged due to the Government's efforts to scale down BTO flats, making resale flats more attractive. Displaced en bloc owners also entered the market, seeking larger and more affordable homes. This year may be an inflection point, with emerging trends reshaping buyers' preferences, influencing pricing, and creating new hotspots. The HDB resale price index declined at a slower pace of 0.9% year-on-year in 2018.

images.alt_text: Based on HDB's record of completed residential developments, an estimated 27,000 BTO flats and 3,500 DBSS flats may reach their Minimum Occupation Period (MOP) this year. In Sengkang and Punggol (above) alone, more than 10,000 BTO HDB flats will reach MOP. Both towns are known for their greenery.

site_title: EU Commission resists May's Brexit delay date of June 30
summary: The European Commission opposes extending the UK's EU membership to June 30 as proposed by Prime Minister Theresa May, citing concerns about protecting EU institutions and preventing institutional difficulties. The Commission suggests a short delay from March 29 to May 23 or a longer extension until the end of the year, with Britain required to hold European Parliament elections in May. Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker warned May against requesting a delay beyond May 23 unless the UK participates in the European vote.

site_title: Google fined 1.49b euros in Vestager's last antitrust case
summary: The European Union fined Google 1.49 billion euros for thwarting advertising rivals, the third and final antitrust case by EU chief Margrethe Vestager. Google was ordered to pay a total of 8.2 billion euros in EU antitrust probes, focusing on its AdSense for Search product and exclusivity agreements with websites. The EU criticized Google's control over advertising on websites, allowing it to control how consumers start shopping. Google has made changes to its products but plans further updates to give more visibility to rivals in Europe.

site_title: Househunt March 2019
summary:
