The company will hold a vote on April 5 to decide on restructuring or liquidation.

site_title: Academic behind Cambridge Analytica data mining sues Facebook for defamation
summary: Academic Alexander Kogan, who helped Cambridge Analytica collect private Facebook data, sued the social media giant for defamation. Kogan claims Facebook misrepresented the data's intended use, shifting blame onto him after the scandal. Kogan's lawyer says Facebook knew what the app was doing but needed a scapegoat, and he's not seeking a specific amount of money. Facebook described the lawsuit as "frivolous" and has tightened its privacy protections since the scandal.

site_title: Ex-Volkswagen chief knew of diesel scheme years earlier than he admitted
summary: Volkswagen's former CEO, Martin Winterkorn, allegedly knew of the company's massive emissions fraud in November 2007, nearly seven years before the scheme was made public. The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) filed a lawsuit accusing Volkswagen of defrauding American investors by concealing the risks of the scheme. If proven, this would contradict Winterkorn's previous denials of wrongdoing and could bolster investors' damage claims, potentially leading to billions of dollars in damages. The SEC seeks to bar Winterkorn from serving as an executive director at any publicly listed company in the US and recover "ill-gotten gains" from the scheme.

site_title: Shanghai's Nasdaq-style tech board to take listing applications from Monday
summary: The Shanghai Stock Exchange will start accepting listing applications for its new Science and Technology Innovation board on Monday, aiming for a first batch of listings by mid-June. The board, announced by President Xi Jinping, will use a registration-based listing procedure to reduce regulatory red tape and allow start-ups to list without turning a profit. This move is seen as part of Beijing's efforts to counter US curbs on China's technology investments, drawing interest from investors and technology start-ups.

site_title: Google's AI struggles to keep mosque shooting video off Youtube
summary: Google's AI failed to remove a video of a New Zealand mosque shooting from YouTube despite efforts by the company to remove violent content. The gunman's video was initially taken down by Facebook after it was streamed live, but it was captured and re-posted on YouTube by others. Despite hiring thousands of human moderators and AI, YouTube was unable to remove the video in time, highlighting the challenges internet companies face in controlling online content. Google said it is "working vigilantly" to address the issue.

site_title: China officially bids for 2023 Asian Cup
summary: China has formally submitted a bid to host the 2023 Asian Cup, a move seen as a step towards staging the World Cup in the future. This marks China's second attempt to host the tournament, following its successful 2004 hosting. The bid is significant given President Xi Jinping's stated desire to host a World Cup. China faces stiff competition from South Korea, but the bid aims to promote football's popularization and development in the country.

site_title: Yale University to review coaches' athletic recruits in response to scandal
summary: Yale University has announced it will review proposed rosters of athletic recruits before sending them to the admissions office, following allegations of bribery and falsification in the college admissions process. The review is part of the school's efforts to bolster its policies after a federal investigation revealed that a Yale coach accepted a bribe to admit a student who had not played the sport competitively. Yale's president, Peter Salovey, stated that situations where a recruited athlete fails to make a team will receive close scrutiny, and the school's director of athletics is working with the dean of undergraduate admissions to implement a code of conduct for athletic recruitment.

site_title: 'Ordinary white man'? Picture of New Zealand accused emerges
summary: A 28-year-old Australian man, Brenton Tarrant, carried out a mass shooting in two New Zealand mosques, killing 49 people. Tarrant, who described himself as an "ordinary white man," was influenced by neo-fascist ideology during his travels in Europe and Asia. He posted a hate-filled manifesto online, citing inspiration from right-wing extremists and a desire to combat multiculturalism. Tarrant had no known criminal history and was not on any terrorist watch-list, sparking questions about how he was able to carry out the attack without detection.

The penalty is considered small for Apple, but setting a per-phone royalty rate gives Qualcomm a fresh line of attack in its dispute with the iPhone maker.

site_title: Receding Chilean glacier a sign of accelerating climate change
summary: A Chilean glacier, Grey Glacier in Patagonia, experienced a significant receding of its ice mass over two weeks, with two large icebergs breaking off in quick succession. The glacier lost over half of its mass in just two weeks, with a total loss of 500 meters over the past decade. Scientists attribute the rapid melting to unusually warm summer temperatures and high rainfall, which weakened the glacier's walls and reduced its ability to reflect sunlight, contributing to global warming. This marks a sign of accelerating climate change, with 95% of Chile's 24,100 glaciers having receded.

The figures, set by Berkshire CEO Warren Buffett, indicate the conglomerate's willingness to pay younger leaders in a manner similar to other publicly-traded companies.

site_title: Global gloom forces BOJ to temper its outlook
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) kept interest rates unchanged but tempered its optimism on exports and factory output, citing heightened overseas risks that threaten Japan's fragile economic recovery. The central bank revised down its view on exports and output, citing the impact of the US-China trade war and slowing global growth. The BOJ maintained its pledge to guide short-term interest rates at minus 0.1% and 10-year government bond yields around zero%.

site_title: H&M shares slip after quarterly sales rise fails to allay concerns
summary: H&M's shares dropped 4.6% after the company reported a 4% increase in local-currency sales for the December-February quarter, meeting forecasts but failing to alleviate concerns over margins and inventory. The retailer's profits have shrunk in recent years as footfall slowed at core-brand stores and competition mounted online. H&M is investing in logistics and digital technology to address these issues, but its shares remain at their lowest in two days.

site_title: Boeing upgrades software on crisis-hit 737 MAX after deadly crash
summary: Boeing upgrades its 737 MAX software following the deadly crash of an Ethiopian Airlines flight, killing 157. The company will fine-tune the MCAS system within 10 days, following similar crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia. The cause of the latest crash has yet to be determined, and the aircraft remains grounded worldwide. The upgrades aim to address concerns over the system's role in the previous accidents.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close at five-month high amid trade and Brexit optimism
summary: European stocks closed at a five-month high on Friday, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks and a vote by UK lawmakers to delay Brexit. The pan-European STOXX 600 rose 0.7%, with Paris's CAC 40 up 1% and London's FTSE 100 gaining 0.6%. Heavyweight oil and mining stocks were boosted by higher metals and crude prices. Germany's trade-sensitive DAX also rose 0.85%. The positive momentum continued despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Tennis: Federer and Nadal to clash in Indian Wells semi-final
summary: Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal will face off in the semi-finals of the Indian Wells tournament on Saturday. Federer defeated Hubert Hurkacz 6-4 6-4 in their first career meeting, while Nadal overcame Karen Khachanov 7-6(2) 7-6(2) after a hard-fought win. The match marks a renewal of one of the greatest sporting rivalries.

site_title: US oil retreats from 2019 high on soaring production
summary: US crude oil futures retreated from a 2019 high, settling down 9 cents at $58.52 a barrel, due to robust US production and global economic worries. Brent crude futures also decreased, settling at $67.16 a barrel, below their 2019 peak of $68.14. The decline was partly attributed to concerns over the global economy and President Trump's tariff threats, which have been bearish for oil prices.

site_title: Gold prices seesaw between US equity vigour and Brexit woes
summary: Gold prices experienced choppy trading conditions this week as Brexit woes and US stock market vigour shifted market sentiments. Brexit troubles kept bullion appeal tight, while a three-day winning streak in US stocks imposed bearish pressures on gold. Despite geopolitical risks, investors are pivoting towards positive trading conditions in interest-yielding assets. The US Fed meeting next week is expected to indicate "patience" in monetary policy tightening, supporting safe haven appeal in gold prices.

site_title: US, EU slap new sanctions on Russia over Ukraine
summary: The US, EU, and Canada have imposed new sanctions on Russia in response to its "continued aggression in Ukraine." Six Russian officials, six defense firms, and two energy and construction firms were targeted, including those involved in the seizure of Ukrainian vessels in the Kerch Strait and activities in Russian-annexed Crimea and separatist eastern Ukraine. The US Treasury Secretary stated that the sanctions will not allow Russia's aggression to go unchecked. This move comes as tensions between Russia and Ukraine remain high.

site_title: US requests consultations with South Korea under trade deal
summary: The US has requested consultations with South Korea under their free trade pact due to concerns over procedures in competition hearings held by the Korea Fair Trade Commission. The US Trade Representative stated that some hearings have denied US parties the opportunity to review and rebut evidence, undermining their ability to defend themselves. This issue arises from a 2016 fine of $900 million against US mobile chipmaker Qualcomm Inc, which the company has contested. The consultations aim to resolve these concerns and ensure compliance with the trade agreement.

site_title: Pentagon intel official pleads guilty in Chinese spying case
summary: A former US Defense Intelligence Agency official, Ron Rockwell Hansen, pleaded guilty to attempting to sell classified information to China. Hansen, 58, will be jailed for 15 years after being paid over $800,000 by Chinese intelligence for US secrets. He had regular meetings with Chinese agents, used their cellphones, and retained classified information. This case is part of US intelligence's efforts to counter a Chinese espionage offensive, following recent high-profile arrests of CIA and State Department officials.

site_title: Indonesia

site_title: Russian metals tycoon Deripaska sues US over sanctions
summary: Russian metals tycoon Oleg Deripaska sued the US on March 16, 2019, claiming the US Treasury Department's sanctions against him were arbitrarily applied and violated his right to due process. Deripaska alleges he was unfairly targeted in a "general hysteria" fueled by unfounded allegations and the Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russia's alleged election interference. He seeks to block the sanctions, which were imposed in April 2018.

site_title: Neo Group breaks ground on high-tech HQ and plans to lease space to F&B startups

The facility will consolidate the company's central kitchens, offices, warehouses, and logistics under one roof, resulting in cost savings and increased production levels through automation. The hub will also provide co-working kitchen and office spaces available for lease to F&B startups, and a research and development centre focusing on designing healthy menu items.

site_title: China ready to use more policy tools to boost economy
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang hinted at additional monetary policy measures to boost the economy, which is expected to slow due to softer domestic demand and the trade war with the US. The government has promised billions of dollars in tax cuts and infrastructure spending. To finance these measures, China is willing to cut its own spending, indicating a willingness to "cut its own flesh" to support economic growth. The goal is to maintain GDP growth within the 6-6.5% range.

site_title: Qatar approves foreigner property rule
summary: Qatar's cabinet has approved a proposal to allow foreigners to own property and be granted residency simultaneously. Non-Qataris will be allowed to fully own property in 10 unspecified areas, including residential villas and commercial properties, with contracts that can last up to 99 years. The government aims to attract further investment in its economy, particularly in the faltering property sector, amid its ongoing diplomatic dispute with neighboring countries. A press conference will be held next week to provide further details on the new law.

site_title: US suspends review on Trafigura oil-port project
summary: US maritime officials have suspended their review of Trafigura AG's application for a Gulf Coast deepwater terminal due to a lack of additional information. Trafigura, one of four groups seeking US permits, is seeking to build deepwater oil export facilities to load oil from US shale fields onto supertankers for export to Asia, Latin America, and Europe. The Maritime Administration and US Coast Guard called on Trafigura to provide data on pipeline construction and consultations with historic preservation groups.

site_title: Back the Brexit deal or face long delay, May's deputy warns MPs
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May's deputy, David Lidington, warns lawmakers that if her Brexit divorce deal is not approved, Britain's exit from the European Union could face a long delay. The UK parliament voted to seek a delay to the March 29 exit date, and Lidington says a long extension is likely if the deal is not approved, potentially beyond June 30. EU leaders may consider pressing Britain to delay Brexit by at least a year to find a way out of the domestic maelstrom.

site_title: More trouble at the top for Facebook
summary: Facebook is experiencing more executive departures after CEO Mark Zuckerberg's plan to integrate its services into a single, privacy-focused platform. Chief product officer Chris Cox and WhatsApp head Chris Daniels are leaving due to disagreements over the direction, which executives fear will harm the popularity and growth of individual products. Zuckerberg has asserted control over Instagram, WhatsApp, and Facebook Messenger, causing concerns about losing autonomy and power. The move is part of Facebook's efforts to recover from scandals over data privacy and disinformation, and the company is undergoing a "tricky transition" with mounting frustration among executives.

site_title: Gojek on track to launch integrated suite of benefits for its drivers
summary: Gojek is recruiting drivers for its GoBlazers programme, a test group for new products and services aimed at improving the driver experience. The invite-only group, launched in November 2018, has already appointed 20 drivers and plans to grow to "hundreds" this year. Drivers participate in feedback sessions, share ideas, and test new features, with the goal of creating a comprehensive suite of benefits for all driver-partners. This initiative follows partnerships with companies such as insurance and healthcare providers, and is seen as a response to rival Grab's Better 365 campaign.

site_title: Crackdown on banks gives Hong Kong an IPO edge
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission has imposed penalties on UBS and three other banks for failing to conduct adequate due diligence on initial public offerings (IPOs) between 2009 and 2014, resulting in fines totaling $100 million. The regulator also banned UBS from leading market debuts for a year. The move aims to increase investor protection in Hong Kong, which has become a popular destination for Chinese companies to raise money offshore due to strict capital controls on the mainland. This provides a layer of assurance for investors, making Hong Kong a more attractive option.

site_title: The rise of Silicon Valley's new breed of entrepreneurs
summary: Venture capital firms are preparing to invest in startups created by former employees of companies like Uber, Airbnb, and Lyft, who are set to go public and cash out their shares. Former employees of these companies are already securing investments, with some venture firms hiring them to get a foothold in their networks. This cycle of entrepreneurship is expected to trigger a "massive explosion" in startups, with investors eager to tap into the talent and connections of these former employees.

site_title: Jawala posts flat half-year profits

The company's subsidiary, Jawala Plantation Industries, has had its main bank accounts and trading suspended, with RM16.5 million of cash and bank balances locked up. Despite this, the company expects growth driven by strong demand for certified sustainable timber, with no dividend recommended.

site_title: New data in eternal debate over eggs, heart health
summary: A new study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA) analyzed 30,000 Americans from six separate studies, finding that eating an extra half-egg a day increased the risk of cardiovascular disease (6%) and premature death (8%) over the study period. The study concludes that moderate egg consumption, defined as one egg per day, is unlikely to pose a significant risk to heart health. The findings contradict previous research suggesting that eggs were a major contributor to heart disease, and may help to settle the long-standing debate over the health effects of egg consumption.

site_title: Businessman Henry Wee makes S$0.158 a share cash offer for Fabchem China

The company has grown rapidly, hiring 480 new employees and expanding to 35 states.

site_title: Thailand
summary: The Tourism Authority of Thailand will feature more golf courses, including the Siam Country Club, at the SPH Golf-Takashimaya Golf & Travel Fair. This addition aims to promote Thailand's golf tourism offerings. No further details on the event or the Authority's plans are provided.

site_title: The Accidental Restaurateur
summary: Desmond Lim, 62, chairman of the Les Amis Group, has built a culinary empire in Singapore with 21 restaurant concepts and 29 outlets, as well as 30 joint ventures overseas. Despite being self-taught and not considering himself a professional restaurateur, Lim has navigated the industry's volatility and achieved significant success. He attributes his idealism and pragmatism to the group's longevity. With a turnover of over S$100 million in 2018, Lim plans to expand in Southeast Asia, particularly in Vietnam, where he sees tremendous potential for F&B growth. He is also nurturing the next generation of chefs and plans to open a Peranakan eatery, Indigo Blue Kitchen, to preserve traditional food culture.

site_title: Council for Estate Agencies to get new head on April 24
summary: The Council for Estate Agencies (CEA) in Singapore will have a new executive director, Lim Chee Hwee, who will take over on April 24. Lim, currently senior director of the Municipal Services Office, will succeed Lee Kwong Weng, who will retire after 37 years in the Public Service.

site_title: Citi inks 2-year tie-up with Singapore National Paralympic Council
summary: Citi Singapore has partnered with the Singapore National Paralympic Council for a 2-year tie-up, as part of the bank's global agreement with the International Paralympic Committee to support National Paralympic Committees in 18 countries. The partnership aims to foster a more inclusive society and promote societal change in perceptions around disability. Citi will sponsor NPCs in various markets, including Singapore, Hong Kong, and Indonesia, and will advocate for disability rights through its "Team Citi" initiative.

site_title: Peace Centre/Peace Mansion collective sale tender extended
summary: The collective sale tender for Peace Centre/Peace Mansion in Singapore has been extended to May 3, 2019, due to owners' wait for authorities' approval for a lease top-up and developers' need to evaluate government land sale sites. The reserve price is S$688 million, or about S$1,474 per square foot per plot ratio. This is the fifth attempt at a collective sale by the owners of the District 9 development.

site_title: Man charged with murder over New Zealand mosque attacks: police
summary: New Zealand police have charged one man with murder in connection with the 2019 mosque attacks in Christchurch that killed at least 49 people. The suspect, a 28-year-old male, is set to appear in court.

site_title: Creating an open corporate culture
summary: A company, Cerebos Pacific Ltd, has implemented a unique approach to creating an open and welcoming corporate culture by publishing all wages, bonus payments, and prerequisites in every office building, factory, and warehouse. This transparency sets the tone for the relationship between the company and its employees. The boss's role in shaping the culture is also emphasized, with suggestions for terms and conditions that promote fairness, open communication, and employee engagement, including performance-based bonuses, regular informal chats, and mentoring and coaching programs.

site_title: DBS snags ex-BoS private banker
summary: DBS has hired Lee Woon Shiu, a former Bank of Singapore private banker, as regional head of wealth planning, family office, and insurance solutions at its private bank, effective March 18. Shiu brings over 20 years of experience advising ultra-high net worth families in Asia-Pacific. He will report to Sim S. Lim and aims to strengthen DBS's suite of services and cement its position as a leading wealth manager in the region, amidst intensifying competition in Asia's wealth industry.

images.alt_text: Mr Lee joins DBS from Bank of Singapore, where he most recently headed its wealth planning, trust and insurance business.

site_title: White supremacist, right-wing chatter abuzz before shooting
summary: A white supremacist gunman attacked two New Zealand mosques, killing 49 people and wounding 20, before being arrested. The attacker broadcast live footage of the attack on Facebook, and his online accounts had circulated white supremacist imagery and extreme right-wing messages in the days leading up to the attack. Four people were in custody, with one charged with murder. The attacker's manifesto referenced "white genocide" and was linked to a 74-page document detailing his motivations. The attack was widely condemned, with social media platforms quickly removing the shooter's accounts and content.

site_title: Snoring, sleep apnoea and other sleep disorders
summary: Poor sleep quality can lead to daytime sleepiness, impaired concentration, and mood changes due to snoring, sleep apnea, and other sleep disorders. Snoring is defined as noisy breathing during sleep with no proven health sequelae and can be caused by various factors, including common colds, upper respiratory tract infections, and enlarged tonsils and adenoids. Treatment options include lifestyle modification, medication, and selective surgery, with referral to an ENT surgeon recommended for recalcitrant cases. Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a sleep disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of upper airway collapse, often associated with snoring, and can have serious consequences if left untreated, including hypertension, stroke, and reduced libido.

site_title: Why the defence business makes for a defensive play
summary: Global military spending has more than doubled since the end of the Cold War, reaching $1.7 trillion in 2017, and is expected to double in size by 2030. The defence sector is recession-proof, generating high returns on equity and being efficient in asset use, making companies like Lockheed Martin and Singapore Technologies Engineering attractive investments. Despite economic slowdowns, defence contractors have largely unaffected revenues, with 11 of 18 major defence contractors growing their revenues since 2006. The median return on equity is around 17%, with some companies generating double-digit profits.

site_title: Personal data of over 800,000 Singapore blood donors exposed online
summary: The personal data of over 800,000 Singapore blood donors was exposed online for 9 weeks due to improper handling by a vendor, Secur Solutions Group. The data, including name, NRIC, and blood donation history, was stored in an unsecured database on an internet-facing server. The Health Sciences Authority (HSA) has apologized and is investigating the incident, considering legal options and terminating the vendor's services.

site_title: It's lights up at Sembcorp's Myanmar power plant
summary: Sembcorp Industries has opened its first project in Myanmar, the US$310 million Sembcorp Myingyan Independent Power Plant (IPP), in Mandalay. The facility was completed after winning an international tender in 2017. The power plant features 106 kilowatt peak of solar panels on its roof, making it an unusual feature. Construction was completed last year, marking a significant milestone for the Singapore-based utilities, marine and urban development group.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Industries had bagged the project through an international tender in 2017

site_title: Dark clouds loom for private equity in Asia-Pacific even as deal value hits new high
summary: A Bain & Co report warns of increasing market bifurcation and macroeconomic headwinds in the Asia-Pacific private equity market, despite record-breaking deal and exit values in 2018. The region now represents 26% of the global private equity market, with China and India dominating deal-making. However, the report notes that vulnerable and less differentiated funds could disproportionately bear the brunt of a downturn, driven by factors such as rising interest rates and the growing divide between large and smaller funds.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sheng Siong's same-store sales growth may face downward pressure due to increased supermarket supply, but its target price remains S$1.25. The company's growth is expected to come from its 10 new stores opened last year and continued gross profit margin expansion. Despite potential challenges, analysts predict Sheng Siong will outperform its peers.

site_title: US new home sales fall more than expected in January
summary: US new home sales declined 6.9% in January to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 607,000 units, falling short of economists' expectations. Affordability remains a challenge, with expensive lumber, land, and labor shortages constraining builders. Sales dropped 15.1% in the South and 11.4% in the Northeast, but rose 27.8% in the West. The median new house price fell 3.8% to $317,200, and it would take 6.6 months to clear the existing supply of houses on the market.

site_title: Fatter commissions, Cross Island Line help boost Feb condo sales
summary: Singapore's private home sales rose 4.4% in February to 455 homes sold, driven by higher commissions for property agents and the upcoming Cross Island Line. Average commission rates for new launches were over 3%, with top-selling projects like Affinity at Serangoon and Riverfront Residences offering median prices of S$1,494 and S$1,322 psf respectively. Despite a festive lull and lack of new launches, the sales figure is a 4.6% increase from January, with year-on-year sales up 18.5%.

site_title: Keppel Infra Trust ups equity fundraising to S$500.8m on strong demand
summary: Keppel Infra Trust (KIT) has increased its equity fundraising to S$500.8 million, up from S$450 million, following strong demand from investors. The funds will be raised through a placement and preferential offering, with the bulk going towards repaying a loan facility for the acquisition of Ixom HoldCo. The issue price of S$0.441 represents a 9.8% discount to the volume-weighted average price. The placement units are expected to list on March 25, while the preferential offering will open on March 27.

site_title: Paul Volcker on conflicts, ethics, and the US banking industry
summary: Former Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker expresses concerns about the US banking industry, citing increased complexity and conflicts of interest. He argues that big banks are bound to have conflicting interests, and bankers should be held legally and morally responsible. Volcker suggests that the solution lies in simplifying regulation, rather than adding more complexity, and that banks should prioritize serving customers over maximizing profits. He also emphasizes the importance of fiduciary responsibility and the need for regulators to have authority and support to enforce rules.

images.alt_text: Mr Volcker: "There was concern by the 'old timers' about introducing incentive pay criteria, how that would be the end of 'honest banking'. The amount of pay involved is worrisome, but it also mirrors what is going on outside the banks."

site_title: US manufacturing sinks again in February: Fed
summary: US manufacturing declined sharply for the second consecutive month in February, with across-the-board declines in nearly every product category, according to the Federal Reserve. Total industrial production edged out a 0.1% gain, despite a surge in utilities, while manufacturing fell 0.4% after a 0.5% decline in January. Economists attribute the weakness to the slowdown in China, partly due to the US trade war. The sector's decline is expected to continue this year, with some predicting a recession through mid-year.

site_title: Malaysia investment approvals up with manufacturing boost
summary: Malaysia's investment approvals rose 0.5% to 202 billion ringgit in 2018, driven by a 37% increase in manufacturing sector approvals. China manufacturing investments surged 20 billion ringgit, making it the largest contributor. The growth is attributed to trade tensions between the US and China, which may divert investments away from China to Malaysia. Despite this, the net impact remains uncertain due to global demand weakness and capacity constraints. Domestic investors accounted for 84% of approvals, with real estate, utilities, and financial services attracting significant investments.

site_title: Osim marks 40 years in grand style
summary: Osim International, a lifestyle products group, celebrated its 40th anniversary with a grand gala dinner at Shangri-La Singapore. Founded by Ron Sim, the company has expanded to over 401 outlets in 85 cities across 19 countries. Listed on the Singapore Exchange in 2000 and taken private in 2016, Osim is best known for its massage chairs. The company's anniversary marks a significant milestone in its growth and success.

site_title: Plain lessons from the ordinary hipster
summary: A study on hipsters found that despite trying to be unique, they often end up synchronizing their actions and looking alike. This sparked a debate on the cult of individuality and the importance of constructive dissent. Experts argue that true originality comes not from trying to stand out, but from finding one's own quiet path and being answerable to one's own conscience and purpose. Building experience, credibility, and self-awareness is key to successful disruption, whether in the workplace or social settings, and that individuality can be found in being part of a collective.

site_title: Why creativity thrives when you goof off
summary: A study by psychologist Holly White and a book by MIT professor Alan Lightman suggest that taking downtime, or "wasting time," can boost creativity by triggering "divergent thinking." Divergent thinking, a process measured by tasks like inventing new uses for everyday objects, is more common in people with ADHD, but can also be cultivated in others through play and relaxation. The authors argue that the modern society's emphasis on productivity and work has led to a time-use crisis, stifling creativity and innovation.

site_title: Neo Group breaks ground on new high-tech HQ, to lease space to F&B startups
summary: Neo Group broke ground on a new 10-storey, 300,000 sq ft high-tech headquarters and F&B hub, set to be completed in Q4 2020. The facility will consolidate operations, including central kitchens, offices, and logistics, resulting in significant cost savings and increased production capacity. The new hub will offer co-working kitchen and office spaces for lease, as well as a flexi-rental scheme for F&B startups, with the goal of fostering collaboration and growth.

site_title: Singapore shares end the week marginally higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed flat on Friday, adding 2.26 points or 0.07% to 3,200.18, after the US and China announced progress on trade talks and China's fiscal stimulus. The blue-chip index gained 4.31 points or 0.1% on the week. Thomson Medical Group led the gains, while ThaiBev and Singtel were among the decliners. Market sentiment remains cautious, with Singtel's stock recovering from a Moody's downgrade and a possible S&P rating downgrade.

site_title: Insignia sees Payfazz going places with boots-on-the-ground solution to Indonesia's unbanked
summary: Payfazz, a fintech startup in Indonesia, has leveraged a boots-on-the-ground solution to serve the country's unbanked population. Insignia Ventures Partners led a pre-Series A investment round in 2017, and the company has since grown 45 times in transaction volume, expanding to all 34 provinces. Payfazz's hybrid offline/online model has allowed it to capture a trust-based market, earning 1% of every transaction, with plans to increase monetization. Despite competition from other players with an "agent model," Payfazz targets the large rural unbanked population, offering lower-cost services with a human touch.

site_title: Central banks stuck in holding pattern
summary: Central banks worldwide are unlikely to make significant policy changes as the global economic slowdown and trade tensions persist. The US Federal Reserve may keep interest rates unchanged, while the Bank of England is expected to maintain its current rate due to Brexit uncertainty. The European Central Bank may have missed its chance to raise interest rates, and Asian central banks are also expected to remain on hold, with Norway being the exception, where the central bank is set to raise interest rates.

site_title: DBS hires Bank of Singapore private banker
summary: DBS has hired Lee Woon Shiu, a Bank of Singapore private banker, as the new regional head of wealth planning, family office and insurance solutions, starting March 18. Shiu will drive expansion of DBS's wealth planning and insurance offerings and advise high-net-worth families. He joins from Bank of Singapore, where he led its wealth planning, trust and insurance business for over 20 years, and will report to Sim S. Lim, group head of consumer banking and wealth management. The hire follows a labor shortage in Asia's wealth industry, with experienced money managers commanding pay rises of 30% or more.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Eneco Energy, formerly Ramba Energy, has applied for an extension of time to convene its annual general meeting to May 31 and to lodge its 2018 annual returns by June 30. The company's external auditors require more time to complete the audit due to missing audit work papers for Mandala Energy Lemang. Meanwhile, OKP Holdings has had its pre-trial conference adjourned to April 26 for a work-site collapse case, and Vibrant Group's CFO Simon Sim Geok Beng has resigned, effective March 31.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Friday, with the FTSE 100 index up 0.4% to 7,211.61 points. The eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also gained, with the DAX 30 up 0.2% and the CAC 40 up 0.1%. The rally was attributed to gains in mining and healthcare shares, as investors focus on US-EU trade talks.

images.alt_text: European stock markets climbed at the start of trading on Friday, with London's benchmark FTSE 100 index up 0.4 per cent at 7,211.61 points.

site_title: US: Wall Street edges higher at open on US-China trade hopes
summary: US stocks rose at open on Friday due to optimism in US-China trade talks, despite uncertainty over tariffs. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite opened higher, with gains of 0.04%, 0.08%, and 0.36% respectively. This follows a UK lawmakers' decision to delay a potential EU exit, which also boosted market sentiment. The gains were largely driven by hopes for improved trade relations between the US and China.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 6.02 points to 1,680.54. The market saw 485 gainers versus 406 losers, with a total trading volume of 4.7 billion lots worth RM3.7 billion.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks shrug off North Korea risk; won drops
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index jumped 0.95% to 2,176.11 points, shrugging off North Korea's consideration to suspend nuclear talks with the US. The won dropped to its lowest intraday level since November 2018, but recovered some losses. Shares in defense-related firms surged, while entertainment shares declined due to increased uncertainties. Foreigners sold 114.8 billion won worth of shares, and the won was quoted at 1,136.7 per US dollar in offshore trading.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close higher on weak yen
summary: Tokyo shares rose on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.77% to close at 21,450.85, and the Topix index increasing 0.90% to 1,602.63. The yen's decline encouraged investors to buy on dips after two days of declines.

site_title: South Korea finds African swine fever in sausage brought in by Chinese traveller
summary: South Korea has detected African swine fever in a pack of pork sausage brought in by a Chinese traveller, marking the second time the virus has been found in Chinese foods carried to the country. The disease, incurable in pigs but harmless to people, has been reported in over 100 outbreaks in China and has also been confirmed in Vietnam. South Korea has tightened quarantine operations at airports and ports and asked livestock farmers to avoid countries with swine fever outbreaks, including China. The country's hog farms remain unaffected.

site_title: Jawala H1 net profit flat at RM6.03m amid bank account freeze
summary: Malaysian timber company Jawala reported flat net profit of RM6.03 million for its latest half-year, despite revenue rising 12% to RM24.2 million. The company attributed lower production volume to higher average selling prices and a log shortage. Administrative costs, staff expenses, and higher cost of sales also contributed to the flat earnings. The company's main bank accounts remain suspended due to a probe by the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission, but it expects growth driven by strong demand for certified sustainable timber.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week higher, with the Hang Seng Index up 0.56% to 29,012.26. The Shanghai Composite Index gained 1.04%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 1.43%. The gains followed Donald Trump's optimistic remarks on China-US trade talks. The Shanghai Composite Index added 1.7% for the week, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 2.2%. The positive momentum was driven by investor confidence despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Personal information of over 800,000 blood donors exposed online: HSA
summary: A Health Sciences Authority (HSA) vendor in Singapore accidentally exposed the personal information of over 800,000 blood donors online. The database, containing registration information, was left unsecured and accessible through the internet. The vulnerability was discovered by a cyber security expert on March 12, and access was cut off soon after. The HSA has apologized and assured donors that its centralised blood bank system is not affected. The agency will step up checks on vendors to ensure safe use of blood donor information.

images.alt_text: The personal information of more than 800,000 blood donors in Singapore was accidentally put online by a Health Sciences Authority (HSA) vendor, but access to the database was cut off soon after the discovery.

site_title: Singapore shares end flat on Friday, STI up 0.1% on the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended flat on Friday, closing at 3,200.18 after a 0.07% gain. The blue-chip index rose 4.31 points on the week, with 206 advancers outnumbering 169 decliners. Thomson Medical Group led gains, while ThaiBev and DBS Group Holdings also saw increases. Singtel rallied after a Moody's downgrade, and the Singapore Exchange recovered from a decline.

site_title: German court rejects motions against 5G spectrum auction
summary: A German court has rejected emergency motions against the rules for Germany's upcoming 5G mobile spectrum auction, allowing the auction to proceed as scheduled. The Federal Network Agency (BNetzA) will begin the auction on March 19. This decision clears the way for the allocation of 5G spectrum to telecommunications companies, enabling them to roll out the new mobile network technology.

site_title: One Championship's ready for a new era in Japan
summary: One Championship is set to make its debut in Japan on March 31 with five world champions competing in a single event. The martial arts organization has partnered with major Japanese media companies and has a strong reputation in the country. The event, "A New Era," will take place at the Ryogoku Kokugikan arena in Tokyo, featuring high-profile bouts including Eduard Folayang vs. Shinya Aoki and Angela Lee vs. Xiong Jingnan. One Championship's Japan operations are focused on growing the company's presence in the country, with plans for a second Tokyo show later this year.

site_title: Swedbank may have handled over 95b kronor in suspect flows
summary: Swedbank, Sweden's largest bank, may have handled over 95 billion kronor (S$13.9 billion) in suspicious transactions tied to the Danske Bank money laundering scandal, according to an internal review. This amount is more than double the initial reported amount of 40 billion kronor. The bank conducted a review of transactions between 2007-2015 and reported 80 warning signs daily, resulting in about four notifications to the Estonian finance police. Swedbank's CEO said the bank takes money laundering seriously and acted on signals, but not all transactions were suspicious in nature.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore private home sales increased 18.5% in February, with 455 units sold. Keppel Infra Trust raised S$500.8 million through equity fundraising to repay a loan facility. Neo Group broke ground on a new high-tech headquarters. Lippo Karawaci's credit rating was upgraded, and Insignia Ventures Partners discussed Indonesia's unbanked population. The STI closed flat, up 0.1% on the week, at 3,200.18.

site_title: Macau extends casino licences for MGM China, SJM until 2022
summary: Macau's government has extended casino concession licences for MGM China and SJM Holdings until 2022, aligning with the expiry dates of other four casino operators. Both companies must pay 200 million patacas (S$33.5 million) each for the extension. Shares of MGM China and SJM were suspended on Friday. The move aims to maintain stability in the world's largest gambling hub.

site_title: Peace Centre/Peace Mansion collective sale tender extended
summary: The collective sale tender for Peace Centre/Peace Mansion in Singapore has been extended to May 3, 2019, by three weeks due to delays in obtaining approval from authorities for a lease top-up. The tender was initially set to close on April 11. The owners are awaiting an in-principle approval for the lease top-up, which is expected to be granted soon, but the schedule has fallen behind expectations. The extension gives developers more time to evaluate government land sale sites currently available in the market.

site_title: China will not let economic growth slip out of reasonable range: Premier Li Keqiang
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang stated that the country will maintain a reasonable range for economic growth, despite facing downward pressure. China's 2018 economic growth of 6.6% was hard-won, and the government is targeting a GDP growth range of 6-6.5% for 2019.

site_title: New private home sales up 18.5% y-o-y in February
summary: Singapore's private home sales rose 18.5% year-over-year in February, with 455 units sold, up from 384 units in the same period last year. This represents a 4.4% increase from January sales. The surge in sales is attributed to factors such as the recent Cross-Island MRT Line announcement and developers offering incentives to boost sales. Notable projects with higher sales include Affinity at Serangoon, Riverfront Residences, and The Tre Ver, which are expected to be closely watched for their sales performance.

site_title: Indonesia to speed up release of Lion Air crash report: safety agency head
summary: Indonesia plans to speed up the release of its report on the Lion Air crash, which killed 189 people, to between July and August. The report was initially expected to be released in 2019. The investigation's head, Soerjanto, stated that the report will be released months earlier than the original timeline. The crash was the world's first of Boeing's 737 Max jet, following a similar incident with an Ethiopian Airlines plane that killed 157 people on board.

site_title: Businessman makes conditional cash offer for Fabchem China
summary: Singaporean businessman Henry Wee has launched a conditional cash offer for shares of explosives maker Fabchem China at S$0.158 apiece, representing a 6.76% premium over the VWAP of Fabchem shares over the last 12 months. The offer is conditional upon the Wees controlling more than 50% of Fabchem China and will remain open for acceptances for at least 28 days. The Wees, through their company Triple Vision, now hold 39.55% of Fabchem, surpassing the 50% threshold required to trigger a mandatory general offer.

site_title: Van Gogh's perennial appeal
summary: Vincent van Gogh's enduring appeal is attributed to his visceral, vibrant paintings and a human interest story of a difficult life that led to his death at 37. At least nine exhibitions on the Dutch artist are scheduled at museums worldwide, including three opening this month in Houston, London, and Amsterdam. The exhibitions, which include loaned works from institutions such as the National Gallery and the Van Gogh Museum, showcase van Gogh's early influence on British art and his later importance on 20th-century painters. The exhibitions highlight van Gogh's prolific correspondence, his artistic evolution, and his continued relevance to artists today.

site_title: The Straits Times partners SGX in new educational series for retail investors
summary: The Straits Times has partnered with Singapore Exchange (SGX) to launch the ST-SGX Research Leaders' Insights Series, a new educational series for retail investors. The series, led by The Straits Times' Invest editor Lorna Tan, will provide insights and analysis of 10 equity research leaders, guiding investors on how to effectively use research-based content for investment decisions. The series will be published in The Sunday Times every month, starting from April, and will also feature seminars and webinars conducted by SGX Academy. The goal is to empower more investors to make informed investment decisions.

site_title: Kim Jong Un rethinks US nuclear talks, pause in missile tests
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is reevaluating US nuclear talks, with Vice Foreign Minister Choe Son Hui stating that the US's "gangster-like" demands led to the breakdown in talks. Kim may decide to halt nuclear disarmament talks, citing a need to protect the situation from US pressure. The US hopes to continue negotiations, with Secretary of State Michael Pompeo saying the administration desires ongoing conversations. The stalemate in talks follows a failed summit in Hanoi, with each side blaming the other for the collapse.

site_title: Many dead in New Zealand shooting at two mosques
summary: Multiple fatalities were reported at two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, when at least one gunman opened fire on worshippers on Friday. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern described the incident as "one of New Zealand's darkest days" and an "extraordinary and unprecedented act of violence." Multiple people were killed, with the Bangladesh cricket team arriving for prayers at one of the mosques but all members were safe. One person is in custody, and police are investigating the incident, which has prompted a lockdown in the city.

site_title: Millions hit in Manila's 'worst' water shortage
summary: Manila, the Philippine capital, is experiencing its worst water shortage in years, affecting around 6 million people. Rolling outages have left taps dry for 4-20 hours per day, with some areas completely cut off. The shortage is due to a lack of rain and inadequate infrastructure. Hospitals have started using supplemental water from tankers, while residents are forced to wait hours for deliveries. The disruption is expected to last until July, when monsoon rains replenish regional reservoirs. The government has acknowledged the problem and is calling for an alternative water source.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,207.69, up 0.31% on day
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.31% to 3,207.69 on Friday, driven by a 158-142 gain/loss ratio. The Straits Times Index saw 565 million securities worth S$432.5 million trade. Gainers included Rex International, while Keppel Infrastructure Trust declined. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data and despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Indonesia posts surprise trade surplus in February as imports slump
summary: Indonesia posted a trade surplus of $329.5 million in February, the first in five months, due to a sharp decline in imports. Exports fell 11.33% to $12.53 billion, while imports plummeted 13.98% to $12.20 billion. The trade surplus was better than expected, alleviating pressure on the government to reduce its record-high trade deficit of $8.5 billion last year. The surprise surplus is seen as a positive sign for the Indonesian economy.

site_title: Australian shares weaker as Sino-US trade woes hit miners; NZ up
summary: Australian shares declined 0.1% to 6,175.20, snapping a three-week winning streak, due to concerns over a US-China trade deal and its impact on mining stocks. The decline was led by mining stocks, which lost 1.3% as Shanghai nickel fell 2%. The financial sector also fell, with Australia and New Zealand Banking Group down 1%, while gold stocks rose 2.2% for the week. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.4% for the sixth straight week.

site_title: Asia coffee: Vietnam prices fall as drought continues; supplies build up in Indonesia
summary: Vietnam's coffee prices fell amid a drought affecting 300 hectares of crops in the Central Highlands, with farmers selling at 31,900-33,700 dong (S$1.86-$1.96) per kg. The situation is forecast to worsen in March and April. In Indonesia, supplies are building up despite muted demand, while traders are making losses on fixed contracts due to falling prices. The May robusta coffee price settled down US$28, or 1.8%, at US$1,490 per tonne.

site_title: Mosque shooting erodes New Zealand reputation for safety, tolerance
summary: A mass shooting at two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, during Friday prayers has killed 49 people and wounded over 20, marking one of the country's darkest days. The attack, described as a terrorist attack, was carried out by a gunman who posted live footage and a manifesto online, targeting migrants and refugees. New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern condemned the attack, stating that the country values diversity and kindness, and that the attack would not shake these values. The attack has eroded New Zealand's reputation for safety and tolerance, with many residents expressing shock and sympathy for the victims.

images.alt_text: Mosque shooting erodes New Zealand reputation for safety, tolerance.

site_title: Malaysia plants hope for palm oil's future in dwarf trees
summary: Malaysia is launching a breeding program to produce dwarf palm oil trees, aiming to improve yields, maximize land use, and reduce environmental damage. The trees, about 30% smaller than regular ones, are easier to harvest and can produce twice the current yield per hectare. However, the high cost of the newly created trees may deter many farmers, and the government has ruled out assistance. Environmental groups praise the initiative but emphasize the need for reforestation efforts to restore areas cleared for plantations.

images.alt_text: Test tubes holding plants line shelves in a Malaysian laboratory, the heart of a breeding programme for dwarf palm oil trees which scientists hope will cut costs and limit the environmental damage caused by the controversial industry.

site_title: Forty killed, more than 20 injured in NZ mosque shootings: PM
summary: Forty people were killed and over 20 injured in mass shootings at two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, on Friday. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern described the attack as "an extraordinary and unprecedented act of violence." Four people in police custody are believed to hold extremist views, but were not on police watchlists. The gunman was identified as a white, blond man wearing a helmet and bulletproof vest, who livestreamed the attack on social media. New Zealand's security threat level has been raised, and the country's foreign minister condemned the attack.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines reviewing order for 25 Boeing 737 Max aircraft
summary: Malaysia Airlines is reviewing its order for 25 Boeing 737 Max aircraft following recent crashes involving the model. The airline, which had planned to receive the jets starting in 2020, is conducting a "process of due diligence" to assess the aircraft's future operations. The move comes amid concerns over the safety of the 737 Max after two fatal crashes in 2018 and 2019. The airline's review is a response to the incidents, which have raised questions about the aircraft's reliability and the airline's decision to order the planes.

images.alt_text: Malaysia Airlines is reviewing its order for 25 Boeing 737 MAX aircraft after recent crashes involving the model, the airline said on Friday.

site_title: Hot stock: Oxley up 3% after S$1.03b offer for Chevron House
summary: Oxley Holdings shares rose 3% after resuming trading following a trading halt, driven by a potential S$1.025 billion sale of Chevron House, an office building acquired for S$660 million in 2017. US-based real estate fund AEW is believed to be the buyer. The counter traded at 34 Singapore cents apiece, with 16.5 million shares exchanged.

site_title: Airbus trials drone delivery to ships anchored off Singapore
summary: Airbus has successfully completed the world's first shore-to-ship package delivery using a drone in Singapore. The drone, which can carry up to 4kg of cargo, delivered a 1.5kg parcel to a vessel anchored 1.5km from the coast in 10 minutes. The trial, conducted with maritime logistics firm Wilhelmsen Ships Services, aims to reduce delivery times, costs, and carbon footprint. The use of drones can make deliveries up to six times faster and lower costs by up to 90 percent, making it a safer alternative to small boats.

site_title: Singapore Sling refreshed: Shaking up an old cocktail for a new generation
summary: The Singapore Sling, a classic cocktail, has been revamped by the Raffles Hotel in Singapore to appeal to a younger generation. The updated drink retains its original recipe but uses superior ingredients, reducing sweetness and balancing flavors. The Long Bar, where the drink was first created in 1915, has reopened after renovations and the new version aims to extend its appeal beyond tourists to locals and expats. The hotel's general manager hopes the updated drink will attract a new following, but it remains to be seen if the revamp will successfully capture the attention of a younger crowd.

site_title: Lippo Karawaci: S&P places CCC+ rating on review with 'positive implications'; Moody's affirms B3 rating
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) has placed PT Lippo Karawaci's CCC+ long-term issuer credit rating on review with "positive implications" due to the company's proposed US$730 million rights issue, which would significantly improve liquidity and reduce debt. The rating firm expects the move to help cover rental and interest expenses until December 2020. Moody's has reaffirmed Lippo Karawaci's B3 rating, indicating the company's creditworthiness.

site_title: Japan to prod regional banks to boost profitability with new rules
summary: Japan's Financial Services Agency will conduct stress tests on 105 regional banks by mid-year to identify those at risk of failing to meet minimum capital adequacy ratios. The agency will review rules to focus on future business outlook and resilience to low interest rates and an aging population. Regional banks face diminishing returns from traditional lending due to ultra-low interest rates. The FSA plans to issue business improvement orders to banks that fail to boost profitability, and new guidelines will be developed by June. This move aims to prod regional banks to increase profitability and mitigate potential failures.

site_title: NZ police order lockdown in Christchurch amid mosque shooting reports
summary: Armed police in New Zealand swarmed central Christchurch amid a shooting at a mosque in the South Island city on March 15, 2019. A serious and evolving situation was reported, with an active shooter.

site_title: China's hog troubles are a boon for American pork producers
summary: China, the world's largest pork consumer, made its largest purchase of US pork in nearly two years due to African swine fever reducing hog herds and driving up prices. The 23,800 metric ton purchase, the third largest in data going back to 2013, boosted US pork prices, with lean hog futures surging 3.4% to 83.6 US cents a pound. Analysts predict China's active importing of US pork will drive global pork prices higher.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks started slightly higher on Friday, edging up 0.05% to 28,866.94, following a volatile week. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.34% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.60%. Investors monitored China-US trade talks, while the US stock market reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: BMW is weeding out its lineup to prepare for the electric future
summary: BMW is cutting its model lineup to reduce costs amid a cooling global economy and trade tensions. The company will eliminate the 3-Series Gran Turismo and other derivative versions, while also streamlining its operations to reduce complexity. BMW's earnings have been pressured by tariffs on US-made cars sold to China and price competition in Europe. The company's return on sales in its core automotive division dropped to 7.2% from 9.2% in 2017. BMW's shares rose 1.3% after the announcement, trimming losses over the past year.

site_title: Eneco Energy seeks to postpone AGM
summary: Eneco Energy, formerly Ramba Energy, has applied to postpone its annual general meeting for the 2018 business year to May 31 and its annual returns to June 30 due to its external auditors, Ernst & Young Indonesia, requiring more time to complete the audit for the 2018 financial results. The delay is caused by issues with obtaining audit work papers from Deloitte Indonesia, the auditors of Mandala Energy Lemang, a company with which Eneco Energy has a 16% participating interest.

site_title: SEC sues Volkswagen, Winterkorn over 'Dieselgate'
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) sued Volkswagen AG and former CEO Martin Winterkorn over the "Dieselgate" scandal, accusing the company of perpetrating a "massive fraud" on US investors. The suit seeks to bar Winterkorn from serving as a public company officer and recover "ill-gotten gains." Volkswagen plans to contest the complaint, stating it is "legally and factually flawed."

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher with eyes on BoJ meeting
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.62% to 21,418.00, driven by a cheaper yen. Investors await the Bank of Japan's policy board decision, which could impact the market. The broader Topix index also gained 0.55%.

site_title: South Korean prosecutors raid exchange in Samsung BioLogics probe
summary: South Korean prosecutors raided Korea Exchange as part of an investigation into Samsung BioLogics' suspected accounting rule violations. The biotech arm of Samsung Group allegedly breached accounting rules ahead of its 2016 listing, leading to a criminal probe. This raid follows a December raid on Samsung BioLogics' head office. The Korea Exchange confirmed the raid but declined to provide further comments.

site_title: Huawei CFO wanted to quit job just before arrest, says founder
summary: Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou had been seeking a new job before her arrest in Canada last December, according to the company's founder Ren Zhengfei. Meng, Meng Wanzhou's father, stated that the two had become closer since her detention. The US seeks her extradition on charges of bank and wire fraud in violation of American sanctions against Iran, which Meng denies.

site_title: Australia's NAB to expand threshold for small business protections
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) plans to expand its definition of small businesses to those with aggregate borrowings of less than A$5 million, up from A$3 million. This move follows a government-mandated inquiry's recommendation to broaden the definition to more borrowers. NAB has completed or is implementing 26 of the inquiry's 76 recommendations.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 0.09 points lower at 1,674.43 on Friday, with a trading volume of 158.68 million lots worth RM38.89 million. The market saw a slight imbalance in favor of gainers, with 130 gainers compared to 59 losers.

site_title: Singapore's Nutrition Innovation raises US$5m to make 'healthier' sugar
summary: Singapore-based startup Nutrition Innovation has raised US$5 million in a Series A round of funding to produce "healthier" sugar. The company's proprietary technology enables industrial-scale production of low glycemic, natural cane sugar (Nucane), a replacement for refined sugar. This investment, led by VisVires New Protein, aims to overhaul the global sugar market with a healthier product, addressing the challenges faced by food manufacturers in replacing refined sugar with alternative sweeteners.

site_title: UK's May wins Parliament's backing for plan to delay Brexit
summary: Theresa May wins Parliament's backing to delay Brexit, with 412 to 202 votes in favor of her motion, allowing her to seek a delay to the March 29 deadline. The UK is tied in political knots over how to leave the EU, with the looming threat of economic chaos if an agreement is not reached.

site_title: US envoy to North Korea urges security council unity on sanctions
summary: US envoy to North Korea, Stephen Biegun, urged UN Security Council unity in maintaining and fully implementing sanctions on Kim Jong Un's government, citing the need to prevent easing of sanctions that could jeopardize the nuclear disarmament talks. The US and China differ on sanctions, with China calling for easing measures. Biegun's remarks came after failed talks between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim in Hanoi last month.

site_title: AIA Singapore posts higher full-year operating profit; value of new business up 18%
summary: AIA Singapore reported a 7% increase in full-year operating profit after tax to US$558 million. The company's value of new business (VONB) rose 18% to US$357 million, driven by firmer sales in the agency channel and a strategic partnership with Citibank. However, VONB margin decreased to 65.4% due to lower profitability from HealthShield business and higher single premium unit-linked sales ahead of a regulatory change.

site_title: Israel launches Gaza strikes after rockets fired at Tel Aviv
summary: Israel launched airstrikes on Hamas facilities in the Gaza Strip on March 15, 2019, after two rockets were fired at Tel Aviv, marking the first such attack since the 2014 war. The airstrikes hit six buildings used by Hamas security forces, which had been evacuated as a precaution. No immediate casualties were reported.

images.alt_text: Israeli military aircraft bombed Hamas facilities in the Gaza Strip on Friday, hours after two rockets were launched from the Palestinian enclave at Tel Aviv in the first such attack since a 2014 war.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Infrastructure Trust, Datapulse, USP Group, Oxley
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust raised S$500.8 million through a placement and preferential offering, with the majority going towards partially repaying a loan facility. Datapulse Technology posted a net loss of S$336,000 in the second quarter, reversing from a net profit in the same period last year. USP Group's largest shareholder, Weng Huixin, has parted with her shares and resigned from the board. Oxley has found a buyer for Chevron House for S$1.025 billion.

site_title: Mt Gox founder handed 2½-year suspended sentence
summary: A Tokyo court handed Mt Gox founder Mark Karpeles a 2½-year suspended sentence for his role in the loss of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of bitcoins and cash. Karpeles was found guilty of data manipulation but innocent on embezzlement charges. The sentence was suspended for four years.

images.alt_text: The court suspended the sentence for Mark Karpeles for four years, finding the French national guilty of data manipulation but innocent on charges of embezzlement, Kyodo said.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday's open; STI up 0.01% to 3,198.18
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.01% to 3,198.18. The STI gained 0.26 point after a weak opening, with 56 gainers outnumbering 50 losers. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally. Key movers included Rex International Holding, which rose 1.2%, and Keppel Infrastructure Trust, which fell 3.1%.

site_title: BOJ keeps policy steady, cuts view on exports and output
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its monetary policy steady, keeping its short-term interest rate target at minus 0.1% and pledging to guide 10-year government bond yields around zero%. The central bank also revised its view on Japan's economy, citing the impact of slowing overseas growth and heightening overseas risks. This move comes as the global economy faces challenges, with China's GDP growth expected to slow. The BOJ's decision aims to support Japan's fragile economic recovery.

site_title: Tesla to unveil Model Y SUV as electric vehicle competition heats up
summary: Tesla is set to unveil its Model Y electric sports utility vehicle, a compact SUV that will face competition from European car makers. The Model Y, built on the same platform as the Model 3, starts at $35,000 and will cost about 10% more, with slightly less range. The unveiling is scheduled for Thursday evening in California, with pricing and details to be shared online.

site_title: Forget flying carpets, flying taxis are coming your way
summary: Experts predict flying taxis will take to the skies by 2025, revolutionizing transportation. The technology, which has been dreamed of for decades, is now a reality. Companies like Bell and Tesla are investing in flying taxi services, with some planning to deploy robots for deliveries and others aiming to offer robotaxi services. The development is expected to transform the transportation industry, but concerns remain about safety and regulations. As one expert noted, "The only question is, what are we going to do with it?"

site_title: Hong Kong seen spending billions more to defend currency peg
summary: Hong Kong's currency peg is expected to require at least another HK$50 billion in intervention to defend, according to Bank of America Merrill Lynch and OCBC Wing Hang Bank Ltd. The city's currency has repeatedly hit the weak end of its trading band, sparking interventions that have cost nearly US$700 million. Analysts predict that shorting the Hong Kong dollar will remain profitable until local borrowing costs rise sharply. The monetary authority will likely spend billions more to defend the peg, putting pressure on the city's financial system.

site_title: Cheques don't lie, says superstar gamer 'Ninja'
summary: Tyler "Ninja" Blevins, a 27-year-old American gamer, credits his family's understanding of his gaming obsession when cheques started rolling in, allowing him to leave his parents' basement. With 35 million followers on YouTube and Twitch, Ninja now collaborates with sports and music superstars, has a Red Bull deal, and has transitioned from a basement gamer to a rockstar. His rags-to-riches story showcases the lucrative multi-million dollar career of gamers streaming Fortnite.

site_title: Dark clouds loom for Asia-Pac private equity even as deal value hits new high
summary: Asia-Pacific private equity deal value reached a record high of $883 billion in 2018, with $165 billion in deals made in the region. However, the market faces uncertainty due to a weakening macroeconomic environment, rising interest rates, and a growing divide between large and smaller funds. China and India dominated dealmaking, accounting for 75% of total value. The region now represents 26% of the global private equity market, up from 9% a decade ago.

site_title: China approves foreign investment law, possible US olive branch
summary: China's rubber-stamp parliament approved a foreign investment law, aiming to address long-running grievances from foreign businesses. The legislation was fast-tracked and may serve as an olive branch in trade talks with the US, following concerns from US and European chambers of commerce about insufficient input time. The National People's Congress voted 2,929 in favor of the law, a rare quick turnaround for the legislature, which meets once a year. The approval comes amid growing tensions between China and the US, but may help ease trade tensions.

site_title: Regulator warns of 'panic' risk from money-laundering scandals
summary: Nordic banks, particularly Danske Bank and Swedbank, are facing a "panic" risk due to allegations of money laundering, with the head of Finland's Financial Supervisory Authority warning of a potential exodus of banks from the region. The banks are responding by withdrawing from the Baltic region and Russia, but regulators are also under scrutiny for their handling of the scandal. The EU is being urged to create an independent anti-money laundering authority to oversee banks, with the goal of preventing further "sloppy" compliance and protecting the financial system.

site_title: Google's work in China benefiting Chinese military: US general
summary: US General Joseph Dunford stated that Google's work in China indirectly benefits the Chinese military, contradicting the company's claims of no direct involvement. Google has previously invested in China and plans to continue, but has faced criticism over its potential compliance with China's internet censorship and surveillance policies. The company has also dropped US defense contracts due to ethical concerns, but continues to work with the US government on other projects. Dunford's comments raise concerns about Google's dual role in China and its relationship with the Chinese military.

site_title: This exchange has 5 stocks and very few investors. That's about to change
summary: The Yangon Stock Exchange in Myanmar, one of the smallest bourses in Asia, is set to open up to foreign investors, with the potential for 35% foreign ownership. The new Companies Law passed last year allows foreign investors to participate, and the exchange expects to welcome retail and institutional investors by year-end. The move aims to boost the exchange, which currently has only five listed companies and limited liquidity. The Securities and Exchange Commission of Myanmar has confirmed the expected timeline, with the exchange anticipating 20-30 companies will be listed in the next five years.

site_title: Oil prices stable amid sanctions and OPEC cuts, but economic concerns drag
summary: Oil prices remained steady amid ongoing OPEC supply cuts and US sanctions on Venezuela and Iran, but were weighed down by concerns of an impending economic slowdown. International benchmark Brent crude oil futures rose to $67.16 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures reached $58.53 per barrel. Despite the dips, crude oil has gained around a quarter in value since the start of the year. OPEC+ producers have pledged to withhold 1.2 million barrels per day to tighten markets and prop up prices.

site_title: Keppel Infra Trust ups equity fundraising to S$500.8m on strong demand
summary: Keppel Infra Trust (KIT) has increased its equity fundraising to S$500.8 million, exceeding its initial target of S$450 million, due to strong investor demand. The funds will be used to partially repay a loan facility for the A$770 million acquisition of Ixom HoldCo and cover fees and expenses. The bulk of the proceeds, S$490.7 million, will go towards loan repayment, while the remaining S$10.1 million will be used for expenses. The trust's preferential offering has also been oversubscribed.

site_title: Trump-Xi summit will not happen in March: Mnuchin
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin announced that a summit between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping will not occur at the end of March as previously discussed due to more work needed in US-China negotiations. Both sides are working in good faith to reach a deal, with Mnuchin stating that "there's still a lot of work to do" but being "very comfortable with where we are." No new face-to-face meetings have been scheduled, and Trump has portrayed the talks as making progress, with a possible resolution in the next three or four weeks.

site_title: AIA Group's 2018 value of new business rises 22%, beats forecasts
summary: AIA Group Ltd posted a 22% rise in new business value in 2018, beating forecasts, driven by higher demand from Hong Kong clients and mainland Chinese visitors. The value of new business rose to $3.96 billion, exceeding analysts' expectations of a 19% jump to $3.83 billion. China and Hong Kong account for about half of AIA's new business growth globally.

site_title: India's top government adviser says the election won't stop economic reforms
summary: India's chief economic adviser, Krishnamurthy Subramanian, assures investors that the country will continue economic reforms regardless of the outcome of the upcoming general election. The economy's growth rate is expected to rise to 7.5-8% due to recent reforms, and Subramanian cites the global slowdown and trade tensions as risks. Despite uncertainty surrounding Prime Minister Narendra Modi's re-election, reforms introduced by Modi, such as a bankruptcy law and inflation targeting framework, have improved India's ease of doing business rankings.

images.alt_text: As reforms in the past few years - from tax to inflation targeting - start to manifest, the economy's potential growth rate will rise by 50 basis points to 7.5 per cent to 8 per cent, Krishnamurthy Subramanian, chief economic adviser in the finance ministry, said in an interview in New Delhi.

site_title: Google employee breaks Guinness World Record calculating 31.4 trillion digits of Pi
summary: Google employee Emma Haruka Iwao has broken the Guinness World Record for calculating Pi to 31.4 trillion digits, surpassing the previous record of 22.4 trillion digits set in 2016. The calculation, completed in 121 days using cloud technology, required 170 terabytes of data and relied on over two dozen virtual machines. The achievement highlights the growing importance of Pi in mathematics and technology, with applications ranging from building design to scientific research. This record-breaking feat showcases the power of cloud computing in facilitating complex calculations.

site_title: Facebook loses top executives, including Chris Cox
summary: Facebook has lost top executives, including chief product officer Chris Cox and WhatsApp head Chris Daniels, amid internal turmoil and a shift in strategy. The departures follow two years of scandals, including data privacy and disinformation issues, and a decision to focus on private conversations across the company's messaging services. The move has been met with controversy and upset among employees. Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook's CEO, expressed gratitude for Cox's contributions but acknowledged the loss of talent, while praising Daniels' work in navigating challenges.

site_title: Japan's finance minister warns BOJ against insisting on hitting price goal
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso warned the Bank of Japan against insisting on hitting its 2% inflation target, citing concerns that "things could go wrong" if the goal is not achieved. Aso stated that the public would not be angry if the target is not met, suggesting a shift in the central bank's approach to inflation goals. This comes as the BOJ has been under pressure to achieve the target, which has been elusive for years.

site_title: New Zealand students walk out of class, kicking off global strike
summary: Thousands of New Zealand students walked out of class on March 15, 2019, kicking off a global student strike against government inaction on climate change. The protests, part of a worldwide movement, aimed to pressure governments to take action on reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The strike was sparked by 16-year-old Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg's protests in 2018. New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern supported the students, while others, including Australian politicians, criticized the protests for disrupting education. The movement is part of a broader global push for climate action.

site_title: Shell sets its first carbon reduction targets on output, consumption
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has set its first carbon reduction targets, aiming to cut greenhouse gas emissions from 2-3% during the 2016-2021 period. The targets, linked to executive pay, include Scope 3 emissions from fuels and products sold to customers. This is the first time Shell has issued carbon footprint targets, and they are more ambitious than those set by rivals BP and Total. The move comes as the oil and gas industry faces growing shareholder pressure to tackle carbon emissions following the 2015 Paris climate agreement.

site_title: MtGox bitcoin founder learns fate on embezzlement charges
