Despite this, the account has been praised for its impact on the industry and has inspired others to follow in its footsteps.

site_title: Rakuten TV to expand movie streaming to 42 European countries
summary: Rakuten TV plans to expand its movie streaming service to 42 European countries, partnering with smart TV manufacturers to offer high-definition content. The service, priced at 4.99 euros, will complement streaming giants Netflix and Amazon Prime Video, targeting viewers who pay for new movie releases. With a 7 million pay-per-view customer base, Rakuten TV estimates it will reach 30 million European households, with availability on over 80% of smart TVs in European living rooms. The service will also offer 4K ultra-high definition and 8K standard films.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.29% at the start of business on Thursday, following a Wall Street advance fueled by upbeat US economic data. The Hang Seng Index increased to 28,891.06, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.44% and 0.80% respectively.

site_title: Vietnamese woman in North Korea murder case seeks freedom
summary: A Vietnamese woman, Doan Thi Huong, accused of assassinating North Korea's Kim Jong Nam, is expected to learn Thursday whether she will be freed. Huong has been on trial for a year and a half over the 2017 assassination at Kuala Lumpur airport. Her lawyers have asked the Malaysian government to withdraw the murder charge against her, citing she was tricked by North Korean spies and believed it was a prank. The prosecution is expected to announce whether her bid for freedom has been successful, with Huong facing death by hanging if convicted.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher after Wall Street gains
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Thursday, following overnight gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.84% to 21,469.03, while the Topix index gained 0.70% to 1,603.29. Investors attempted to recover losses from the previous day, driven by the US stock market's edge to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore and Vietnam to explore tie-ups in energy, Industry 4.0
summary: Singapore and Vietnam will explore collaborations in smart cities, energy, Industry 4.0, and start-ups, with both countries' ministers discussing possibilities at the 14th Singapore Vietnam Connectivity Ministerial Meeting. Memoranda of Understanding were signed in 2018 on LNG and solar projects, and the two countries agreed to expand education cooperation to support innovation and exchanges of technopreneurs. Bilateral trade between Singapore and Vietnam has doubled over the past decade, with Singapore remaining the top ASEAN investor in Vietnam.

site_title: Asia is getting tougher on auditors after high-profile defaults
summary: Asian regulators are cracking down on auditors after high-profile defaults by Noble Group and Infrastructure Leasing & Financial Services, prompting concerns over the quality of financial reports. In response, the Singapore Exchange plans to increase accounting oversight and proposes new rules requiring a second auditor in exceptional circumstances. The move aims to provide earlier warning signs to investors amid expectations for debt failures to mount. Regulators in the region are also looking into amending laws to allow sanctions for lapses in quality controls.

site_title: Over 100 Malaysian schools shut after toxic waste dump
summary: Over 100 schools in Malaysia's southern Johor state have been closed after toxic waste was dumped into a river, causing hundreds of people, mostly children, to fall ill with symptoms of poisoning. The Education Minister ordered the closure of 111 schools in the area, citing environmental concerns. Three men were arrested earlier this week over the toxic waste dumping, with one expected to be charged and face up to five years in jail. Medical treatment was provided to over 500 people, with 160 admitted to hospital.

site_title: Sim Lian to open mega Treasure At Tampines condo for preview on March 15
summary: Sim Lian Group will open the mega Treasure At Tampines condominium for preview on March 15, with sales set to begin later this month. The 2,203-unit, 99-year leasehold development spans 650,000 sq ft, offering one to five-bedroom units and 128 recreational amenities. Located near Changi Airport and major employment hubs, Treasure At Tampines is expected to receive its temporary occupation permit by 2023 and has an average price of S$1,280 psf.

site_title: Facebook faces criminal probe of data deals: report
summary: US prosecutors have launched a criminal investigation into Facebook's practice of sharing users' data with companies without consent, amid controversy over the handling of user data following the Cambridge Analytica scandal. A grand jury in New York has subpoenaed information from smartphone makers, and Facebook has cooperated with investigators while announcing moves to tighten data handling. The probe aims to determine whether Facebook protected users' privacy in its data-sharing practices.

site_title: British pound surges in Asia in wake of Brexit vote
summary: The British pound surged in Asian markets on March 13, 2019, following Parliament's rejection of a no-deal Brexit. Sterling reached a 2018 high of US$1.3380, as investors assumed a disorderly exit was less likely. The euro dropped to its lowest level since mid-2017. The vote paved the way for a delay in Brexit, providing relief for investors.

images.alt_text: Sterling jumped in wild Asian trading on Thursday as markets priced in less risk of a disorderly exit from the European Union after Parliament rejected leaving without a deal.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars pressured as bond yields keep falling
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars were pressured as domestic bond yields fell to multi-year lows, with the Aussie down 0.3% and the Kiwi holding at US$0.6853. Investors narrowed the odds on interest rate cuts, with Australian futures fully priced for a quarter-point cut in August. Yields on three-year bonds dropped to 1.513%, the lowest since 2016, and 10-year yields in both countries are now at their lowest in history.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday, STI down 0.2% to 3,188.35
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) losing 7.24 points or 0.2% to 3,188.35. Gainers outnumbered losers 51 to 41, with about 21 million securities worth S$60.4 million changing hands. The STI has had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 2.36 points to 1,675.88 on Thursday, with a trading volume of 103.19 million lots worth RM39.07 million. Gainers outpaced losers 146 to 73. The drop comes despite a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong performance in the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: Australia: Shares subdued as weak banks offset strong miners, New Zealand up
summary: Australian equities fell 0.1% on Thursday, as weak lenders offset gains from strong miners. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 4.6 points to 6,156.6, with financial stocks sliding 0.4% and Commonwealth Bank of Australia falling 0.7% in its sixth straight losing session. Mining stocks, however, outperformed, with zinc prices near an eight-month high and major miners such as Rio Tinto and BHP Group advancing.

site_title: Venezuela calls public sector back to work as blackout recedes
summary: Venezuela's public sector has been called back to work after a nearly week-long blackout, which was the worst in the country's history. The blackout, caused by a power outage in 22 of 23 states, cost the country $875 million and deepened the economic crisis. President Nicolas Maduro has accused the US of waging a cyber attack, but experts say it was likely an internal failure. The opposition leader Juan Guaido has gained support from the US and 50 other countries, and Maduro's government has been hit with a criminal investigation for alleged sabotage.

site_title: US and India commit to building six nuclear power plants
summary: The US and India agreed to strengthen security and civil nuclear cooperation, including building six US nuclear power plants in India. The deal comes after two days of talks in Washington, with Indian Foreign Secretary Vijay Gokhale and US Undersecretary of State Andrea Thompson involved. The project aims to support India's plan to triple its nuclear capacity by 2024, reducing its reliance on polluting fossil fuels.

site_title: US investigating if Jho Low secretly donated to Trump's re-election campaign
summary: The US Justice Department is investigating whether Malaysian fugitive Jho Low secretly donated $100,000 to a Trump re-election campaign through a US citizen, Larry Davis. The donation was made in December 2017 to the Trump Victory committee. Authorities are seeking to determine if payments of $1.5 million made by Low financed the donation, which is a federal offense for foreign individuals or companies to make donations to US politicians. Low faces charges in the US and Malaysia for allegedly laundering money and bribing officials.

site_title: Enterprise Singapore assisted 76,000 companies in 2018
summary: Enterprise Singapore (ESG) reported assisting 76,000 companies in Singapore in 2018, including 30,000 through SME Centres and 7,000 capability upgrading projects. The agency facilitated over 570 overseas projects, generating S$11.1 billion in sales and S$6.1 billion in investments. ESG chairman Peter Ong stated that the organisation made "significant strides" despite a challenging environment and organisational integration. The agency also supported over 1,000 startups, co-investing S$36.5 million in 52 startups and catalysing S$118 million in private investments.

site_title: US crude stockpiles drop unexpectedly last week: EIA
summary: US crude oil stockpiles unexpectedly decreased by 3.9 million barrels last week, contrary to analyst expectations. The decline was mainly driven by a drop in Gulf Coast stockpiles, while East Coast and Midwest inventories increased. Refinery crude runs rose, and domestic production slipped to 12 million barrels per day. Oil prices briefly extended gains before steadying, with US crude futures reaching a four-month high above $58 a barrel.

site_title: If Berlin picks Huawei for 5G, Nato will not communicate: US general
summary: US General Curtis Scaparrotti warned that if Berlin selects Huawei for its 5G telecom infrastructure, NATO forces would stop communicating with German colleagues due to security concerns. The US has already shut Huawei out of 5G tenders in several Western nations, fearing the company's ties to the Chinese government pose security risks. NATO's Supreme Allied Commander stated that compromised telecommunications backbone would be a significant problem, affecting military communication. Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel said Berlin would consult with Washington on using Huawei technology, while the company denies allegations of espionage.

site_title: Fast cars, polo and parties: Wealthy Thais flourish in unequal kingdom
summary: In Thailand, where 50 billionaires reside, the sport of polo is experiencing a resurgence, with wealthy patrons funding teams of elite players. The sport is seen as elitist, with teams composed of CEOs and royalty. The country's widening wealth gap, with the top 20% owning 80% of wealth, is a pressing issue ahead of the March 24 polls. The junta's rule has led to a concentration of power and wealth, stifling economic growth and exacerbating inequality. Despite this, many Thais remain focused on voting and seeking a better economy for the grassroots.

site_title: Vietnam woman in North Korea murder case has release bid rejected: prosecutor
summary: A Vietnamese woman, Doan Huong, charged with assassinating North Korea's Kim Jong Nam, had her release bid rejected by Malaysian authorities. The lead prosecutor stated that the court will proceed with the case despite Huong's claims of innocence. Huong has been in trial for over a year and a half, while her Indonesian co-accused, Siti Aisyah, was unexpectedly released on Monday after prosecutors withdrew the murder charge against her. The Vietnamese ambassador expressed disappointment at the decision and urged Malaysia to be fair and release Huong as soon as possible.

site_title: MAS seeks 'good long-term returns' on reserves through balanced asset allocation
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) seeks "good long-term returns" on its reserves through a balanced asset allocation, according to Managing Director Ravi Menon. The central bank invests in a diversified portfolio, including equities, inflation-linked bonds, and cash, with a longer investment horizon than many peers. The portfolio is geographically diversified and includes US dollars, euros, and other currencies. MAS also monitors factor-based investing and conducts vulnerability-based stress tests to create efficient and diversified portfolios.

site_title: Brexit set for delay after May wounded by rejection of "no-deal"
summary: The British parliament rejected leaving the European Union without a deal, voting 321-278 in favor of a motion that rules out a "no-deal" Brexit under any circumstances. The move weakens Prime Minister Theresa May's position and paves the way for a vote that could delay Brexit until at least June 30. The European Commission reiterated that a delay requires a justification, but EU members are inclined to help find a viable deal. The pound rose 2% on the rejection of "no-deal," with the government now considering a short delay or failing to agree on a deal.

site_title: Trump announces immediate grounding of Boeing 737 Max planes
summary: US President Donald Trump announced the immediate grounding of all Boeing 737 Max planes following the second deadly crash of the airliner in less than five months. The Federal Aviation Authority (FAA) issued an emergency order, and those in mid-flight will be suspended from service upon landing. The grounding comes after mounting international and political pressure, with the US being the last major country to pull the jet from service. Trump expressed hope that Boeing will come up with an answer, but until then, the planes are grounded.

site_title: Sino Grandness seeks extension to hold AGM, announce Q1 results
summary: Sino Grandness Food Industry Group has applied to the Singapore bourse for an extension of its annual general meeting (AGM) and Q1 financial results release due to addressing a default loan to Soleado Holdings. The company is seeking to push back the AGM deadline from April 30 to May 31 and Q1 results release from May 14 to June 14, citing staff turnover and disruptions to financial information. The company is also requiring more time for external auditors to complete their work.

site_title: US: Wall Street rallies amid Brexit, Boeing turmoil
summary: US stocks rallied on Wednesday as British lawmakers ruled out a no-deal Brexit and President Trump grounded Boeing's 737 Max aircraft, citing safety concerns. The Dow rose 0.6%, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq gained 0.7%, and Boeing's shares rose 0.5% after a three-day decline. Economic data showed a modest boost in the US manufacturing sector and tame wholesale inflation in February. Investors were also reassured by the Federal Reserve's signal that interest rates may not rise in the short or mid-term.

site_title: Singtel ramps up e-sports support and community initiatives ahead of SEA Games
summary: Singtel has announced a significant sponsorship deal to support Singapore's e-sports team ahead of the Southeast Asian Games, providing funding for training, competitions, stipends, and scholarships. The company will also offer extra tuition classes for athletes, enhance athlete experience, and promote the e-sports ecosystem in the region. Additionally, Singtel has launched two new amateur leagues, PVP Campus and PVP Corporate, to foster friendly competition and develop the e-sports industry. The move is seen as a key step in growing the gaming ecosystem in Asia and providing job opportunities for Singapore's youth.

site_title: Why Kim Jong Un might not care for the riches Trump is promising
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un may not be interested in the economic benefits promised by US President Donald Trump, despite calls for relaxing sanctions. Kim's regime sees foreign businesses as a risk, potentially spreading outside information that could undermine his control. The young leader may prefer to develop his economy on his own terms, maintaining his nuclear deterrent. Experts argue that Kim's priorities lie in control and stability, rather than economic growth or reform, making it unlikely that he will abandon his nuclear program for economic incentives.

site_title: New training programme offers bite-sized learning for busy SME bosses
summary: A new training program called U Leap Community has been launched in Singapore to provide bite-sized learning for busy small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) bosses. The program, in partnership with the National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) and the Employment and Employability Institute (e2i), covers areas such as leadership thinking, organisational development, and best-in-class practices. SME bosses who complete relevant modules can earn an e-certification, which can be further stacked with industry-recognised classroom-based workshops for higher certification. The goal is to equip SME leaders with relevant skills and knowledge to help them transform their businesses and stay ahead of the game.

site_title: Outage hits Facebook, Instagram users worldwide
summary: A global outage affected Facebook and Instagram users worldwide, causing limited functionality and complete loss of access in some areas. The outage, which started on March 13, 2019, was initially attributed to an unknown cause but later ruled out as a distributed denial of service (DDoS) attack. Facebook stated they were working to resolve the issue as soon as possible. The outage was reported in North America and Europe, with some users in other regions also affected.

site_title: Uber nears US$1b spinout of self-driving car unit
summary: Uber is in advanced discussions to spin out its self-driving car unit and sell a $1 billion stake to a consortium of investors led by SoftBank Group Corp. The deal could value the autonomous-vehicle business at $5 billion to $10 billion. Selling a stake would allow Uber to offload part of its expensive endeavor as it prepares for an initial public offering. The group led by SoftBank, Uber's largest shareholder, may also include other investors and possibly an automaker, though their identities are unclear. The deal is still in late-stage discussions and may not be finalized.

images.alt_text: Uber Technologies Inc is in advanced discussions to spin out its costly self-driving-car unit and sell a US$1 billion stake to a consortium of investors led by SoftBank Group Corp, people familiar with the plans said.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Courts Asia, Shanghai Turbo, Sino Grandness, Vibrant Group, LifeBrandz
summary: Singapore stocks saw various developments on Thursday, March 14, 2019. Singapore Airlines established a S$2 billion medium-term bond program, while Courts Asia will be delisted due to less than 10% public ownership. Shanghai Turbo narrowed its 2018 net loss to S$2.8 million. Sino Grandness Food Industry Group applied for an extension of its AGM and financial results release. Vibrant Group reported a net profit of S$3.9 million in its fiscal third quarter, and KOP successfully defended a court claim against one of its subsidiaries. LifeBrandz posted a net loss of S$599,000 in the three months ended January 31.

site_title: US says 'no basis' to ground 737 MAX jets
summary: The US has refused to ground Boeing's 737 MAX jets, citing "no basis" for such an action, despite two deadly crashes in less than five months. The European Union, Britain, India, and several other countries have grounded the plane or banned it from their airspace. Boeing has assured the US that the aircraft is safe, and has made changes to flight systems and pilot training procedures. However, experts warn that the increasing automation of planes means crews have less experience flying manually, and that the issue is not just mechanical or software-related, but also one of communication and trust.

site_title: Qatar Cabinet approves foreigner property rule
summary: Qatar's Cabinet has approved a proposal allowing foreigners to own property and be granted residency simultaneously. Non-Qataris will be able to fully own residential villas and shops in 10 areas, with commercial property also covered. Property contracts can be held for 99 years in 16 identified areas. The move aims to boost Qatar's economy, particularly its faltering property sector, as the country seeks further investment amid its ongoing diplomatic dispute with neighboring countries. The new law's implementation details will be announced in a press conference next week.

images.alt_text: Qatar's Cabinet on Wednesday approved proposals to allow foreigners to own property and be granted residency at the same time, according to an official statement.

site_title: Singapore moving into IPO radar with rising interest in Asean: PwC poll
summary: Singapore is gaining interest as a potential initial public offering (IPO) location, driven by growing focus on South-east Asian markets. A PwC survey found 15% of executives cited the Singapore Exchange (SGX) as a listing destination by 2030, a 4 percentage point increase from 2011. Liquidity, valuations, and costs remain top priorities, with technology expected to be a significant driver in the future of public companies. SGX's reputation as a pro-business exchange and stable environment are seen as advantages for companies considering a listing.

site_title: Adidas expects supply chain problems to rein in H1 sales growth
summary: Adidas expects supply chain issues to slow its sales growth in the first half of 2019, particularly in North America, where it faces competition from Nike. Despite this, the company forecasts a currency-neutral sales growth of 5-8% for 2019, with a one to two percentage point fall due to supply chain problems. Adidas expects to return to growth in Europe, where it plans to shift focus from fashion shoes to sports performance gear, and reach an operating profit margin of 11.3-11.5% for 2019.

site_title: Insurtech startup CXA raises US$25m, expects to break even next year
summary: Singapore-based insurtech startup CXA Group has raised US$25 million in a bridge funding round to expand in the Asia-Pacific region. Key investors include HSBC, Singtel Innov8, and Telkom Indonesia MDI Ventures. CXA's platform, which offers health and wellness services to employees, is expected to break even next year. The company plans to use the funds to invest in engineering, data science, talent, and acquisitions, and to work with partners to integrate its platform into their services.

site_title: Malaysia bauxite miners must conduct environmental study
summary: Malaysia requires bauxite miners to conduct environmental impact assessments (EIAs) before receiving licenses to operate. The assessments, expected to take at least six months, will determine the environmental impact of each site. Mine operators must meet strict requirements, including the use of specific lorries and the export of processed bauxite. The moratorium on bauxite mining, set to end on March 31, may slow global supply and boost prices, affecting China's top-buyer status.

site_title: SingPost may wind down or sell US e-commerce unit: analysts
summary: SingPost is considering winding down or selling its loss-making US e-commerce business, according to analysts. The unit has suffered losses for three consecutive years and has been a drag on the company's profit. A strategic review is underway, and potential divestment or shutdown could improve SingPost's long-term profitability. Analysts expect an exit from the US e-commerce business, which could provide an immediate boost to earnings, but may not impact the company's core mail and package business.

site_title: SIA sets up S$2b bond programme for senior unsecured debt
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has established a S$2 billion medium-term bond programme for senior unsecured debt. DBS has been appointed as the arranger, while DBS, OCBC, and UOB will be dealers. The bonds may be issued to retail investors with varying tenors and interest rates. Net proceeds will be used to refinance existing borrowings, finance investments, and cover working capital. This is SIA's second bond issue this year, following a S$600 million bond in October 2018.

site_title: Shanghai Turbo 14m yuan in the red for full year
summary: Shanghai Turbo Enterprises reported a narrowed full-year 2018 net loss of 14 million yuan, down from a restated year-ago loss of 158.1 million yuan. Revenue shrank 23% to 30.3 million yuan due to ongoing legal suits and quality control issues. Despite a gross loss of 17.6 million yuan, the company collected doubtful trade receivables, reversing provisions made in 2017. Looking ahead, Shanghai Turbo expects a challenging business landscape due to the US-China trade war and ongoing legal disputes.

site_title: UOB prices Singapore's first Panda bond at 3.49%
summary: UOB successfully priced the first Panda bond from Singapore, priced at 3.49% for a 2 billion yuan (S$404 million) three-year offering. The bond garnered a 2.7 times subscription rate from Asian investors, with 62% allocated to international offshore investors. The issue aims to diversify UOB's investor base and promote China's foreign bond market, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore supporting the cross-border issuance. The deal was led by Bank of China, with UOB shares falling 0.56% after the announcement.

site_title: Asia boosts Prudential profit, demerger of British business making progress
summary: Prudential, Britain's largest insurer, reported a 6% increase in 2018 operating profit to £4.8 billion, exceeding forecasts. The firm's Asian business saw a 14% rise, while its British pensions business benefited from lower life improvement expectations. A demerger of its British business, M&G Prudential, is making progress, with a stock market listing expected before the end of the year. The US business, however, saw a 11% decline in profit due to accounting measures.

site_title: BT's Angela Tan wins Excellence in Journalism award
summary: Journalist Angela Tan of The Business Times (BT) won the Excellence in Journalism award at the Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) annual ceremony. Tan was also a nominee for the Journalist of the Year award, which went to photojournalist Kevin Lim of The Straits Times. Two of Tan's articles were recognized, including "Given a second chance, die-hard Vard shareholders must come out to vote" and "Noble - too much faith in a clean audit?". BT editor Wong Wei Kong praised Tan's work, describing her as "outstanding" for her coverage of corporate governance and minority shareholder interests.

site_title: Trading surge in oil options creates a whirl of speculation
summary: Global oil options markets experienced their busiest trading week since November after a large producer bought millions of barrels of oil contracts to protect against a potential price drop. Trading in US$60 puts dominated the market, with 16 million barrels changing hands in June, August, and September. This buying spree, likely tied to a major hedging programme, led to increased implied volatility for Brent August US$60 puts, the highest since November. Petrobras, a major Brazilian oil company, was reportedly involved in the trades, having hedged 128 million barrels of crude in 2018.

site_title: Top American universities shun cash from Huawei under Trump pressure
summary: US top universities are cutting ties with Huawei due to pressure from the Trump administration over national security concerns. Princeton, Stanford, Ohio State, and UC Berkeley have severed or reduced their relationships with the Chinese telecommunications company. The US claims Huawei poses an espionage threat, partly because it must respond to Beijing's security agencies. Despite Huawei's denials, US officials have devoted attention to the issue, with the FBI and intelligence agencies briefing Education Department staff. The move reflects US concerns over intellectual exchange and the potential for espionage, with some universities expressing regret at being "locked out" of interactions with Huawei.

site_title: iPhone trends going from 'bad to worse': Longbow Research
summary: Apple Inc. continues to struggle with iPhone demand, particularly in China, with trends going "from bad to worse", according to Longbow Research. Analyst Shawn Harrison affirmed his neutral rating on the stock, citing a lack of iPhone sales rebound and increased focus on a March 25 event where Apple is expected to introduce a video programming service and premium magazine subscription plan.

site_title: Pound's yo-yo causing headaches; DBS strategist urges defensive stance
summary: The British pound's value has been fluctuating wildly due to the uncertainty surrounding Brexit, causing headaches for money changers and those relying on the currency. The pound's value has swung between S$1.74 and S$1.80 against the Singapore dollar, with some money changers resorting to lying about shortages to avoid haggling. Experts warn of a high risk of a hard Brexit, which could lead to a collapse in the pound's value and exacerbate EU growth. Philip Wee, a DBS FX strategist, advises buying the pound daily due to its potential to fall further, while other experts predict a low probability of a no-deal Brexit and a neutral view on the pound's future value.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Influence: Siti Noor Mastura, Singaporean of the Year 2018
summary: Siti Noor Mastura, Singaporean of the Year 2018, shares her story of overcoming adversity, including a difficult childhood and family struggles. Despite these challenges, she founded the non-profit organisation Back2Basics, which helps homebound elderly and single mothers through dialogue and interfaith understanding. Mastura's approach emphasizes the importance of dialogue and understanding in breaking down barriers, and her work has made a significant impact in the community.

site_title: Europe: Hopes Britain will reject no-deal Brexit buoy shares
summary: European shares rose 0.6% on Wednesday as investors bet against a no-deal Brexit, but results from companies like Inditex and Adidas limited gains. The Stoxx 600 index climbed despite disappointing earnings from the companies. Oil prices jumped 1%, boosting the Stoxx 600 oil & gas index, while Wirecard fell 6.6% after allegations of fraud. Sterling extended gains as lawmakers voted against Prime Minister Theresa May's amended Brexit deal, forcing parliament to decide on a no-deal Brexit.

site_title: Bribes to get into Yale and Stanford fly in the face of social mobility
summary: The US Justice Department has indicted dozens of wealthy parents, including actress Felicity Huffman, for bribery and fraud to get their children into elite schools like Yale and Stanford. These parents allegedly paid college coaches and exam administrators to manipulate admissions processes. The scheme involved millions of dollars in bribes, undermining social mobility and the integrity of the college admissions system. The indictments highlight the corrupt practices that have become all too common in the pursuit of elite education.

site_title: Singapore co-working space reaches next level of luxury
summary: Singapore's co-working space, THE Great Room, has elevated its luxury offerings with marble floors, brushed gold finishes, and premium amenities like coconut water in the pantry. The upscale space reflects its higher pricing. This trend of luxury co-working spaces is part of the sector's shift from utilitarian offerings, with more high-end options emerging in the market.

images.alt_text: The Great Room's premises in Centennial Tower. The company has just signed with Raffles Hotel to open its fourth location in Singapore.

site_title: High time Singapore sets up proper whistleblower laws, protection
summary: Singapore's lack of proper whistleblower laws and protection is highlighted after Australia passed amendments to its whistleblowing laws, which will take effect in July. Currently, whistleblower policies in corporate Singapore are optional and not required by law. This raises concerns about the safety and protection of whistleblowers who report corporate malfeasance. It is time for Singapore to institutionalize legal protection for whistleblowers, similar to Australia's new laws.

site_title: Nasa chief acknowledges more trouble with SLS rocket
summary: NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine acknowledged significant development delays for the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket, which is years behind schedule. The rocket, intended to support manned missions to the Moon, won't meet its June 2020 deadline. Bridenstine proposed using existing private launch systems, such as SpaceX's Falcon Heavy or United Launch Alliance's Delta IV Heavy, to accomplish the mission. The decision could impact thousands of jobs and billions of dollars in funding, with Congress set to decide on the space budget in the coming months.

site_title: Asian jet fuel profit margins hit over 8-month low on weak demand
summary: Asian jet fuel profit margins dropped to a 8-month low due to weak demand and firm crude prices. Refining margins for jet fuel fell to US$13.19 a barrel, the lowest since June last year, during Asian trading hours. Crude prices firmed while demand for the distillate fuel remained low, contributing to the decline in margins.

site_title: Core US capital goods orders beat forecasts with 0.8% jump in January
summary: US capital goods orders increased by 0.8% in January, the largest jump in six months, beating forecasts. This solid business spending on equipment suggests a strong start to the year, potentially prompting economists to upgrade their low growth estimates for the first quarter. However, retail sales rose moderately and inflation remained tame, indicating that the economy continued to lose momentum early in the year.

site_title: Brexit defeat could end May's premiership
summary: Theresa May's premiership is at risk after the House of Commons voted down her Brexit withdrawal deal, 391-242. The deal, reached with the EU, includes measures to replace the backstop indefinitely, a provision that could keep the UK tied to the EU. Attorney-General Geoffrey Cox ruled that the deal did not eliminate the likelihood of indefinite backstop arrangements, potentially jeopardizing May's control over the withdrawal process and her term of office.

site_title: Asean increasingly important to US firms: AmCham survey
summary: US firms increasingly rely on economic ties with Asean, particularly Singapore, with the country boasting a $242 billion stock of foreign direct investment. Minister for Foreign Affairs Vivian Balakrishnan emphasized the importance of the US private sector in Southeast Asia, citing the US-Asean Smart Cities Partnership and the demographic dividend of the youthful Asean region. This underscores the growing significance of Asean to US economic interests, with Singapore at the forefront of this relationship.

site_title: Trump sees 'very good chance' of trade deal with China
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed a "very good chance" of reaching a trade deal with China, but is in no rush to agree. Trump stated that China wants to make a deal, but emphasized the importance of getting it right. The comments come as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said on Wednesday he sees a "very good chance" of reaching a trade deal with China but is in "no rush" to reach an agreement.

site_title: Japan's top life insurer taps derivatives to fight low yields
summary: Japan's leading life insurer, Nippon Life Insurance Co, is expanding its use of derivatives to boost income and offset hedging costs amid low bond yields. The firm has increased its use of currency swaps, dollar-yen options, and interest rate derivatives since October. Nippon Life aims to ride out the low-yield environment with a globally diversified allocation and enhanced risk-return efficiency. The move reflects the company's exposure to overseas debt markets, with 40% of its assets in Europe and 50% in the US.

site_title: Singapore firms to ride out Brexit with eye on buy opportunities
summary: Singapore firms with UK exposure are preparing for Brexit's uncertainties, with diversification helping minimize the impact. Companies like Ho Bee Land and others acknowledge the persistent uncertainty but see opportunities in the market. Some, such as Creative Technology, warn of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. Despite this, Singapore property players are taking a cautious approach, with NTT DC Reit's public offer being oversubscribed.

site_title: Gold bulls could spark interest in Singapore-listed miners
summary: Gold prices have surged to over US$1,301 per ounce, driven by a weakening US dollar and Brexit fears, with analysts predicting the precious metal could hold firm around this mark for months. This is a significant comeback from its low of US$1,184.25/oz in August last year. The recent gold bull charge has sparked interest in Singapore-listed miners, potentially leading to increased investment in the sector.

site_title: Your surrounds may be safer but your immune system has never been weaker
summary: A dermatologist warns that despite being surrounded by cleanliness, people's immune systems have never been weaker. The doctor advises against using anti-bacterial soap and hand sanitizers, instead recommending the use of antibacterial-free soap and encouraging people to get vaccinated. Overuse of antibiotics is also a concern, with the doctor suggesting that people immunize themselves and take advantage of new vaccines when available.

site_title: It's game over for traditional banking as we know it
summary: Traditional banking is facing a significant shift as disruptor banks, favored by millennials, receive substantial funding and gain traction. Exponential growth in funding for digital banks like WeBank and Kakaobank is expected this year. These newcomers are gaining popularity with millennials due to their simple, beautifully designed, and transparently communicated propositions. As a result, traditional banks' barriers, such as strong balance sheets and compliance expertise, are no longer enough to prevent material impact from these challengers.

site_title: Trump's nepotism chipping away at America's democracy
summary: US President Donald Trump's children, particularly Barron, have been subject to intense media scrutiny and Secret Service protection, undermining their normalcy and childhood. Unlike previous presidents' children, who were largely left alone, Trump's children are constantly followed and have their lives scrutinized, a phenomenon that can be "shocking to the system." This has raised concerns about the impact of nepotism on America's democracy, particularly for young children who should be able to have a relatively normal life.

site_title: China-US trade war biggest wildcard for Singapore economy
summary: Singapore's economy is seen as vulnerable to the US-China trade war, with private-sector economists citing it as the biggest wildcard. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has trimmed its 2019 growth forecast to 2.5%, citing weak economic data and muted Brexit impact. Economists warn that the trade war's impact could swing either way, with an easing of tensions potentially boosting growth and continued protectionism posing a further drag.

site_title: Japan's machinery orders fall as trade war bites
summary: Japan's machinery orders declined 5.4% in January, the fastest month-on-month drop since September 2018, due to the US-China tariff war affecting the auto and telecommunications sectors. This is a significant decrease from the median estimate of a 1.7% decline. The core machinery orders, a leading indicator of capital expenditure, has been declining for two consecutive months, indicating a hit to demand.

site_title: Nissan HR exec exits as Ghosn power structure is dismantled
summary: Arun Bajaj, Nissan's senior vice-president for human resources, left the company on March 11 as part of a senior management shuffle following Carlos Ghosn's arrest in November. Bajaj's departure comes as Nissan revamps its leadership structure. He will be replaced by Jose Luis Valls, who will take on the additional responsibility of president of Nissan North America. The move is part of a broader effort to reorganize the company's management following Ghosn's arrest.

site_title: Vietnam's elephant race draws cheers and critics' jeers
summary: The Buon Don elephant festival in Vietnam's central highlands drew cheers and criticism, with locals celebrating the revered animals, but conservation groups calling for an end to the festival due to animal cruelty. The event, which features football matches, swimming sessions, and a parade, culminated in a race where elephants were beaten with sticks. Only 14 elephants participated this year, down from dozens in years past. Conservation groups, including Animals Asia, have launched ethical elephant tours and criticized the festival as outdated and inhumane.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Vibrant Group reported a net profit of S$3.9 million for the quarter ended Jan 31, 2019, reversing a loss of S$664,000 in the same period last year. Revenue increased 13% to S$51.7 million, driven by the completion of the Master-Riviera project and a revaluation gain on a Chinese development. Earnings per share rose to 0.56 Singapore cents, compared to a loss of 0.1 cents the previous year.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) maintained its buy rating with a price target of S$8.20, citing first mover advantage and multiple revenue streams despite potential competition from MSCI China A Index futures. CEI Limited reported stable FY2018 results, driven by cost management, and is expected to maintain its 100% dividend payout trend. The company faces risks of foreign exchange losses and a pull-back in customer orders, but new customers and projects due to trade tensions could provide earnings upside.

site_title: Singapore, US derivative trading venues deemed comparable
summary: Singapore and the US have agreed to mutually recognise some derivatives trading venues, allowing participants to trade most over-the-counter derivatives on the same platforms. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will exempt US-regulated trading venues from MAS-authorisation, while US-regulated facilities will not have to register with the MAS. This move aims to improve cross-border market efficiency and resilience, giving participants access to deeper pools of liquidity. The agreement is seen as a win for cross-border market regulation and follows similar plans with the European Union.

site_title: Cathay Pacific posts HK$2.35b profit after two years of losses
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd reported a HK$2.35 billion annual profit after two years of losses, driven by rising airfares and a cost-cutting turnaround plan. Revenue increased 14.2% to HK$111 billion in 2018. The airline expects a challenging 2019 outlook due to geopolitical tensions and global trade issues, but analysts project further improvements this year. Cathay plans to expand its route network, increase frequencies, and operate fuel-efficient aircraft to boost revenue.

site_title: Claremont Hotel back on market with lower asking price
summary: The Claremont Hotel in Singapore is back on the market with a lower asking price of S$70 million, down from S$90 million in 2016. The 90-room budget hotel, located near Farrer Park MRT Station, is being marketed with either a one-year sale and leaseback arrangement or vacant possession. With no additional buyer's stamp duty or seller's stamp duty applicable, foreigners are eligible to purchase the building, and interest from real estate funds, developers, and hotel operators is expected due to its prime location and gentrification in the area.

site_title: Facebook deletes, then restores Warren's ads
summary: Senator Elizabeth Warren's presidential campaign had ads removed by Facebook for violating policies against using the company's logo. The ads, which criticized Facebook's power and influence, were restored after a report in Politico. Facebook declined to say how the ads were targeted, citing its advertising policies against using the Facebook logo. Warren's campaign had sponsored over a dozen ads on Facebook, including plans to curb tech giants' power. The incident was seen as ammunition for Warren's anti-tech stance, with her later tweeting that Facebook's actions proved her ideas were good ones.

site_title: Australia shares extend slide after strong run; NZ dips
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to 6,161.20, extending losses for a fourth straight session, after investors locked in gains from a strong run since January. Financial and healthcare stocks led the decline, with Westpac and National Australia Bank down 0.7% and 0.4%, respectively. New Zealand's benchmark index edged down 0.1%. A sentiment survey found Australian consumers have turned gloomy, raising the risk of an interest rate cut as early as next month.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler to recall 863,000 autos over emissions
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles will recall nearly 863,000 SUVs and sedans in the US due to emissions issues. The affected models, produced for 2011 and 2016, include Dodge Journey, Chrysler 200, Jeep Compass, and Jeep Patriot. Owners can continue driving their vehicles during the recall, which will involve replacing catalytic converters. This comes two months after the company agreed to pay $515 million for installing "defeat devices" on cars to cheat on emissions tests. The recall will be carried out in phases this year, starting with the oldest vehicles.

site_title: Asia markets will keep eye on China data
summary: Asia markets will closely monitor China's economic data released on Thursday, which may indicate the state of China's economy amid growing growth concerns. The data includes industrial production, retail sales, and foreign direct investment figures. Investors in Asia had a cautious session on Wednesday due to the UK parliamentary vote on Brexit and awaited updates on US-China trade negotiations. Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.52% to close at 3,195.59, with 19 of its 30 constituents ending the day in the red.

site_title: Hammond says Brexit war chest has grown
summary: The UK has slashed its 2019 economic growth forecast to 1.2%, sharply down from 1.6% in October, as Finance Minister Philip Hammond cited Brexit's "cloud of uncertainty" as the country's most urgent task. The lower forecast comes amid concerns of China's slowdown and trade war tensions. Hammond also announced a temporary reduction in most import tariffs in the event of a "no deal" Brexit, with 87% of imports eligible for zero tariffs, but business leaders expressed frustration and warned of a potential economic impact.

site_title: Aviation authorities are best placed to decide whether or not to ground jets
summary: Aviation authorities are best suited to decide whether to ground jets, but few airlines have done so voluntarily following the Ethiopian Airlines crash. China and Indonesia ordered their airlines to ground Boeing 737 Max 8 planes, with Singapore Airlines' SilkAir continuing to operate its six aircraft. The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) have not issued a directive, but are monitoring the situation. Several countries, including the US, Canada, and Australia, have also grounded the aircraft, but the decision remains with individual authorities.

site_title: Six foreign-controlled miners to start divestments in 'near future': Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's Energy and Mineral Resources ministry announced that six foreign-controlled miners, including Vale Indonesia and PT Nusa Hamahera Mineral, plan to divest some of their shares in the "near future" to meet regulations. The divestments are required to reduce foreign ownership to at least 49% within 10 years. The companies involved include nickel miner Vale Indonesia, gold miner PT Nusa Hamahera Mineral, and others, with some already in talks with the government about their plans. The divestments are expected to start before October this year, according to Vale Indonesia's CEO.

site_title: No bodies, only small remains recovered from Ethiopia Airlines crash site
summary: Ethiopian Airlines flight 302, which crashed on Sunday after takeoff from Addis Ababa, killing all 157 people on board, has left only small, fragmented remains at the crash site. The airline's spokesman stated that no bodies will be recovered due to the severity of the impact. The cause of the crash remains unexplained.

site_title: Fed bars 2 ex-Goldman executives in 1MDB scandal
summary: The Federal Reserve barred two former Goldman Sachs executives, Tim Leissner and Roger Ng, from working in the banking industry due to their roles in a multibillion-dollar 1MDB scandal. Leissner pleaded guilty and forfeited $44 million, while Ng is charged with money laundering and bribery. Goldman helped the Malaysian fund sell $6 billion of debt, with at least $2.7 billion allegedly going to fuel lavish lifestyles of those close to former Malaysian prime minister Jho Low. The Fed also fined Leissner $1.4 million.

site_title: 'Beehive' housing opens in Barcelona on the sly
summary: A Spanish start-up company, Haibu, has opened a "beehive"-style housing project in Barcelona without a permit from city authorities. The project features 20 tiny living pods, each around 2.4 square meters, and is marketed as affordable housing with a monthly rent of 200 euros. However, the city's left-wing government has deemed the project unfit for humans and violates local building laws. The project's promoters argue it is a solution to Barcelona's affordable housing shortage, but critics say it is a form of "slum" housing that lacks dignity.

site_title: British panel calls for stricter antitrust rules on tech giants
summary: A British government report calls for stricter antitrust rules on tech giants, citing concerns over reduced consumer choice and stifled innovation. The report recommends overhauling Britain's antitrust policies to address the growing power of technology companies, particularly in the areas of acquisitions and data control. This comes as other countries, including the European Union, India, and the US, also scrutinize the industry for antitrust violations and regulation. The report's lead author, Jason Furman, says the current lack of competition is a pressing economic policy question, and stricter rules are needed to ensure new rivals can emerge.

site_title: Condo, HDB rents stagnate in Feb as leasing volumes drop
summary: Singapore's condo and HDB rental markets stagnated in February, with leasing volumes dropping by double digits, according to SRX flash estimates. Rents for non-landed private properties remained unchanged month-on-month, while HDB rents also remained stable. Year-on-year, HDB rents fell 0.3% and are 15.3% off their peak in August 2013. The drop in leasing volumes may be seasonal, with January renewals potentially contributing to the decline.

site_title: Stop the Brexit 'circus', pleads UK business
summary: UK business leaders urge politicians to avoid a "no deal" Brexit, citing the potential damage to jobs and livelihoods. The Confederation of British Industry and the British Chambers of Commerce call for the government to extend the Article 50 deadline, allowing sufficient time for an acceptable deal. The business community expresses frustration with the ongoing political impasse and warns of the consequences of a messy exit on March 29.

site_title: Latest rejection of May's Brexit deal opens up several scenarios
summary: Theresa May's Brexit deal has been rejected again, leaving uncertainty over the UK's exit from the EU. With a no-deal exit likely to be thrown out, the possibility of an extension or a second referendum is back on the table. The UK's economic woes continue, with the economy shrinking for the second month in a row, adding to the pressure on Labour leader Keir Starmer.

site_title: China likely to boost pork imports; spurs rally in US hog futures
summary: China's pork prices surged 12% since March 8, reaching the highest in 23 months, amid African swine fever outbreaks, prompting investors to bet on a supply squeeze. This has lifted US hog futures, signaling a potential boost in Chinese pork imports.

site_title: China offers to help Venezuela restore power after vast blackout
summary: China has offered to help Venezuela restore its power grid after a week-long blackout, which is the country's worst in history. The blackout, which has left millions without electricity and water, has exacerbated Venezuela's economic crisis. President Nicolas Maduro's US-backed rival, Juan Guaido, has accused Maduro's government of sabotage and has received support from the US and 50 other countries. China's assistance includes technical support and equipment to restore the power system, and the country is "very concerned" about reports of a cyber attack.

site_title: The challenge of monetary policy independence
summary: The US Federal Reserve has signaled a more relaxed stance on monetary policy, boosting emerging-market currencies and stock markets despite concerns about economic slowdowns and trade wars. This shift has provided a much-needed breather for Latin American countries, where markets had anticipated tighter monetary policy. With the Fed's indications of a wait-and-see approach, central banks in Chile, Peru, and Mexico are now considering withdrawing monetary stimulus, offering a welcome reprieve to the region.

site_title: Claim against KOP In Batam court fails
summary: A court claim against KOP In Batam has failed, with the court ruling in favor of the property developer. A statement of claim filed by Dominic Andrla in 2017 to cancel a lease and unit management agreement for two KOP units was rejected. As a result, Dominic Andrla is ordered to pay all costs incurred by the court.

site_title: Contrarian chefs' backstories
summary: Singaporean chef Jimmy Lim opened a high-end restaurant serving Singaporean food in Taiwan, despite a gamble. After struggling, he and his wife are making a comeback into the restaurant scene with a profitable pizza venture. Contrarian chefs Rishi Naleendra and Freddie Lee, who gave up Michelin stars and a French bistro, respectively, are now exploring new opportunities. Meanwhile, entrepreneur Carolyn Kan is celebrating 10 years of her successful jewelry business after leaving a corporate job. The chefs and Kan share their personal stories, revealing what drives them and their plans for the future.

site_title: Aussie dollar retreats again on concerns over economy
summary: The Australian dollar fell half a percent to US$0.70495 due to a slump in consumer confidence, which triggered concerns about a slowing economy. The measure of Australian consumer confidence hit its lowest in over a year in March, adding to recent signs of economic weakness. The Aussie's decline was largely attributed to a slowdown in consumer spending and a property market. The New Zealand dollar also fell 0.3% to US$0.6838, following a similar trend.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks snap two-day win streak
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended lower on Wednesday, snapping a two-day winning streak, amid uncertainty over the China-US trade talks. The Hang Seng Index declined 0.39%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices fell 1.09% and 2.32% respectively. Investors await fresh cues from the ongoing trade talks, which have impacted the region's markets.

site_title: Co-working space The Great Room to open fourth Singapore location at Raffles Hotel
summary: The Great Room, a Singapore-based co-working space, is opening its fourth location at Raffles Hotel Singapore. The 15,000 sq ft space will offer flexible workspaces to multinational corporations, corporates, and entrepreneurs. This will be the first co-working space integrated in a six-star hotel. The co-founder and CEO, Jaelle Ang, stated that the vision of an all-day journey of work, live, and play aligns with the hotel's restoration. The move aligns with recent calls for local companies to expand abroad and reflects the escalating demand for flexible co-working spaces.

site_title: UK must convince 'every EU state' on Brexit delay: Dutch minister
summary: The Dutch foreign minister, Stef Blok, warned that Britain must convince "each and every" EU state to grant a Brexit delay. The Netherlands has stepped up preparations for a "no deal" Brexit, with 500 extra customs staff recruited at the Vlaardingen port. EU leaders will consider a delay request only if Britain provides a clear goal for the extension, according to Blok. The Dutch government regrets the British parliament's rejection of the withdrawal deal, and EU negotiator Michel Barnier has also emphasized the need for a plan from Britain before deciding on a delay.

site_title: Top cardinal gets six years jail for 'appalling' choirboy abuse
summary: Cardinal George Pell, a former Vatican official, was sentenced to six years in prison for the "appalling" sexual abuse of two choirboys in 1996-1997. Judge Peter Kidd described Pell's actions as "brazen" and "forceful" and noted that the cardinal's "significant history of cardiac problems" may impact his eligibility for parole in 2022. Pell, who maintains his innocence, will appeal the sentence and is the most senior clergy member to be convicted of historical child sex abuse.

site_title: Singapore shares drop 0.5% on Wednesday as Brexit issues and trade deal caution weighs
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 0.52% on Wednesday to close at 3,195.59, weighed down by Brexit concerns and trade deal uncertainty. The index saw 817.48 million securities traded worth S$1.05 billion, with decliners outnumbering advancers 221 to 176. Investors remained cautious ahead of US-China trade negotiations and the UK parliamentary vote on Brexit.

site_title: US missile defence budget cut as North Korea pushes ahead
summary: US President Donald Trump has proposed cutting the missile defence budget as North Korea pushes ahead with its ballistic missile testing programme. The proposed cut delays the expansion of the Ground-based Midcourse Defense system by two years due to a redesign delay of the "kill vehicle" system. The US Missile Defence Agency will now focus on fielding the existing system instead of expanding it. This development comes at a time when North Korea's missile testing programme appears to be resuming. The delayed expansion may impact the US's ability to deter North Korea's aggression.

site_title: Generous 'Robin Hood' figure mystifies Spanish village
summary: Residents of Villarramiel, a small Spanish village, have been receiving anonymous envelopes containing up to 100 euros in cash, with some messages including the recipient's name and a heart. The mysterious benefactor has been dubbed the "Robin Hood of Villarramiel" by local news. Mayor Nuria Simon said the recipients include a widow, couples with small children, and elderly couples, with no apparent link between them. No police investigation has been opened as no offense has been committed, leaving the villagers bewildered and expectant about the identity of the donor.

site_title: Vibrant Group back in black for Q3
summary: Vibrant Group reported a net profit of S$3.9 million for its fiscal third quarter, up from a net loss of S$664,000 in the same period last year. Revenues increased 13% year-on-year to S$51.7 million, driven by the completion of the Master-Riviera project and a revaluation gain on a Chinese development. Earnings per share rose to 0.56 Singapore cents, compared to a loss of 0.10 Singapore cents the previous year.

site_title: Singapore, US regulators agree on mutual recognition of derivatives trading venues
summary: Singapore and US regulators have agreed to mutually recognise certain derivatives trading venues, allowing participants from either market to trade most over-the-counter derivatives on the same platforms. The agreement, announced on March 13, 2019, exempts derivatives trading venues regulated by the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission from Singapore's requirements, while Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore will not require US facilities to register. The move aims to improve cross-border market efficiency and resilience, and provides access to deeper pools of liquidity for market participants.

site_title: Production bottlenecks to hobble Adidas in 2019
summary: German sports apparel company Adidas reported a 45% year-on-year increase in net profit to €1.7 billion in 2018, driven by a 3% revenue increase to €21.9 billion. However, the company expects lower earnings this year due to production bottlenecks, particularly in the US, where supply chain shortages and manufacturing capacity issues will impact sales. Adidas forecasts a 10-14% increase in net profit for 2019, with Asia expected to drive sales growth and Europe to see a slight increase.

site_title: US construction spending posts biggest increase in nine months
summary: US construction spending surged 1.3% in January, the largest increase in nine months, boosted by a 4.9% rise in public construction projects. This followed a revised 0.8% drop in December and exceeded economists' forecasts. Public construction projects reached an eight-year high, while private construction projects rose 0.2% and private residential projects fell 0.3%. The increase could boost economic growth estimates for the first quarter, despite the housing market being weighed down by higher mortgage rates and labor shortages.

site_title: China Environment unit may be wound up
summary: China Environment unit may be wound up as a result of a Chinese court ruling on a civil suit brought by Bank of China Longyan against its subsidiary Fujian Dongyuan Environmental Protection Co Ltd. Land use rights and property assets of Anhui Dongyuan Environmental Protection Co Ltd were auctioned off for 60.6 million yuan. China Environment expects Fujian Dongyuan to be unable to repay outstanding balance, potentially leading to involuntary winding up. The company will await Bank of China Longyan's claim on the balance owing to it.

site_title: Landmark Australian ruling could spark land compensation claims
summary: The Australian High Court ruled that Aboriginal owners stripped of land rights should be compensated for "spiritual harm" due to government actions disconnecting them from their lands. The Ngaliwurru and Nungali peoples in the Northern Territory are entitled to compensation for being disconnected from their lands, including Aus$1.3 million for "cultural loss." The ruling could spark a slew of cases nationwide, with potential costs exceeding Aus$1 billion, and has implications for native title holders across Australia.

site_title: UK slashes 2019 economic growth forecast
summary: The UK has slashed its 2019 economic growth forecast to 1.2% from 1.6% in October, citing the "cloud of uncertainty" surrounding Brexit. Finance Minister Philip Hammond said lifting this uncertainty is parliament's "most urgent task." Analysts expect a delay in the Brexit departure date, following the rejection of the country's draft divorce agreement with Brussels. The UK economy is also expected to grow by 1.4% in 2020, unchanged from the October forecast. The downgrade reflects the impact of China's slowdown and trade war tensions on the economy.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Private sector economists have lowered Singapore's 2019 growth forecast to 2.5% due to a quarterly survey by the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Singapore ranked high in Mercer's quality of living survey, topping Asia in quality of living and personal safety. Insurtech startup CXA Group raised US$25m and expects to break even next year. The US is seen as a key partner in growth, with US Ambassador Vivian Balakrishnan praising the US's commitment to Singapore and Southeast Asia. Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.5% on Wednesday due to Brexit and trade deal concerns.

site_title: Europe: London stocks fall before UK budget, Brexit vote
summary: London's stock market fell 0.3% to 7,131.23 points ahead of the UK budget and Brexit vote, with the benchmark FTSE 100 index also influenced by the rejection of the Brexit divorce agreement by British MPs for a second time. The House of Commons is expected to vote on a 'no deal' Brexit in two weeks, and finance minister Philip Hammond will update the government's spending and tax plans in the Spring Statement. UK growth forecasts are expected to be downgraded due to Brexit uncertainty and global economic headwinds.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 6.96 points to 1,678.24. The index saw a four billion lots worth RM2.4 billion in trading volume, with 459 losers outnumbering gainers 421-0.

site_title: Motor racing: Mercedes look to burst Ferrari's bubble in Melbourne
summary: Formula One's Australian Grand Prix is set to test the pre-season optimism surrounding Ferrari, with five-time champion Lewis Hamilton and Mercedes seeking to crush the team's hopes. Ferrari, under new management, has arrived in Melbourne with a fast car, and team boss Toto Wolff believes the team will have a proper fight on their hands. German rival Sebastian Vettel aims to start the championship with a win, while 21-year-old Charles Leclerc will be under scrutiny in his debut season. The event marks the beginning of a potential title race between Mercedes and Ferrari.

site_title: US aircraft, equipment sales lift US durable goods in January
summary: US durable goods orders rose 0.4% to $255.3 billion in January, driven by a surge in aircraft sales, despite weakness in other sectors. Orders for autos, electronics, and defense declined, while primary metals sales fell 1.5%. Core capital expenditures rose 0.8%, supporting GDP growth in the first quarter, but economists expect it to be slower than prior quarters. The data, delayed due to the government shutdown, suggests a recovery in business investment, but weakness in the transportation sector and declining capital expenditures may offset this growth.

site_title: US: Wall St rises at open after tame inflation data; Boeing turns higher
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 82.57 points, or 0.32%, to 25,637.23. Boeing rose for the first time in three days following a fatal aircraft crash in Ethiopia. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with the S&P 500 up 8.26 points, or 0.30%, and the Nasdaq up 30.35 points, or 0.40%. The data supported the Federal Reserve's patient stance on future rate hikes.

site_title: LifeBrandz net loss widens to S$599,000 in Q2
summary: LifeBrandz, a lifestyle group, reported a net loss of S$599,000 in Q2, widening 18% from the previous year. Revenue rose 65% to S$1.5 million, mainly due to an increase in food and beverage revenue. Total expenses jumped 50% to S$2.15 million. The company remains cautious on the outlook for the travel and F&B industries and may explore fund-raising exercises to strengthen its cash position. It plans to expand its presence through acquisitions and joint ventures, including a new high-end sushi restaurant in San Francisco.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust, Oxley call for trading halts pending announcements
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust and Oxley Holdings requested trading halts on the Singapore Exchange pending announcements. Keppel Infrastructure Trust's units traded at 48.5 Singapore cents, down 0.5 cents or 1.02% as of 3:36pm. Oxley's last traded price was S$0.32, up one cent or 3.13% as of 4:00pm. The trading halts were requested by trustee-manager Keppel Infrastructure Fund Management and Oxley Holdings, respectively.

site_title: Cathay Pacific made HK$2.35b in 2018
summary: Cathay Pacific reported a net profit of HK$2.35 billion (S$405.6 million) in 2018, ending two consecutive annual losses. The recovery comes despite a data breach that damaged its reputation and could be costly. This marks a significant turnaround for the airline, which has embarked on a massive overhaul. The company's improved financial performance is a positive sign for its future prospects.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares flat at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks remained flat at the opening on Wednesday, following a two-day rally. The Hang Seng Index rose 3.41 points to 28,924.28, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index edged up marginally. Investors took a breather, awaiting further market direction.

site_title: Temasek to buy stake in Danish engineering firm
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore state investor, agreed to buy approximately 30% of Danish engineering firm Haldor Topsoe A/S for around US$1.5 billion. As part of the deal, Temasek will subscribe to secondary shares issued by the Topsoe family, who currently own 100% of the company. The transaction is expected to bring value to Haldor Topsoe through Temasek's global reach and connections in emerging markets, and the company aims to accelerate growth with a long-term intention to list.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,186.18, down 0.8% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday, edging down 0.8% to 3,186.18 as at 1:03pm, with 193 losers outweighing 140 gainers. Total trading volume reached 459.4 million securities worth S$550.5 million.

site_title: Six foreign-controlled miners to start divestments in 'near future' - Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's Energy and Mineral Resources ministry announced that six foreign-controlled miners, including Vale Indonesia and Newcrest Mining's PT Nusa Hamahera Mineral, plan to divest shares "in the near future" to meet regulations requiring a 49% foreign ownership cap within 10 years. The divestments are part of a gradual reduction in foreign ownership, starting after five years of production. site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei down nearly 1% on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index dropped nearly 1% on profit-taking, closing at 21,290.24. The broader Topix index fell 0.84%. Investors disregarded the British Parliament's Brexit deal vote, and global markets continued to rally. US stocks hit fresh records, while Europe saw gains in mining and healthcare shares. Meanwhile, eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in funding, lifting its valuation to over $1 billion.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday due to profit-taking, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.34% and the Topix index down 0.28%. The decline was driven by concerns about business confidence receding following benign US inflation data.

site_title: South Korea steps up fight against pollution, says problem is 'social disaster'
summary: South Korea has passed a set of bills designating air pollution a 'social disaster', allowing the government to access emergency funds to tackle the issue. The bills also mandate air purifiers in schools and remove emissions limits on liquefied petroleum gas vehicles. The move comes as the country struggles with poor air quality, with its exposure to fine particulate matter exceeding the OECD average. The government's reserve funds stand at up to 3 trillion won, which could be used to respond to pollution-related emergencies. The bills are expected to become law in around 15 days.

site_title: Cautious Japan Inc offer smaller wage hikes as economy wobbles
summary: Japanese companies offered smaller wage hikes, averaging 10.7% for Toyota Motor Corp and 1,000 yen for Panasonic Corp, down from last year's increases. The move reflects growing uncertainty about the economy, fueled by a global slowdown, the US-China trade war, and Brexit. As a result, firms are focusing on annual total sum payments and bonuses rather than fixed base salaries. The government's work-style reform aims to curb long work hours and narrow the pay gap between full-time and contract workers, shifting focus away from wage hikes.

site_title: Private sector economists again lower Singapore's 2019 growth forecast: MAS survey
summary: Private sector economists have lowered Singapore's 2019 growth forecast to 2.5% from an earlier prediction of 2.6%, citing trade tensions and a slowdown in China. The forecast falls within the Ministry of Trade and Industry's (MTI) range of 1.5-3.5%. Construction is the only sector to see a surge in positive sentiment, with a growth estimate of 2.1%. Easing of trade tensions with China is seen as a potential upside risk, while trade protectionism and a slowdown in China are major concerns.

site_title: Claremont Hotel back on sale with lower asking price
summary: The Claremont Hotel in Singapore is back on the market with a lower asking price of S$70 million, down from its previous sale price of S$90 million in 2016. The 90-room budget hotel sits on a 4,838 sq ft land area and is zoned for hotel use, making it eligible for foreign buyers. With vacant possession and a one-year sale and leaseback option, the property is expected to attract strong interest from real estate funds, developers, and hotel operators, particularly in the popular tourist destination of Farrer Park.

site_title: Asia: Markets retreat from rally, pound stable after Brexit drop
summary: Asian markets retreated on Wednesday after two days of gains, following the rejection of Theresa May's Brexit deal by MPs, which has sparked uncertainty and a possible referendum. The pound saw stability after sharp losses, with lawmakers set to vote on whether to leave the EU on March 29 without an economic agreement. Analysts suggest the decision could lead to a no-deal exit or an extension to the deadline, adding to global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Japan Jan core machinery orders down 5.4% month-on-month
summary: Japan's core machinery orders fell 5.4% in January from the previous month, exceeding the median estimate of a 1.7% decline. This represents a 2.9% decline compared to the same period last year. The data is considered an indicator of capital spending in the coming six to nine months.

site_title: US private sector is 'indispensable partner' in growth: Vivian Balakrishnan
summary: Minister for Foreign Affairs Vivian Balakrishnan stated that the US private sector is an "indispensable partner" in growth, citing its $242 billion foreign direct investment in Singapore. A recent survey of US companies in Asean found 61% expect Asean markets to become more important to their worldwide revenue over the next two years. Availability of raw materials and regional integration were top reasons for Asean's growing importance, with Singapore's firms citing regional integration as the top reason. However, Balakrishnan also expressed concern over the ongoing US-China trade talks, which could impact Singapore's trade volumes.

site_title: Anchor Resources to issue up to S$10m in convertible notes to repay bonds, fund working capital
summary: Anchor Resources Limited plans to issue up to S$10 million in convertible notes to repay existing bonds and fund working capital. The notes, with a 1% interest rate, will be subscribed by Advance Opportunities Fund and Advance Opportunities Fund I, which have agreed to subscribe for the notes. The company aims to repay outstanding bonds and provide fresh funding for working capital, with net proceeds of approximately S$9.29 million.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Singtel, Thomson Medical, SIIC Environment, China Sunsine, Anchor Resources
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) priced its first Panda bond from Singapore at 3.49% and raised S$404 million, while Singtel's planned investment in Bharti Airtel may trigger a downgrade. Thomson Medical Group and SIIC Environment reported new developments, including a potential collaboration and a signed supplementary agreement. China Sunsine Chemical Holdings and Anchor Resources also made announcements, including a land acquisition and a proposed note issuance.

site_title: Ghosn's Global Auto Alliance restructures, leaving him behind
summary: Nissan, Renault, and Mitsubishi Motors Corp have adopted a new governance structure, separating from Carlos Ghosn, who is no longer involved in the alliance. The new operating board will meet monthly to make operational decisions, aiming to enhance collaboration and compete in the industry's shift to electric and driverless cars. Ghosn remains a director at Nissan and Renault, but his bid to join a Nissan board meeting was rebuffed due to court restrictions on his interactions with the case against him.

site_title: Singapore tops quality of living ranking and personal safety for Asia: Mercer poll
summary: Singapore tops Mercer's Asia-Pacific quality of living ranking, followed by five Japanese cities, Hong Kong, and Seoul. The survey also highlights notable cities in South-east Asia, such as Kuala Lumpur and Bangkok, while Phnom Penh ranks lowest for personal safety. Mercer's regional practice leader, Mario Ferraro, attributes Singapore's success to its forward-thinking policies and sustainable development, making it an attractive destination for foreign talent. The survey, based on 231 cities, was analyzed between September and November 2018 and reflects significant developments in the region.

site_title: Singapore condo and HDB rents stagnant in February; rental volume falls: SRX flash estimates
summary: Singapore's condo and HDB rents remained stagnant in February, with a double-digit drop in rental volume, according to SRX flash estimates. Non-landed private properties and HDB flats saw a 22.1% and 28.5% decline in rental units, respectively. Rents for non-landed private properties remained unchanged month on month, while HDB rents fell 0.3% year on year. The drop is attributed to seasonal factors and landlords' willingness to negotiate lower rents, with the gap between public and private home rentals expected to add downward pressure on HDB rentals.

site_title: StanChart suffers senior private banker exits in Asia as unit earnings sag: sources
summary: Standard Chartered PLC has seen the departure of at least four senior Asia-based private bankers from its unit in recent months, amid growing earnings pressure. The departing staff include Teddy Kwong, Peter Lam, Ray Li, and Sandeep Das, who have left for rival banks or new roles. The bank has declined to comment on the exits, but stated it continues to invest in and hire for its private banking business in 2019. The departures come as the bank faces declining unit earnings.

site_title: Y Ventures appoints Deloitte to independently review internal control lapses
