summary: Y Ventures appoints Deloitte to review internal control lapses, including adjustments to prior years' financial statements. The review will assess the adequacy and effectiveness of internal controls from 2014 to 2018 and investigate circumstances and responsible parties involved in lapses and misstatements. This follows accounting mistakes announced in January that led to restatements of half-year and full-year financials. The independent review was made in consultation with the Singapore Exchange Regulation and the company's sponsor, RHT Capital.

site_title: China investors turning positive towards convertible bonds
summary: China's fixed income investors are shifting towards convertible bonds, driven by the desire for equity-like returns. The market has seen a surge in demand, with issuers raising $13 billion from convertible bonds this year, surpassing initial public offerings. Investors are optimistic about the market, citing a supportive regulator, growth policies, and prospects for a resolution to the trade war with the US. The convertible bond market is expected to continue growing, with an estimated 200 billion yuan in issuance planned by the end of June.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday, STI down 0.26% to 3,203.82
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.26% to 3,203.82 on Wednesday, retreating 8.43 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 61 to 41, with Thomson Medical being the most actively traded counter. The Straits Times Index had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, and investors brushed off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: US$20m settlement reached in Uber driver lawsuit
summary: Uber has agreed to pay US$20 million to settle a lawsuit alleging the ride-share service misclassified drivers as contractors to avoid paying minimum wage and providing benefits. The six-year-old case affects approximately 13,600 drivers in California and Massachusetts. The settlement also requires Uber to make changes, including ending account deactivation for accepting few rides and creating a formal appeals process. The deal does not resolve the classification of gig economy workers, but Uber plans to expand its services to include e-scooters, e-bikes, and robotaxis.

images.alt_text: Uber has agreed to pay US$20 million to settle a lawsuit accusing the ride-share service of classifying drivers as contractors to avoid paying them minimum wage and providing benefits.

site_title: EU warns of no-deal Brexit, says cannot offer more
summary: The European Union warned that a no-deal Brexit is increasingly likely due to the UK parliament's rejection of the Brexit agreement, with senior EU officials stating there is no more they can do to help Prime Minister Theresa May. The EU has set March 29 as the deadline for a no-deal Brexit unless a delay is agreed. EU ambassadors will meet on Wednesday to assess the vote and discuss a potential delay, with Brussels expressing concern that the UK is heading into "uncharted waters."

site_title: New Zealand suspends Boeing 737 Max flights
summary: New Zealand's aviation regulator suspended Boeing 737 Max flights to or from the country following fatal crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia. The decision affects only Fiji Airways, the only airline impacted. The suspension is temporary while authorities monitor the situation and assess safety risks. This move follows similar actions by the European Union and Australia, which have also grounded their Boeing 737 Max fleets.

site_title: Japan eyes 2020 Olympics to retake place on tech podium
summary: Japan is gearing up to showcase its technological innovation at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, aiming to regain its position as a leader in the tech world. The country plans to unveil new products and services, including driverless cars, robots, and ultra-high-definition TV. Japanese companies, such as Panasonic and Toyota, are working on cutting-edge technologies, including facial recognition systems and motion sensor devices. The goal is to demonstrate Japan's capabilities and inspire innovation, following a decline in its technological standing in recent years.

images.alt_text: Driverless cars, robot volunteers and ultra high-definition TV: Japan Inc hopes to use the Tokyo 2020 Olympics to show the world it has regained its touch for innovation and technology.

site_title: Brexit tension sends pound tumbling
summary: The British pound tumbled on Tuesday after Attorney General Geoffrey Cox cast doubt on Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal, citing unchanged legal risk of Britain being "indefinitely" held in the Irish border backstop. Sterling hit a three-week peak overnight but slid to US$1.3005 after Cox's statement, while the euro jumped to 86.55 pence. Despite the volatility, the pound remains the best performing G-10 currency this year, with analysts citing a view that a hard Brexit will be avoided.

site_title: Siemens collaborates with industry partners to develop building technology
summary: Siemens collaborates with industry partners in Singapore to develop innovative building technology solutions ahead of the launch of its new division, Smart Infrastructure. The company has signed a research collaboration agreement with Nanyang Technological University (NTU) Singapore, using machine learning to analyze data from building operations and enhance energy savings. This collaboration is part of Siemens' efforts to develop new technologies and support Singapore's Smart Nation initiative, which aims to make the city a smart and sustainable hub.

site_title: Singapore expected to be on the rise as firms' listing destination outside home market: PwC poll
summary: Singapore is gaining popularity as a listing destination for firms outside their home market, driven by an increasing focus on South-east Asian markets. A PwC survey of 370 executives found that 15% of respondents cited the Singapore Exchange (SGX) as a potential listing destination in 2030, a 4% increase from 2011. The survey highlights SGX's reputation for being a pro-business exchange with a stable political landscape, transparent regulatory environment, and low volatility. Liquidity remains the top priority for companies when choosing a listing location, with valuations and costs also becoming increasingly important.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.19 points to 1,671.09. The market saw 42.74 million lots traded worth RM19.15 million, with gains beating losses 90 to 57. This news is unrelated to the other articles provided, which cover Singapore stock market, mergers and acquisitions, US and EU trade talks, and the tech sector.

site_title: UK needs to meet Facebook, Google competition with new rules: report
summary: The UK government needs to overhaul its competition rules to tackle tech giants like Facebook, Google, and Amazon, increasing consumer choice. A new competition unit and innovation policies are recommended, including giving users control over their data and access to social media platforms' user data. The report aims to boost the UK tech start-up economy, increase predictability for large digital companies, and deliver an economic boost. The government plans to introduce measures to ensure digital markets are competitive later this year.

site_title: Protesters united against Brexit deal, divided over the future
summary: Hundreds of protesters from rival camps gathered outside Britain's parliament, united against the Brexit deal that was overwhelmingly voted down by MPs. The vote raises the possibility of Brexit being indefinitely delayed or the UK leaving the EU without an agreement, dividing the pro-EU and Leave camps. Pro-EU demonstrators chanted "Brexit is dead," while pro-Brexit supporters vowed to continue the fight, citing the need for the UK to leave the EU.

site_title: My SME Story Ep 4: UglyGood
summary: A Singapore SME startup, UglyGood, is creating a circular economy by harvesting food waste from fruit pulp and peel byproducts to produce animal feed and natural agents, diverting waste away from landfills. The episode is part of "My SME Story," a series featuring six Singapore SMEs, and will be available on various platforms from January to April.

site_title: Philippine peso falls after new central bank governor says it is near top end of band
summary: The Philippine peso fell 0.7% to 52.55 against the US dollar after Central Bank Governor Benjamin Diokno said the currency is near the top end of its forecasted band of 52-55 to a dollar. Diokno stated that the central bank won't intervene as long as the currency remains within reasonable bounds, giving room to ease monetary policy and potentially cut the policy rate. This move was seen as supportive for the peso, which is expected to trade between 51.50 and 54.65 per dollar this year.

site_title: China Sunsine unit buying land in China's Shandong to expand production capacity
summary: China Sunsine Chemical Holdings' subsidiary has entered into an investment agreement with Shanxian County to acquire 534,000 sq m of land for an 800 mu plot. The project aims to expand production capacity in rubber chemical products. The investment amount is up to 2.5 billion yuan, with 1.5 billion yuan for property, plant, and equipment. The unit price of the land will be determined by an open tender, and the lease period will be set in due course. The acquisition is funded by internal resources and is not expected to impact the company's financials.

site_title: Top US universities shun cash from Huawei under Trump pressure
summary: Top US universities are cutting ties with Huawei due to pressure from the Trump administration over national security concerns. Princeton, Stanford, Ohio State, and the University of California at Berkeley have all reduced or eliminated research collaborations with the Chinese telecommunications company. The move comes amid federal indictments and accusations of espionage, with the FBI and intelligence agencies briefing Education Department staff on the issue. Despite Huawei's invitations for research collaborations, universities are reevaluating their relationships with the company, citing the need to protect academic freedom and resist pressure from government influence.

site_title: Sibor surge driving mortgage rates up
summary: Mortgage rates in Singapore have surged to a decade-high, with the 3-month Sibor reaching almost 2% and home loan rates increasing by 50% compared to a year ago. The rate hikes are attributed to the rising interest rates in Singapore since 2017. The nation's largest home loan provider, DBS Bank, has raised its home loan rates, with the most popular fixed deposit home rate mortgages increasing by up to 40 basis points. However, experts expect the rate increases to moderate in 2019, with the US Federal Reserve's hike cycle likely to slow down.

site_title: UOB prices Singapore's first Panda bond at 3.49%
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) successfully priced Singapore's first Panda bond at 3.49% in a three-year, two billion yuan offering. The onshore Renminbi bond was subscribed 2.7 times, with 38% placed to China's onshore investors and 62% to international offshore investors. The issue enables UOB to diversify its investor base and promote China's foreign bond market, according to the bank's deputy chairman. The Monetary Authority of Singapore congratulated UOB on being the first Singapore entity to tap the onshore bond market in China, expanding financing channels and strengthening capital markets connectivity.

site_title: US seeks 'way out' of metal tariffs for Canada, Mexico: official
summary: US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer is working with Canadian and Mexican officials to find a compromise on US steel and aluminum tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump in June 2018. The tariffs continue to hit Mexican and Canadian producers despite the updated US-Mexico-Canada Agreement signed in November 2018. Lighthizer is exploring options, including quotas, to ease the tariff burden on North American trading partners while maintaining US industry protections. The goal is to find a "sweet spot" that balances the two interests.

site_title: Malaysia's stock market is Asia's only loser of 2019
summary: Malaysia's stock market is the only loser in Asia for 2019, with the benchmark FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI falling over 1% this year. Despite a new administration's efforts to address corruption and boost purchasing power, investors remain cautious due to weak financial results and a predicted 4.5% economic growth. Finance Minister Lim Guan Eng is urging investors to buy Malaysian assets now, but analysts warn of execution risks and political uncertainty, particularly with the expected handover of power from Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad to Anwar Ibrahim.

site_title: Singapore grounds all Boeing 737 Max planes after Ethiopian Airlines crash
summary: Singapore has grounded all Boeing 737 Max planes, following two fatal accidents involving the aircraft in less than five months. The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) suspended the operation of the Boeing 737 Max and all its variants into and out of Singapore, effective immediately. This decision comes after the Ethiopian Airlines Boeing 737 MAX 8 crash, which killed all 157 people on board, and the Lion Air crash last October, which killed 189 people.

site_title: Beijing scrutinising US$43b pawnshop lending boom
summary: China's government is drafting new rules to regulate the US$43 billion pawnshop lending industry, which has doubled since 2010 and is a part of the country's US$9 trillion shadow banking sector. The rules will target high-interest rates and lack of transparency, with potential minimum capital requirements for pawnshops. This move aims to reduce financial risk and is part of a broader government effort to clean up the industry, which has seen more than half of pawnshop loans backed by real estate and a high overdue loan ratio.

site_title: More nations ban Boeing 737 Max jets after Ethiopia crash
summary: The European Union has closed its airspace to Boeing 737 Max planes following a second deadly accident in five months, with 157 people killed in the latest crash in Ethiopia. The move joins similar actions by other nations, including India, Turkey, and several countries in Asia and Africa, as safety concerns swirl. Boeing shares have tumbled 7% in trading, wiping billions off the company's market value. The US Federal Aviation Authority has not grounded the Max, but ordered design changes.

site_title: Britain in Brexit chaos: parliament crushes May's EU deal again
summary: British lawmakers voted against Prime Minister Theresa May's European Union divorce deal, crushing her last-minute talks with EU chiefs. The 391-242 vote puts the UK in uncharted territory, with options including a no-deal Brexit, delay, snap election, or another referendum. May may try again, but the margin of defeat was smaller than the previous record loss. Lawmakers will vote on a no-deal Brexit on Wednesday, with a possible delay on Thursday, leaving the UK's future uncertain and market leaders warning of potential chaos.

site_title: Bank of England's practices 'years out of date,' say lawmakers
summary: Lawmakers in the UK's Public Accounts Committee have criticized the Bank of England's practices as "years out of date," citing complex job titles, non-compliant staff purchases, and outdated leadership. The committee called for clarity on improving staff diversity, updating working practices, and making better use of the bank's property portfolio. The Bank of England was also accused of failing to enforce its own compliance rules, leading the panel to request a plan by June to address these issues.

site_title: Macron visits Djibouti and Ethiopia in effort to counter China expansion
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron visited Djibouti and Ethiopia, seeking to counter China's expanding presence in the region. Macron announced a new defense deal with Ethiopia and a major transport contract in Kenya, while also promising "respectful" partnerships in the face of growing regional indebtedness to China. Macron described Djibouti as a "historical partner and strategic ally," while China's Belt and Road initiative has seen Beijing lend developing countries to develop infrastructure and ease trade.

site_title: Canada sees no reason to ground Boeing 737 Max 8, ready to act if need be
summary: Canada's Transport Minister Marc Garneau stated that the country has no plans to ground Boeing 737 Max 8 aircraft, but is prepared to "act immediately" if new information emerges indicating a problem. This decision comes after a crash in Ethiopia and another in Indonesia involving the same model. Garneau has cancelled meetings and is consulting with civil aviation experts, but there are no immediate plans to order carriers to stop operating the aircraft. Canada's two main airlines operate 37 737 Max 8 planes.

site_title: Trump, Boeing CEO discuss Ethiopia crash: industry source
summary: President Donald Trump spoke with Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg about the crash of a 737 Max 8 aircraft that killed 157 people, following a tweet by Trump stating "Airplanes are becoming far too complex to fly." Muilenburg assured Trump that the aircraft is safe and reliable. Despite the US Federal Aviation Administration's ongoing investigation, many countries have banned the 737 Max 8, while the EU has closed its airspace to the aircraft. Boeing is working on flight control software enhancements to address a faulty sensor issue.

site_title: LMIRT to buy retail mall in Jakarta for 3.7t rupiah
summary: LMIRT, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, plans to acquire Lippo Mall Puri in West Jakarta for 3.7 trillion rupiah (S$354.7 million), financed with debt and equity. The acquisition aims to boost assets by 19% and increase net lettable area by 12.69%. Vendor PT Mandiri Cipta Gemilang will provide income support, guaranteeing net property income of 348 billion rupiah until 2023, with a potential NPI yield of 9.41%. The deal is conditional on land title segregation and sufficient financing.

site_title: Wells Fargo CEO avoids major stumble at heated congressional hearing
summary: Wells Fargo CEO Tim Sloan navigated a tense congressional hearing without major stumbles, despite criticism from lawmakers over the bank's consumer abuse scandals. The House Financial Services Committee, led by Maxine Waters, pressed Sloan on remediation efforts, personnel changes, and risk management. While some Republicans expressed frustration with the bank's progress, others acknowledged efforts to change. The committee's ranking Republican, Patrick McHenry, vowed bipartisan criticism, but Sloan remained calm and rebuffed claims that Wells Fargo should be broken up. The Federal Reserve may pressure the bank to improve governance and risk management, with regulators expressing disappointment over the bank's performance.

site_title: Oil edges higher on cuts to Saudi exports
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday, supported by Saudi Arabia's plan to cut oil exports in April to below 7 million barrels per day, and the US government's reduced forecast for domestic crude output growth. Brent crude futures rose 9 cents to $66.67 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 8 cents to $56.87 a barrel. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies also agreed to reduce supply by 1.2 million barrels per day for six months, boosting prices.

site_title: More than 800 needy households to receive free Lianhe Zaobao for a year
summary: Singapore's non-profit foundation Ngee Ann Kongsi has partnered with Singapore Press Holdings to provide free Lianhe Zaobao print subscriptions to over 800 needy households for a year, starting from April. The initiative, valued at S$150,000, aims to empower education and inform beneficiaries. The foundation, which funds educational and charitable projects, hopes to provide beneficiaries with access to knowledge in a changing global landscape. The partnership is seen as a model for helping the needy in the community, with the foundation's president stating that it recognizes the importance of being well-informed.

site_title: New York governor calls for permanent 2% property tax cap
summary: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo is calling for a permanent 2% cap on local property taxes, a policy currently set to expire. Cuomo argues that the state can exercise fiscal discipline and survive without a cap. The proposal aims to reduce the average property taxes above the US$10,000 limit, which could pressure homeowners to leave the state for lower-tax areas. Cuomo's budget plan also includes congestion pricing, Internet sales taxes, and a pied-a-terre tax to raise revenue. The state legislature has until April 1 to approve the budget.

site_title: Mahathir weighing shutdown or sale of Malaysia Airlines
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad is studying options for Malaysia Airlines, including shutting it down, selling it off, or refinance. The airline has faced pressure to turn itself around after a RM6 billion investment by sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional Bhd in 2014. Mahathir said shutting down the national airline is a serious matter, but the government will decide soon. The airline has received a strategic plan to compete in the industry, but faces increased pressure to revive its performance after Khazanah swung into a pretax loss last year.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Mahathir says the government will have to make a decision soon regarding the fate of the national carrier.
Prime Minister Mahathir says the government will have to make a decision soon regarding the fate of the national carrier.

site_title: Lack of archival law ensnares Hong Kong's government
summary: Hong Kong's government is facing criticism over its lack of archival law, which has led to issues with document preservation and access. The city's unique position in the world, having no such law, has resulted in problems with safety features, immigration, and police records. A Commission of Inquiry discovered that the Marine Department had decided not to implement safety features on ferries before 2008, and officials couldn't recall who set the policy. The government has now asked the Law Reform Commission to look into the issue, with a consultation paper seeking public views on an archives law. The law should apply to public bodies and include penalties for those who violate it, with preservation and access going hand-in-hand.

site_title: Malaysia PM says release of Indonesian in North Korea case within rules
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said the surprise release of Indonesian woman Siti Aisyah, who was acquitted of assassinating North Korean leader Kim Jong Nam, followed the "rule of law". Aisyah was freed after prosecutors withdrew a murder charge without explanation, amid intense lobbying by Jakarta. The decision sparked anger in Malaysia, with accusations of diplomatic pressure and interference in the justice system. Indonesia's President Joko Widodo expressed relief at Aisyah's release, while Vietnam's government has also requested the release of the other woman, Doan Thi Huong, who remains on trial.

site_title: Murdoch's News Corp wants Australia to break up Google to protect news media, advertising
summary: News Corp Australia has called for an enforced break-up of Google to protect news media and advertising in Australia. The demand, made as part of a government inquiry, suggests Google's dominance in the market has led to "anti-competitive" behavior, harming publishers and the news industry. To address this, News Corp recommends Google's advertising sales unit or Alphabet Inc. must be sold, with a possible divestment involving foreign government agencies and initial regulatory oversight.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Chasing Cars: The Geneva Motor Show
summary: The Money FM podcast "Chasing Cars: The Geneva Motor Show" discusses the latest automotive trends at the Geneva Motor Show. Hosts lament the lack of big engine cars, instead focusing on hybrid and electric vehicles. The conversation highlights the shift towards sustainable mobility and the absence of traditional internal combustion engines. Key topics include the MG ZS Hybrid+, BMW's adrenaline tourism, and the road to EVs.

site_title: London's real estate market stumbles as Brexit kills dealmaking
summary: London's real estate market has slowed significantly due to Brexit uncertainty, with spending on UK offices, malls, and warehouses plummeting 40% in the first two months of the year to £4.3 billion. This has led to reduced sales, delayed leases, and a wait-and-see attitude among investors. Even if a Brexit deal is approved, rents in London's financial district are expected to drop by 4% due to the ongoing turmoil. In contrast, European cities like Berlin have seen record price increases, making them more attractive to global investors.

site_title: Obscure Japanese firm ensures iPhones get slimmer, better
summary: A Japanese firm, Lasertec Corp, has developed equipment that tests glass squares to create stencil templates for chip designs, enabling the production of smaller circuit patterns. This technology, known as extreme ultraviolet lithography, is crucial for the development of slimmer and more powerful iPhones. Lasertec has secured orders for 4 billion yen worth of machines and may see additional sales as major chipmakers ramp up mass production. The company's success may hinge on its monopoly over EUV mask testing, a critical step in the production process.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Advanced Holdings' shareholders approved the acquisition of a 12.25% minority stake in Agricore Global for S$15 million at an extraordinary general meeting. The acquisition will be completed once the conditions are met.

site_title: Europe: Shares end a choppy Brexit-led session with a whimper
summary: European shares ended a choppy session flat on Tuesday, with the pan-European index down 0.04% after hopes for British Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit plans faded. The British FTSE 100 rose 0.3% as a retreating pound boosted big exporters. Individual stocks saw mixed results, with French firm Spie jumping 8.6% and German carmaker Volkswagen falling 1.8%. The fourth-quarter earnings season has been underwhelming, with analysts cutting earnings growth expectations for 2019 from 9% to 5%.

site_title: To rebalance or not to rebalance
summary: The traditional risk-reward trade-off between bonds and equities has shifted, with correlations between the two asset classes rising sharply over the past decade. Historically, bonds and equities were negatively correlated, but the gap has narrowed, making it less effective to shift from equities to bonds as a defense against a bad equity market. Investors must consider a more diverse set of asset classes, including alternative strategies, fixed income, and real assets, to achieve optimal portfolio diversification. The changing market dynamics, driven by factors such as technological advancements and global events, require a re-evaluation of traditional portfolio construction processes.

site_title: US: Crisis weighs on Dow but most stocks advance
summary: US stocks ended the day in a mixed finish, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.3% due to Boeing's 6.1% decline, its largest drop since Friday. The broader S&P 500 and tech-heavy Nasdaq, however, gained 0.3% and 0.4%, respectively. The market was boosted by benign US inflation data and a lack of impact from the British parliament's rejection of Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal. Despite Boeing's struggles, market analysts say the positive momentum is starting to re-emerge.

site_title: Early birds catch The Hummingbird Project
summary: Eighty lucky subscribers to The Business Times can win a pair of tickets to the tech thriller film "The Hummingbird Project" through a contest via the SPH Rewards app. The film, directed by Kim Nguyen, follows two cousins who attempt to build a fibre-optic cable line to gain an edge in high-frequency trading. They face challenges from their manipulative ex-boss and geographic obstacles, all while racing against time to beat their competitors. The contest is open until March 19 at 7pm at Shaw Lido.

site_title: US dollar claws back losses as Brexit nerves hurt pound
summary: The US dollar recovered from earlier losses on Tuesday as Brexit nerves hurt the pound, causing it to decline 0.8% to $1.3050. British Attorney General Geoffrey Cox's legal advice stated that Britain could not unilaterally withdraw from the Irish border backstop, dampening hopes for a Brexit breakthrough. This reversal of earlier market gains led to a decline in sterling and US bond yields, while emerging markets remained positive.

site_title: 9 concerts in 7 days at the world's most famous concert hall
summary: Carnegie Hall in New York recently hosted 9 concerts in 7 days, showcasing the classical field in the 21st century. The renowned concert space is considered one of the world's most famous, effectively presenting the vast sprawl of classical music to audiences.

site_title: Uber hires more IPO underwriters as it prepares to go public: sources
summary: Uber hires more investment banks, including Bank of America, Barclays, Citigroup, and Deutsche Bank, to its IPO underwriting lineup, aiming to go public as early as the first half of 2019. The company has added over half a dozen banks to its syndicate, supporting Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, which Uber hired late last year to lead its public offering. This move comes as rival Lyft is racing to list in the stock market at the end of March. Uber's IPO could be valued at up to $120 billion, according to bankers.

site_title: Kim Jong Un has more to lose if he tests missile
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un appears to be preparing to launch a missile or satellite, contradicting his efforts to reduce tensions with the US. Satellite images show North Korea rebuilding a long-range rocket site, fueling speculation that he is bluffing. This move could derail the goodwill from past year's summit with US President Donald Trump, who was seeking sanctions relief and disarmament steps in exchange for concessions.

site_title: Keeping keen eye out for business ventures
summary: Singapore firms must identify viable business opportunities to start or reposition existing operations. A study by the Nanyang Business School found that entrepreneurs identify potential opportunities by looking inwards (market trends), outwards (industry analysis), and beyond (global market shifts). The study suggests that companies can develop a viable business model by leveraging these methods, increasing entrepreneurial activity and innovation.

site_title: US core inflation unexpectedly cools on weaker car, drug prices
summary: US core inflation unexpectedly cooled in February, with the core consumer price index rising 0.1% from the prior month and 2.1% from a year earlier. Falling car and prescription drug prices contributed to the easing of inflation. This data supports the Federal Reserve's plan to remain patient about raising interest rates, giving policymakers more room to adjust their monetary policy.

site_title: Apple says 'It's showtime' on March 25 with TV service announcement expected
summary: Apple is set to announce its TV streaming service on March 25, targeting a launch in April, in an effort to rival Netflix and Amazon's Prime Video. The event, held at the Steve Jobs Theater, is expected to reveal the service's details and pricing. Apple's move comes as the company aims to expand its presence in the streaming market, with sources indicating the service will include a subscription TV component.

site_title: 139 Cecil Street up for sale again after revamp
summary: CBRE and JLL announced that 139 Cecil Street, formerly known as Cecil House, is up for sale via an expression of interest exercise after an 18-month revamp. The building, now with 16 floors, features a restaurant on the ground floor and a pool on the roof terrace. The revamp increased the property's value and is expected to attract potential buyers.

site_title: Lippo Karawaci unveils US$1b funding plan, new management team
summary: Indonesian real estate developer Lippo Karawaci has secured US$1.01 billion in funding to pare debt and implement a transformation program. A new management team, led by John Riady as CEO, will focus on the company's core competencies in urban housing, lifestyle malls, and healthcare. The funds will be used to sharpen the company's focus and improve its financial position.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices up 0.5% in Feb from Jan: SRX
summary: Singapore condo resale prices increased 0.5% in February from January, marking the largest price increase since July 2018. This follows two consecutive months of cooling in December and January. Year-on-year prices rose 4.6% compared to February 2018, indicating a rebound in the market.

site_title: Opec sits down to dinner with shale adversaries in Texas
summary: OPEC Secretary General Mohammad Barkindo met with senior shale oil executives in Houston, marking the third consecutive year of talks between rival producers. The dinner, held on the sidelines of the CERAWeek conference, aimed to discuss industry issues and challenges. The gathering reflects the shifting balance of power in global energy markets, with the US increasingly displacing Middle Eastern producers. The meeting was described as "friendly" and focused on current industry issues.

site_title: Traders now pay close attention as farmers become live-streaming stars
summary: Traders in China are turning to live-streaming apps to predict grain prices, as commodity production and stockpiling remain unclear. Farmers share footage of their fields and supply-demand situations, which traders analyze for clues. This phenomenon is seen in rural areas, where farmers film trucks loading crops, and traders watch from locations thousands of kilometers away. The practice has gained traction, with traders using the information to make informed decisions in the market.

site_title: AEW sells Rivervale Mall for S$230m to SC Capital Partners
summary: US-based property fund manager AEW has sold Rivervale Mall in Sengkang, Singapore, for S$230 million to SC Capital Partners. The sale price reflects a net yield of slightly over 4% and translates to S$2,833 per square foot. AEW acquired the mall in 2015 for S$190.5 million and undertook renovation works, increasing the share of food and beverage tenants to 30%. The sale marks AEW's exit from Singapore, leaving it with three remaining assets in the Central Business District.

images.alt_text: AEW bought Rivervale Mall in 2015 for S$190.5 million from CMT and refurbished it in the second half of 2016 The mall is on a site with 99-year leasehold tenure starting Dec 6, 1997.

site_title: SGX shares continue to fall on heavy trading
summary: SGX shares fell 1.6% on heavy trading, closing at S$7.35, amid Hong Kong's plans to introduce MSCI China A Index futures. Citi Research downgraded SGX to "sell" citing potential loss of demand for the SGX's China A50 Index futures, which could curb profits. Credit Suisse and Goldman Sachs also downgraded the counter, while Morgan Stanley maintained its "equal weight" rating.

site_title: Ensuring economic security in the gig economy
summary: The gig economy, characterized by flexible and freelance work arrangements, has transformed the way people earn a living. While it offers opportunities for inclusivity and flexibility, it also poses concerns about economic security, social cohesion, and workers' rights. The debate surrounding the gig economy's impact on workers and society highlights the need for a balance between flexibility and security. Governments, firms, and society must adapt social protection systems to accommodate the changing nature of work, potentially including universal basic income or improved financial support for households with children.

site_title: Pound rallies as May gets new Brexit deal for Parliament vote
summary: The British pound surged 1.1% against the dollar after the UK government secured changes to its Brexit divorce deal, paving the way for a vote in Parliament. The European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker urged the British Parliament to approve the deal. The news boosted sterling, following a 1% gain on Monday. The UK government is now set to hold a vote on the deal, which could mark a significant step forward in resolving the Brexit standoff.

site_title: Amazon, Google Forays into banking seen as threat by RBC's CEO
summary: Royal Bank of Canada's CEO Dave McKay expressed concern over Amazon and Google's foray into banking, seeing it as a threat to traditional banks. McKay stated that tech giants are inserting themselves between banks and customers, earning economic rent from their insights, and are growing in their demands for payment services. McKay aims to build out Royal Bank's services to be a bigger part of customers' lives before they make financial decisions, aiming to regain control and not be beholden to another platform.

site_title: China lawmakers urge easing family planning rules as birth rates plunge
summary: China lawmakers are urging a review of the country's family planning policies, citing a significant decline in births and a rapidly shrinking workforce. The one-child policy, in place since 1978, is being reconsidered amid a rapidly aging population. The relaxation of the policy in 2016 allowed couples to have a second child, but birth rates remain low. Lawmakers argue that radical changes are needed to "liberate fertility" and address the demographic challenges facing the country.

site_title: Google Cloud hires another Oracle veteran for top post
summary: Google Cloud has hired Amit Zavery, a former Oracle executive, to lead its engineering team, specifically the Apigee team. Zavery, who left Oracle last week, will help Google add to its tools platform, focusing on specialized services for big companies. This move follows Google Cloud's CEO Thomas Kurian's strategy to win business from top companies in specific industries. Zavery's portfolio, acquired by Google in 2016, is estimated to generate $2.1 billion in revenue for Oracle during its fiscal 2019.

site_title: Yum China to open KFC outlets at petrol stations
summary: Yum China Holdings, the parent company of KFC, Pizza Hut, and Taco Bell in China, is partnering with state oil giants Sinopec Corp and China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) to open over 100 KFC outlets at petrol stations over the next three years. The move aims to tap new growth areas as China's economy slows. The company is also adapting to changing consumer demands by rolling out value promotions and introducing a new menu with 15% fewer items.

images.alt_text: Joey Wat, CEO of Yum China, which is partnering China's two biggest state oil giants, said: "We're going to open some stores and figure out the economics."

site_title: Singapore property market: developers standing firm for now in supply glut
summary: Singapore's property market remains subdued due to the supply glut, with developers standing firm on prices despite a plethora of new launches. Sales have been slow for recent projects, with some selling only 60 units out of 200 units released. Developers are keen to launch projects quickly to clinch buyers, but may not be able to offer competitive pricing due to high breakeven costs. Commission rates for property agents are increasing, with some developers offering 2-3% commissions to incentivize agents. The market is characterized by a surplus of choice but limited room for bargain hunting.

site_title: The bull market began 10 years ago; why aren't more people celebrating?
summary: The bull market, which began in 2009, has reached a significant milestone, ranking among the greatest stock market rallies in history with a 300% surge in the S&P 500. Despite its impressive performance, many are not celebrating, citing concerns about market volatility and potential downturns. Experts point to factors such as productivity gains, dollar asset diversification, and shifting safe havens as driving the market's rise. As the market continues to climb, investors are advised to remain cautious and focus on long-term wealth creation.

site_title: Sime Darby Plantation looking downstream for growth
summary: Sime Darby Plantation, the world's largest oil palm plantation operator, plans to boost its refining capacity to cut exposure to volatile palm oil prices. The company aims to increase its refining capacity by expanding existing plants and new refineries in key markets India and China. This move is expected to provide consistency in income, as about 80% of its net profit currently comes from its upstream business. The company plans to double its capacity at two refineries and increase its refining capacity to 3.8 million tonnes a year.

site_title: S$200m to be set aside to beef up Singapore's supercomputing capability
summary: Singapore's National Research Foundation (NRF) will set aside S$200 million to upgrade the country's supercomputing capability, network speed, and quality of access. The funds, part of the S$19 billion RIE2020 Plan, will provide 15-20 PetaFLOPS of high-end computing performance. This upgrade aims to support Singapore's national research and education programs, and tap international research platforms. The move is crucial for Singapore's transformation into a Smart Nation, enabling the country to tackle complex challenges more effectively and efficiently.

site_title: Is it time to let Malaysia Airlines fend for itself?
summary: Malaysia's sovereign-wealth fund Khazanah reported its first pre-tax loss since 2005 for 2018, largely due to huge impairments of RM7.3 billion related to Malaysia Airlines. The airline has continued to bleed by RM2.4 billion between 2015 and 2017. Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has said the government is mulling options such as shutting, selling, or refinancing the national carrier. Experts argue that it's time to let the airline fend for itself, citing restructuring fatigue and poor management decisions.

site_title: China shows that all roads lead to Rome
summary: China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) gained significant support with Italy considering an initial framework accord with Beijing. Italian Undersecretary of Economic Development Michele Geraci mentioned Rome's consideration of signing the accord, which could be timed around President Xi Jinping's visit to Italy on March 22-24. This move marks the first time a G7 state has endorsed the $1 trillion US plan, which is part of a global struggle for influence between China and the US. The development has potential significance due to Italy's systemic importance in Europe and its significant debt load.

site_title: Matilda spins magic at Marina Bay Sands
summary: Matilda The Musical, a stage adaptation of Roald Dahl's children's book, has been praised for its humor and charm. The musical, featuring Sofia Poston as the title character, tells the story of a young girl who lives in a house where she's regarded as a pariah by her parents. Despite the hype, the reviewer finds the musical to be a genuine delight, with Poston's performance bringing the character to life. The show's charm comes from its portrayal of Matilda's struggles and her determination to find her place in the world.

site_title: Singtel close to ratings downgrade trigger: S&P
summary: Singtel's credit rating is at risk of downgrade due to operational weakness, according to Standard & Poor's. The telco's earnings ratio has shown softer performance in Singapore and Australia, bringing it closer to the ratings threshold. Despite maintaining its "A+" rating and "stable" outlook, S&P warned that Singtel's struggles could lead to a downgrade. The company's long-term rating is currently at "A+" with a stable outlook.

images.alt_text: S&P analysts have now called Singtel's operating performance "slightly weaker than we expected", which they say thins the buffer room that Singtel needs to keep its rating.

site_title: Trump: Today's airplanes 'too complex to fly'
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that modern airplanes are "too complex to fly," suggesting that pilots should be replaced with "computer scientists from MIT." This comes after two deadly crashes of Boeing's 737 MAX 8, resulting in 346 fatalities. Trump's comments follow his criticism of the complexity of various products, which he believes often prioritize innovation over simplicity.

site_title: GGV Capital's Jenny Lee to speak at forum of Cutting Edge thought leaders
summary: GGV Capital's managing partner Jenny Lee will speak at a forum of cutting-edge thought leaders. Lee, who has backed successful Chinese tech firms like Alibaba, Didi Chuxing, and Xiaomi, will share her insights on venture investments. GGV Capital manages $6.2 billion across 13 funds and has backed 52 "unicorns." Lee's speech is part of a series of events featuring prominent figures in the tech industry.

site_title: US aviation authority says no update on Boeing, probe continues
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has not made any decisions on the Boeing 737 MAX 8 aircraft despite countries grounding the plane and airlines pulling it from service. The FAA is continuing its investigation into the Ethiopian crash that killed 157 people, with no updates so far. The agency will make decisions on further steps based on the evidence. Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg has expressed confidence in the plane's safety, but the FAA has ordered Boeing to update its manual and training requirements and complete "flight control enhancements" to reduce reliance on pilot procedures.

site_title: Japan firms and unions wary of wage hike
summary: Japanese firms and unions are set to offer smaller pay increases, around 1.5-2%, due to a sputtering economy. This marks a departure from the past five years when major firms raised wages above 2% in an effort to combat deflation. The move is seen as a response to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's pressure on businesses to boost pay. The decision may temper hopes that domestic consumption will offset external risks to growth.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) maintains a "Buy" rating with a price target of S$1.95. The company is proactively engaging tenants, particularly for leases expiring in 2019 and 2020. CCT is also exploring asset enhancement initiatives for its HSBC Building, which will help mitigate space shortages. The company has limited capital management plans for this year, but is open to convertible bonds. CCT is focusing on maintaining revenue and dividend visibility, and is cautious about the growth of co-working spaces.

site_title: VW beats forecasts in 2018, still marked by diesel fallout
summary: Volkswagen reported a 6.0% year-on-year increase in profits to 12.15 billion euros, beating analyst forecasts despite facing dieselgate emissions scandal and new pollution tests. Revenues grew 2.7% to 235.8 billion euros, with operating profit adding 1.0%. The company incurred 3.2 billion euros in special items related to "dieselgate" costs, with a total of 29 billion euros spent since 2015. VW aims to sell 22 million electric cars by 2028 and increase electric vehicle share in its fleet to 40% by 2030.

site_title: Food for thought on grounding of Costa Concordia
summary: A lecture by retired ship's master Captain Michael Lloyd highlighted the contributory causes of the 2012 Costa Concordia disaster, which resulted in 32 deaths. The ship collided with a submerged rock, causing a 50-meter gash in its hull, and partially capsized. Captain Francesco Schettino was found guilty of manslaughter and sentenced to 16 years in jail. Lloyd criticized the actions of the captain, crew, shore-based management, and international regulations, as well as the ship's preparedness and emergency equipment. The incident was attributed to a combination of factors, rather than a single cause.

site_title: Renault, Nissan, Mitsubishi unveil new joint board
summary: Renault, Nissan, and Mitsubishi Motors unveiled a new joint board, replacing previous bodies, as they seek to revitalize their alliance after Carlos Ghosn's downfall. The new board will be headed by Renault chairman Jean-Dominique Senard, marking a "new start" for the three-way alliance. The Japanese firm has outperformed Renault recently, leading to speculation about a shift in dominance within the alliance. The move comes as the alliance seeks to plot a future after Ghosn's departure, who is credited with creating the three-way alliance that now outsells rival groups.

site_title: US: Wall Street ekes out gains at open after inflation data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq gaining 0.15% and 0.18% respectively, driven by benign February inflation data supporting the Federal Reserve's patient approach to rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.20% to 25,600.30, pressured by Boeing's second day of losses.

site_title: ECB policymakers to tailor new loans to reduce demand - sources
summary: European Central Bank policymakers are considering tailoring a new loan facility to reduce banks' reliance on central bank cash. The facility, aimed at curbing appetite, will have a rate set at a premium of 25 basis points above the ECB's main refinancing rate, currently at zero. The discussion is ongoing, with some policymakers pushing for more favorable terms to support lenders, while others consider a lower rate to reduce banks' addiction to ECB funding. The ECB aims to delay a rate hike and provide more multi-year loans to prop up the fragile economy.

site_title: EU adds 10 countries, including UAE, to tax blacklist
summary: The European Union has added 10 countries to its tax haven blacklist, including the United Arab Emirates, due to concerns over tax evasion by multinationals and the rich. The list now includes 15 countries, with seven being moved back from a grey list due to lack of reform commitments. The UAE's addition was opposed by Italy, but the country's finance minister expressed confidence that new legislation would resolve the issue. The move aims to "name and shame" countries into better tax policies, following the Panama Papers and LuxLeaks scandals.

site_title: Europe: Shares jump; British stocks drop ahead of Brexit vote
summary: European shares rose 0.5% on Tuesday, led by banks and basic resources shares, following a strong Asian market session. UK shares fell, with the FTSE 100 declining, as investors await a vote on a new Brexit deal. The deal was agreed upon by Prime Minister Theresa May and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, but investors remain skeptical about its approval.

site_title: Financial advisers get 1-year reprieve from zero sales fees
summary: Financial advisers in Singapore will not face a one-year reduction in sales fees under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS), as previously planned. The move, which aimed to cap fees at 0.25% per annum, has been deferred by one year. This reprieve affects about 20,000 financial advisers who focus on selling investment-linked insurance policies and unit trusts under the CPFIS. The delay is seen as a relief to the industry, allowing advisers to adapt to the new fee structure.

site_title: Meituan shows pragmatism is a dish best served hot
summary: Meituan, a Chinese food delivery and hotel booking company, posted fourth-quarter revenue of 19.8 billion yuan, beating analyst estimates, despite a nearly tripled operating loss of 11.1 billion yuan. As a public company, Meituan is shifting focus from expansion to tightening margins and boosting the bottom line. The company's decision to exit the bike-rental business allows it to concentrate on its core battle against ele.me, a delivery service backed by Alibaba. Meituan's pragmatism in cutting losses may pay off as it prioritizes profitability.

site_title: EU sets out 10-point plan to balance economic ties with China
summary: The European Commission unveiled a 10-point plan to balance economic ties with China, urging EU leaders to curb Chinese state-owned enterprises and increase cyber-security measures. The plan aims to promote a more reciprocal economic relationship, protect EU industry, and address concerns over market distortions and technology transfer. Key proposals include reforming World Trade Organization rules, concluding a deal on investment rules by 2020, and adapting EU law to limit state-owned enterprise influence. The plan will be discussed at the EU's next summit meeting on March 21-22.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore has suspended all Boeing 737 Max flights due to two fatal accidents in under five months. The country's Civil Aviation Authority also approved a US$1.01 billion funding plan for Lippo Karawaci, while retail sales rose 7.6% in January. The National Research Foundation has allocated S$200 million to upgrade Singapore's supercomputing capability. Meanwhile, the Straits Times Index rose 0.7% on Tuesday, driven by gains in the Singapore shares market.

site_title: EU parliament lifts far-right founder Le Pen's immunity
summary: The European Parliament voted to lift the immunity of far-right founder Jean-Marie Le Pen, allowing France to investigate claims he improperly spent EU funds. The charges include breach of trust and complicity in breach of trust over salaries paid to his staff. Le Pen, 90, was absent from the proceedings, while his estranged daughter Marine, who now leads the renamed National Rally, has already been charged in the case. MEPs also voted to lift the immunity of Dominique Bilde, a fellow National Rally member implicated in the same case.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 6.65 points to 1,671.28. The index saw a significant volume of 3 billion lots worth RM2 billion, with 523 gainers outnumbering 346 losers.

site_title: Japanese Emperor's abdication ceremonies begin
summary: Japanese Emperor Naruhito's abdication ceremonies began on March 12, 2019, with the Emperor announcing his April 30 abdication to ancestors and deities at three sanctuary buildings within the Imperial Palace grounds. The Emperor, in formal court dress, walked slowly while holding a ritual scepter, bowed, and read out his statement in classical Japanese, declaring his intention to abdicate. The Empress, who suffers from a spinal condition, offered prayers at her residence. The abdication marks the end of Naruhito's 30-year reign as emperor.

images.alt_text: The Emperor, in formal court dress traditionally worn by emperors, appeared at a cloister of the Kashikodokoro sanctuary. The building is where the goddess Amaterasu Omikami, the Imperial family's ancestral deity, is worshipped.

site_title: SIIC Environment unit inks supplementary agreement for wastewater treatment project in Shanghai
summary: SIIC Environment's subsidiary, Shanghai Fudan Water Engineering Technology Co, signed a supplementary agreement with the Shanghai Fengxian Water Authority for the Fengxian West Wastewater Treatment Plant project in Shanghai. The project involves upgrading wastewater treatment facilities to increase capacity and quality, with Phase I aiming to increase treated effluent quality from Grade 2 to Grade 1A for 100,000 tonnes per day. The agreement is expected to positively contribute to SIIC Environment's performance, with base rates for the water tariff set to increase.

site_title: Sumitomo buys Nordic parking lot operator Q-Park from KKR
summary: Japanese trading house Sumitomo Corp has agreed to buy Q-Park Nordics, the largest Nordic parking lot operator, from US investment firm KKR for approximately 400 million euros (S$610 million). The deal aims to capitalize on the growth of electric vehicles, with global automakers planning a $300 billion surge in EV and mobility technology spending over the next five to 10 years. Q-Park Nordics operates 370,000 parking lots in Sweden, Finland, and Norway, and has been expanding its services to include EV charging equipment and car sharing options.

site_title: Sweden wants a bank tax that 'really hits' the right targets
summary: Sweden's Finance Minister Magdalena Andersson proposes a bank tax targeting the financial sector, aiming to have a more narrow tax base that "really hits what it's meant to hit." The proposal comes amid a money laundering scandal, including allegations against Swedbank AB, and follows previous failed attempts due to EU competition rules. Andersson's goal is to increase public sympathy for the government's move, which could include a 4 billion kronor tax, and demonstrate the government's commitment to addressing the issue.

site_title: Fight over Pilgrim's Pride chicken claims expands to seven states
summary: The Humane Society of the United States is investigating Pilgrim's Pride Corp. over claims of inhumane treatment of chickens, citing evidence of crowded barns and drowning in scalding hot water. The company has pledged humane treatment but its website has been revised to include language that the Humane Society says is misleading. The group has sent letters to seven state attorneys general, urging them to launch investigations. This comes after a previous complaint filed with the FTC and a lawsuit by consumer advocacy groups, to which Pilgrim's Pride strongly disagreed.

site_title: US consumer prices rise; underlying inflation slowing
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.2% in February, the first increase in four months, but the pace was modest, resulting in the smallest annual gain in nearly 2-1/2 years. The core CPI, excluding volatile food and energy components, edged up 0.1%, the smallest increase since August 2018. Underlying inflation remained benign, supporting the Federal Reserve's "patient" approach to interest rate increases this year.

images.alt_text: US consumer prices rose for the first time in four months in February, but the pace of the increase was modest, resulting in the smallest annual gain in nearly 2-1/2 years.

site_title: Australian shares inch lower as financial stocks drag; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares declined 0.1% on Tuesday, reversing earlier gains, as financial stocks fell amid further scrutiny. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 6,174.80. The decision to walk away from banning trailing commissions for brokers and financial planners is seen as a potential setback for the government's plans to crack down on the financial sector. Meanwhile, resource-based stocks gained due to encouraging comments from the US-China trade talks, with mining stocks rising 0.3% and energy stocks 0.7%.

site_title: Mothercare shares rise on plans to sell educational toy brand
summary: Mothercare Plc plans to sell its educational toy brand ELC to Teal Brands Ltd for £13.5 million (S$24.2 million) to cut debt. The company aims to reduce debt by £17.5 million over the next year. Sales have been declining due to intense competition from supermarkets and online retailers, leading to a 18% drop in sales in the third quarter. The sale will help the company achieve its goal of being debt-free by the end of the year and allow it to focus on its core business.

site_title: Over 800 needy households to receive free Lianhe Zaobao for a year
summary: Singapore Press Holdings' Chinese media group is partnering with Ngee Ann Kongsi to provide free Lianhe Zaobao print subscriptions to over 800 needy households for a year, starting from April, as part of a S$150,000 public education initiative. Beneficiaries include households with elderly people and students, with the goal of empowering them through education and promoting well-informed knowledge. This collaboration aims to support the community's educational and welfare needs, aligning with Ngee Ann Kongsi's mission to promote empowerment through education.

site_title: Chicago Symphony Orchestra members go on strike
summary: Members of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra went on strike after 11 months of labor negotiations failed to reach an agreement. The contract expired at midnight, and a picket line formed in front of the Symphony Center. The strike, which is expected to last at least until Friday, is over the musicians' demands for reduced salary and benefits, as well as a guaranteed pension structure. The orchestra's leadership has deemed the musicians' demands "unreasonable," while the musicians warn that management's plans would harm their ability to attract top talent.

site_title: Britain's Aldermore says costs of managing risk rise on Brexit concerns
summary: Britain's Aldermore bank reported a 20% increase in its statutory profit before tax to £75 million due to rising costs of managing risk exposure, primarily due to concerns over Brexit. The bank's cost of risk rose to 0.23% from 0.15% in the same period last year, attributed to new accounting rules requiring banks to model the impact of Brexit on loan books. This follows similar increases by rival banks Royal Bank of Scotland and HSBC, amid uncertainty over Britain's exit from the European Union.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks jump after Brexit deal changes; won gains
summary: South Korean stocks rose nearly 1% on Tuesday, following the European Commission's agreement to changes in the Brexit deal, which is expected to be voted on in the British Parliament later. The won strengthened, while the benchmark bond fell. The Kospi index ended 19.08 points higher, its biggest daily gain since February 20. Foreigners were net buyers of 0.9 billion won worth of shares, and the won rose 0.35% against its previous close.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend recovery from last week's losses
summary: Hong Kong and mainland Chinese stocks rose on Tuesday, extending a recovery from last week's losses. The Hang Seng Index jumped 1.46% to close at 28,920.87, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 1.10% and 1.68%, respectively. The gains were driven by a pick-up in oil prices. The recovery comes after sharp losses last week, with energy firms benefiting from the oil price increase.

site_title: Singtel gets closer to S&P rating downgrade, agency warns
summary: Singtel is at risk of a downgrade to its "A-" credit rating from Standard & Poor's (S&P) due to concerns over its operating performance, particularly in Singapore and Australia. The telco's planned investment in debt-hit Bharti Airtel, which will add to net debt, also raises concerns. S&P has projected Singtel's funds from operations-to-debt ratio to be near the downgrade trigger of 45% by March 2020, citing a 10.6% drop in third-quarter Ebitda. Singtel's cash flows have been largely unaffected by Bharti Airtel's performance, but S&P warns that the telco's financial headroom is thinning.

site_title: Singapore's O2O platform Shoffr acquired by Microsoft-backed Affle
summary: Singapore-based online-to-offline (O2O) platform Shoffr has been acquired by Microsoft-backed consumer intelligence group Affle for an undisclosed sum. As part of the deal, Shoffr's business, intellectual property rights, and employees were transferred to Affle. Shoffr's platform converts online engagements into in-store transactions by displaying offline retail store inventories online. The acquisition strengthens Affle's consumer and enterprise platforms, allowing brands to track the impact of digital advertising on in-store footfalls and transactions. This is Affle's third acquisition in 12 months, expanding its O2O commerce business.

site_title: Singapore shares end 0.7% higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.65% to 3,212.25 on Tuesday, driven by US-China trade talks progress, UK Prime Minister Theresa May's revised Brexit deal, and an overnight Wall Street rally. Advancers outnumbered decliners 261 to 183. Key gainers included Rex International, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, and DBS Group Holdings, with DBS rising 0.7% to S$25.30. The rally marks a 5-day streak for Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Liposuction, breast augmentation and Botox use up in US
summary: US cosmetic procedures saw a total of 17.7 million in 2018, with minimally invasive procedures outnumbering surgical ones. Breast augmentations remained the most popular, with 300,000 operations, while liposuction procedures decreased by 5% from 2000. Botox use increased, with 7.4 million procedures. These figures are based on data from the American Society of Plastic Surgeons, which reported a two% growth in minimally invasive procedures.

site_title: Volkswagen beats forecasts with 12.1b euros net profit
summary: Volkswagen reported a net profit of 12.1 billion euros in 2018, beating analyst forecasts despite facing charges related to the "dieselgate" emissions scandal. The company booked 3.2 billion euros in charges to cover the fallout, but the result still exceeded expectations. Volkswagen's 2018 profit surpassed its forecast, demonstrating resilience in the face of ongoing challenges.

site_title: UK PM May suffers blow ahead of big Brexit vote
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal faced a major blow ahead of a crucial vote, as Attorney General Geoffrey Cox ruled that risks from the deal's most contentious points remained unchanged. The deal, which aims to address the Irish border issue, could spark economic chaos if Britain crashes out of the EU without a deal on March 29. May secured some concessions, but the pound plummeted after Cox's advice, and some Conservative MPs said they would vote against the deal again. A defeat could lead to a "no-deal" scenario, a vote on requesting a delay, or an extension of the Brexit deadline.

images.alt_text: A grab from a handout video made available by the UK Parliamentary Recording Unit shows British Attorney General Geoffrey Cox reacting during a debate at the House of Commons parliament in London, Britain, 12 March 2019.

site_title: Malaysian palm oil firm Sime Darby Plantation looks downstream for growth
summary: Malaysian palm oil firm Sime Darby Plantation plans to boost its refining capacity to cut exposure to volatile palm oil prices. The company aims to increase its refining capacity by 3.8 million tonnes a year, with a focus on higher-margin products such as specialty oils and fats. Sime Darby expects to generate more consistent income from its downstream business, which currently accounts for only 20% of its net profit. The company plans to expand its refining capacity in key markets like India and China, and increase its production of specialty products.

site_title: Pakistan to offer gas fields to foreign explorers, investors: official
summary: Pakistan plans to auction dozens of onshore gas blocks by the end of 2019 to fill a fuel shortage, with the goal of attracting foreign investors. The country has identified over 30 onshore blocks and is drafting its first shale gas policy. Improving security and a pipeline network are seen as key factors in attracting investors, with Italy's ENI and US oil major Exxon Mobil already exploring offshore gas fields. The government aims to meet current demand with domestic exploration, with estimates suggesting shale gas reserves of over 100 trillion cubic feet.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei jumps nearly 1.8%
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index surged 1.8% on Tuesday, driven by concerns over the US economy receding and news of a revised Brexit deal between Britain and the European Union. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 21,503.69, while the broader Topix index rose 1.52%. Japanese shares gained ground, with carmakers such as Toyota and Honda, and fast-retailing company Fast Retailing, among the winners. Investors welcomed the news, with analysts citing the UK-EU deal as supporting the market.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,226.14, up 1.1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading at 3,226.14, up 1.1% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 34.72 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 217 to 128, with shares of Rex International, Hi-P, AEM Holdings, and City Developments Limited leading the gains. The market saw significant trading volume, with 583.4 million shares exchanged for S$488.7 million.

site_title: Standalone CBD building formerly known as Cecil House up for sale again after revamp
summary: A standalone CBD building at 139 Cecil Street, formerly known as Cecil House, is up for sale via an expression of interest exercise after an 18-month revamp. The building, now featuring 16 floors, a restaurant, and a pool, is fully leased for six years to Campfire Collaborative Spaces. With a net lettable area of 85,000 square feet, it's Campfire's largest site globally. The property, valued at S$210 million, offers investors a brand new, high-quality office building with stable cash flow and rental escalations. The expression of interest closes on April 17.

site_title: US regulators order improvements to Boeing jet after latest crash
summary: US regulators ordered Boeing to make urgent improvements to its 737 Max 8 aircraft after the second deadly crash in a few months, grounding fleets worldwide. The crash in Ethiopia killed 157 people, and investigators recovered the black box flight recorders. The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) ordered Boeing to improve anti-stalling software and the model's maneuvering system, with the deadline set for the end of April. The FAA ruled out grounding the fleet for now, citing ongoing investigations.

images.alt_text: US regulators have ordered Boeing to make urgent improvements to its popular 737 Max 8 aircraft after the second deadly accident in a few months prompted the grounding of fleets around the world.

site_title: Asia: Most markets stocks rise as Brexit deal assurance boosts risk appetite
summary: Southeast Asian stock markets rallied on Tuesday, led by Singapore, after the European Commission agreed to changes in the Brexit deal, boosting appetite for riskier assets. MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index rose 0.3%, with Singapore's index jumping 1% and other markets, such as the Philippines and Vietnam, also gaining ground. The rally was also driven by Wall Street's recovery overnight.

site_title: Yaohan, Casio, Oshin: Edwin Tong reminisces Japan's influence in S'pore as he calls for more bilateral cooperation
summary: Singapore's Senior Minister of State for Law Edwin Tong emphasized Japan's influence in Singapore during a three-day official visit to Japan. He cited Japanese brands like Casio, Fujifilm, and Toyota, as well as Japanese companies' involvement in Singapore's infrastructure projects. Tong urged Japan to increase bilateral cooperation, particularly in infrastructure projects, dispute resolution, and as an Asian base for companies. Japan has invested over $230 billion in Asean infrastructure projects since 2000, and Singapore offers expertise in master planning and dispute resolution services.

site_title: Changi Airport to almost double cargo handling capacity to support strong growth in region
summary: Singapore's Changi Airport aims to nearly double its annual cargo handling capacity to 5.4 million tonnes by 2025, supporting growth in the air cargo sector. The expansion is part of the Changi East development, which includes a new Terminal 5 (T5) expected to open in 2030. The airport's handling capacity will be increased through an industrial zone, which will utilize advanced automation and data-driven systems. The move is driven by the global air cargo market's growth, driven by e-commerce and rising affluence in Asia's middle class.

site_title: Mobike applies to LTA to withdraw from Singapore
summary: Mobike, Singapore's largest bike-sharing operator, has submitted a proposal to the Land Transport Authority (LTA) to withdraw from the market, citing a plan to "rationalize" its operations in South-east Asia. Mobike currently operates 25,000 bikes and has a license to do so. The LTA is assessing the proposal and will work with Mobike to minimize impact on consumers. If approved, Mobike must conduct a proper exit, remove all bicycles, and provide refunds for user deposits and pre-paid credits.

site_title: India fights diabetic blindness with help from artificial intelligence
summary: The Aravind Eye Hospital in Madurai, India, is using artificial intelligence (AI) technology to diagnose diabetic retinopathy, a condition that can cause blindness. The hospital, which treats over 2,000 patients daily, is testing a system developed by Google that can recognize the condition on its own, without the need for trained physicians. The system has shown promising results, performing on par with trained ophthalmologists, and could help expand access to eye care in rural areas of India where few doctors are available.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.8% to 3,216.24
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.8% to 3,216.24 on Tuesday, driven by gains from YZJ Shipbuilding, Venture, and Hi-P. Gainers outnumbered losers 109 to 30, with 42.4 million shares worth S$68.1 million changing hands. This marks the fifth consecutive day of gains, ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.32 points to 1,667.95 at 9am on Tuesday, with gains beating losers 138 to 38. Volume reached 57.67 million lots worth RM23.18 million.

site_title: London's real estate market stutters as Brexit kills dealmaking
summary: London's real estate market has slowed due to Brexit uncertainty, with spending on UK offices, malls, and warehouses plummeting 40% in the first two months of 2019. Investors have cut or stopped purchases of commercial property, and leases have been delayed. Despite this, global investors are pouring money into other European capitals, such as Berlin, where office building yields are now 3%. Experts predict rents in London's main financial district will drop 4% this year due to the Brexit impact, and real-estate funds have seen 1.1 billion pounds pulled out since October.

site_title: Oil tanker and fishing boat collide off Hong Kong
summary: An oil tanker and a fishing boat collided off Hong Kong's Lamma Island, sinking the fishing vessel. Thirteen people on the oil tanker were found safe, but police are still searching for possible missing people from the fishing boat. The incident occurred near a busy shipping channel, but officials reported no leak from the oil tanker, which was not carrying oil cargo. This is the second major incident involving oil tankers in Hong Kong in recent months, following a January incident that killed one person and declared two missing.

site_title: Singapore retail sales rise 7.6% in January
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 7.6% year-on-year in January, rebounding from a 5.8% decline in December. Total sales reached S$4.2 billion, driven by a 20% increase in motor vehicle sales and a 8-10.5% surge in apparel and food retailers. Online retail sales accounted for 4.8% of total sales. While growth is encouraging, doubts remain about the sector's sustainability, with some analysts attributing the January spike to the pre-Chinese New Year festive season.

site_title: Tourism in Osaka, often overshadowed by Tokyo, is catching up
summary: Osaka, Japan's "second city," is gaining popularity among foreign tourists, outpacing Tokyo in growth. Tourism surged five-fold between 2012 and 2017, driven by low-cost carriers and the city's proximity to Kyoto and Nara's World Heritage sites. However, the tourism industry is shifting towards more affordable services like makeup consulting and maternity goods, rather than luxury brands. The city plans to build a large casino resort and host major events, which could boost the economy and cement Osaka's position for longer, more sustainable growth.

site_title: Former Redmart CFO joins fashion e-commerce startup Pomelo
summary: Fashion e-commerce startup Pomelo has appointed Jim Boland, former CFO of Redmart, as its new CFO. Boland will focus on building financial infrastructure to drive profitability and rapid growth. Co-founder Casey Liang will transition to enhance the growth team, which includes performance marketing and business intelligence teams. Boland brings 19 years of experience in e-commerce from roles at Amazon, Dell, and Alibaba-owned Redmart. His appointment follows two recent core hires, including Cathriona Nolan as AVP of creative operations and Vorada Hiransomboon as AVP of buying.

site_title: In Paris pub, British punters drown sorrows with Brexit beer
summary: In a Paris pub, a British-themed establishment, a "Brexit" beer has been brewed by a pro-remain beer maker in Suffolk, England. The beer's hoppy bitterness reflects the maker's feelings towards Brexit. The pub's patrons, mostly British expats, have mixed reactions to the beer, with some finding it a relief to drown their sorrows over the ongoing Brexit uncertainty, which will be decided by British lawmakers on Tuesday.

site_title: Potential Thai Premier touts regulated marijuana to win votes
summary: Tycoon Anutin Charnvirakul, a potential Thai Premier, is campaigning for the legalization of household marijuana cultivation to win votes. His Bhum Jai Thai party would allow households to grow up to six cannabis plants, generating an income of up to US$2,200 per kilogram. Anutin envisions a policy that supplements incomes, given Thailand's growing demand for cannabis products and its existing medical marijuana market. He views the policy as a key component of his party's platform to form a coalition government after the March 24 general election.

site_title: OPEC to break bread with shale competitors for third year
summary: OPEC officials will meet with US shale oil executives for the third consecutive year, aiming to maintain dialogue and address the shift in global energy markets. The dinner gathering, scheduled for Monday night, follows an afternoon meeting of OPEC officials and finance industry leaders. The US has increased oil production, forcing OPEC to cut production to prop up oil prices, which slumped in 2018. The event is seen as an attempt to maintain a balance of power and address the growing influence of US shale producers in global energy markets.

site_title: National Research Foundation to allocate S$200m to upgrade Singapore's supercomputing capability
summary: The National Research Foundation (NRF) in Singapore will allocate S$200 million to upgrade the country's supercomputing capability, network speed, and quality. The funds will support institutions of higher learning and research institutions, enabling the country to meet growing research needs and tap international platforms. The upgrade will provide 15-20 PetaFLOPS of high-end computing performance, allowing Singapore to solve complex national challenges more quickly and effectively, and supporting industries such as Keppel Corporation. The investment is part of the RIE2020 Plan, which sets aside S$19 billion for R&D capabilities from 2016 to 2020.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Coffee with Claressa: Lyn Lee VP diversity & inclusion, Shell
summary: Claressa Monteiro's podcast "Coffee with Claressa" features Lyn Lee, Shell's Vice President of Diversity & Inclusion.
