Lee shares insights on Shell's efforts to attract more women to the energy industry and increase diversity in senior management ranks. As the first Asian female chief diversity and inclusion officer to work outside of Asia for Shell, Lee emphasizes the company's commitment to greater diversity and inclusion. The conversation highlights Shell's initiatives and Lee's personal experiences as a woman in the industry, sparking discussions on the importance of diversity and inclusion in the energy sector.

site_title: Singapore suspends Boeing 737 Max flights after Ethiopian Airlines crash
summary: Singapore's Civil Aviation Authority (CAAS) has temporarily suspended all Boeing 737 Max flights into and out of the country due to the recent fatal accidents involving the aircraft. The suspension, effective from 2pm on March 12, comes after the Ethiopian Airlines crash on Sunday, which killed 157 people, and a Lion Air crash in October that killed 189. Singapore Airlines' SilkAir, which operates six 737 Max aircraft, will be affected, and customers will be contacted for re-accommodation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged in early trading on Tuesday, driven by a rally in oil prices and healthy gains on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.90%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close for the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: Facebook pulls but then restores Warren ads aimed at Big Tech
summary: Facebook initially pulled and then restored ads by Democratic presidential hopeful Elizabeth Warren calling for tech giants to be broken up, citing policy violations. The ads were aimed at Facebook and other US tech giants, with Warren arguing that firms like Amazon, Google, and Facebook hold too much power. The social network later restored the ads, stating they were in the interest of allowing robust debate. Warren unveiled a proposal to break up Big Tech, calling for legislation to designate online companies as "platform utilities" barred from owning participants on their platforms.

site_title: Lippo Karawaci secures US$1b in funding; names new CEO and CFO in transformation plan
summary: Indonesian real estate developer Lippo Karawaci has secured $1.01 billion in funding through a rights issue and asset divestment to "recapitalize" the company and refocus on three core competencies. The funding will be used to deleverage the balance sheet, repay up to $275 million of debt, and invest in existing key projects. New CEO John Riady and CFO Surya Tatang have been appointed, and the company has also made changes to its board of commissioners. The funding programme aims to "unlock shareholder value" and provide sufficient liquidity buffer to fund debt interests and Reit rental obligations.

site_title: Pound extends rally as May secures Brexit deal revision
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May secured a revision to her Brexit deal, securing "legally binding" guarantees with the EU on the Irish border question. This move boosted the pound by 1.5% against the dollar and 2% against the euro, as investors anticipate a possible deal on the UK's exit from the EU. Markets are watching closely as May's plan faces key votes in parliament, with a vote on avoiding a hard Brexit on Wednesday and a possible extension of the exit deadline on Thursday.

images.alt_text: The pound extended its rally in Asian trade after British Prime Minister Theresa May hammered out a revision to her controversial Brexit deal she hopes will be enough to push through parliament.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices up 0.5% in February from January: SRX
summary: Singapore condo resale prices rose 0.5% in February, the first increase in two months, according to SRX Property. This follows a 4.6% year-on-year increase compared to February 2018. The largest price increase since July 2018 was seen in the suburbs, with prices rising 0.5%. Sellers have increased asking prices in recent months, with some buyers opting for primary market options due to affordability concerns. The effects of cooling measures and global economic uncertainty may continue to impact the resale market.

images.alt_text: Singapore condo resale prices increased for the first time in February, up 0.5 per cent from January, after two consecutive months of cooling in December and January, according to monthly figures from real estate portal SRX Property on Tuesday.

site_title: JCG to get new substantial shareholder in S$3.4m share swap for Brand X Lab
summary: JCG Investment Holdings agreed to buy Brand X Lab for S$3.35 million in shares and warrants. Brand X Lab's owner, Tan Suying, will receive 1.86 billion new shares and 310 million warrants, giving her a 14.91% stake in JCG. The acquisition is seen as synergistic with JCG's medical aesthetics and healthcare business. The consideration shares were issued at a 10% discount to JCG's volume-weighted average price, and the warrants can be exercised at any time during the next five years.

site_title: Levi Strauss looks to deepen pockets with IPO
summary: Levi Strauss & Co plans to sell US$587 million worth of shares in an initial public offering (IPO), valuing the company at US$6.17 billion. The company will offer 36.7 million shares priced between US$14 and US$16 per share. The IPO aims to raise funds to enhance its portfolio of brands and expand into a global lifestyle leader. The company's descendants will retain 80% voting control, and Goldman Sachs, J.P. Morgan, and others will handle the IPO.

site_title: China demand for palm oil to pick up: analysts
summary: Malaysia's crude palm oil (CPO) stockpile remained stagnant at 3 million metric tons in February, but is expected to decrease in April as China demand recovers. China's output of soymeal reduced, potentially boosting imports of other edible oils, including CPO. Analysts from DBS and Citi Research predict CPO prices to rebound due to Indonesia's zero export levy on CPO and its biofuel program, as well as the potential for hydrogenated vegetable oils to drive demand.

images.alt_text: A worker unloads palm oil fruit bunches from a lorry inside a palm oil mill in Bahau, Negeri Sembilan, Malaysia.

site_title: Broker's take: Citi Research downgrades SGX to 'sell' as HKSE's China futures contract product may curb profits
summary: Citi Research downgraded Singapore Exchange (SGX) to "sell" due to the potential impact of Hong Kong Stock Exchange's (HKSE) MSCI China A Index futures, which may reduce demand for SGX's China A50 Index futures. The new futures product is expected to launch in months, posing a threat to SGX's derivatives growth and revenue. Despite this, Citi maintained a target price of S$7.00, citing SGX's commitment to a sustainable dividend.

site_title: Australian business conditions slips in February
summary: Australian business conditions eased in February, with the National Australia Bank's index of business conditions slipping to +4, below the long-run average of +6. The volatile measure of business confidence declined to +2, while forward orders and sales fell, and employment remained steady at +5. This data is a blow to the central bank's optimism and adds to views that a rate cut is needed to boost economic growth and inflation, with investors already narrowing the odds on a rate cut this year.

site_title: iPhones are improving every year thanks to an obscure Japanese company
summary: A Japanese company, Lasertec Corp, is making a significant impact in the tech industry by developing equipment that tests glass squares for chip designs, enabling the creation of smaller circuit patterns. The company's success has led to a 32% increase in forecasted sales and a 14% growth in operating income. Lasertec's technology, known as extreme ultraviolet lithography, is used by major chipmakers such as Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. to produce smaller, more powerful chips, including those in Apple's iPhone XS and XR.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares higher on China stimulus prospects
summary: Australian stocks rose 0.3% on Tuesday, driven by hopes of China's economic stimulus and a global rally. The S&P/ASX 200 index recovered from a 0.4% decline on Monday, with commodity stocks and financials leading the gains. Mining stocks, including Rio Tinto and BHP Group, rose over 2%, while energy stocks benefited from higher oil prices. New Zealand stocks also advanced, with financial and utility stocks driving the gains.

site_title: Brazilian airline Gol grounds its Boeing 737 Max 8 aircraft
summary: Brazilian airline Gol has grounded its Boeing 737 Max 8 aircraft following the Ethiopian Airlines crash that killed 157 people, the second such incident in six months involving the same model. Gol operates seven of the 121 Boeing aircraft it has, and passengers booked on the 737 Max 8 will be transferred to other flights. China has also grounded all 737 Max 8 aircraft, while US authorities have ordered Boeing to modify the model. Gol remains confident in its operations and Boeing, aiming to resume flights as soon as possible.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, tracking gains in New York, driven by the stable dollar-yen rate and news of a Brexit deal between the UK and EU. The Nikkei 225 index gained 1.11% to 21,359.66, while the Topix index rose 0.97% to 1,596.73.

site_title: E-sports platforms stream into a new chapter
summary: E-sports platforms have entered a new chapter, driven by increased funding and institutional backing. Online streaming platforms, such as Twitch and Huya, have seen significant growth, with over 55 million users and $180 million in funding raised by Huya. The e-sports industry is expanding globally, with the Southeast Asia region projected to have an audience of over 31.9 million people. To succeed, platforms must integrate talent development, mass adoption, and community engagement, as well as address regional infrastructure gaps. The industry's future success will depend on its ability to create a platform that attracts key talents, game publishers, and influencers, while also developing the skills and community reach of key talent and influencers.

site_title: Nvidia buys Israeli chipmaker Mellanox for US$6.9b
summary: Nvidia acquired Israeli chipmaker Mellanox for $6.9 billion, expanding its presence in high-performance computing. The combined firm will optimize data center performance for cloud computing and AI applications. The deal is expected to close later this year, subject to regulatory and shareholder approval. This acquisition will enhance Nvidia's offerings in video games, facial recognition systems, and autonomous vehicles, and will enable the creation of more efficient systems for computing, connectivity, and storage.

site_title: Musk defends Tesla tweets that US SEC says violated court order
summary: Elon Musk defended his tweets about Tesla's electric vehicle production, citing his constitutional right to free speech. The US Securities and Exchange Commission claims the tweets were misleading and required vetting, but Musk's defense was met in a Manhattan federal court. If found in contempt, Musk faces new fines, controls on his social media use, and potential suspension or ban from running Tesla. The outcome could impact Tesla's market value, which plummeted $7.3 billion after the SEC initially sought to bar Musk from serving as an officer or director.

site_title: International Cement to acquire African company for US$104.4m
summary: International Cement Group is acquiring Schwenk Namibia Pty Ltd for US$104.4 million, gaining control of a 100% stake in Ohorongo Cement, a cement plant in Namibia with an annual production capacity of 1 million tonnes. The acquisition eliminates project risk and provides access to growing business opportunities in Africa, particularly with China's Belt and Road initiative. The deal is subject to shareholder and government approvals, with penalties for non-compliance.

site_title: UK says 'legally binding changes' to Brexit deal agreed with EU
summary: The UK government announced it has agreed "legally binding changes" to the Brexit deal with the EU, following a last-minute meeting in Strasbourg. The changes strengthen and improve the withdrawal agreement and the political declaration, addressing concerns over the "backstop" plan to keep the Irish border open. The UK and EU have agreed a joint legally binding instrument that confirms the EU cannot trap the UK in the backstop indefinitely. The changes aim to persuade MPs to vote for the agreement on Tuesday, just 17 days before Britain is scheduled to leave the EU.

site_title: Pelosi, on impeachment, says Trump 'not worth it'
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi stated she does not support impeaching President Donald Trump, citing the potential for division in the country. Pelosi argued that impeachment is only warranted if there is compelling and bipartisan evidence, and she believes Trump is "just not worth it." This comes as Democrats debate whether to initiate impeachment proceedings or use Trump as a key election issue in the 2020 race.

site_title: French businessman Tapie on trial over huge Sarkozy-era payout
summary: French businessman Bernard Tapie is on trial for allegedly defrauding the state of nearly half a billion euros through a 2008 arbitration award that led to IMF chief Christine Lagarde being found guilty of negligence. The case centers on a payment of 404 million euros awarded to Tapie to settle a dispute over the sale of Adidas. Tapie, who has bounced back from previous setbacks, including a conviction for match-fixing, denies obtaining the award through fraud and vows to clear his name.

site_title: Oil gains over 1% as Saudi stands by Opec output cuts
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Monday, driven by Saudi Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih's comments that Opec-led supply cuts would unlikely end before June. Brent crude futures rose to $66.58 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose to $56.79 a barrel. The Opec+ group, which has pledged to cut 1.2 million barrels per day in crude supply, will meet in April and June to discuss supply policy.

site_title: Eurozone delays Greece debt relief over reforms
summary: Eurozone ministers delayed granting Greece debt relief due to the government's failure to implement promised reforms. Greece exited its third bailout in August and is seeking approximately €1 billion in debt relief. The delay comes as the country prepares to issue a 10-year bond and aims to raise €9 billion in the markets this year. European officials downplayed the delay, emphasizing the need for reforms to boost investor confidence in Greece's economy, which is expected to grow 2.4% in 2019.

site_title: LMIRT to buy retail mall in West Jakarta for 3.7t rupiah
summary: LMIRT, a real estate investment trust, plans to acquire Lippo Mall Puri in West Jakarta for 3.70 trillion rupiah (S$354.7 million). The acquisition, financed by debt and equity, aims to boost assets by 19% and increase total net lettable area by 12.69%. Lippo Mall Puri has seen significant growth, with average footfall increasing 62% since its operations began in 2014. The acquisition is conditional on the completion of land title segregation and issuance of strata title certificates, with expected completion in the second half of 2019.

site_title: Nvidia nears deal to acquire Mellanox for more than US$7b
summary: Nvidia is nearing a deal to acquire Mellanox Technologies Ltd for over $7 billion in cash, its largest-ever acquisition. The deal would boost Nvidia's data centre chip business, reducing its reliance on the gaming industry. Intel had previously bid on Mellanox but was outbid by Nvidia. The acquisition would also benefit activist hedge fund Starboard Value LP, a shareholder of Nvidia. The deal could be announced as early as Monday.

site_title: Japan court blocks Ghosn from attending board meeting: NHK
summary: A Tokyo court denied Carlos Ghosn's request to attend a Nissan board meeting, blocking a potential face-off with colleagues he accused of a coup. Ghosn, released on a $9 million bail, faces charges of under-reporting his salary by $82 million. The meeting coincides with a plan to set up a joint board structure, which some at Nissan opposed. Ghosn remains on the boards of Nissan, Renault, and Mitsubishi, but was expected to dial in via teleconference if his request had been approved.

site_title: Kim Jong Un seen having more to lose if he tests missile
summary: North Korea may be preparing to launch a missile or satellite, contrary to its recent commitment to not restart testing. Satellite images show activity at a long-range rocket site, which could be a bluff or a genuine attempt to push back against US President Donald Trump. A launch would anger Trump and potentially undermine diplomatic goodwill, while also risking support from China and Russia, which have veto power on the UN Security Council. The move could also provide valuable data to improve North Korea's missile capability.

site_title: May's deal hangs on the EU concessions A-G Cox can obtain
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is seeking EU concessions to persuade Brexiteer MPs to vote for her withdrawal deal, which is set to be put to a second parliamentary vote on Tuesday. Attorney-General Geoffrey Cox is negotiating with the EU to secure an "arbitration mechanism" allowing the UK to leave the customs union without EU permission. The EU is unwilling to compromise on its core priorities, and a deadlock remains. A successful vote would see Brexit take place on March 29, while a failed vote would lead to an extension and potential second referendum.

site_title: LME launches seven new contracts
summary: The London Metal Exchange (LME) launched seven new cash-settled futures contracts, including hot-rolled coil steel, alumina, and cobalt, to boost its product portfolio amid increased competition. The move follows a decline in profits last year and aims to attract more business. The new contracts are part of the LME's efforts to strengthen its offerings and stay competitive with rival exchanges.

site_title: As China prevails, France's Macron shuffles his cards in Djibouti
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron visited Djibouti, a former French colony, to reassert France's influence in the region amid China's growing economic and military presence. Djibouti, strategically located at the southern entrance to the Red Sea, hosts France's largest naval base and is a key location for African troops and monitoring the Horn of Africa. Macron seeks to strengthen France's presence in Djibouti economically, culturally, and militarily, amid criticism from Djiboutian President Ismail Omar Guelleh that France has abandoned the country.

site_title: HKEx's China stock futures to pose competition for SGX
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEx) has signed an agreement with index publisher MSCI to offer futures contracts on the MSCI China A Index, posing competition to Singapore Exchange (SGX) FTSE China A50 Index Futures. The new product, set to launch in November 2019, could negatively impact SGX's profitability and share price. The move is seen as a rival to SGX's existing offshore futures contract, which generates about 40% of the exchange's derivatives business. International fund interest in China is expected to increase, with MSCI quadrupling the weighting of Chinese shares in its global benchmarks later this year.

site_title: Second 737 Max crash in months raises more questions
summary: A Boeing 737 Max 8 aircraft crashed shortly after takeoff, killing 157 people, in a separate incident from the Lion Air crash that killed 189 in October last year. The Ethiopian Airlines plane reportedly sought to return to the airport due to technical problems, but it plummeted into the ground. The similarities with the Lion Air crash have raised concerns among travelers and cast a shadow over Boeing's Max program, which has thousands of planes on order. The investigation is ongoing, and it may take a year or more to determine the cause of the crash.

site_title: Washington news has elements of a potboiler
summary: Washington has been preoccupied with the "Russian Collusion" story, a complex plot involving international intrigues and secret encounters, for over two years. The investigation, led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, aims to determine if President Trump's 2016 campaign colluded with Russian officials to deny Hillary Clinton's victory. While some expect a "smoking gun" to prove direct collusion, few believe that will be found. Instead, Mueller's report is likely to charge Russian interference in the election through disinformation, but the investigation will continue to focus on crimes and misdemeanors committed by President Trump's family members and close aides.

site_title: January retail sales rise, stabilising after December slump
summary: US retail sales rose 0.2% in January, stabilizing after a 1.6% decline in December, indicating consumers may support growth. The Commerce Department reported the data on Monday. This marks a recovery from a dismal end to 2018, suggesting consumers can still contribute to economic growth.

site_title: Bollywood films banned in Pakistan amid tension with India
summary: Pakistan has halted the screening of Bollywood movies in theaters across the country due to the ongoing tension with India. The nation's largest cinema chain, Cinepax Cinemas, is forced to show reruns of old Pakistani films. Bollywood movies account for 60% of total cinema consumption in Pakistan, with cinemas experiencing their lowest footfall. The ban is a result of the worst military conflict in decades between India and Pakistan, with nationalist sentiment stoked on both sides.

site_title: Hi-P adds 11% during Monday session
summary: Hi-P International's shares surged 11% to close at a 10-month high on Monday, reaching S$1.72. The stock was the most heavily traded on the Singapore bourse, with 27.9 million shares traded. Despite brokerages upgrading the stock, market watchers attributed the surge to speculative activities. Hi-P posted a fourth-quarter net profit of S$44.8 million, beating market expectations, but revenue fell 10.2% due to US-China trade relations.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singtel will subscribe fully to its rights entitlement for a 15% stake in Bharti Airtel, reducing its effective stake to 35.2% after a $3.5 billion rights issuance. Despite this, management remains optimistic about Airtel's prospects, citing 4% quarter-on-quarter growth in mobile ARPU. UG Healthcare's production capacity expansion is expected to drive earnings growth, with a planned increase of 300 million pieces per annum. Both companies maintain their buy recommendations, citing potential for long-term growth.

site_title: Cuba taps into high-end luxury tourist market
summary: Cuba is targeting the high-end luxury tourist market with exclusive hotels, including the 5-star Gran Hotel Manzana in Havana, which features A-list brands and a 1,000-square-metre spa. The hotel attracts a clientele of private airplanes and celebrities, and its prices range from $370 to $5,000 per night. The Kempinski group, which owns the hotel, is planning to open two or three more luxury hotels in Cuba, sparking interest from foreign hotel chains such as Iberostar and Accor. The hotels are owned by Gaviota, Cuba's branch of the army's tourism division, and have been criticized for being on Washington's blacklist due to restrictions on US tourists.

site_title: In shadow of Ghosn, Nissan, Renault and Mitsubishi meet to hash out future
summary: Nissan, Renault, and Mitsubishi Motors are set to meet in Japan to discuss their future alliance, following Carlos Ghosn's ouster. A Tokyo court rejected Ghosn's request to attend Nissan's board meeting, denying him a seat at the table despite Renault's plans to bolster the alliance. Renault and Mitsubishi are in talks to set up a new alliance body to improve collaboration, with Renault's new chairman, Jean-Dominique Senard, likely to chair the joint board meeting. The alliance's future appears secure, with the partners planning to maintain their cross-shareholding structure.

site_title: Resilience can help Singapore private equity leapfrog to pole position
summary: Singapore's private equity sector is making strides with recent budget announcements, including a US$5 billion private markets programme and the establishment of the SME Co-Investment Fund III. However, to leapfrog to a pole position, business leaders must focus on resilience and innovation, adopting a mindset that embraces failure and uses it to pivot to new ideas. Despite being ranked third in the world for ease of starting a business, Singapore still trails behind India and China in private equity deals. To become more competitive, business leaders must nurture their ability to grow, adapt, and perform through times of change and challenge.

site_title: SilkAir continues to operate 737 Max 8, monitoring developments
summary: SilkAir, a regional wing of Singapore Airlines, continues to operate its Boeing 737 Max 8 aircraft on 12 routes, despite the recent fatal Ethiopian Airlines crash. The airline closely monitors developments and prioritizes passenger and crew safety. SilkAir has six Max 8s in service and 31 on order. Other airlines have suspended 737 Max operations following the crash, including Chinese carriers and Ethiopian Airlines. Boeing is sending a technical team to the crash site and shares have fallen in early trading.

site_title: Captain Marvel scoops US$455m for 6th biggest global debut
summary: Captain Marvel achieved a record-breaking global debut of US$455 million, becoming the 6th highest global opening weekend of all time. The film, starring Brie Larson, earned US$153 million in North America and US$302 million internationally, surpassing studio projections of US$125 million. The movie's success boosted the 2019 box office, which had declined 27% before the weekend, with total domestic box office now down 21% at US$1.79 billion.

site_title: New S$2m fund to help construction firms acquire quieter building equipment
summary: Singapore has launched a new S$2 million Quieter Construction Innovation Fund to encourage construction firms to invest in quieter building equipment. The fund, which replaces the original S$2 million fund, aims to reduce noise levels from construction sites. Firms can receive up to S$300,000 in grants for purchasing quieter equipment, with increased funding support for leasing specialist contractors. The fund also lowers the minimum amount for innovative construction methods and localized noise enclosures. The move aims to slash noise levels from construction sites, with 9,500 public complaints received last year.

site_title: Oil rises as Saudis continue to slash supply
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday as Saudi Arabia plans to produce below 10 million barrels a day in April, extending its supply cuts. This move aims to regain control of the oil market, with prices currently trading above $55 a barrel. Despite US production at a record high, uncertainty over the US-China trade tiff weighs on prices. West Texas Intermediate rose 1.3% and Brent advanced 74 cents to $66.48 a barrel.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia's deep production cuts show the world's largest oil exporter is determined to re-balance the market more quickly even though events in Venezuela have left some refiners short of crude.

site_title: Europe: Shares rebound, helped by bank merger talk
summary: European shares rebounded 0.8% on Monday, their best daily performance in four weeks, as merger chatter in the banking sector helped offset global economic slowdown worries. German lender Commerzbank rose 7.1% after reports of a possible tie-up with Deutsche Bank, which also gained 5%. UK challenger banks Charter Court Financial and OneSavings Bank also rose after entering advanced talks about a possible all-share tie-up. Shares in Boeing fell 7% after the 737 MAX 8 crash.

site_title: Is Huawei's rise due to its corporate governance style?
summary: Huawei, the world's largest telecommunications equipment provider, has been shrouded in controversy due to espionage and theft allegations. However, its corporate governance style may be a key factor in its success. The company is a fully employee-owned, private entity with shareholders who are employees, and it has a unique rotating chairman system. CEO and founder Ren Zhengfei holds multiple governing roles, including on the representatives' commission and board of directors. Despite criticisms of its governance model, Huawei's business performance has been impressive, with compound annual growth rates of 26% for revenue and 18% for operating profit over the past five years.

site_title: Buyout offer for Keppel T&T 'fair and reasonable': IFA
summary: Independent financial adviser Rothschild & Co has recommended that Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation (T&T) shareholders vote in favour of a buyout offer by parent company Keppel Corp, valuing each share at S$1.91. The recommendation is due to the low trading liquidity of Keppel T&T's shares, which makes a "clean cash exit" a viable option for shareholders. If the offer is accepted, Keppel Corp will acquire Keppel T&T's shares without incurring brokerage and other trading costs.

site_title: Few trade war jitters in Macau's booming casino enclave
summary: Macau, a special administrative region of China, has bucked the trend of trade war uncertainty, with its four major casino giants reporting record-breaking gaming revenues and profits. The city's economy, which relies almost solely on the gambling industry, has shown resilience despite the slowing Chinese economy and US trade tensions. Visitor numbers have also increased, with 35.8 million tourists visiting in 2018, driven by the city's food and family tourism appeal. Analysts predict the market will continue to grow, albeit at a mid-single-digit pace, with the mass-market segment driving operating profits.

images.alt_text: In the past few weeks, Macau's four casino giants - SJM, Sands China, Galaxy Entertainment and Wynn - have all reported a bumper year of gaming revenues and profits.

site_title: Ramping up the fight for renewable energy
summary: Singapore-based WEnergy Global, led by CEO Asean Atem Ramsundersingh, is working to electrify communities in South-east Asia by focusing on microgrid hybrid projects that combine solar, battery, and diesel power. The company's first project, a hybrid microgrid in the Philippine island of Palawan, aims to produce half of its energy from renewable sources over a 20-year lifespan. WEnergy's efforts are part of its mission to provide clean energy to underserved communities, with a goal of building a portfolio of electrification projects worth US$100 million in the next four years.

site_title: Sats unveils S$25m investment in new technology to boost output, cut waste
summary: SATS, a major airline caterer, has invested S$25m in new technology to extend the shelf life of cooked food, reducing waste. Meals can now be stored for up to 90 days without added preservatives and up to 24 months without refrigeration, with no impact on safety, nutrition, or taste. The technology uses pasteurisation and sterilisation, and Singapore Airlines' budget arm Scoot is the first to adopt it, featuring the meals from June 2019. This move aims to reduce food waste, packaging waste, and support consumers seeking convenient, safe, and authentic meals.

site_title: How women can build the future of business in Singapore
summary: Women in Singapore's business community are breaking barriers and paving the way for future generations. A recent study found that women-led businesses in the Asia-Pacific region could create an economy equivalent to Germany and Austria combined. Raena Lim, co-founder of Style Theory, a fashion rental subscription platform, is a prime example of a woman entrepreneur's success. Despite facing funding challenges, women business owners in Singapore are leveraging social media and digital technologies to grow their businesses. Facebook's #Shemeansbusiness initiative has trained over 130,000 women in digital skills, and the platform has seen a significant increase in female business owners in Singapore.

site_title: US: Stocks rally despite deadly Boeing crash
summary: US stocks rallied on Monday, snapping a five-day losing streak despite Boeing's 5.3% decline following a deadly crash of one of its 737 MAX 8 jets. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.8%, while the S&P 500 jumped 1.5% and the Nasdaq rose 2%. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's remarks reaffirmed the central bank's patience on interest rate hikes, providing stability for investors. Other notable gains included Apple's 3.5% surge following an analyst upgrade.

site_title: Powell says Fed policy is appropriate, sees no hurry to change
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that interest rates can remain on hold as the central bank waits to see how the US economy and external factors evolve. He described the current rate setting as "roughly neutral," neither stoking nor slowing growth, and emphasized the Fed's patient stance. Powell cited solid US economic growth, low unemployment, and muted inflation as reasons for not changing interest rates, while also monitoring global economic conditions, including China and Europe.

site_title: Will a fancy mall help sell Hudson Yards' pricey apartments?
summary: A luxury mall is set to open at Hudson Yards, a $25 billion redevelopment in Manhattan, with the goal of selling pricey apartments. The 15 Hudson Yards and 35 Hudson Yards condominiums offer luxury living with prices starting at $4.3 million and $5 million, respectively. While some brokers are optimistic about the project's potential, others consider it a gamble due to New York's struggling housing market. The development's unique blend of office space, department stores, and cultural amenities may draw buyers, but its high prices and untested market pose challenges.

site_title: No date yet for Trump-Xi trade summit: White House
summary: The White House has stated that a possible summit between US President Donald Trump and Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping remains uncertain, with no date set for the meeting. Negotiators are continuing to work on resolving the US-China trade dispute, which has imposed tariffs on over $360 billion worth of mutual trade. Trump has expressed optimism about meeting with Xi, but a spokesperson said it's too early to announce a meeting. The US president will only agree to a deal beneficial to the US, and top-level negotiators are working to hammer out an agreement before a truce expires.

site_title: Wirecard told judicial review is legal route for move against CAD
summary: Singapore's High Court dismissed criminal motions by Wirecard Asia and Wirecard Singapore, stating that judicial review is the legal route for their move against the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD). The motions aimed to restrict the seizure of documents related to allegations of forgery and falsification of accounts by employees based in Singapore. Wirecard Asia's vice-president and director Edo Kurniawan has reportedly gone missing since February 9, and the case is now set to proceed through judicial review, which may evaluate the decisions of public authorities.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hyflux postpones a restructuring meeting due to space constraints, citing "as soon as possible" for a new time and venue. Halcyon Agri to redeem US$150 million of senior perpetual securities on April 26. Fraser and Neave acquires 60% of Print Lab for S$24.48 million. Wilmar International buys out Goodman Fielder's half-stake for US$180 million. Stamford Tyres Corp reports a 97.9% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$20,000 for the third quarter.

site_title: Citi joins UBS in setting up Singapore currency trading hub
summary: Citi is joining UBS in setting up an electronic currency trading and pricing platform in Singapore, enhancing liquidity in Asia's largest foreign-exchange hub. This marks Singapore's fourth FX trading engine location for Citi, alongside Tokyo, New York, and London.

site_title: French government working on 'more ambitious' energy and climate bill
summary: The French government has delayed the presentation of a draft energy and climate law to allow for more ambitious environmental goals. The initial proposals were criticized for being too vague on targets, including a goal of achieving "carbon neutrality" by 2050. President Emmanuel Macron has vowed to push ahead with green policies while balancing costs with measures to help lower-income households. The reworked bill will include a more detailed outline of France's target for reducing greenhouse gases and will still be presented to parliament in June.

site_title: Reclaims Global shares down 35.7% from IPO price on trading debut
summary: Reclaims Global, a Catalist-listed company, closed at 14.8 Singapore cents on its trading debut, down 35.7% from its IPO price of 23 Singapore cents. The company's shares opened at 17.9 Singapore cents, 22% lower than the IPO price. The debut was marked by about 1.44 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Rate hike bets send Norway's kroner to 4½ month highs
summary: Norway's kroner reached a 4½-month high against the Swedish krona after strong inflation data exceeded expectations, raising interest rate hike bets. The February core CPI data showed a 2.6% annualized increase, above the forecast and the central bank's 2% target. This increased pressure on the central bank to raise interest rates, potentially as early as this month.

site_title: Sim Leisure says IPO has enabled it to be debt free
summary: Sim Leisure Group, a Singapore-listed theme park operator, has said it does not expect its business to be negatively impacted by the use of its initial public offering (IPO) proceeds to redeem preference shares and pay for listing expenses. The company reiterated this statement, despite using IPO funds for these purposes rather than expansion and working capital.

site_title: Companies racing to innovate drive a booming business
summary: Companies are emerging to help organizations innovate, partner startups, or invest in them, driven by the surge in corporate innovation and venture investment. These firms offer services such as organizing hackathons and building startups within client corporations. The growth of the market for advisory services is a response to the necessity of innovation for large corporations, rather than just a trend. This expansion is expected to continue as companies seek to unlock deep tech innovation through startup partnerships.

site_title: Aussie home price boom fuelled by low rates
summary: A new study by the Reserve Bank of Australia found that lower real interest rates and strong migration drove the Australian home price boom over the past decade. The research also suggests that further rate reductions could revive home prices after recent weakness. Strong migration tends to increase rents, further fueling the boom. The study's findings provide insight into the factors influencing the Australian housing market, highlighting the importance of interest rates and migration trends.

site_title: British PM May to go to Strasbourg to break Brexit impasse
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is set to visit Strasbourg to break the Brexit impasse, following talks with EU officials. The EU is working on a Brexit proposal to address concerns over the "backstop" insurance policy for the Irish border, but remains committed to its core priorities. May aims to finalize an agreement, with the EU emphasizing the backstop is intended to be temporary and not a trap. The negotiations are ongoing, with the outcome uncertain.

site_title: US to start fabricating parts for ground-launched cruise missile systems
summary: The US will begin fabricating parts for ground-launched cruise missile systems, contrary to its obligations under the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty. This move comes after the US announced its withdrawal from the treaty in six months, unless Russia ends alleged violations. The Pentagon emphasized that the efforts will be conventional and reversible, should Russia return to compliance. The UN has urged the US and Russia to preserve the treaty, warning it would make the world more insecure.

site_title: Indonesian property stock soars nearly 1,700% since January IPO
summary: Indonesian property stock PT Citra Putra Realty has seen a nearly 1,700% surge since its January 2019 IPO, with shares rising from 180 rupiah to 3,190 rupiah. The company now values at 8.2 trillion rupiah (S$779.9 million). This remarkable performance is attributed to the company's hotel and restaurant businesses.

site_title: Acesian Partners to sell loss-making unit for S$321,000
summary: Acesian Partners, a CATALIST-listed environmental-control exhaust systems provider, has agreed to sell its loss-making unit, Acesian Sun, to Metro Transit Solutions for S$321,000 in cash, mostly in monthly instalments. The sale is aimed at improving the group's financial performance and focusing on its core business. Acesian Partners expects a net gain of roughly S$277,000 from the sale, which will be used for working capital requirements.

site_title: Singapore a hotspot for business e-mail scams: Trend Micro
summary: Singapore is the most vulnerable country in South-east Asia for business e-mail compromise scams, with 27.3% of detected incidents occurring in the country, according to Trend Micro. The country is also a 'hotbed' for hosting malicious URLs, ranking second in the region after Indonesia. Malaysia and Indonesia follow closely with 26.1% and 25% of incidents, respectively.

site_title: Is trade deficit good news for America?
summary: The US trade deficit of $621 billion in 2018 should teach President Donald Trump a lesson in trade economics. Contrary to his stance, a trade deficit is not inherently bad. In fact, the deficit has grown significantly, increasing by 25% from the previous year, and is now the largest in nearly a decade. This challenges Trump's assertion that a trade surplus is the only successful policy. Many economists argue that a trade deficit can be a sign of a growing economy.

site_title: Harvest to buy Verano for US$850m in largest US pot deal
summary: Harvest Health & Recreation Inc is acquiring Verano Holdings LLC for approximately $850 million, creating one of the largest multi-state operators in the US. The combined company will have licenses to operate up to 200 facilities in 16 states and territories, including 123 retail dispensaries. By the end of 2019, it expects to have over 70 dispensaries, 13 cultivation facilities, and 13 manufacturing facilities in operation. This deal will give Harvest a leadership position in the US cannabis market.

site_title: Full year results ended December 2018
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating loss for the second half of the year. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO is Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC are to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Qatar seeks more Russia deals after 'great' Rosneft investment
summary: Qatar's sovereign wealth fund is seeking more investment opportunities in Russia, capitalizing on the country's "huge" growth potential. The Qatar Investment Authority is satisfied with its 18.93% stake in Rosneft, a Russian state oil producer, following a $9 billion deal in May last year. Qatar's ambassador to Moscow, Fahd bin Mohammed Al-Attiyah, described the investment as "great" and "attractive," indicating a potential for future partnerships.

site_title: VW CEO gears up for labour fight with overhaul on the line
summary: Volkswagen CEO Herbert Diess is pushing forward with a major overhaul of the company's 12-brand global empire, aiming to increase speed and efficiency. The overhaul includes a partial share sale in the trucks division and other structural changes. The company is under pressure to deliver on its pledge to become a global transportation leader, facing new and old rivals. The overhaul is crucial to the company's success, with the future of the company's share sale and overall strategy hanging in the balance.

site_title: US: Dow drops at open as heavyweight Boeing slides after plane crash
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 242.24 points, or 0.95%, to 25,208.00 at the open on Monday, after a fatal plane crash in Ethiopia caused a decline in Boeing Co shares. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell, with the S&P 500 opening higher and the Nasdaq gaining 34.42 points, or 0.46%. The decline in Boeing shares capped gains in the broader markets.

site_title: US retail sales rise in January, stabilising after a slump
summary: US retail sales stabilized in January, rising 0.2% after a 1.6% decline in December, exceeding forecasters' expectations. This indicates consumers may continue to support growth despite a weak December. Sales in the "control group" subset rose 1.1%, topping estimates, with eight of 13 major retail categories showing improvement. The stronger-than-expected report may ease concerns about consumer strength, but the Federal Reserve is unlikely to be swayed, with interest rate decisions on hold for now.

site_title: Australian regulator rebukes banks for delays in fixing faulty systems
summary: Australia's corporate watchdog, ASIC, has rebuked the country's four largest banks and two financial firms for delays in fixing faulty systems that led to customers being billed wrongly. The review, which covered up to 10 years of operations, found systemic failures and poor record-keeping as major causes. The banks and firms have paid or offered compensation of about A$1.15 billion, but ASIC says the amounts are incomplete. Enforcement action is planned against unspecified entities for taking customer fees for services not rendered.

site_title: Boeing feels the heat as China, Indonesia ground 737 Max jets
summary: Boeing faces its biggest crisis as China and Indonesia ground 737 Max jets following the second deadly crash, killing 157 people. The Ethiopian Airlines Flight 302 crash bears similarities to the Lion Air 737 Max that crashed in October. Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg faces a major crisis, and the company's shares are on track for their biggest loss since the 9/11 attacks. The grounding affects 96 of Boeing's newest 737 model, with the flight recorders to be analyzed.

site_title: HSBC chases Asia's wealthiest with new ultra-high-net-worth team
summary: HSBC is building an ultra-high-net-worth team in Asia, targeting clients with assets of $30 million or more, as part of its plan to add 700 private banking jobs by 2022. The team, led by veterans Gabriel Tam and Erik Bergqvist, will cater to the growing demand for wealth management services in the region. With Asia's billionaire population expected to rise 27% to 1,003 by 2023, HSBC aims to capitalize on this growth and expand its presence in the ultra-high-net-worth segment.

site_title: A Changi Airport spin-off may benefit investors more so than Singaporeans
summary: A proposed spin-off of Changi Airport's first three terminals into a listed real estate or business trust may benefit investors more than Singaporeans. The trust could revive the Singapore stock market with a marquee listing and reduce the government's fiscal burden on airport infrastructure. Investors in the Singapore market have a demonstrated affinity for high-yielding counters, and a Changi Airport trust could draw international investors, potentially boosting the market. However, the benefits to the broader market and public financing are not as clear-cut as the hype suggests.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, exceeding expectations. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo from President Trump targeting Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to the first half of the year. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO.

site_title: Asian markets waiting to exhale
summary: Asian markets are trading cautiously due to uncertainty surrounding the UK's Brexit vote and the US-China trade deal. Investors are waiting for data releases this week for a clearer regional outlook, with Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 0.14% on Monday. Markets in Australia and Malaysia ended lower, while North Asia saw gains due to Chinese officials boosting sentiment on policy support. Mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.92% on Monday, driven by gains from tech counters like Hi-P International and Memtech International.

site_title: Nearly 5,000 bankers in EU earn more than a million euros a year - watchdog
summary: Nearly 5,000 bankers in the European Union earned over a million euros ($1.53 million) in 2017, according to the European Banking Authority. The majority were based in Britain, but some may move to continental hubs due to Brexit. The EU capped bonuses in 2014, leading to a decrease in the average ratio of variable to fixed pay, from 123% in 2014 to 101.08% in 2017. Many big London-based banks have opened new hubs elsewhere in the EU in preparation for Brexit.

site_title: Sygnum aims to tokenise investments with digital asset platform
summary: Sygnum, a fintech startup, is developing a digital asset platform to tokenize investments in real estate, aiming to turn infrastructure and real estate into investment options for investors. The firm is in talks with infrastructure and real estate players in Singapore to tokenise parts of their properties, potentially opening up new investment opportunities.

site_title: Plastic in crosshairs at UN environment forum
summary: Countries at the UN Environment Assembly in Nairobi aim to curb plastic waste, with a goal to significantly reduce plastic production, including phasing out single-use plastics by 2030. The assembly, inspired by the Paris Agreement on carbon emissions, seeks international commitments to reduce plastic pollution, which harms ecosystems and contaminates oceans. The world produces over 300 million tonnes of plastics annually, with at least 5 trillion plastic pieces in oceans. A landmark report is expected to highlight the threat of plastic waste, with UN officials calling for transformative change to protect the planet.

site_title: IEA sees US leading global oil supply growth to 2024
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) forecasts that the US will lead global oil supply growth to 2024, adding 4 million barrels per day to its output. US oil production is expected to rise to 19.6 million barrels per day, with crude exports doubling and surpassing shipments from Russia and Saudi Arabia. Global oil demand growth is expected to ease as China slows, but will still rise by 1.2 million barrels per day to 106.4 million barrels per day. The IEA does not expect a peak in oil demand yet, citing growth in petrochemicals and jet fuel.

site_title: Top universities join to push 'Public Interest Technology'
summary: Top 21 US universities have formed the Public Interest Technology University Network to promote education in developing technology for the public good. The initiative aims to train students in software engineering, policy, civic leadership, and social justice advocacy to address the consequences of technology on society. The universities, including Harvard, MIT, and UC Berkeley, aim to humanize technologists and technologize humanists, and to make public interest technology as integral to the industry as public interest law. The network is backed by over $18 million in funding from foundations and seeks to counter the influence of private interests in the tech industry.

site_title: Steep descent likely for China's biggest property insurer
summary: China's largest property insurer, People's Insurance Co (Group) of China Ltd, is facing a steep decline in its stock price, with shares falling 10% on Monday. Analysts predict a prolonged and rocky journey, with Citic Securities recommending a sell and Goldman Sachs placing a sell rating. The company's core business is facing increasing competition, and premium growth is expected to slow. The stock trades at a 300% premium to its Hong Kong-listed shares, making it a target for speculators. Analysts believe the valuation is "definitely out of sync with fundamentals."

site_title: Unsold luxury homes raise red flags in Sweden
summary: In Sweden, the construction industry is facing significant challenges, with economists predicting a 30% drop in construction from 2017 to the end of the year. Luxury homes, such as the 125-meter Innovationen building in Stockholm, are struggling to sell, with one-third of its apartments remaining unsold. The housing market slump is raising concerns about the broader economy, with bankruptcies up 24% this year and the Swedish housing market expected to slow down. Developers are being forced to diversify their portfolios and offer more affordable housing options to stay afloat.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher, following China
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Monday, following Chinese shares higher, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.47% and the Topix index up 0.57%. Investors awaited US retail sales data to gauge the US economy's health.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 15.27 points to 1,664.63. The index saw 2.5 billion lots worth RM2.3 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 638 to 266.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund establishes helicopter operator
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has established the kingdom's first commercial helicopter operator with an initial capital of 565 million riyals. The company will offer private air transport within major cities and tourist trips to other parts of the country. This move supports the government's plans to diversify its economy through investments in renewable energy, infrastructure, and entertainment. The PIF, which has US$360 billion in assets, also owns stakes in Tesla and Uber Technologies, and is expected to expand its services.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets advanced at the start of trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.6% and eurozone indices gaining 0.4%. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares. In the US, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Wilmar to take over Goodman Fielder for US$180 million
summary: Wilmar International has agreed to acquire a 50% stake in food manufacturer and distributor Goodman Fielder for US$180 million under a share purchase agreement. The deal also includes taking over US$95 million in shareholder loans and potentially paying an additional US$50 million if Goodman Fielder meets certain earnings targets by 2020.

site_title: China Mining axes S$37.2 million pomegranate deal involving its chairman
summary: China Mining International has terminated a deal to buy a Chinese pomegranate cultivator worth S$37.2 million, citing unresolved diligence matters. The deal, involving chairman Guo Yinghui, was initially scheduled for completion six months after its signing in July 2018. The company will reconsider the deal's structure and make further announcements on any material developments. China Mining reported a net loss of S$604,000 for the year to Dec 31, 2018.

site_title: Strengthening intergenerational relationships amid societal changes
summary: A new concept, "multi-stage life," is proposed to reconfigure life plans, offering more flexibility and transitions. Traditionally, life is divided into three stages: school, work, and retirement. However, with increasing life expectancy, people can now expect to live eight or nine decades. This shift has led to a significant increase in life expectancy, with Singapore ranking third globally. With an extra 262,000 hours in their lives, individuals must re-evaluate their priorities and make the most of their extended lifespan. This concept challenges the traditional three-stage life plan and encourages people to adapt to a more dynamic and flexible life journey.

site_title: F&N's Times Publishing acquires 60% of Print Lab
summary: F&N's Times Publishing unit has acquired a 60% stake in Print Lab for S$24.48 million, subject to post-completion adjustments. The acquisition, aimed at leveraging complementary businesses, is not expected to impact F&N's net asset value or earnings per share for this year. The counter declined 1.12% before the announcement, closing at S$1.77.

site_title: JPMorgan merges commercial banking groups for fast-growing startups
summary: JPMorgan Chase is merging its middle-market technology and emerging growth commercial banking teams to cater to fast-growing startups. The new group, led by James Millar and Alton McDowell, will focus on promising startups in software, semiconductors, and other industries. The bank aims to provide comprehensive banking services, including treasury, payments, credit, and financing, to these companies. This move follows the rapid growth of dozens of young businesses in the last decade, with JPMorgan seeking to position itself to handle their complex banking needs.

site_title: Stamford Tyres posts Q3 net profit of S$20,000 - down by 98%
summary: Stamford Tyres Corp reported a Q3 net profit of S$20,000, down 98% from the same period last year, due to high business costs and joint ventures' showings. Revenue declined 14.2% to S$54.1 million. The company attributed the decline to challenging operating environment and intense competition. Earnings per share dropped to 0.01 Singapore cent, and no dividend was recommended. Stamford Tyres plans to focus on core markets in South-east Asia in the next 12 months.

site_title: Hyflux postpones Wednesday's meeting over space issues
summary: Hyflux, a water treatment company, has postponed its town hall meeting on restructuring due to space constraints. The meeting, originally scheduled for March 13, will be rescheduled once a larger venue is secured. This comes ahead of a creditors' vote on April 5, where retail investors have filed claims totaling S$969.7 million, including S$540.7 million for perpetual securities and S$429.3 million for preference shares. The company aims to tweak its debt restructuring scheme to provide a higher recovery rate for retail investors.

site_title: Barrick withdraws US$17.8b hostile bid for Newmont
summary: Barrick Gold Corp has withdrawn its US$17.8 billion hostile takeover bid for Newmont Mining Corp, opting instead for a joint venture around their Nevada projects. The decision comes after Newmont's board rejected Barrick's initial bid, and both companies agreed to collaborate on maximizing returns from their operations in Nevada. Barrick will hold a 55% stake in the joint venture, while Newmont will retain 45%. The move ends two weeks of animosity between the two gold producers, allowing Newmont to focus on securing shareholder approval for its offer to buy Goldcorp Inc.

site_title: Bank of America names new co-heads of UK investment banking
summary: Bank of America has appointed James Robertson and Peter Luck as co-heads of UK investment banking, marking a push to win business from large corporate clients in Britain despite Brexit. The appointments follow departures from the bank, including Diego De Giorgi and Christian Meissner, and come after the bank revitalized its corporate and investment banking business under Matthew Koder. The new co-heads bring experience from UBS and will report to Matt Cannon and Richard King, and will also retain their existing responsibilities in corporate broking.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end with gains
summary: Hong Kong shares ended Monday with gains, rebounding from last week's losses. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.97% to 28,503.30, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 1.92% to 3,026.99. The Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 3.90%. Despite global economic concerns, traders remained optimistic.

site_title: Singapore's MyDoc, UK's Synergix Health to jointly offer telemedicine services across Europe and Asia
summary: Singapore's MyDoc and UK's Synergix Health are partnering to offer telemedicine services across Europe and Asia, serving a combined 500 corporate clients. The joint platform will provide online and in-person medical advice in multiple languages, allowing users to access services round-the-clock. The partnership aims to offer coordinated health management, repeat prescription ordering, and licensed clinician connections with zero service interruption.

site_title: Policy continuity assured as Thailand goes to polls: UOB
summary: Thailand is set to hold elections on March 24, with policy continuity assured due to the 20-year National Strategy, which supports a democratic government and boosts growth prospects. UOB economist Manop Udomkerdmongkol expects the Thai economy to grow 3.5-4% annually for five years, driven by mega-project investments in infrastructure, particularly the Eastern Economic Corridor. A coalition government is likely, with markets awaiting official results within 60 days, and the new government expected to be in place ahead of June's Asean summits.

site_title: UK department store chain Debenhams in talks with lenders for £150m loan
summary: UK department store chain Debenhams is in advanced talks with its lenders for a £150m loan to refinance a bridge facility. The loan would help the company address financial concerns, following a recent takeover bid by Mike Ashley. Ashley has expressed his willingness to take control of the company and remove the current board. The loan would be used to pay off the £40m bridge facility and provide additional funds for Debenhams.

site_title: Mermaid Maritime associate extends rig contract at 'materially lower' rates
summary: Asia Offshore Drilling, a 33.76% associate of Mermaid Maritime, secured a three-year contract extension for a jack-up rig at "materially lower" day rates. The deal, with a Middle East client, is expected to add $80 million to Asia Offshore Drilling's contract backlog. Mermaid Maritime warned that the extension would have had a material adverse effect on its 2018 earnings per share due to the lower day rates, but would have a non-material impact on its consolidated net tangible assets per share.

site_title: SingTel-backed Sygnum partners European exchange operator, telco to build digital asset platform
summary: Sygnum, a fintech startup backed by SingTel, is partnering with Deutsche Börse Group and Swisscom to build a digital asset platform that tokenises real estate and other assets, allowing for more granular trading and portfolio differentiation. The platform has been launched in Switzerland and plans to launch in Singapore within 12 months. Sygnum aims to incorporate digital assets into traditional finance, including banking services, asset management, and capital raising. The firm has applied for a Swiss banking licence and is seeking a Singaporean banking licence, with plans to raise over S$75 million in funding.

site_title: Prodigy star Flint died from hanging: inquest
summary: Keith Flint, 49, frontman of British rave group The Prodigy, died from hanging, an inquest heard. Found dead on March 4 at his home in Essex, northeast of London, Flint took his own life, according to bandmate Liam Howlett. A post-mortem examination revealed hanging as the provisional medical cause of death, with toxicology reports pending. The investigation remains open, and an inquest adjourned until July 23 to examine the sudden death. Flint was one of the most influential acts from the underground rave scene, known for hits like "Firestarter" and "Breathe".

site_title: Oyster farmer frets about Brexit in Irish grey area
summary: Oyster farmer William Lynch, based in Northern Ireland, is concerned about the impact of Brexit on his business, which relies on a grey area in the territorial dispute between Ireland and the UK. The dispute affects his ability to export to the EU and face potential cross-border checks. Lynch fears the conflict could boil over into a power struggle between the UK and the remaining EU members, disrupting his business and potentially leading to the loss of a lucrative market in France.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks recoup losses on China stimulus hopes; won jumps
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index ended flat on Monday, rebounding from seven straight losses, as China's central bank pledged to further support the slowing economy. The won gained 0.22% against the US dollar, while benchmark bond yields climbed. The Shanghai Composite index rose 1.92% and China's CSI300 index recovered from a 4% drop on Friday. Foreigners were net sellers of 109.7 billion won worth of shares, but the market sentiment eased after the Fed's signal to hold rates and money flowing into Chinese markets.

site_title: Singapore shares end 0.14% lower on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 4.45 points or 0.14% to close at 3,191.42 on Monday, amid mixed trading in Asia. Investors remained cautiously optimistic about a US-China trade deal, while Chinese officials boosted sentiment in North Asia about policy support for a slowing economy. Decliners outnumbered advancers 234 to 168, with Hi-P International being the most traded stock, and ThaiBev, DBS Group Holdings, and United Overseas Bank also seeing notable price movements.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: MSCI and Hong Kong's HKEX are launching futures contracts on the MSCI China A Index to provide a hedging tool as international investor interest in Chinese shares surges. Keppel's proposed buyout offer for Keppel T&T has been recommended by Rothschild & Co, while International Cement is acquiring Schwenk Namibia for $104.4 million. SATS is investing $25 million in new technology to extend the shelf life of cooked food, reducing waste. Singapore shares fell 0.14% on Monday, while Vietnam reacted to the US tariff announcement, and the UK economy shrank for the second month.

site_title: Sim Leisure Group board doubles down on preference share redemption
summary: Sim Leisure Group, a CATALIST-listed theme park operator, has doubled down on its decision to use IPO proceeds to redeem preference shares and pay listing expenses. The company's board asserts that this move will not impact business operations, citing improved financial position with no debt on its balance sheet. Sim Leisure plans to expand in Malaysia, Asean, and China through joint ventures, with no reliance on external financing. The company expects to maintain a scalable and profitable business model, with rising visitor numbers and operations at a third facility in 2019.

site_title: Winds of change for Irish village bisected by Brexit border
summary: Residents of Pettigoe, a village in Northern Ireland, are applying for Irish citizenship in anticipation of a hard border with the EU if Britain exits on March 29. The local post office has seen a surge in applications, with some doubling every year. The village, which is bisected by the Irish border, has experienced sectarian violence in the past, but current residents are hopeful for a more peaceful future. With the EU's withdrawal looming, Pettigoe's residents are seeking a sense of security and stability.

site_title: Japan Tobacco unit gets court protection after legal defeat
summary: Japan Tobacco's Canadian unit, JTI-Macdonald Corp, received creditor protection from the Ontario Superior Court after a legal defeat over smoking risks, citing damages exceeding its capacity to pay. The company must pay an initial damages deposit of C$145 million. The ruling is part of a larger trend of legal defeats for tobacco companies in Canada, with total industry liability estimated at C$13.5 billion. The court's decision may force the federal government to negotiate a settlement, as the industry faces the risk of a boom in illicit tobacco if companies go under.

site_title: Australia regulator chides banks' delays repaying wrongly charged fees
summary: Australia's corporate watchdog, ASIC, has criticized the country's four biggest banks and financial institutions for delays in fixing internal systems that resulted in customers paying for services they didn't receive. The institutions had paid or offered A$1.15 billion in compensation by January 2019, but ASIC said the amounts were incomplete. The regulator cited systemic failures, including a "legalistic approach" and poor recording keeping, as the causes of the delays. ASIC plans enforcement action against entities that took customer fees for services not rendered, amid a broader Royal Commission inquiry into misconduct in the financial services sector.

site_title: Shale on the brink of M&A as oil majors flex muscles in Permian
summary: The Permian Basin, the world's largest shale oil field, is poised for a major transformation as oil majors flex their muscles, leading to potential mergers and acquisitions. Exxon Mobil and Chevron have unveiled ambitious growth plans, while Royal Dutch Shell and BP are also seeking deals. Smaller independents face pressure to merge or sell out to end the relentless production growth that has burned through $200 billion in cash over the past eight years. The industry is shifting towards economies of scale, with around 20 companies valued under $3 billion expected to be combined in a "merger of equals."

site_title: Singapore a hotspot for business email scams, malicious Web addresses, says Trend Micro
summary: Singapore is the most vulnerable country in South-east Asia for business email compromise scams and a hotspot for hosting malicious Web addresses, according to Trend Micro. The country accounted for 27.3% of business email compromise incidents and 68.1% of malicious URL attacks in the region. Attackers have become more targeted, using social engineering tactics to evade traditional security measures. Experts warn that enterprises must strengthen their cyber defenses to prevent such attacks, which can yield an average of S$177,000 per attack.

site_title: Two Flamenco divas, two kinds of showmanship
summary: Flamenco stars Sara Baras and Soledad Barrio showcased their unique styles in New York City. Sara Baras's "Shadows" concert at NYC Center was a visually impressive but narrow and unvaried show, with a focus on her trademark footwork and elaborate costumes. In contrast, Soledad Barrio's Noche Flamenca at the Connelly Theater presented a more stripped-down and intimate performance, with a focus on the dancers and musicians connecting with each other. Barrio's style was described as a "corkscrew" compared to Baras's "jackhammer," highlighting the difference between shadow and substance in flamenco performances.

site_title: Will a fancy mall help sell Hudson Yards' pricey apartments?
summary: A luxury mall is opening at Hudson Yards in New York, hoping to attract buyers for the pricey apartments in the complex. The development, which includes a public school, park, hotel, and dozens of restaurants, is seen as a unique draw, with some buyers willing to pay over $8 million for a two-bedroom apartment. However, some experts question the market's ability to support such high prices, citing a slump in New York's housing market. Related, the developer, remains optimistic, citing the appeal of the lifestyle and amenities offered by the complex.

site_title: Nissan, Renault, Mitsubishi are said to plan shift to one board
summary: Nissan, Renault, and Mitsubishi plan to form a single board to oversee their alliance's governance and operations, replacing two separate entities. Renault Chairman Jean-Dominique Senard is likely to chair the new committee. The move aims to streamline decision-making following Carlos Ghosn's arrest and allegations of improper payments. The automakers will hold a joint press conference on Tuesday to discuss the matter, with Ghosn possibly attending as a board member, pending court approval. The new structure is seen as a step towards more balanced decision-making.

site_title: Boeing's US$55b rally put to the test after Ethiopia crash
summary: Boeing's shares plummeted 8.7% after an Ethiopian Airlines 737 Max crashed, killing all 157 people on board, marking the second 737 Max crash in five months. The Dow Jones Industrial Average futures contracts fell 0.6% due to concerns over the jet, which has been a major contributor to the Dow's gains this year. Boeing's market value has risen by $55 billion this year, largely due to improving US-China trade talks and a record cash pile. Analysts predict volatility in Boeing's shares until clarity is found on the crash.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,196.27, up 0.01% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Monday at 3,196.27, up 0.01% on the day, with 469.8 million securities worth S$373 million changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 178 to 132. Notable stocks traded included Hi-P International and Keppel Infrastructure Trust. The market is expected to be influenced by upcoming GDP data and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed after last week's hefty losses
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Monday following last week's sharp losses, with investors seeking bargain opportunities. The US jobs report showed a weak 20,000 job creation, while the European Central Bank's growth and inflation forecasts were slashed. China announced a decline in exports and imports, further impacting markets. Despite early gains in Hong Kong and Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, and Singapore suffered losses, with investors awaiting the outcome of US-China trade talks.

site_title: Powell says Federal Reserve will watch January retail sales data for rebound
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated the central bank will closely monitor January retail sales data for signs of a consumer spending rebound. The December sales index dropped 1.2% due to a surprise, despite low unemployment and rising wages. Economists expect the January index to remain unchanged or rebound 1.4% from the previous month. Powell noted that January spending has shown signs of a rebound, but the December reading was weak. The Fed leans towards the latter projection, indicating a potential for consumer spending to bounce back.

site_title: UBS, StanChart agree to settle 2009 HK IPO misconduct case: regulator's counsel
summary: UBS Group AG and Standard Chartered PLC have agreed to settle a case of alleged misconduct related to a 2009 Hong Kong IPO, where a Chinese forestry company subsequently collapsed. The case, which was set to be appealed, resulted in an 18-month ban on leading IPOs in Hong Kong for UBS. The terms of the settlement and misconduct details have not been disclosed. The settlement marks a resolution to a widely-observed test of increased scrutiny of IPO practices in Hong Kong, where banks play a significant role in helping firms list.

site_title: Indonesian property stock soars 1,700% since January IPO
summary: Indonesian property stock PT Citra Putra Realty has seen a 1,422% surge since its January IPO, making it the best-performing stock this year. The company's shares, which debuted at 180 rupiah, are now valued at 7.04 trillion rupiah. Another property-related stock, PT Nusantara Properti International, has soared 580% since its listing on the same day. Analysts attribute the rally to investors seeking windfalls from IPOs, despite concerns that the rally may not be sustainable.

site_title: MinLaw seeking public's views on proposed IP (Dispute Resolution) Bill
summary: Ministry of Law (MinLaw) in Singapore is seeking public feedback on a proposed Intellectual Property (IP) (Dispute Resolution) Bill, which aims to improve the IP dispute resolution system. The Bill will consolidate most civil IP disputes in the High Court, provide clarity on IP disputes being arbitrated in Singapore, and introduce post-grant patent re-examination. The consultations will conclude on April 5, 2019.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.19 points to 1,680.09 at 9:01am on Monday, with volume reaching 55.17 million lots worth RM27.99 million. Gainers outpaced losers 96 to 63.

site_title: Australia shares falter on weak US, China data; NZ down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% on Monday, led by financial and energy stocks, after weak US and Chinese data sparked concerns about a global economic slowdown. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 6,180.20, with mining majors BHP Group and Rio Tinto down 1% and 0.7%, respectively. Energy stocks also declined, and investment bank Macquarie fell 2.3%. However, gold stocks rose 4.5% after Newcrest Mining announced a major acquisition deal.

site_title: Nvidia nears deal for data centre tech firm Mellanox
summary: Nvidia Corp. is nearing a deal to acquire Israeli chipmaker Mellanox Technologies, a move that would help the company gain technology used to speed data flow in data centers. The sale, valued at about $5.9 billion, is Nvidia's bid to expand its capabilities in transferring information within and between computers. The deal, which could be announced as soon as Monday, comes amid speculation that Intel Corp. was also a bidder. The acquisition would signal a restart of consolidation in the semiconductor industry, which has seen companies combine to add scale amid rising costs and shrinking customer lists.

site_title: NEA unveils S$2m innovation fund to get construction firms to adopt quieter equipment, methods
summary: The National Environment Agency (NEA) launches a S$2 million Quieter Construction Innovation Fund (QCIF) to encourage the adoption of quieter construction equipment and methods. The fund, set to be disbursed over two years, offers higher grant limits, funding support for quieter piling and demolition equipment, and lower minimum costs for innovative construction methods. Key incentives include increased grant amounts up to S$300,000 for quieter piling and demolition equipment, and a reduced minimum cost of S$3,000 for innovative construction methods. The fund aims to reduce noise impact and create a quieter living environment.

site_title: To lure young talent, banks mimic tech workspaces
summary: Banks are adapting to attract young talent by mimicking tech workspaces, offering amenities like massage rooms, ping pong tables, and flexible seating. Companies like Nordea and Danske Bank are hosting fashion shows, pop-up car washes, and other events to create an inspiring workplace atmosphere. The shift is driven by the need to compete with tech giants and prioritize workplace benefits over salary, with 77% of millennials citing workspace importance over salary.
