China has accused Canada of abetting a "political persecution" and detained two Canadians, Michael Spavor and Michael Kovrig, in secret jails. Meng's lawyers are gearing up for a full-blown legal offensive, while US President Donald Trump has made conflicting statements on intervening in the case.

site_title: AT&T joins global cybersecurity alliance co-founded by Singtel
summary: US telecom giant AT&T has joined the Global Telco Security Alliance (GTSA), a global cybersecurity alliance co-founded by Singtel. The alliance now has over 6,000 security experts and 28 security operations centers. AT&T's addition increases resources and insights offered by the group, which aims to address cybersecurity issues and enable its global customers to detect and respond to threats faster. The alliance plans to expand its scope and global footprint over time.

site_title: South Korea court grants bail for ex-president Lee
summary: A South Korean court granted bail to former President Lee Myung Bak, who was found guilty of corruption charges, including bribery and embezzlement, and sentenced to 15 years in prison. Lee, 77, cited ill health due to diabetes and sleep apnea. He denies wrongdoing, labeling the allegations as "political revenge." This is the latest in a trend of former South Korean presidents ending up in prison, with all four living presidents convicted of criminal offenses.

site_title: Transcorp issues notice of demand to recover S$2.6m from supplier
summary: Transcorp Holdings issued a notice of demand on March 4 to recover S$2.6 million in advance deposits from a supplier after a failed attempt to seek a full refund. The deposits were secured by letters of undertaking from the supplier's owner and Transcorp's former executive chairman. The company will take legal action if the amount is not refunded within seven days.

site_title: Startup Beam providing foodpanda riders with 20 LTA-registered e-scooters in 3-month trial
summary: Beam, a Singapore-based startup, has partnered with foodpanda to provide 20 e-scooters to its riders for a three-month trial. The e-scooters are LTA-registered and conform to the updated fire safety standard. Foodpanda riders can use an exclusive code to unlock and ride the e-scooters, which will be monitored and maintained by Beam. The partnership aims to improve delivery efficiency, reduce carbon footprint, and provide riders with new ways to deliver food.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won slide on North Korea tensions
summary: South Korean stocks and the won slid on Wednesday due to renewed tensions between North Korea and the US, dampening market sentiment. North Korea restored part of a missile launch site, and the US warned it would consider increasing sanctions if North Korea doesn't scrap its nuclear program. The benchmark Kospi index closed down 0.17%, and the won hit a near three-week low, falling 0.29% against the dollar. Foreigners were net sellers of 9.7 billion won worth of shares, and the currency has lost 1.2% against the US dollar this year.

site_title: 90 year old noodle vendor helps keep Singapore foodie culture alive
summary: A 90-year-old Singaporean noodle vendor, Leong Yuet Meng, continues to run a stall despite her frailty, selling over 200 bowls a day. The city-state's hawker culture, with over 6,000 stalls, is at risk of disappearing as younger generations shun the physically demanding jobs for office work. The government has submitted a bid to UNESCO to recognize the culture, but faces challenges in encouraging younger hawkers to take over. To address this, the government has introduced schemes to teach business skills and subsidize equipment and rent, but more needs to be done to ensure the long-term viability of the industry.

site_title: France tries to set trend with internet tax bill
summary: France is set to introduce a bill taxing internet and technology giants on their digital sales, with a 3% tax on sales of over 750 million euros, to curb global tax evasion. The move aims to generate 500 million euros and is part of France's efforts to reach a worldwide agreement on the issue. The tax will be in addition to taxes already owed by the companies, and affects around 30 companies from the US, China, and other countries.

site_title: White meat or dark? UK farmers had it all worked out, until now
summary: UK farmers face a major problem as Brexit threatens to disrupt the country's carcass balance, where one country's leftovers are another's prized cuts. Most British customers now prefer white meat, while Eastern European countries crave dark meat. This imbalance could lead to devastating losses for farmers, who need to export unwanted cuts to maintain profitability. Tariffs and border checks could further exacerbate the issue, potentially creating a two-tier market where only richer Britons can afford the best fresh chicken.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.14% to 29,003.25. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up, driven by investors returning after previous day's losses and awaiting updates on China-US trade talks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.64 points to 1,684.98. The market saw 31.51 million lots traded worth RM16.13 million, with gainers beating losers 102 to 48. The decline was not directly attributed to any specific event.

site_title: Italy plans to join China's Belt and Road Initiative: FT
summary: Italy plans to sign a memorandum of understanding to join China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) by the end of March, despite criticism from the US, which views the project as a 'made by China, for China' initiative. The BRI aims to link China with Southeast Asia, the Middle East, Europe, and Africa through infrastructure development, boosting trade, investment, and exchanges in science, technology, culture, and education. The move is seen as a strategic partnership for Italy, but its economic benefits are questioned by the US.

site_title: Canada FM decries China halting canola shipments
summary: Canada's Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland has criticized China for halting shipments of Canadian canola to the country, citing "no scientific reasons" for the move. The decision affects Richardson International, a major canola exporter, and risks leaving Canadian farmers with a glut. The move is the latest escalation in tensions between Ottawa and Beijing, which have been strained since the December arrest of Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou.

site_title: Value of rare whisky rockets in Knight Frank's lucrative assets index
summary: Rare whisky saw a 40% value increase in 2018, outperforming collectors' coins, which rose 12%. Over 10 years, rare whisky's value surged 600%. This surpasses Britain's FTSE share index 12% decline in 2018. The Knight Frank Luxury Investment Index included rare whisky for the first time, marking its debut among alternative assets.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower tracking falls in US shares
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, tracking falls in US shares. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.32% to 21,656.97, while the Topix index dropped 0.19%. Investors are cautious due to US-China trade talks and Brexit negotiations.

site_title: Transforming logistics
summary: Key game-changers in the logistics sector in Singapore are embracing digitalization and talent development to stand out and move the sector forward. As the country's backbone of trade and goods flow, logistics firms must adapt to stay competitive. Singapore has consistently ranked as Asia's top logistics hub, but global rivals are emerging, prompting firms to innovate. By leveraging digitalization and developing talent, logistics firms can enhance efficiency, reduce costs, and maintain their position in the market. This shift is crucial for Singapore's economy, which relies heavily on the logistics sector.

site_title: Nico Steel files key aluminium alloy trademark in China
summary: Nico Steel has registered a trademark for its proprietary aluminium alloy material, NICO AL50, with China's National Intellectual Property Administration. The trademark protects the unique symbol and design for the Nico range of products, used in LED display panels, smartphones, and drones. The company expects new orders for NICO AL50 to contribute positively to its financial results, with shares rising 0.1 Singapore cent to S$0.006 following the news.

site_title: CEO of oldest bank in Sweden 'humbled' by laundering allegations
summary: Swedbank AB CEO Birgitte Bonnesen has acknowledged the need to change her handling of money laundering allegations, feeling "humbled" by the scandal. The bank is accused of handling $6 billion in suspicious funds linked to the Estonian dirty money scandal. Swedbank has lost about a fifth of its market value since the allegations surfaced in February. Investor Bill Browder plans to file a criminal complaint against the bank, citing evidence supporting the allegations.

site_title: Virgin Atlantic won't make female flight attendants wear makeup or skirts anymore
summary: Virgin Atlantic has announced changes to its uniform policy for female flight attendants, allowing them to choose between wearing makeup and skirts or opting for a more relaxed, pants-only uniform. The airline cited a desire to give employees more choice and individuality while maintaining its signature style. This move is seen as a step towards a more inclusive and flexible work environment, reflecting a broader shift in the aviation industry.

site_title: Australia's economy slows ahead of election
summary: Australia's economic growth slowed to 0.2% in the second half of 2018, with annual growth at 2.3% and consumer spending weakening. Conservative Prime Minister Scott Morrison's re-election campaign is based on economic stewardship, but the slowdown has raised concerns about a potential Labor government. The central bank is expected to cut interest rates to support households, and markets anticipate up to two cuts by the end of 2019. The slow growth has thrust the issue into the election campaign, with Morrison's government citing the need for fiscal stimulus to boost the economy.

images.alt_text: Australia's economic growth ground to a near halt in the second-half of 2018, official data showed Wednesday, thrusting the issue to the front and centre of an already contentious general election campaign.

site_title: Grab secures US$1.46b investment from SoftBank Vision Fund; eyes growth in Indonesia
summary: Grab secures $1.46 billion in funding from SoftBank Vision Fund, bringing total investment to over $4.5 billion. The company plans to use funds to advance its "super app" vision in Southeast Asia, expanding services such as GrabFood, GrabExpress, and partnerships with HOOQ, Ping An Good Doctor, and Booking Holdings. Grab aims to boost its Indonesian business, which saw revenue more than double in 2018, and roll out new verticals, including on-demand video and insurance services.

site_title: Singapore shares inch slightly higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.04% to 3,235.42
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.04% to 3,235.42 on Wednesday, driven by 68 gains for every 44 losses. Active stocks included Cache Logistics Trust, Genting Singapore, Suntec Reit, and Keppel Reit, with some stocks up 0.7% to 1.04%. The gains come ahead of upcoming GDP data and amid a global stock rally.

site_title: Tencent-backed Sea raises US$1.35b in share sale
summary: Sea Ltd, a Singapore-based internet company, has raised US$1.35 billion through a share sale, increasing the initial offering from 50 million shares to 60 million. The shares were sold at US$22.50 apiece, a 6.5 discount to its last close in New York. An affiliate of Tencent Holdings and a separate firm linked to a Sea director are expected to buy 6.3 million shares at the discounted price. This is part of a trend of Asian-Pacific firms raising US$14.2 billion in equity offerings in the US over the past 12 months.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Hyflux, ESR-Reit, Raffles Education, Transcorp Holdings
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Hyflux subsidiary Tuaspring Pte Ltd received a default notice from Singapore's water agency for failing to keep its desalination plant operational. ESR-Reit secured a $155 million loan facility to refinance existing debt and acquire assets. Raffles Education cancelled a planned rights issue due to market conditions. Transcorp Holdings issued a notice to recover $2.6 million in advance deposits from a supplier.

site_title: China's worst banking stock last year is the best performer this year
summary: China's worst banking stock last year, Ping An Bank, has become the best performer this year, rising 39% in 2019 and outpacing the sector's average. Analysts attribute this to its focus on retail banking, which is less cyclical and provides higher returns. Ping An Bank's retail operations have a lower bad-loan ratio and higher return on equity compared to its corporate lending business, making it an attractive investment. The bank's strength in retail banking is expected to continue, potentially fueling further gains.

site_title: ESR-Reit secures S$155m loan facility; files proofs of claim against Hyflux
summary: ESR-Reit secured a S$155 million loan facility to refinance debt, acquire assets, and improve existing ones. The loan, comprising two tranches, will mature in 36 and 48 months. The lenders include the Singapore branches of ANZ, CTBC Bank, and Standard Chartered Bank. Separately, the Reit's trustee filed proofs of claim against Hyflux, a water treatment firm, which leases its property, citing potential losses if Hyflux had defaulted on rent. Despite this, leasing interest for the property has increased due to its location near a future Tuas Mega Port.

site_title: China's Huawei opens its gates in widening PR assault
summary: Chinese telecom giant Huawei is opening its headquarters to foreign media, a move seen as part of a counter-offensive against US warnings that the company could be used for espionage and sabotage. Huawei's founder Ren Zhengfei has given interviews to foreign media to deny the threat, while executives have dismissed US warnings as baseless. The company aims to boost its image and counter US pressure, which has led to a ban on its equipment in the US. This move is part of Huawei's aggressive PR campaign to address concerns and maintain its global reputation.

site_title: Samsung working on two more foldable smartphones
summary: Samsung is working on two new foldable smartphones, following the success of its Galaxy Fold. The devices, expected to be released later this year or early next year, will have different designs: one with an extra screen on the outside and another that folds away from the user. Samsung aims to improve the durability of the Galaxy Fold's display, which has a crease that develops after 10,000 folds. The company forecasts production of at least 1 million foldable phones this year, seeking to gain an edge in the new market segment and lure back consumers.

site_title: Grab considers raising more funds after US$4.5b financing round
summary: Grab, South-east Asia's top ride-hailing firm, is considering raising more funds from strategic investors after securing over US$4.5 billion in a financing round led by SoftBank's Vision Fund. Grab's president, Ming Maa, stated that the company is seeing strong interest from global investors and may consider upsizing the financing in the future. Grab, valued at US$11 billion, is focused on growing its market and business, rather than pursuing an IPO at this time.

site_title: China remains key market for local firms, says Enterprise Singapore
summary: Singaporean companies will continue to see China as a key market, despite the country's cut to its annual growth target. The Singapore Business Federation plans to bring over 100 companies to the China International Import Expo (CIIE) in November, with a focus on trade in services, food, and agriculture. Interest has been strong among small- and medium-sized enterprises, particularly in the services, food, and agricultural products sectors. China remains Singapore's top foreign investor and biggest trading partner, with Enterprise Singapore officials calling the CIIE a valuable platform for companies to reach savvy Chinese consumers.

site_title: Worker outcomes tied to grant funding need not be wage increases: Koh Poh Koon
summary: Singapore's Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Koh Poh Koon announced that worker outcomes tied to grant funding will be assessed through a "flexible engagement" with firms, rather than solely focusing on wage increases. The Inclusive Growth Programme, set to merge with the Enterprise Development Grant, will require firms to share productivity gains with workers through various means, such as job redesign or improved working environments. The goal is to ensure deep transformation and worker participation in the process, rather than superficial changes.

site_title: Raffles Education cancels rights issue
summary: Raffles Education cancels its planned rights issue due to "recent market conditions" and its share price being below the proposed issue price. The company had planned to raise 275.86 million new shares at 10 Singapore cents, but shares closed at 8.8 cents, down 2.2% from the previous day. This decision comes after the company reassessed its market conditions and determined it was not in the best interest to proceed with the issue.

site_title: Britain eyes 27,000 skilled offshore wind jobs by 2030
summary: Britain plans to increase skilled offshore wind jobs to 27,000 by 2030, tripling the current number. The government aims to boost the industry's workforce to 33% women by 2030, up from 16% currently. This is part of the 10th sector deal announced as part of the industrial strategy to bolster businesses ahead of Brexit. Britain is already the world's largest offshore wind market, hosting 40% of globally installed wind capacity.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed, traders await movement on US-China talks
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Wednesday as investors await US-China trade talks updates, with Shanghai rising 0.7% and Hong Kong up 0.5%. Australian stocks rose despite weak economic growth data, fueling speculation of a rate cut. Analysts expect clarity on trade talks to give markets another boost, but warn of potential disappointment if a deal doesn't meet expectations. The US-China trade truce rally may fade if final terms are not agreed upon, according to OANDA senior market analyst Edward Moya.

site_title: Australia central bank calm as house prices skid, watching credit supply
summary: Australia's central banker, Governor Philip Lowe, expressed calmness over the country's housing market downturn, which is expected to have a limited impact on its 27-year recession-free expansion. Lowe urged banks to ease credit supply to mitigate the effect of lower housing prices on household consumption. The labor market is seen as a critical factor in assessing monetary policy, with a tightening labor market expected to boost wages growth and counteract the impact of lower housing prices.

site_title: US Federal Reserve mulls tighter rules on foreign bank branches: Sources
summary: The US Federal Reserve is considering stricter rules on foreign bank branches, which could impact lenders like Deutsche Bank, Credit Suisse Group, and UBS Group. The proposed changes aim to tighten the current loophole that allows overseas lenders to shield assets from tougher US bank rules by holding more liquid assets. This move could increase costs for foreign banks and potentially inflame tensions with European regulators. The changes are part of a broader package to be unveiled by the Fed in coming weeks.

site_title: Design Studio: Loan waiver conditional on not paying out dividends; accounts for S$19.1m loss from one-off items
summary: Design Studio Group received a loan waiver on a S$3 million bank loan, provided it refrains from paying out dividends if it records a full-year loss after tax. The loan, due on March 6, 2019, has been extended till June 6, 2019. The company reported a S$19.1 million loss in FY2018, primarily due to one-off items such as manufacturing operations in Malaysia, factory overheads, and staff redundancy. Design Studio is addressing excess capacity and consolidating operations to mitigate losses.

site_title: Companies falsely labeled products 'Made in USA.' Their financial penalty? $0
summary: The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has reached proposed consent agreements with four US companies that falsely labeled their products as "Made in USA." The companies, including Patriot Puck and Nectar Sleep, were accused of violating federal law by making false claims about their products' origins. The FTC will not impose fines, and the companies will not be required to admit wrongdoing or notify customers. Democratic lawmakers are criticizing the FTC's leniency, urging the agency to pursue tougher punishments for companies profiting from producing products in China and mislabeling them as American-made.

site_title: Niger busts fake medicines lab
summary: Police in Niger's capital Niamey have closed a lab producing fake medicines and beauty products, seizing 10 tonnes of counterfeit goods. Nine people with no medical knowledge were arrested. The lab allegedly sold its products in local markets and neighboring Nigeria. Authorities have taken action against the individuals involved, but no further information is available on the consequences of their actions.

site_title: Mandiri eyes deal for US$2 billion StanChart-backed rival
summary: Indonesia's state-run Bank Mandiri is exploring a potential US$2 billion takeover of PT Bank Permata, a rival lender backed by Standard Chartered. Mandiri is working with Morgan Stanley on the deal, considering buying control of Permata and merging it with itself or its unit Bank Mantap. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to expand Mandiri's market share, as Permata's shares have risen 76% this year, valuing the lender at US$2.2 billion. The potential deal is subject to formal talks and may be influenced by Standard Chartered's decision to consider its Permata investment as non-core.

site_title: Urban Outfitters starts 2019 on frosty note, shares slip
summary: Urban Outfitters Inc reported a weaker start to 2019, citing colder weather and costly fashion line mistakes. The company forecast a possible drop in same-store sales, leading to a 3.5% decline in shares to $29.29. CEO Richard Hayne attributed declines in store traffic to chilly weather in California and early spring fashion line releases.

site_title: Ex-New York mayor Bloomberg rules out run for US president in 2020
summary: Former New York mayor Michael Bloomberg has ruled out a presidential run in 2020, citing the difficulty of winning the Democratic nomination in a crowded field. He acknowledged the leftward tilt among other major Democratic candidates and stated he would not change his views to match the polls. Bloomberg, a billionaire Democrat, previously positioned himself as a potential challenger to Donald Trump.

site_title: China to take steps to boost domestic consumption this year: state planner
summary: China's state planner, Ning Jizhe, announced the government will implement measures to boost domestic consumption this year, aiming to expand the economy by 6.0 to 6.5% in 2019. This comes after the economy grew 6.6% in 2018, with private consumption being a key driver. The government plans to boost urban and rural residents' incomes to further enhance domestic consumption. China is confident of meeting its economic growth target for 2019.

images.alt_text: China's state planner said on Wednesday that the government will implement measures to further boost domestic consumption this year.

site_title: Adidas executive sentenced to jail for bribing basketball players
summary: A former Adidas executive, Jim Gatto, was sentenced to 9 months in prison for bribing young basketball players to secure their loyalty to the company. Gatto, who was Adidas' marketing director, made payments to star high school basketball players to steer them towards universities sponsored by Adidas, secure professional contracts, and sign with agent Christian Dawkins. The case highlights the excesses of amateur sports in the US.

site_title: Venezuela's Guaido tells Maduro 'pressure just beginning'
summary: Venezuela's opposition leader Juan Guaido vowed to intensify pressure on President Nicolas Maduro, saying "the pressure had just begun" after defying threats of arrest to return home. Guaido stated that Maduro's government is "drowning in contradictions" and unable to respond to the Venezuelan people's demands. Despite Maduro's silence, Guaido's homecoming was met with a hero's welcome in Caracas, indicating a shift in public opinion.

site_title: Europe: Shares eke out in directionless choppy session
summary: European stocks rose 0.2% at close, extending a three-day rally, as trading remained directionless due to lack of news on Sino/US trade talks. The Stoxx 600 hovered around the flotation mark. Analyst Connor Campbell attributed the trading to no overriding theme. The rally was supported by mining and healthcare shares.

site_title: High gas prices threaten Australian manufacturers
summary: Australia's gas prices are threatening the imminent shutdown of manufacturing operations on the east coast, according to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. Chairman Rod Sims warned that high gas costs and electricity prices are making it difficult for businesses, posing an imminent threat. The watchdog urges gas producers to boost local supply and offer reasonable prices. States are also needed to lift blanket drilling bans to encourage new gas development.

site_title: Shanghai Stock Exchange says China's planned tech board now in 'sprint stage'
summary: China's proposed Nasdaq-style technology board has entered the "sprint" stage, with the Shanghai Stock Exchange (SSE) expecting the technical system to be ready by May. The board's issuance and listing systems are already ready, and a debugging test is planned for March. The SSE has published trading and listing rules for the board, aiming to smooth the way for Chinese IPOs.

site_title: Impact Investment Exchange partners Australia government body for US$100m bond
summary: Impact Investment Exchange (IIX) has partnered with the Australian Government's Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) for a US$100 million Women's Livelihood Bond (WLB2) Program. The bond, launched in the second quarter of 2019, aims to benefit one million underserved women in Asia. Proceeds will be allocated to impact enterprises, with issuances listed on a stock exchange and sold to global investors. This partnership seeks to drive women's empowerment and grow the impact investing market, providing attractive financial products for traditional private sector investors.

site_title: France's Charles de Gaulle aircraft carrier sets off for Asia
summary: France's aircraft carrier Charles de Gaulle set sail from Toulon for an Asian deployment, following a two-year refurbishment and upgrade process. The 18-month refit included upgrades to radars, communications, combat systems, and nuclear reactors, extending the ship's service life to 20 years. The vessel will travel to the Indian Ocean and Singapore, marking a significant milestone in France's military presence in the region.

site_title: NTU, Volvo launch world's first autonomous electric bus for trial
summary: Singapore's Nanyang Technological University (NTU) and Volvo have launched the world's first autonomous electric bus for trial, with the bus capable of traveling 25km on a full charge. Equipped with AI technology, the bus can navigate through traffic conditions and reach a location accuracy of 1cm. The on-the-road trials will begin later this year, with the goal of being a successful tenderer for the Government's plans to deploy autonomous vehicles in Singapore by 2022.

site_title: Airlines lack clear flight path to lower carbon emissions: researchers
summary: Researchers from the London School of Economics' Grantham Research Institute warn that top publicly listed airlines have significantly reduced their "emissions intensity" in recent years, but have yet to set clear long-term targets for reducing emissions to meet internationally agreed climate goals. This lack of clear plans is concerning, as airlines are not making the necessary emissions reductions to meet climate goals. The researchers urge airlines to set ambitious targets to reduce their carbon footprint.

site_title: Digital era will force Singapore banks to be more transparent with customers
summary: Singapore banks will be required to be more transparent with customers as regulators push for greater financial literacy and planning. The Personal Data Protection Commission and Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore are studying the introduction of a data portability requirement, allowing individuals to easily switch between competing offers. This move aims to cut switching costs and promote greater consumer protection. As fintech firms gain traction, banks must adapt to the digital era and prioritize data analytics, customer service, and financial planning to remain competitive.

site_title: Taleb was right. We're still fooled by randomness
summary: A new study suggests that even successful fund managers are often "lucky" rather than skilled, with winning streaks attributed to chance rather than expertise. This finding aligns with Nassim Nicholas Taleb's 2001 book "Fooled by Randomness," which argues that randomness plays a significant role in success, particularly in finance. The study's results contradict the conventional notion that talented managers consistently outperform their benchmarks.

site_title: Louis Vuitton ends Paris fashion week with night in two museums
summary: Louis Vuitton's Paris fashion week show ended with a surprise twist, as guests were initially led to the Louvre Museum before being transported to the Pompidou Centre, a kilometre away. Designer Nicolas Ghesquiere had recreated the Pompidou's modern art galleries inside the Louvre, showcasing his "shock" concept. The unconventional venue demonstrated the innovative and unexpected nature of the new designs.

site_title: Asia still leads the world when it comes to minting billionaires
summary: Asia is expected to see the fastest billionaire population growth, with a 27% increase to 1,003 billionaires by 2023, accounting for over a third of the world's total. The region's growth rate surpasses North America and Europe, with India leading the way with a 39% surge. The Asia-Pacific region is also expected to see the largest increase in ultra-high net worth individuals, with China and the Philippines following closely.

site_title: Trump plans to end preferential trade treatment for India
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to end preferential trade treatment for India, allowing duty-free entry for up to $5.6 billion worth of exports, effective 60 days after notifications to Congress and the Indian government. The move is seen as a punitive action against India, which has high tariffs, and is expected to hit farm, marine, and handicraft products. India downplays the impact, saying it is keeping retaliatory tariffs out of talks with the US.

site_title: Shareholder e-voting on agenda as Singapore trials blockchain-based system
summary: Singapore is set to trial a blockchain-based electronic voting system for shareholder meetings, with the help of four major banks and the Singapore Exchange. The system aims to improve speed, accuracy, and security, and will enable real-time monitoring of voting results. The trial, led by Belgium's Swift, is part of a broader effort to explore the use of distributed ledger technology (DLT) in the capital market. The system is expected to reduce paperwork and increase transparency, with potential benefits including improved straight-through-processing and reduced operational risks.

site_title: Cheap eggs get a boost from Australia's stagnant wages
summary: Australia's stagnant wages and a slumping property market have led to an increase in egg consumption, with a 6% jump to 6 billion eggs in the year ending June 2018, or 245 eggs per person. Affordability is the main reason for the growth, as prices of other farm products have risen due to a drought in eastern states. This is a positive trend for the egg industry, contrasting with declines in beef and chicken consumption.

site_title: US: Stocks edge lower amid questions on trade talks
summary: US stocks closed slightly lower on Tuesday amid uncertainty over US-China trade talks and the US economic outlook. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.1% to 25,806.63, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined 0.1%. Investors sought clarity on trade talks and the US economic outlook, but no significant developments were reported. The US stock market ended the session at fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: GE's CEO warns of negative industrial cash flow in 2019, shares drop
summary: General Electric's CEO Larry Culp forecasted a negative industrial cash flow in 2019, citing the ailing power-plant unit as the main reason. This gloomy outlook led to a sharp decline in shares and bonds. The stock, which had gained nearly 36% this year, fell below a third of its value in mid-2016. The announcement dealt another blow to investors who had seen the conglomerate slash its dividend and take massive asset write-downs and insurance charges last year.

site_title: China announces plan to form oil and pipeline firm
summary: China announced plans to form a national oil and pipeline company, the first public acknowledgment of a massive energy industry overhaul since 2014. The new company will separate transmission and sales businesses, removing impediments to oil and gas exploration. The creation of the pipeline company was mentioned in the National Development & Reform Commission's work report during the National People's Congress meeting. The move aims to reform the energy sector and is part of the government's efforts to increase efficiency and reduce costs. No further details on the company or timing of its creation were provided.

site_title: Smart data could be key to help restore trust in corporate reporting: EY
summary: A new study by EY suggests that smart data and technological advancements can help restore public trust in corporate reporting and improve decision-making. However, businesses are not fully utilizing the vast amounts of financial and non-financial information they collect. Only 58% of CFOs surveyed believe that businesses are highly trusted by the public, and many are not leveraging non-financial information to raise trust. EY recommends that businesses adopt new frameworks, use smart data, and upgrade their talent pool to stay on top of data management.

site_title: Yum China banking on robot servers, AI menus to defy slowdown
summary: Yum China Holdings Inc, the owner of KFC and Pizza Hut brands in China, is expanding at a rapid pace, opening two stores a day, despite economic concerns. Despite a trade war with the US and slow economic growth, CEO Joey Wat remains optimistic about the fried chicken and pan pizza market. Yum China is positioning itself as a tech-driven brand suite for China's growing middle class, focusing on fun and modern offerings, unlike its US counterparts. The company aims to open over 11,000 more outlets.

site_title: Local staff must earn S$1,300 or more to count in quotas
summary: The Singapore government has increased the "local qualifying salary" for foreign workers to S$1,300 starting from July, as part of its efforts to tighten its foreign worker policy and promote economic restructuring. This move aims to give a stronger push to making Singapore more manpower-lean, particularly in the services sector. The hike is made in line with current wage trends and is expected to have a small cost impact. The government also plans to cut the quota for foreign workers in the services sector from 40% to 35% starting January 1, 2021.

site_title: Japan plans rule change to spur regional bank consolidation
summary: Japan's government plans to change its anti-monopoly rules to encourage regional bank consolidation, aiming to address declining profits and a shrinking population. The proposed exemptions will allow regional banks to merge more easily for 5-10 years. The move is part of a growth strategy to be announced this summer, and reflects Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's desire for greater transparency on bank consolidation. The government hopes to submit the legislation to parliament next year, but has not yet decided on the details. This change aims to improve the financial health of regional banks affected by years of low interest rates.

site_title: Elon Musk should be enabled to step back from Tesla, investor says
summary: Tesla's largest investor, James Anderson, suggests that CEO Elon Musk should step back from being overly outspoken, as it hinders the company's mission. Anderson, a partner at Baillie Gifford & Co., claims to have failed to persuade Musk to adopt a more peaceful approach in July. Musk later settled a Securities and Exchange Commission lawsuit and ramped up Model 3 production. Anderson believes Musk should be "enabled to step back from having to feel so driven to comment." This comes after Musk secured funding, abandoned the pursuit, and made significant production progress.

site_title: New permanent secretaries for several ministries from April 1
summary: Singapore has announced changes to senior leadership ranks in five ministries and two agencies starting April 1. The Ministry of Education will get two new permanent secretaries, while the Ministry of Communications and Information, Ministry of Trade and Industry, and Ministry of Home Affairs will also receive new appointments. Lai Chung Han will relinquish his current roles and be appointed Second Permanent Secretary at MOE, while Lai Wei Lin will be the only new permanent secretary appointed. Outgoing Permanent Secretary Chan Lai Fung will be appointed Permanent Secretary at the National Research & Development agency.

site_title: Goldman sees more gains in China's yuan
summary: Goldman Sachs forecasts the Chinese yuan to advance about 1.5% to 6.6 per dollar in the next 12 months, slightly more bullish than the 6.7% forecast in January. The currency has surged 2.7% in 2019 due to China's economic recovery, driven by stimulus measures and infrastructure investments. This view contradicts analysts at NatWest Markets and Commerzbank AG, who predict the yuan's depreciation. China's top economic planner has stated that the yuan will be kept stable at reasonable levels and the exchange rate will be increased in flexibility.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Far East Group plans to acquire Tech Air-Con & Security Engineering for S$7 million in cash and new shares, representing 2.75% of the company's existing shares. 8Telecom International Holdings replaced two executive directors with two former Eastern Airlines staff and disclosed changes in major shareholder interests, with private company Tian Di Internet acquiring a 10.67% stake in the company.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Chasing Cars: Choosing a mechanic
summary: The Money FM podcast "Chasing Cars: Choosing a mechanic" discusses the importance of selecting a reliable mechanic for vehicle maintenance. The episode highlights common mistakes people make when choosing a mechanic, such as relying on price rather than quality. Experts emphasize the need to research and read reviews to find a trustworthy mechanic. The podcast also emphasizes the importance of communicating clearly with the mechanic and asking questions to ensure a smooth repair process. Ultimately, choosing a skilled mechanic can help prevent costly repairs and ensure a vehicle's longevity.

site_title: Luke Perry, star of Beverly Hills 90210, dies
summary: Luke Perry, 52, star of the hit 1990s TV series Beverly Hills 90210, died on March 5, 2019, after suffering a massive stroke while working on the TV series Riverdale. Perry was hospitalized in Los Angeles and surrounded by his family and friends at the time of his death. He played Dylan McKay on Beverly Hills 90210 and was also known for his roles in Riverdale, Buffy the Vampire Slayer, and The Simpsons. Tributes poured in from his former co-stars, including Shannen Doherty and Molly Ringwald, who expressed their grief and condolences on social media.

site_title: Don't expect more than a lull in the Sino-American trade war
summary: US President Donald Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping are set to sign a trade deal in Florida, marking a potential lull in the ongoing Sino-American trade war. Trump's decision to scrap planned tariffs on Chinese goods and agree to increased purchases of US agricultural products suggests he may be seeking to avoid rocking the economy ahead of the 2020 presidential campaign. Despite this, major differences remain between the two countries, and tensions are likely to persist, with potential implications for the global economy.

site_title: The AI way to cleaner air for smart cities
summary: Singapore can excel in deploying artificial intelligence to achieve a cleaner, greener environment in smart cities. The government aims to collect nearly $1 billion in carbon tax revenues and spend more on projects that reduce emissions. AI-powered systems can analyze real-time data from sensors and IoT devices to identify pollution hotspots, allowing for proactive measures to reduce emissions. This technology can also enable autonomous decision-making, such as remotely turning off polluting engines in self-driving cars. Singapore can take a first-mover advantage in AI-enabled emissions abatement, leveraging its expertise to power environmental innovation and drive better public health.

site_title: Khazanah posts weak results; plans to revamp fund under two groups
summary: Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund, Khazanah Nasional, has announced a new investment strategy that divides its portfolio into a commercial and strategic fund, following weak results in 2018. The restructuring aims to deliver more cash to the government by pruning non-strategic assets. Khazanah's realisable asset value fell to RM136 billion in 2018, with a loss before tax of RM6.27 billion. The fund plans to target a 3% return on its commercial fund and is considering selling non-core assets, including Legoland Malaysia Resort.

site_title: Driven by a vision
summary: Haulio, a container haulage startup, aims to modernize the logistics sector with its digital platform. Co-founders Alvin Ea and Sebastian Shen, both in their 30s, left their family businesses to pursue a dream of revolutionizing the industry. The company seeks to address issues of fragmentation and manual processes, with a focus on fresh ideas and new blood. By leveraging technology, Haulio aims to breathe life into an ageing workforce and create a new era for the logistics sector.

site_title: Teeny tiny handbag becomes big fashion sensation
summary: Jacquemus' miniature handbag, "Le Mini Chiquito", has become a big fashion sensation at Paris fashion week, sparking excitement and humor on social media. The tiny bag, only 5.2cm long, is a shrunken version of the US$500 "Le Chiquito" bag and has sold "tens of thousands" of units, with lengthy waiting lists for some colors. Fashionistas are embracing the trend, using their imagination to come up with creative uses for the bag, while the brand's founder, Simon Porte, has gained a following for his affordable prices and personal charm.

site_title: HK releasing less land for new private homes
summary: Hong Kong's government has announced plans to release just 15 residential sites in the fiscal year starting April 1, providing around 8,800 private homes, a 42% decrease from last year. This move aims to address the city's housing shortage by increasing focus on public housing. The reduced private land supply is expected to slow down home sales over the next three to four years, potentially putting a floor under falling residential property prices.

site_title: Thinking of flouting rules on hiring foreigners? Watch out
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Josephine Teo has warned employers that they will be held accountable if they unfairly treat locals in hiring. The Fair Consideration Framework ensures fair hiring practices, and 350 employers are currently on the watchlist for violating this rule. Since 2016, 2,300 EP applications have been rejected or withdrawn due to hiring practices. The Tripartite Alliance for Fair and Progressive Employment Practices (TAFEP) works with these companies to improve their HR practices, and 260 firms have been taken off the watchlist.

site_title: Hillary Clinton rules out 2020 presidential run
summary: Hillary Clinton has ruled out a 2020 presidential run, stating she's "not running" but will continue to work and speak out on issues. The move comes after months of speculation, and she will remain a presence in the Democratic Party despite her loss in 2016. Several female candidates, including Kamala Harris and Elizabeth Warren, have already entered the primary campaign, while others, like Bernie Sanders and Joe Biden, are considering a run. Clinton plans to continue speaking out and advocating for her beliefs, signaling she won't be leaving politics anytime soon.

site_title: Why standards matter in the food industry
summary: Standards play a crucial role in Singapore's food industry, enabling innovation, improving quality and reliability, and facilitating market access. The country's food safety management systems, such as ISO 22000 and BRC Global Standard, ensure the integrity of products across the food value chain. Non-traditional food concepts, such as food vending machines, have also gained popularity, prompting regulatory intervention. Industry associations, like Food Industry Asia, are working to develop new standards, giving companies a competitive edge in global markets. By adopting standards, Singapore aims to become Asia's leading food and nutrition hub.

site_title: Moody's cuts Singtel outlook to 'negative', warns of further risks to A1 credit rating
summary: Moody's cut Singtel's outlook to "negative" due to earnings and debt concerns. The credit rating agency cited price competition and expected increased leverage in a potential rights issue at Bharti Airtel, putting Singtel's A1 credit rating at risk. Singtel's net debt-to-Ebitda ratio and projected debt from a Bharti Airtel fund-raising exercise also contributed to the downgrade. Despite this, Singtel maintained its senior unsecured rating of A1, citing its leading market positions and diversified cash flow.

site_title: Franchise sales-related expenses added to jump in 2018 payables: Best World
summary: Best World International reported a more than doubling of trade and other payables to S$95.1 million in 2018, driven by sales-related expenses from its franchise segment. The company incurred S$3.7 million in sales-related expenses, mainly for marketing support and training services, and S$12.1 million for distribution costs. These expenses were recorded in the income statement and will be paid in 2019. The company's revenue increased 24% in 2018, leading to a 24% decrease in cost of sales despite a higher revenue, due to advance orders placed by an export agent in 2017.

site_title: Mind the labour gap
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat has announced measures to address the country's labour gap in the services sector, with the aim of reducing the Services Dependency Ratio Ceiling from 40% to 38% by next year. The move aims to curb foreign manpower tightening and encourage local hiring. The government also emphasizes the need for firms to redesign jobs, adopt flexible work arrangements, and upskill workers, particularly older workers and Professionals, Managers, Executives, and Technicians (PMETs).

site_title: With personal data comes great responsibility
summary: Singapore businesses handling online transactions and customer personal data must comply with the Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA). The PDPA requires nine obligations, including consent, purpose, and notification, and appointing a data protection officer (DPO) to manage personal data. SMEs must also develop and implement a data breach management and response plan, with mandatory breach notification requirements proposed by the PDPC. Non-compliance can result in significant financial penalties and reputational damage, with the average cost of a data breach globally estimated at US$3.84 million.

site_title: Ghosn closer to release as Tokyo court grants bail request
summary: Tokyo court grants bail to former Nissan Motor Co chairman Carlos Ghosn, allowing him to spend more time with his defense team ahead of his trial. The bail decision comes after 107 days in custody, with conditions including staying in Japan, having cameras set up in his home, and limiting contact with the outside world. Prosecutors have appealed the decision, potentially keeping Ghosn incarcerated until his trial. If convicted, Ghosn could face a decade in prison for aggravated breach of trust and filing false statements.

site_title: UK shoppers slow their spending ahead of Brexit
summary: UK shoppers slowed their spending in February ahead of Brexit, with total sales up 0.5% compared to 2.2% in January. Consumer confidence levels are at five-year lows as the scheduled Brexit date of March 29 approaches. Shoppers focused on buying food and essentials, with 18% stockpiling food and supplies. Non-essential spending slowed, and pubs and restaurants saw a decline in spending. The uncertainty surrounding Brexit is driving consumers to cut back on non-essential spend and prepare for potential shortages.

site_title: AT&T reshuffles WarnerMedia team, merges HBO with Turner
summary: AT&T has reorganized its WarnerMedia team, merging HBO with Turner networks and giving a broader portfolio to CNN chief Jeff Zucker. The new WarnerMedia Entertainment unit, led by TV veteran Robert Greenblatt, will include HBO, TNT, TBS, and truTV. The unit will also manage a "direct-to-consumer" streaming service, set to launch this year. The reorganization comes after an appeals court confirmed AT&T's acquisition of Time Warner, and aims to compete with streaming rivals like Netflix. The move gives WarnerMedia a more comprehensive portfolio of brands and intellectual property.

site_title: Don't fault ex-Barclays traders for high pay, says judge
summary: A London judge instructed a jury to disregard the high salaries of three former Barclays traders accused of rigging a key interest rate. The traders, Carlo Palombo, Colin Bermingham, and Sisse Bohart, are being tried for their alleged roles in manipulating the Euro interbank offered rate from 2005 to 2009. The judge emphasized that remuneration may play a role in deliberations if a defendant could gain financially from helping the bank earn more. The jury will focus on the defendants' intent and whether they deliberately disregarded proper Euribor submissions.

site_title: Airlines not doing enough to tackle climate change: investor group
summary: A study by the Transition Pathway Initiative, funded by $13 trillion in investor assets, found that airlines are not doing enough to combat climate change, despite accounting for 2% of global greenhouse gas emissions. The review of 20 major airlines rated Delta, Lufthansa, United Airlines, and ANA Holdings as the best performers in managing climate risks, but all could improve. The study recommends more fuel-efficient planes, biofuels, and full capacity flights to limit emissions. Investors, including BNP Paribas and Legal & General Investment Management, are urging airlines to prioritize long-term sustainability.

site_title: Making moves
summary: The logistics industry in Singapore, a crucial backbone of the economy, is under pressure to modernize and adopt technology to stay competitive. Small to mid-sized logistics firms, often family-run businesses, are lagging behind traditional players and manual processes. A startup, Haulio, is leading the way by creating a digital platform to match container trucking companies to jobs, moving over 100,000 containers in 2018. Other issues discussed include the suitability of co-working spaces for SMEs, the importance of data protection for SMEs, and the need for creativity in the food industry.

site_title: Government, unions and employers agree to raise retirement, re-employment age
summary: Singapore's Tripartite Workgroup on Older Workers has agreed to lift the mandatory retirement and re-employment ages, currently set at 62 and 67 years respectively. The decision, backed by Manpower Minister Josephine Teo, aims to encourage older workers to continue working and investing in skills upgrades. The retirement age will remain at 65, and the re-employment age will be raised in "small steps over time" to ensure employers can adjust. The move is expected to benefit the economy, with employers and labor unions generally supporting the change.

site_title: Keeping your cool while cutting costs
summary: Barghest Building Performance, a Singapore startup, has developed an innovative energy efficiency solution using data analytics to enhance the sustainability of heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) systems. The company's proprietary software and customized engineering allow for a 40% reduction in energy consumption, resulting in annual savings of S$100,000 to S$3 million for commercial and industrial buildings. By offering a subscription model, BBP eliminates upfront costs, making its solution competitive and creating a win-win scenario for customers. With over 50 employees serving customers across eight geographies, BBP is poised for growth in the Asia-Pacific and worldwide.

site_title: It's time SGX and sponsors get tougher with firms looking to list
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has faced criticism for its lack of scrutiny in allowing companies with questionable business models to list. Several cases have highlighted material errors and potential fraud, including Y Ventures, No Signboard, and Ayondo. These companies have reported significant losses, inventory errors, and share buyback violations. Regulators must review the due diligence done by sponsors and auditors, and hold those responsible accountable. The SGX's failure to address these issues may lead to more fraud in its listed companies. Investors are urged to question the board and management about steps to address the situation.

site_title: Batam's latest crown jewel project
summary: Former Indonesian President BJ Habibie's company, Pollux Habibie International (PHI), celebrated the topping-off ceremony for its second residential tower on Batam Island, part of the Meisterstadt Batam project. The project aims to establish an urban landscape on the island, with a 860,000 sq ft mega-mall and eight residential towers. The mall is expected to be completed by the second quarter of next year, with four residential towers set to be completed by the end of 2019. The project is expected to attract both locals and tourists, with units already selling 95% of the first three towers.

site_title: Some investors turning their sights to Dubai
summary: Dubai is gaining attention from investors as Saudi Arabian stocks are set to join major emerging-markets benchmarks, but Dubai's market has been battered due to real estate concerns. Despite Saudi shares trading at a premium, Dubai's market is seen as a more attractive opportunity, with potential gains of 14% in dividend yields this year. Analysts recommend a double-upgrade on UAE equities, citing fundamental improvements in the property sector and continued financial strength. Dubai is poised to become a hub for businesses expanding into the Middle Eastern and African markets.

site_title: Even a trade deal will be much ado about nothing much
summary: The US and China are close to a deal that would end trade hostilities, with the US removing most tariffs and China ending retaliatory tariffs and making changes to its investment and competition policies. However, the deal does little to address real complaints about Chinese policy and US President Donald Trump's trade imbalance, with Trump having backed down. The agreement undermines America's reputation and global economy, with the world now knowing that the US is unreliable and easily rolled.

site_title: PUB to take over Tuaspring plant if latter's defaults not resolved
summary: Hyflux's subsidiary Tuaspring Pte Ltd has received a default notice from PUB for failing to keep its desalination plant "reliably operational" as required under the Water Purchase Agreement. The 30-day cure period ends on April 5, after which PUB can terminate the contract and take control of the plant. If Hyflux's restructuring scheme fails, PUB may also take back the plant, affecting Maybank's secured project finance lender. The default notice comes amid a petition by Hyflux retail investors seeking a government bailout.

Shatec has shut its Orchard campus and cut staff, putting the building up for sale. A local otah business is rebranding heritage for younger generations, while Munchi Pancakes modernises traditional min jiang kueh.

site_title: UK still staring down barrel of a no-deal Brexit
summary: The UK is facing a possible no-deal Brexit on March 29, despite a majority of MPs opposing the scenario. A no-deal exit would have severe economic impacts, with the UK's economy potentially shrinking by 6-9% over the next 15 years. The government has prepared for a no-deal scenario, including unilateral actions to maintain continuity, but the EU's response is unclear. MPs must find a majority in favor of an alternative outcome to prevent a no-deal Brexit, which could lead to a general election or further referendum.

site_title: UK negotiators seek to get Brexit 'over the line' in new EU talks
summary: UK negotiators are set to meet with EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier in Brussels, aiming to "get a deal over the line" ahead of the March 29 Brexit deadline. The talks come after Barnier offered further guarantees to help push a troubled divorce deal through the British parliament. UK attorney general Geoffrey Cox will be present, offering a legal opinion that could determine whether key MPs will approve the accord. The EU has agreed to a separate document to placate doubters in London, while some hardline Brexit supporters have softened their positions, raising hopes for a deal.

site_title: Sunningdale urged to raise reporting quality after Q4 earnings miss
summary: Sunningdale Tech, a Singapore-listed high-precision plastic components maker, has reported a Q4 earnings miss, prompting activist fund Quarz Capital Management to urge the company to increase shareholder value by clarifying one-off costs in its income statement. The estimated costs, including production ramp-up and duplication of operating costs, are over S$3 million in the fourth quarter. Quarz estimates core net profit without these costs could be S$5 million, closer to consensus estimates. The company's shares have tumbled 12.8% since the earnings report, and its board is working on a reply to Quarz's open letter.

site_title: Euro loses traction ahead of ECB meeting
summary: The euro has lost traction ahead of the European Central Bank's Thursday meeting, which is expected to hint at delaying interest rate hikes and re-launching long-term bank loans to tackle economic slowdown. The euro fell to near one-week lows versus the dollar at US$1.1318. The Canadian dollar also slumped to nearly six-week lows due to trade troubles, resignations, and expectations of a potential policy shift by the Bank of Canada. Investors are seeking out higher-yielding currencies as price volatility in major currencies has plummeted.

site_title: Trump scraps trade privilege for India; Delhi plays down impact
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to scrap preferential trade treatment for India, allowing duty-free entry for up to $5.6 billion worth of its exports to the US. The decision comes as a result of Trump's vow to cut US trade deficits and amid ongoing trade tensions between the US and China. India downplayed the impact, stating it would keep retaliatory tariffs out of talks. The move is seen as a strong punitive action against India, which has been criticized for its high tariffs and trade barriers.

site_title: Google and Apple see the ghost of future taxes
summary: France has proposed a "GAFA tax" targeting tech giants with annual global online revenues exceeding $1.2 billion, imposing a 3% tax on their gross digital sales. The tax, which could raise approximately $500 million, aims to increase public support for President Emmanuel Macron amidst the Gilets Jaunes protests. The move, inspired by an EU proposal, may lead to a unified approach across the bloc and pressure on holdout countries. The response from tech giants such as Google, Apple, and Facebook will be crucial, with potential court challenges or lobbying for a harmonized EU approach.

site_title: It's hedge funds against long-term players in Japan stock market
summary: Foreigners, particularly hedge funds, have been buying futures contracts linked to the Topix and Nikkei 225 indices, pushing Japanese equities to a three-month high. However, they have also sold off 785 billion yen of cash equities, making them net sellers of both contracts and stocks. Long-term players, such as pension and mutual funds, continue to sell, making the purchasing force "fragile." Economic data has been weak, with manufacturing contracting and disappointing company results, making Japanese equities unattractive to long-term investors, who prefer the US or emerging markets.

site_title: Sri Lanka raises sin taxes ahead of elections
summary: Sri Lanka's Finance Minister Mangala Samaraweera has introduced significant tax hikes ahead of presidential elections, including a $50 entry tax on casinos, doubling of taxes on cigarettes and alcohol, and a 20% increase on popular small Japanese cars. The measures aim to fund public sector salary increases and subsidized loans for small businesses. The country's economy has been affected by a power struggle between President Maithripala Sirisena and Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe, leading to a credit downgrade and capital flight. The government expects the economy to grow 3.5% in 2019.

site_title: Does coworking work for you?
summary: Flexible workspace centers are becoming increasingly attractive to large multinational corporations, offering a viable alternative to traditional office space. The sector has ballooned in the past two years, with corporates drawn to the affordability, community, and flexibility offered by coworking spaces. The average price of a flexible hot-desk membership in Singapore is around S$390-600 per month, while dedicated desks cost S$700-900 per month. Flexible workspace enables occupiers to adjust space needs easily, making it an attractive option for businesses seeking to adapt to changes in their workforce and market cycles.

site_title: Google moves to address wage equity, and finds it's underpaying many men
summary: Google has found that men are paid less than women for similar work, contrary to the company's efforts to address wage equity. The study, which was conducted annually, revealed that men account for 69% of the workforce but received a higher percentage of pay raises. Google has agreed to review its processes to ensure fairness and equity for all employees, including a comprehensive review of levelling, performance ratings, and promotions. The company has also given $9.7 million in additional compensation to 10,677 employees.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers' Take: Singapore Hospitality Reits have posted positive total returns year-to-date, with CDL Hospitality Trusts up 14.4%, OUE Hospitality Trust up 10.9%, Ascott Residence Trust up 10.1%, and Far East Hospitality Trust up 9.1%. OCBC Investment Research maintains an overweight rating for Singapore Hospitality, citing Ascott Residence Trust as a defensive Reit with a geographically diversified portfolio and expected gearing drop post divestment. Japfa Limited is also upgraded to Buy, maintaining a target price, driven by its Indonesian poultry segment's strong turnaround and potential market share gains.

site_title: South Carolina resident wins US$1.54b jackpot after allowing punter to cut queue
summary: A South Carolina resident claimed the record-setting US$1.54 billion Mega Millions jackpot, opting for a one-time lump sum payment of US$877,784,124. The winner, who remained anonymous, took advantage of South Carolina's lottery anonymity laws and retained a lawyer to minimize potential complications. The winning ticket was purchased at a convenience store in Simpsonville, and the store owner will receive US$50,000. The lottery commission praised the winner's decision to allow another customer to cut in line, citing "a simple act of kindness led to an amazing outcome."

site_title: China lowers annual growth forecast as slowdown accelerates
summary: China has lowered its annual growth forecast to 6-6.5% for 2019, down from a previous target of 6.5%, amid a slowdown in economic activity. The government also announced tax cuts worth 2 trillion yuan to support the economy. Premier Li Keqiang said the move was made to mitigate risks from the ongoing trade war with the US, while also addressing structural deceleration and bad debt build-up. The government aims to create over 11 million new urban jobs and control inflation at around 3%.

site_title: No easy way out of those sulphur rules
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) finalized draft guidelines for the 2020 sulphur limit, which will cap fuel sulfur content at 0.5% starting January 1, 2020. Ship-owners are advised to ensure their vessels are ready to use low-sulphur fuels, with inaction not being an option. The IMO also agreed to review the 2015 Guidelines on Exhaust Gas Cleaning Systems, and the European Commission is taking a tough line on washwater discharge, causing concern among ship-owners who have invested in scrubbers. The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) warned that ship-owners must remain focused on compliance and be prepared for potential quality or compatibility issues with new fuels.

site_title: Newly registered companies
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several new companies were registered, including Royal Healthcare, which plans to open a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka, and a NUS researcher's startup aiming to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. Meanwhile, Hao Mart's Taste Orchard faces vacant units due to poor footfall, and tenants lament the struggling mall. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec shuts its Orchard campus and cuts staff, putting its building up for sale. Additionally, businesses like Munchi Pancakes and Nanyang Old Coffee are innovating traditional snacks and rebranding heritage.

site_title: Facebook to curb foreign political ads in run-up to Indon poll
summary: Facebook has banned foreign political ads in Indonesia ahead of the country's presidential poll, following criticism from the EU for not doing enough to counter election meddling. The ban, effective immediately, restricts paid material from outside Indonesia related to politicians or voter suppression. Facebook aims to make it harder for foreign entities to interfere with elections and easier for people to make their voices heard. This move comes after Facebook unveiled new tools and rules to scrutinize political ads linked to the EU elections in May.

site_title: DBS bets on 'poisoned chalice' of India banking to lift profits
summary: DBS Group Holdings, South-east Asia's largest bank, plans to expand its operations in India to boost loans to consumers and small businesses, aiming to reduce its reliance on Singapore. The bank will push credit through its newly-formed unit and beef up physical branches and digital presence. DBS CEO Piyush Gupta views India as a "once-in-a-lifetime opportunity" to tap the world's second-most populated nation, despite the challenges posed by the country's bad-loan ratio and regulatory environment. The bank aims to scale up its presence to 100 touch points and triple its balance sheet to 1.5 trillion rupees by 2023.

images.alt_text: DBS Group Holdings, South-east Asia's biggest bank, aims to bolster loans to Indian consumers and small businesses as part of a plan to reduce its reliance on Singapore.

site_title: Oil drops as China cuts growth target
summary: Oil prices dropped on Tuesday as China cut its 2019 economic growth target to 6.0-6.5%, reducing fuel demand outlook. Analysts say the market is still working off 2018 surpluses, making it hard to get bullish on oil prices. OPEC-led supply cuts, along with US sanctions, have supported prices, but the US is producing record amounts of crude, weighing down WTI prices. A decision on OPEC's supply cuts is expected to be delayed until June, providing some support to prices.

site_title: Fostering creativity for business
summary: Singapore's economy needs creativity, innovation, and fresh ideas to grow. While the country's education system is ranked highly globally, businesses also require a creative mindset to thrive in a changing market. The government has implemented initiatives such as Industry Transformation Maps and financial aid to support businesses, but local companies must also prioritize employee creativity and invest in new ideas. A financial cushion is also crucial for businesses to execute creative ideas, and technology can help with cash flow management. By addressing these areas, Singapore can foster a culture of innovation and drive economic growth.

site_title: Keppel Capital unit in lead position to buy Seoul buildings
summary: A South Korean unit of Keppel Capital has emerged as the frontrunner to acquire three office buildings in Seoul, worth 450 billion Korean won (S$0.54 billion), beating out Seoul-based IGIS Asset Management Co. The buildings, Yeouido Finance Tower, Nonhyeon Building in Gangnam, and Hannuri Building in Jongno, were previously acquired by Samsung SRA Asset Management Co for 295.5 billion won in 2009. This deal is part of a growing trend of foreign investors entering South Korea's real estate sector, driven by limited supply and strong leasing demand.

site_title: Want trillions of dollars injected into the economy? Pay women the same as men
summary: A global accounting firm, PwC, found that increasing women's participation in the workforce and ensuring they earn as much as men could add trillions of dollars to economies in OECD countries. Closing the gender pay gap could swell economies by $2 trillion, while increasing female labor force to Sweden's rate could add $6 trillion. The study ranked 33 OECD countries, with Iceland leading and Italy, Chile, Greece, Mexico, and South Korea performing poorly. Globally, women earn half as much as men, and it will take 202 years to achieve equal job opportunities.

site_title: New AT&T chief to revamp company
summary: AT&T's new TV chief, Bob Greenblatt, plans to revamp the company's streaming service by offering a wide range of content, including programmes from TNT, TBS, and Cartoon Network, and TV movies. The service will be based on HBO and will have a larger budget, with a 50% increase in HBO's budget this year. Greenblatt aims to take on Netflix, which has over 139 million customers, and is confident that AT&T's stable of brands and shows, including Time Warner's assets, will give him an advantage.

site_title: BMW could shift some UK engine output if no orderly Brexit
summary: BMW may shift some UK engine production to Austria if the UK does not secure an orderly Brexit departure from the EU. The German carmaker, citing a risk that British-made engines will no longer be counted as EU content, has "flexibility" to relocate production to Steyr in Austria. BMW has not yet made a final decision on transferring production from its Hams Hall plant in central England, where it built over 375,000 engines last year. A no-deal Brexit could hit the UK's car industry, which employs around 850,000 people.

site_title: Indian central bank fines 19 lenders for non-compliance on SWIFT use
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), has fined 19 lenders, including top banks ICICI Bank and State Bank of India, for failing to comply with its guidelines on SWIFT use. The fines total over 400 million rupees (S$7.6 million) and range from 10 million rupees to 40 million rupees per bank. The penalties come after the RBI's audit revealed gaps in compliance with its rules, including the requirement for banks to connect the SWIFT interbank messaging system with their core banking software by April last year.

site_title: Two Nobel Prizes in Literature to be awarded this year after scandal
summary: The Nobel Foundation announced that two Nobel Prizes in Literature will be awarded this year, after the Swedish Academy was hit by a scandal involving sexual abuse, financial wrongdoing, and a cover-up. The scandal led to the resignation of several members, including King Carl XVI Gustaf's patron, and the academy's patron, King Carl XVI Gustaf, publicly demanded change. The prize winners for 2019 and 2018 will be announced in October, with a new selection process involving independent experts to restore trust. However, some in Sweden question whether it's too early to award a prize due to the ongoing public distrust in the academy.

site_title: Global markets, while jittery, have bounced back: BIS
summary: Global markets have recovered sharply this year, with investors becoming more relaxed about central bank policies. However, the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) warns that developed and emerging market foreign currency borrowing remains high, particularly among highly indebted companies. Total global non-bank borrowing outside the US reached $11.48 trillion in the third quarter of 2018, with emerging markets holding up relatively well despite a slowdown in China. The BIS cautions that leveraged companies could be vulnerable to economic downturns and urges financial institutions to tighten controls on risk-taking.

site_title: US confirms it's delaying China tariff increase indefinitely
summary: The US has postponed indefinitely the scheduled tariff increase on Chinese goods, previously set to take effect on March 1. The 25% tariff rate will remain at 10% until further notice. The move comes as the US and China are close to a trade deal that could lift US tariffs if Beijing meets its pledges, including better protecting intellectual property rights and buying American products. This de-escalation could have significant implications for global trade and the economies of both countries.

site_title: Firefox maker fears DarkMatter 'misuse' of browser for hacking
summary: Mozilla considers blocking DarkMatter, a cybersecurity company linked to a UAE-based cyber espionage program, from serving as an internet security gatekeeper for Firefox. DarkMatter has denied conducting the operations, but Mozilla worries about potential misuse of its certification authority, which could allow interception of encrypted web traffic. Mozilla is considering stripping DarkMatter's over 400 certifications and may deny the company's request for full authority to grant certifications, citing concerns about its role in cybersecurity.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.37 points to 1,685.62. Losers outnumbered gainers 469 to 353, and volume reached 2.6 billion lots worth RM2.1 billion.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens flat, investors focus on trade talks
summary: US stocks opened flat on Monday, awaiting fresh developments in US-China trade talks. The Dow Jones rose 9.42 points, the S&P 500 gained 1.60 points, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 4.73 points, all at 0.06% gains. Investors focus on the ongoing trade talks, despite recent US President Trump's threats to extend a stock rally.

site_title: Slow and steady may lose the race
summary: A new review of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) found that brief, intense exercise can be as effective as longer, moderate workouts for fat loss. Studies with over 1,000 participants showed that HIIT, especially sprint-interval training, burned more fat than prolonged moderate exercise. While the difference was only 1 pound, the review concludes that there can be flexibility in choice of exercise approach, allowing individuals to plan workouts around their preferences and schedules.

site_title: Debenhams shares drop after it withdraws FY outlook
summary: Debenhams shares dropped 12% after the company withdrew its full-year outlook, citing talks with stakeholders to restructure its balance sheet. The department store chain reported a string of profit warnings due to struggling sales and higher financing costs. Despite a 5.3% improvement in like-for-like sales in the first half, Debenhams expects to shut 50 stores and still needs to address its funding requirements. The company's annualized cost-saving program remains on track.

site_title: Bank of Thailand says economic stability strong, can handle external volatility
summary: The Bank of Thailand's Governor Veerathai Santiprabhob stated that Thailand is economically stable and can handle external volatility due to its low foreign debt, high international reserves, and current account surplus. However, the country faces structural challenges, including low labour productivity and high household debt. The government's spending and short-term policies put pressure on the fiscal position, and a deficit budget is expected for the next 12 years.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets steady at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets remained steady at the start of trading on Tuesday, with the FTSE 100 index up 0.1% at 7,140.51 points. The eurozone saw a slight dip in Frankfurt's DAX 30 index and a near-flat Paris CAC 40. Meanwhile, US stocks continued to edge towards fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching new highs.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower after Wall Street falls
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Tuesday, following declines on Wall Street, due to weak US construction data triggering profit-taking. The Nikkei 225 index lost 0.44% and the Topix index declined 0.51%. This is the first of two articles about the topic.

site_title: Soccer-Man City owners keen to invest in Indian club this year
summary: Manchester City owners, City Football Group, are considering investing in an Indian club this year, aiming to increase their presence in Asia. The group, which owns several clubs globally, has been looking at India for nearly two years.
