They have recently bought a stake in Chinese third-tier side Sichuan Jiuniu FC and plan to add at least two or three more clubs to their stable, with Ferran Soriano stating that completing the vision of having 10 teams within the next five years is possible.

site_title: Australia shares trim losses after RBA stands pat; NZ down
summary: Australian shares ended the day down 0.3% at 6,199.30, trimming earlier losses after the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) left its cash rate at 1.5% and signalled a steady policy outlook. China announced plans to introduce stimulus measures to shore up its cooling economy, boosting market sentiment. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.15%, while mining stocks declined due to concerns about a slowdown in China, Australia's top raw material importer.

site_title: China International full-year profit drops 63.8% after absence of one-off gains
summary: China International Holdings reported a 63.8% drop in full-year profit to 7.2 million yuan due to the absence of one-off gains. Revenue dipped 1.3% and gross profit margin fell to 56.9%. The company repaid debt and increased cash balances. Despite a share loss from associated companies, China International expects positive performance from its Tianjin Water project, which is expected to complete in the second half of 2019 and increase water supply capacity.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end marginally higher
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index closed marginally higher on Tuesday, rising 2.01 points to 28,961.60, amid optimism over China's tax cuts and potential US trade deal. Shanghai stocks also surged, with the Shanghai Composite Index climbing 0.88% and the Shenzhen Composite Index adding 2.28%.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index closed marginally higher on Tuesday after China unveiled huge tax cuts to boost the stuttering economy, while investors remain optimistic about the chances of a trade deal with the United States.

site_title: Call for public-private tie-ups to spur Indonesian growth
summary: Indonesian economist Enrico Tanuwidjaja has proposed increased public-private partnerships (PPPs) to boost the country's growth, citing the failure of existing investment to deliver higher GDP growth since the 1997 Asian Financial Crisis. He suggests PPPs in high-potential, under-invested sectors such as the food industry, motor vehicles, and food crops. Tanuwidjaja also calls for supportive structural reforms to achieve sustainable economic growth, including land acquisition and project management capabilities.

site_title: Luke Perry was a '90s heartthrob with charisma to burn
summary: Luke Perry, a 1990s heartthrob known for his role as Dylan McKay on "Beverly Hills, 90210," has died after suffering a stroke. Born in Ohio, Perry's charisma and effortless masculinity made him a teen idol, with girls swooning over his soft-spoken demeanor and soulful gaze. He went on to appear in various TV shows and movies, including "Riverdale" and "Buffy the Vampire Slayer," cementing his status as a small-screen staple.

site_title: German market puts brakes on high-frequency traders
summary: Deutsche Boerse plans a six-month pilot project to slow down high-frequency trading on its Eurex platform by 1,000 times, reducing "aggressive" behavior. The test, starting June 3, will introduce a 1-millisecond delay on orders, allowing market participants to focus on customer needs. High-frequency trading, which accounts for 50-60% of options trades, has been linked to market volatility. The move follows similar measures by US exchanges, aiming to curb the impact of such trading on financial markets.

site_title: Govt, unions and employers agree retirement, re-employment ages should be raised
summary: The Government, unions, and employers in Singapore have agreed to raise the retirement and re-employment ages beyond 62 and 67, respectively. The tripartite consensus marks a significant milestone, with the Tripartite Workgroup on Older Workers to work towards a tripartite agreement on the pace and extent of the age increases. The group believes a higher retirement age will motivate workers and employers to invest in skills upgrading and job redesign, allowing for more years of good health. Implementation will occur in small steps, with a focus on ensuring flexible employment arrangements.

site_title: Co-working space provider WeWork opens new location at 380 Jalan Besar
summary: WeWork has opened a new location at 380 Jalan Besar in Singapore, marking the company's first non-central business district space. The 380-member co-working space features additional amenities such as a sky terrace with a swimming pool and gym. WeWork currently has 10 locations in Singapore and plans to expand to 11 with the opening of a new location at 109 North Bridge Road (Funan) in the second quarter. Managing director Turochas Fuad sees this as an opportunity to grow with ambitious startups and enterprises in the region.

site_title: PUB issues default notice to Tuaspring over failure to fulfil 'contractual obligations'
summary: Hyflux subsidiary Tuaspring Pte Ltd has received a default notice from PUB for failing to keep its desalination plant "reliably operational" as required under the Water Purchase Agreement. The notice was issued due to Tuaspring's inability to produce financial evidence to demonstrate its ability to keep the plant running for the next six months. PUB has given Tuaspring a 30-day cure period to resolve the defaults, and if not, the water contract can be terminated, allowing PUB to take control of the plant.

site_title: Pakistan navy says it stopped Indian sub from entering its waters
summary: Pakistan's navy has stopped an Indian submarine from entering its waters, according to a naval spokesman. The incident occurred days after a rare aerial dogfight between the two nuclear-armed foes over the disputed territory of Kashmir. The Pakistani navy said the Indian submarine was not targeted, following the government's policy of maintaining peace. The development comes amid escalating tensions between India and Pakistan, which have been at odds over Kashmir since the end of British colonial rule in 1947.

images.alt_text: Pakistani traders shout slogans and carry posters with the image of Pakistani Army Chief General Qamar Javed Bajwa during an anti-India protest, in Lahore on March 5, 2019. Pakistan has stopped an Indian submarine from entering its waters, the navy said Tuesday, as tensions continue to run high between the nuclear-armed foes.

site_title: Ladbrokes owner GVC moving some servers ahead of Brexit
summary: Ladbrokes owner GVC Holdings Plc has relocated servers hosting online gambling platforms to Ireland due to Brexit uncertainties. The move aims to protect business operations. The company also plans to operate EU customers under Malta licenses and maintain its online headquarters in Gibraltar. GVC reported a surge in pro forma underlying profit before tax, with a 9% increase in pro forma net gaming revenue. The company expects an EBITDA impact of £135 million in 2019 due to the cut in maximum stake on fixed-odds betting terminals.

site_title: Asia dips as China lowers growth target
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday, led by Singapore's Straits Times Index, which dropped 0.5% to close at 3,234.07, amid China's lower growth target of 6-6.5% for 2019. Despite tax cuts and increased public expenditure, China's domestic economy remained sluggish. Other Asian markets, including Australia, Japan, South Korea, and Malaysia, also ended lower, while Hong Kong closed flat. The Shanghai composite index rose 0.9%, but the effect was contained domestically.

site_title: Asia's top stock is now a Chinese pig farmer after 85% surge
summary: China's top stock, Muyuan Foodstuff Co, has surged 85% this year, becoming the best performer on the MSCI Asia Pacific Index. The company's pork production and food processing project in Zhengyang County is expected to boost sales and prices, driven by African swine fever disrupting the pork business. Analysts see a cyclical bottom in prices and a potential bounce in the second quarter. The Chinese government is also supporting the company through share listing and fundraising. Muyuan's shares have risen 142% over six months, outperforming the MSCI gauge.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore business confidence weakened for the third consecutive quarter, with the overall index easing to +5.08 percentage points in Q2 2019. The government, unions, and employers agreed to raise retirement and re-employment ages. DBS Group Holdings plans to increase loans to Indian consumers and businesses to boost profits. Moody's lowered Singtel's outlook to "negative" due to price competition and debt concerns. The Straits Times Index slipped 0.5% on Tuesday, closing at 3,234.07.

site_title: WWF orders probe into allegations of abuse by rangers
summary: The World Wildlife Fund (WWF) has commissioned an independent investigation into allegations of abuse by anti-poaching rangers funded by the organization. A Buzzfeed investigation reported that WWF-backed units have killed and tortured people, attacked indigenous villagers, and committed other human rights abuses in national parks in Asia and Africa. WWF has denied these claims, stating it has stringent policies in place to protect local communities, and will take swift action if any breaches are found. This is not the first time WWF has faced allegations of fostering rights abuses, following a similar claim in 2017.

site_title: Bankers are circling Europe's growing cannabis market
summary: Investment bankers are gearing up for a potential cannabis boom in Europe, with firms like Canaccord Genuity and Jefferies Financial Group initiating coverage on North American pot stocks and laying the groundwork for stock sales and mergers and acquisitions. European medical cannabis companies are seeking stock market listings, with companies such as Spinnaker Opportunities Plc and Gour Medical AG raising funds to capitalize on investor interest. However, the European market remains small and underdeveloped, with investors still wary of the industry due to its association with recreational cannabis and past market frenzy.

site_title: Singapore shares slip 0.5% on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index slipped 0.5% on Tuesday, closing at 3,234.07 points. The decline followed a weak US session and China's cut of its GDP target for 2019. The most traded counter, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, fell 2.1% to S$1.40. Financials DBS, OCBC, and United Overseas Bank also dropped, with DBS losing 0.3% and OCBC 0.4%. Defensive counters Singtel and ThaiBev closed flat.

site_title: Brazil's Vale fired inspection firm that failed to certify dam -prosecutors
summary: Brazil's Vale fired an inspection firm, Tractebel, after it refused to certify one of its dams as safe. The firm cited "divergences in criteria" but Vale instead relied on TÜV SÜD, which signed off on the dam that collapsed and killed hundreds in January. Prosecutors allege Vale pressured inspectors to sign off on reviews despite violating technical specifications, making it a "recurrent practice." The company's senior executives have apologized but not accepted responsibility, leading prosecutors to recommend the temporary removal of top executives, including CEO Fabio Schvartsman.

site_title: Khazanah weighing sale of RM1 billion Legoland theme park
summary: Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional Bhd is weighing the sale of its Legoland Malaysia Resort, valued around RM1 billion, as part of its review of non-core assets. The theme park, operated by Merlin Entertainments, is the first Lego-themed park in Asia. No final decisions have been made, and Khazanah could decide to keep the property. Managing director Shahril Ridza Ridzuan stated that Khazanah will consider selling Legoland if there's a good offer, but no talks are currently underway.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at lunch
summary: Hong Kong stocks remained flat at lunch, awaiting developments in US-China trade talks. The Hang Seng Index declined 8.82 points to 28,950.77, as Beijing announced large tax cuts to boost economic growth. Investors are cautious about the impact of the trade tensions on the global economy.

site_title: Alibaba's Office Depot deal won't help Trump's trade balance
summary: Alibaba has partnered with Office Depot to create a strategic collaboration that allows US businesses to access Alibaba's e-commerce platform, primarily benefiting Chinese clients. The deal aims to make it easier for buyers to purchase products from Alibaba by leveraging Office Depot's logistics network. However, critics argue that the partnership is more focused on facilitating Chinese imports rather than promoting US businesses. The agreement is unlikely to significantly impact US President Donald Trump's trade balance with China, which remains a major concern.

site_title: At US$12.5m, this Bugatti is the most expensive new car ever
summary: Bugatti has unveiled the "La Voiture Noire," a $12.5 million jet black car celebrating its 110th anniversary, making it the most expensive new car ever. The 16-cylinder engine features six tailpipes and is inspired by Jean Bugatti's Type 57 SC Atlantic. The car's owner is speculated to be former VW CEO Ferdinand Piech, who previously signed off on Bugatti's development costs. The move highlights VW's balancing act between luxury brands like Bugatti and cost-cutting measures. The car has already been sold, with Piech being described as an "enthusiast" by the company.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall on China growth target cut, weak U.S. data
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.52% for the third straight session, closing at 2,179.23, amid uncertainty over the Sino-US trade deal. China cut its 2019 economic growth target to 6.0-6.5%, while US construction spending unexpectedly fell in December. South Korea's February inflation rate grew 0.5%, the lowest since August 2016. Shares of companies making masks and air purifiers rallied, while the won ended flat. Foreigners were net sellers of 156.8 billion won worth of shares, and bond yields edged up.

site_title: Singapore motor insurers swing to underwriting profit of nearly S$10m for 2018
summary: Singapore motor insurers reported an underwriting profit of nearly S$10 million for 2018, a significant turnaround from a loss of S$12.6 million in the previous six months and a loss of S$27.2 million in 2017. The improvement was attributed to year-end housekeeping of accounts. The general insurance sector saw stable growth of 3.4% in total gross premiums, with the personal accident insurance segment posting a profit of S$17.3 million.

site_title: China says can 'absolutely' reach deal with US on financial opening
summary: China's top banking regulator, Guo Shuqing, stated that the country can "absolutely" reach an agreement with the US on opening its financial sector, despite difficult talks. China's Commerce Minister, Zhong Shan, also acknowledged the challenges but emphasized the potential benefits of a trade deal for both countries and the global economy. The US and China appear close to a deal that would roll back US tariffs on at least $200 billion worth of Chinese goods, with Beijing making pledges on structural economic changes.

site_title: Elon Musk blindsided Tesla staff with store-closing plans
summary: Elon Musk blindsided Tesla staff with plans to close many stores and shift to online-only sales, catching employees and investors off guard. The move, aimed at reducing costs, will enable the company to offer a lower-priced Model 3 sedan and reduce prices of all vehicles by an average of 6%. The stock has dropped 11% since the announcement, shaving $6 billion from Tesla's market value. Musk described the decision as a cost-cutting move, but investors are concerned about the company's financial health, with some speculating that it may be struggling with cash flow issues.

site_title: DBS bets on 'poisoned chalice' of India banking to lift profits
summary: DBS Group Holdings, South-east Asia's largest bank, plans to expand its presence in India, aiming to bolster loans to consumers and small businesses. The bank seeks to reduce its reliance on Singapore, where it derives 62% of its revenue. DBS has established a wholly-owned unit in India and plans to scale up its presence to 100 touch points and triple its balance sheet to 1.5 trillion rupees by 2023. The bank believes the Indian market offers a unique opportunity to grow, despite being a "poisoned chalice" for other foreign banks.

site_title: In rural Nepal, solar irrigation helps keep families together
summary: In rural Nepal, a solar-powered water pump has significantly improved the lives of apple growers in the Jumla district, particularly women. The pump, installed by the European Union and Jersey Overseas Aid, has enabled farmers to irrigate their orchards, increasing yields and enabling them to sell surplus produce. This has reduced pressure on men to migrate in search of work, allowing them to stay in their villages and support their families. The project has also led to increased income and improved health for women, such as Bhadri Sarki, who no longer has to walk for hours to fetch water.

site_title: Singapore tech counters mostly up after post-opening dip on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's technology and manufacturing counters rose after a post-opening dip on Tuesday, with Venture Corp and other tech stocks gaining 3.5-11% due to possible trade resolution between the US and China. Market watchers attributed the gains to profit-taking after recent strong performances, with earnings season nearing its close. The Singapore market followed the US market's weaker close, but China's announcement to cut the value-added tax rate for manufacturing could have given a lift to some counters, which mostly pared post-opening losses.

site_title: China commerce minister says US trade talks have been difficult
summary: Chinese Commerce Minister Zhong Shan stated that US trade talks have been difficult but progress has been made in some areas. Working teams from both countries are continuing negotiations, with the possibility of a deal that would roll back US tariffs on at least $200 billion worth of Chinese goods. Both China and the US stand to benefit from a trade agreement, according to Zhong.

site_title: SUTL Enterprise bags management contract for new China integrated marina
summary: SUTL Enterprise has secured a five-year management contract for the day-to-day operations of the ONE°15 Marina Zhongshan China in Guangdong province, China. The contract, which began on January 1, 2019, was awarded by master developer Sunsea Yacht Club. The marina, which is part of the ONE°15 Marina group, will feature 158 wet berths, a member clubhouse, and other facilities. The development is a key gateway between Guangdong, Hong Kong, and Macau, with direct sailing routes between Zhongshan and Macau.

site_title: Instant Pot Maker bought by Pyrex's parent as old kitchen meets new
summary: Corelle Brands, the parent of Pyrex and CorningWare, has acquired Instant Brands, the maker of the popular Instant Pot electric multicooker. The acquisition, financial terms undisclosed, aims to expand Instant Brands' product lineup and international presence. Instant Pot, created by Robert Wang, has gained a massive following since its 2010 launch, with 1.8 million members in an Instant Pot Facebook group. The deal will merge Instant Brands with Corelle, with Instant Brands' CEO remaining in charge and Wang becoming chief innovation officer.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,239.17, down 0.37%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Tuesday with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.37% at 3,239.17, after 740.7 million securities worth S$521.1 million changed hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 182 to 146, with Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings and DBS Group Holdings among the most traded stocks. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with investors seemingly unfazed by recent US trade tensions.

site_title: How to make meals from office snacks
summary: Office workers are repurposing free snacks to create makeshift meals, often due to limited options or abundance of choices. They use ingredients like Chobani yogurt, Kind bars, and bread to create dishes like "work pizzas" and "cheese plates." The phenomenon is not unique to the US, with Chinese YouTuber Ms. Yeah gaining a following for her elaborate workplace lunches. Employees are finding creative ways to overcome the sweetness of snack food, and some companies are offering a wide range of snacks to fuel their employees' creativity. However, the ethics of snacks raise questions about compensation levels, supply, and the impact on the group.

site_title: Moody's lowers Singtel outlook to 'negative' on price war and Bharti debt
summary: Moody's has downgraded Singtel's outlook to "negative" due to concerns over price competition in Singapore and Australia, and the company's expected contribution to a multibillion-dollar rights issue at debt-hit Indian associate Bharti Airtel. The downgrade comes as Singtel's net leverage is expected to rise to 2.2-2.4 times, surpassing Moody's expectations for a company with an A1 rating. The outlook could be returned to "stable" if Singtel's profitability improves and borrowings are reduced, with a focus on maintaining an adjusted net debt-to-Ebitda ratio below two times.

site_title: Malaysia joins ICC in boost for beleaguered court
summary: Malaysia has become the 124th member of the International Criminal Court (ICC), joining the world's only permanent war crimes court. The move, announced by Human Resources Minister M. Kula Segaran, comes after the country's reform-minded government vowed to join the ICC last year. The ICC faces criticism over high-profile acquittals, with Burundi becoming the first country to quit in 2017 and the Philippines announcing its intention to withdraw. Malaysia's membership aims to play an important role in crimes against humanity cases.

site_title: NTU and Volvo to trial world's first full-sized driverless bus
summary: NTU and Volvo have launched the world's first full-sized, driverless bus, a 12m-long autonomous electric bus that can fit about 80 people. The bus has undergone multiple tests at NTU's Centre for Excellence for Testing and Research of Autonomous Vehicles and is now ready for on-road trials in Singapore later this year. Equipped with advanced sensors and an artificial intelligence system, the bus can travel 25km on a full charge and reach Level 4 autonomy, with plans to test it in residential areas and mixed traffic conditions.

site_title: China to cut value-added tax rate for manufacturing, construction sectors
summary: China has announced a plan to cut taxes and fees by nearly 2 trillion yuan in 2019, aiming to stimulate a slowing economy. The country will lower the value-added tax rate for manufacturing, transportation, and construction sectors to 13%, 9%, and 9% respectively. The move is expected to benefit companies in these sectors, while purchasing taxes for new energy vehicles will remain exempted. The policy adjustments are part of China's efforts to boost economic growth and counteract the impact of a slowing economy.

site_title: Online direct debit payments firm Curlec completes seed funding round led by Captii Ventures
summary: Curlec, a Malaysia-based fintech company, has completed a seed funding round led by Captii Ventures, though the amount raised was not disclosed. The funds will be used to expand the company's sales and marketing team in Malaysia and regionally. Curlec's online direct debit payments platform has processed over RM50 million in transactions since its launch in 2018 and aims to bring direct debit to the Malaysian SME market and beyond, where the payment method has historically had low penetration.

site_title: Philippines Feb CPI returns to target, gives cbank policy leeway
summary: The Philippines' annual inflation rate returned to the central bank's 2-4% target range in February, easing to a one-year low of 3.8%. This move gives the central bank more leeway on interest rates, with some analysts suggesting a possible easing of monetary policy to support economic growth. The central bank's next policy review is on March 21, and policymakers may consider cutting interest rates or reducing banks' required reserves. The inflation rate is expected to remain within the target range for the year, with fuel prices expected to ease further.

site_title: Australia's competition watchdog warns high gas prices threaten manufacturers
summary: Australia's gas prices are threatening the nation's manufacturing sector, with the country's competition watchdog warning that high costs could force shutdowns. Gas prices have risen due to LNG exports, cuts in exploration spending, and drilling bans, reaching A$10-12 per gigajoule. The watchdog urges gas producers to increase output and offer reasonable prices. The high cost of gas is making it hard for businesses to remain internationally competitive, with some manufacturers considering moving or shutting operations. The government and states need to take action to boost local gas supply and encourage new development.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Tuesday's open; STI down 0.41% to 3,237.88
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.41% at Tuesday's open, closing at 3,237.88, after China trimmed its official growth outlook for the year. Losers outnumbered gainers 63 to 36, with AEM Holdings and DBS Group Holdings leading the decline, while Jardine Strategic Holdings rose 0.2%. Trading volume reached 28.2 million securities worth S$49.6 million.

site_title: Northern China pollution soars in February: official data
summary: Air pollution in 39 northern Chinese cities surged in February, exceeding the country's winter air quality targets. PM2.5 concentrations rose 40% to 108 micrograms per cubic meter, with Anyang in Henan province being the most polluted, reaching 163 micrograms. China's Ministry of Ecology and Environment attributes the surge to unfavorable weather and increased industrial output. Despite Premier Li Keqiang's vow to strengthen pollution prevention, only six cities have seen a decrease in PM2.5 concentrations since October, raising concerns about the country's progress in its "war on pollution".

site_title: Best World says franchise sales-related expenses helped drive increase in 2018 payables
summary: Best World International's trade and other payables more than doubled in 2018, reaching S$95.1 million, driven by franchise sales-related expenses and higher accruals for commissions and convention expenses. The company's franchise business began in June 2018, resulting in sales-related expenses of S$3.7 million payable to third-party vendors. Payables also included S$10.9 million of sales rebates and allowances. The company expects to pay these liabilities in 2019.

site_title: China's defence budget rise to outpace economic growth target
summary: China's 2019 defence budget rose 7.5% to 1.19 trillion yuan (S$240.38 billion), outpacing its economic growth target of 6.0-6.5%. The increase comes as China develops new military capabilities, including stealth fighters and anti-satellite missiles. The budget is closely watched for clues to China's strategic intentions and has raised regional tensions, particularly with neighbours Japan and Taiwan. China's military spending ranks as the world's second largest, lagging behind the US, and is likely to underestimate true military spending for the People's Liberation Army.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks drop as investors lose confidence after weak US data
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index fell 0.42% to 2,181.40, as investors lost confidence following weak US construction spending data in December. The Korean won weakened, while the benchmark bond yield rose. Foreigners were net sellers of 48.5 billion won worth of shares, and the won lost 1.0% against the US dollar this year. The decline was attributed to concerns about an expected revision of the government's economic growth estimate for the fourth quarter.

site_title: Tokyo court grants ex-Nissan chief Ghosn bail after over 3-month detention
summary: A Japanese court granted bail to ousted Nissan Motor chairman Carlos Ghosn, allowing him to walk free after over 3-month detention. Ghosn, who faces charges of aggravated breach of trust and under-reporting his compensation, was released on a 1 billion yen (S$12 million) bail with conditions of video surveillance and communications monitoring. Ghosn denies wrongdoing and has a trial pending, where he could face up to 10 years in jail if convicted. His lawyers have argued the allegations should have been resolved as an internal matter, and Ghosn's rights have been violated during detention.

site_title: Sunningdale Tech urged to raise quality of reporting after Q4 earnings miss
summary: Sunningdale Tech faces pressure from activist fund Quarz Capital Management to improve its reporting quality after missing Q4 earnings estimates. The company's shares have plummeted 10.25% since the earnings report, citing production ramp-up costs and duplicate operating costs. Quarz estimates one-off costs at over S$3 million and suggests Sunningdale's core net profit could be S$5 million for Q4 and S$24 million for 2018. The activist fund urges Sunningdale to separate one-off costs from core net profit and increase shareholder value.

site_title: US, UK still way behind on women's equality in the workplace
summary: The US and UK rank 23rd and 13th respectively in PricewaterhouseCoopers' annual ranking of women's representation and welfare in the workplace, behind Nordic countries like Iceland and Sweden. The UK's female participation rate is 57%, lagging Sweden's 69%, and the US has fallen 14 places since 2000. Increasing female employment could boost the UK economy by $178 billion and global GDP by over $6 trillion. Britain's gender pay gap remains a key issue, with London's gap remaining "barely budged" since 2010.

images.alt_text: The US and UK have a lot of catching up to do when in comes to treating women in work well.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropped 10.41 points to 1,683.58 at 9:01am on Tuesday, with losers outnumbering gainers 116 to 73. The market saw 50.6 million lots worth RM26.5 million traded.

site_title: Hong Kong is releasing less land for new private homes
summary: Hong Kong's government plans to release 15 residential sites in the fiscal year starting April 1, providing around 8,800 private homes, a 42% decrease from last year. This reduction in private land supply is aimed at addressing the city's housing shortage and is a result of the government's increased focus on public housing. The decrease may lead to slower home sales over the next three to four years, potentially helping to stabilize home prices, which have declined about 10% since August.

site_title: UK budget airline Flybe says investors back takeover
summary: Flybe, a UK budget airline, has announced that its shareholders have overwhelmingly approved a takeover from the Connect Airways consortium, led by Virgin Atlantic. The deal, valued at £2.2 million, has received 83% support from investors, with the takeover expected to be sealed on March 11. This comes after Flybe rejected a counterbid from US airline Mesa Air and New York-based Bateleur Capital last month. The deal is seen as a lifeline for the struggling airline, which has faced challenges including volatile fuel costs and Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Japan plans rule change to encourage regional bank consolidation: Nikkei
summary: Japan's government plans to change anti-monopoly rules to encourage regional bank consolidation, aiming to address declining profits due to low interest rates and a shrinking population. The changes will provide exemptions to Japan's anti-monopoly law for regional banks to consolidate more easily, with exemptions in effect for five or 10 years. The goal is to enhance transparency and facilitate consolidation to improve financial health, following comments from BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda. The legislation is expected to be submitted to parliament next year.

site_title: China to form national oil and gas pipeline company: state planner
summary: China plans to create a national oil and gas pipeline company, a reform anticipated by the energy industry, to separate pipeline transportation costs from oil and gas sales. The National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) did not provide a timeline or details in its annual work report. This move aims to help state-owned energy companies by reducing costs. The NDRC also reiterated its goal of accelerating domestic oil and gas exploration.

site_title: China to raise defence spending by 7.5%, lower than 2018
summary: China is increasing its defense spending by 7.5% in 2019, a lower rate than the 8.1% increase in 2018. The government plans to spend 1.19 trillion yuan ($241 billion) on defense. This move comes as the country's economy slows down, with a growth target of 6.0-6.5%. Despite being the world's second-largest military spender, China still lags behind the US, which budgeted $716 billion for defense in 2019. The increased spending is aimed at modernizing the People's Liberation Army and asserting China's territorial claims in the South China Sea.

site_title: Singapore business confidence weakens for third straight quarter
summary: Singapore businesses showed decreased confidence for the third consecutive quarter, with the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau's Business Optimism Index easing to +5.08 percentage points in Q2 2019. Financial and services sectors remained optimistic, while construction and manufacturing sectors saw downward moderations. The moderation in business sentiments was attributed to weaker external demand, particularly in China, and the impact of the slowdown on wholesale trade and manufacturing. Despite this, the services and financial sectors are expected to drive growth for the first half of 2019.

site_title: Passenger jet parts not properly checked by Japanese engine maker
summary: Japanese heavy-machinery maker IHI Corp. confirmed that employees didn't properly check some aircraft engines, leading to a 5.2% drop in its stock. The company is investigating how many engines were involved and over what period. This quality-control issue follows other recent problems at Japanese manufacturers, including Nissan and Subaru. The incident may raise concerns about corporate governance and product quality, with Citigroup analyst Graeme McDonald stating that it could be a "knock-on effect" of a labor shortage in Japan.

site_title: Malaysia's Khazanah restructures fund in two groups, posts weak 2018 results
summary: Malaysia's Khazanah Nasional Bhd, the country's sovereign wealth fund, has restructured its portfolio into two groups: a commercial and strategic fund. The move aims to deliver more cash to the government, which is facing a fiscal deficit and massive debt. The commercial fund targets a 3% return on investment, while the strategic fund focuses on companies deemed strategic to the nation. Khazanah reported weak 2018 results, with a loss of 6.27 billion ringgit and a realisable asset value of 136 billion ringgit.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street lower, China slashes growth target
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday as investors awaited updates on China-US trade talks, following a lower opening on Wall Street. China lowered its growth target to 6.0-6.5% and unveiled massive tax cuts to support the stuttering economy. Despite this, equity investors remained cautious, with Shanghai down 0.2%, Hong Kong 0.6% lower, and Tokyo 0.6% down. The move is seen as a sign of the Chinese leadership's efforts to address a mounting debt crisis and trade row, with Premier Li Keqiang warning of a "tough struggle" ahead.

site_title: AT&T's new TV chief looks to revamp company for the Netflix era
summary: AT&T's new TV chief, Bob Greenblatt, aims to revamp the company's streaming platform by leveraging its stable of brands and shows, including HBO, TNT, and TBS. He plans to broaden content offerings to include TV movies and animation from the Cartoon Network. Greenblatt faces an uphill climb, competing with established players like Netflix, but believes AT&T's resources and budget will help. Despite concerns about corporate culture change, Greenblatt plans to maintain the tradition of quality established by HBO's long-time chief, Richard Plepler.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares edge down at open
summary: Hong Kong shares opened with losses on Tuesday, slipping 0.47% to 28,823.16, following a recent rally. The market was already pricing in US-China trade hopes, while Beijing lowered its growth forecasts and unveiled tax cuts. China's Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.25% and the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.24%. The losses were attributed to the recent market movements and the ongoing trade tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Australia's economy may have stalled in Q4, outcome a close call
summary: Australia's economy may have stalled in the fourth quarter of 2019, with trade shaving more from growth than expected. Despite this, government spending added to GDP, and analysts downgrade forecasts of growth to near nothing. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) holds its March policy meeting amid speculation of interest rate cuts, which could be triggered by a weaker regional and global growth environment. Annual growth is seen slowing to around 2.6%, and investors expect a quarter-point cut in rates by year end.

site_title: Hillary Clinton states it definitively: 'I'm not running' in 2020
summary: Hillary Clinton, the 2016 Democratic presidential nominee, has officially ruled out a 2020 presidential run, stating "I'm not running" in a New York City television interview. Despite not seeking the presidency, Clinton plans to remain active in politics, speaking out on issues and potentially seeking other office. Her decision comes as several female candidates, including Kamala Harris and Elizabeth Warren, have already entered the Democratic primary. Clinton's presence on the political scene remains, with her signaling she will continue to advocate for her views.

site_title: US judge uses rare move to throw out case against Barclays trader
summary: A US federal judge, Charles Breyer, dismissed a market manipulation case against Barclays trader Robert Bogucki before the jury reached a verdict, preventing a potential appeal. The judge found that prosecutors had not proved their case, citing a lack of evidence that Bogucki made material false or fraudulent pretenses to Hewlett-Packard. The decision was a rare move, as judges typically rule on such requests after the jury verdict. Bogucki was indicted on charges of wire fraud and conspiracy, but the case was dismissed on a Rule 29 motion.

site_title: Brexit talks resume as divorce day looms
summary: EU's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier meets with Britain's negotiating team in Brussels as the UK's divorce deadline from the EU looms on March 29. Barnier offers to provide further guarantees and consider a short "technical" delay to help push a troubled divorce deal through the British parliament. Britain's attorney general Geoffrey Cox will provide a legal opinion on the Brexit deal, which could determine its approval by MPs. The talks aim to find a solution to the Irish border "backstop" plan, a major sticking point for pro-Brexit MPs.

site_title: Singapore Intellectual Property Office named best in Asia, second worldwide
summary: The Intellectual Property Office of Singapore (IPOS) has been named the most innovative IPO in Asia and second worldwide by the World Trademark Review, following its third annual IP Office Innovation Ranking study. IPOS shares the second-place spot with Chile and Spain, praised for its education and business development support.

site_title: Office landlord Priam properties is considering an IPO
summary: Priam Properties Inc., a real estate investment company, is considering an initial public offering (IPO). The Nashville, Tennessee-based company, which owns and manages office buildings in the US Midwest and Southeast, has discussed selling shares with investment banks. A decision has yet to be made. Priam focuses on high-growth markets and has not gone public since US real estate investment trusts experienced a 12% rally in the first half of 2019, slightly outperforming the S&P 500 Index.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Coffee with Claressa: Terry and Janice O'Connor
summary: Claressa, a Money FM podcast host, sat down with Terry and Janice O'Connor for a conversation. The conversation centered around various business topics, but no specific key facts or events were mentioned from this podcast.

site_title: Democrats launch sweeping probe targeting dozens in Trump orbit
summary: US Democratic lawmakers launched an investigation into alleged obstruction of justice and abuse of office by Donald Trump, targeting dozens of individuals in the president's inner circle. The House Judiciary Committee chairman sent strongly worded letters to family members, confidantes, and related entities, demanding documents that could shed light on possible wrongdoing. This is the most ambitious investigation yet, amid controversies swirling around Trump.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust, Declout, China Jinjiang, Far East Group
summary: Stocks to watch on March 5, 2019, include DBS, which launched its locally incorporated subsidiary DBS Bank India, and Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust, which will be included in the FTSE EPRA/NAREIT Global Real Estate Index Series. Declout was acquired by Exeo Global, with the offeror securing 95.04% of issued shares. China Jinjiang's corporate family rating was downgraded by Moody's, while Far East Group plans to buy Tech Air-Con & Security Engineering for S$7 million. Compact Metal's restructuring scheme has become effective.

site_title: AT&T reshuffles WarnerMedia team, merges HBO with Turner
summary: AT&T's media-entertainment arm, WarnerMedia, announced a major reorganisation merging HBO with Turner networks, giving CNN chief Jeff Zucker a broader portfolio. The new WarnerMedia Entertainment unit will be led by Robert Greenblatt and includes HBO, TNT, TBS, and truTV. This move comes days after an appeals court affirmed the tie-up, rejecting a government antitrust challenge.

site_title: China cuts taxes, sees 'tough struggle' as growth slows
summary: China's premier, Li Keqiang, warned of a "tough struggle" as the country faces a slowing economy, with growth expected to reach 6.0-6.5% this year. To combat the slowdown, the government unveiled tax cuts and other measures, including a 2 trillion yuan tax reduction and a 2.8% fiscal deficit. The government aims to achieve above 6% growth for the next two years to meet its promise of doubling GDP by 2020. The country also faces challenges from the trade war with the US, but Li expressed confidence in continuing negotiations.

images.alt_text: Premier Li Keqiang told the opening session of China's annual National People's Congress that the government is targeting growth of 6.0 to 6.5 per cent this year for the world's second-largest economy, lowering its range from 2018.

site_title: Luke Perry, star of 'Beverly Hills, 90210' dead at 52
summary: Actor Luke Perry, star of the 1990s TV series "Beverly Hills, 90210," died at 52 after suffering a massive stroke in Los Angeles. He died surrounded by family and friends. Perry was hospitalized last week and his family appreciates the outpouring of support, requesting privacy during this time.

site_title: Lockheed gets US$1b down payment for Saudi Thaad missile system
summary: Lockheed Martin Corp received a $946 million payment from the US government for the installation of a $15 billion missile defense system in Saudi Arabia. This payment is part of a 2017 US$110 billion arms package negotiated by the Trump administration. The system, consisting of 44 Thaad launchers and missiles, was formalized in November with the signing of letters of offer and acceptance.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after Wall St declines
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, following a decline on Wall Street due to weak US construction data. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.58% to 21,696.43, while the Topix index dropped 0.63% to 1,617.29. The losses were attributed to market sentiment dampened by the US market's decline.

site_title: To build an international business, it's about growing better, not faster
summary: Singaporean businesses must focus on customer-obsessed growth rather than rapid expansion to succeed internationally. Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for scaling up and venturing into new markets. To support ambitious firms, the government plans to provide better financing options and technology adoption. This approach is crucial for overcoming the challenges of international expansion, which is no easy feat.

site_title: Achieving better policy outcomes with analytics
summary: Asia's megacities are driving global urbanization, with two-thirds of Asia expected to live in cities by 2050. The public sector must adapt to increased citizen expectations, leveraging analytics for better societal outcomes. To ensure accuracy in long-term forecasts, governments must consider future scenarios and develop strategies for deploying analytics across the public sector. This will enable informed policy-making and drive better societal outcomes.

site_title: Meng Wanzhou, seen as 'poor little rich girl,' proves a polarizing detainee
summary: Meng Wanzhou, Huawei's CFO, remains a polarizing figure in Vancouver, Canada, after being detained on US fraud charges. Despite being out on bail, tensions between Canada and China remain high, with China accusing a Canadian diplomat of espionage and detaining several Canadians in apparent retaliation. Meng's case has tapped into Vancouver's fixation on skyrocketing real estate prices and the effect of foreign investment, with many viewing her as a symbol of the city's inequality. Her residence in a $6 million mansion has sparked outrage, with some criticizing the luxury accommodations while others sympathize with her plight, citing historical memories of Canada's discrimination against Chinese people.

images.alt_text: "Meng is a source of national pride in China, and I wanted to see a superrich Asian lifestyle," said the student, Parker Li. "Many Chinese people from mainland China feel she is being unfairly bullied by the United States."

site_title: Canada budget minister quits crisis-plagued Trudeau cabinet
summary: Canadian Budget Minister Jane Philpott resigned on Monday, citing a loss of confidence in Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government amid a major crisis. Philpott stated that the government's handling of a justice system matter and response to raised issues had led to her decision. This move comes as the Trudeau cabinet faces significant challenges, leaving the government with a reduced number of ministers.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Mirach Energy is seeking a six-month extension to exit the Singapore Exchange's watch-list, citing improved financial performance. The company reported a consolidated pre-tax profit of US$766,000 for the 2018 financial year, up from a US$9.6 million loss in 2017. Mirach Energy aims to streamline its business and diversify into new revenue streams, resulting from efforts to improve cash flow.

site_title: Europe's slowdown is worse than investors imagined: Allianz SE's El-Erian
summary: Mohamed El-Erian, chief economic adviser for Allianz SE, warned that Europe's slowdown is worse than investors initially thought, posing a significant risk to the market. The European Central Bank has limited tools to respond to economic weakness, and European governments are not prepared to respond with increased spending. This assessment highlights the challenges facing the European economy and the need for policymakers to take action to mitigate the slowdown.

site_title: Good weather expected to bolster Indonesia, Malaysia palm output
summary: Record palm oil production is expected in Indonesia and Malaysia due to favorable weather conditions over the past few months. The two countries, accounting for over 80% of global output, are likely to drive up production, putting pressure on benchmark prices. However, reduced fertilizer usage, labor shortages, and older trees in Malaysia may limit growth in output. This could lead to downward pressure on prices after recent seven-month highs.

site_title: Huawei said to be preparing to sue US government
summary: Huawei is preparing to sue the US government in the Eastern District of Texas, where it has its US headquarters, following the ban on federal agencies using its products. The lawsuit aims to make the US case against Huawei more public and defend the company against a campaign seen as a security threat. This move comes after executives spoke out against US actions and new marketing campaigns were launched to mend Huawei's image. The company plans to announce the suit this week.

site_title: China lowers growth target, cuts taxes as economy slows
summary: China has lowered its economic growth target to 6-6.5% for 2019, marking the slowest pace in nearly three decades. The country also announced a 2 trillion yuan tax cut, worth $404 billion, to stimulate the economy amid a debt legacy and trade standoff with the US. Policymakers aim to rekindle lending to the private sector while avoiding an accelerated debt run-up. The move is seen as a gradual deceleration of the economy, with economists expecting further slowing in 2020 and 2021.

site_title: UK shoppers slow their spending ahead of Brexit, some stockpile
summary: UK shoppers reduced spending in February ahead of Brexit, focusing on essential items like food and stockpiling. Total sales increased by 0.5% annually, a slowdown from January's 2.2% growth. Consumer spending on cards rose 1.2%, the weakest increase since 2015, according to Barclaycard data. The British Retail Consortium attributed the slowdown to Brexit uncertainty, with shoppers prioritizing food and non-perishable goods over discretionary purchases.

site_title: US, China 'on the cusp' of possible end to trade war: Pompeo
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said the US and China are "on the cusp" of a deal to end their trade war, with both sides expressing optimism about negotiations. The US has demanded significant changes to China's laws and practices, including protecting US intellectual property and increasing Chinese purchases of US goods. While progress has been made, enforcement issues remain a major sticking point, and some Chinese officials expect concessions to fall short of massive changes. A deal could be agreed in coming weeks, with some tariffs potentially lifting in stages as commitments are met.

site_title: Moody's downgrades China Jinjiang Environment's corporate family rating, USD bond
summary: Moody's downgraded China Jinjiang Environment's corporate family rating to Ba3 from Ba2 and senior unsecured rating to B1 from Ba3 due to the company's tight liquidity position and refinancing risk. The ratings outlook is negative, and an upgrade is unlikely. The downgrade is attributed to the company's challenges in meeting its debt obligations, including a challenging liquidity position and refinancing task. Moody's also cited the risk of accelerated debt repayment obligations due to further ratings downgrade. The company has been expanding overseas, increasing its financial leverage and credit profile risk.

site_title: Stricter emissions limits jolt Europe's auto industry
summary: Europe's auto industry is adapting to stricter CO2 emissions standards set to take effect next year. The Geneva Motor Show will feature electric vehicles, with automakers scrambling to meet the new limits. The show highlights the shift away from petrol-guzzling SUVs and towards electric vehicles. Automakers are under pressure to cut emissions, with BYD and other EV battery makers facing increased pressure to meet the new standards. The move aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and meet European climate goals.

images.alt_text: Electric vehicles will take centre stage at this year's Geneva Motor Show, as automakers scramble to bring their fleets into line with strict CO2 emissions standards set to kick in next year.

site_title: Pulling federal high-speed rail funds would be 'disastrous': California
summary: California's High-Speed Rail Authority has urged the Trump administration to reconsider plans to withhold $929 million in federal funding and claw back $2.5 billion already spent, calling the effort "disastrous" and "unlawful." The authority claims seeking the return of funds could put 2,600 people out of work. California Governor Gavin Newsom previously scaled back the $77.3 billion project due to cost hikes, delays, and management concerns. The Federal Railroad Administration has a March 5 deadline to respond to the request.

site_title: Trump says he plans to end India's preferential trade treatment
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to end India's preferential trade treatment, allowing $5.6 billion worth of Indian exports to enter the US duty-free. The decision comes after "intensive engagement" between the US and India, as Trump stated that India has not assured the US of equitable market access. This move is expected to impact the Asian garment industry, which relies heavily on US tariffs. The decision is part of a broader trend of US trade policy shifts under Trump's presidency.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said Monday he intends to end India's preferential trade treatment under a programme that allows $5.6 billion worth of Indian exports to enter the United States duty free.

site_title: Will DBS be third time lucky in transforming its retail equities strategy?
summary: DBS Bank is considering transferring its retail equity trading to its brokerage arm, DBS Vickers, by year's end. The move has sparked support for its remisiers, who have been underappreciated for their roles in setting trading limits, monitoring margin ratios, and managing risks. However, Leong Mun Wai, CEO of Wintop Capital, warns that this could harm Singapore's shrinking stock market. The decision could be a test of DBS' retail equities strategy, which has faced criticism for its treatment of remisiers.

site_title: Oil rises 1% on US-China trade optimism, Opec+ supply cuts
summary: Oil prices rose about 1% on Monday as the US and China appeared closer to ending a trade war, while Opec ally Russia said it would increase its crude supply cuts. Brent crude futures settled at $65.67 a barrel, up 60 cents or 0.9%, and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures ended 79 cents, or 1.4%, higher at $56.59 a barrel. Gains were tempered by a drop in equity indexes, which weakened sentiment on oil markets.

site_title: Australian, NZ shares retreat on profit taking, weak US lead
summary: Australian shares retreated 0.6% on Tuesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index falling 35.6 points to 6,181.7, due to profit taking after a series of strong gains. The weak US lead and China's cut of its growth target to 6.0-6.5% also contributed to the decline. Mining stocks, heavily exposed to Chinese markets, were the biggest weights on the benchmark, with BHP Group and Rio Tinto shedding 1.2% and 0.7%, respectively. New Zealand shares also fell 0.2% as investors awaited the outcome of the Reserve Bank of Australia's policy meeting.

site_title: Largest gold ETF shrinks most in year as trade tensions ease
summary: The world's largest gold ETF, SPDR Gold Shares, saw a record net withdrawal of $496 million on Friday, the largest single-day outflow in over a year. Easing trade tensions have led investors to pull cash from safe-haven assets, with a five-day total of $720 million in outflows. Analysts attribute this to "good sentiment" and a strengthening dollar, eroding demand for gold. The outflows mark the fourth consecutive week of withdrawals, as investors weigh the prospect of a trade deal that could boost risk appetite and reduce the appeal of gold.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as markets await trade deal details
summary: US stocks fell on Monday as investors awaited details on a potential US-China trade deal, despite the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.8%, while the S&P 500 fell 0.4% and the Nasdaq lost 0.2%. Weak US construction data also contributed to the decline. The market's focus remains on the trade deal, with investors seeking clarity on its terms and potential impact on the economy.

site_title: Ocean heatwaves devastate wildlife, worse to come
summary: Ocean heatwaves have damaged ecosystems worldwide, with a 50% increase in marine heatwave days since the mid-20th century, according to a study in Nature Climate Change. Researchers found that these heatwaves are becoming more frequent and prolonged, with record-breaking events in most ocean basins over the past decade. Lead author Dan Smale warned that the impacts will worsen, posing a significant threat to marine life and ecosystems globally.

site_title: Teeny tiny handbag becomes a fashion sensation
summary: French fashion brand Jacquemus' miniature handbag, "Le Mini Chiquito", has become a sensation at Paris Fashion Week, sparking laughter and excitement on social media. The tiny bag, measuring 5.2cm long, is a scaled-down version of the already popular "Le Chiquito" bag and has sold tens of thousands of units in the past year. Fashion insiders and users on Instagram and Twitter have been joking about its impractical uses, but also praising the brand's creativity and charm, with some seeing deeper meaning in its tiny interior.

site_title: Can one really make money in the market during a war?
summary: A short war can have mixed effects on markets, contradicting the common assumption that brief conflicts benefit economies. In India, the 1999 Kargil War boosted stocks, while the 2008 Mumbai attacks had a smaller impact. However, recent airstrikes against Pakistan have rattled markets. Historically, longer wars tend to devastate economies, making the outcome of a short war uncertain. The impact of a war on markets depends on various factors, including the duration and intensity of the conflict.

site_title: Google moves to address wage equity and finds it's underpaying many men
summary: Google has found that it underpays men, not women, in similar work, contrary to expectations. The study, conducted annually, led to pay raises for thousands of men. The Labor Department investigates whether Google systematically underpays women. Critics argue that the results give a false impression, as the study didn't address whether women were hired at a lower pay grade. Google denies underpaying women and is now reviewing its human resources processes to ensure fairness and equity for all employees. The company provided $9.7 million in additional compensation to 10,677 employees, with men receiving a higher percentage of the money.

site_title: Ted Baker founder and CEO quits after misconduct allegations
summary: Ted Baker founder and CEO RAY Kelvin resigned on Monday following misconduct allegations related to his hugging of business colleagues. The allegations led to an independent investigation in December, which Kelvin denied but agreed to step down from his position. Kelvin, who held a 35% stake in the company, cited a desire to allow the business to "face 2019 with fresh energy and renewed spirit." Acting CEO Lindsay Page and executive chairman David Bernstein will continue in their roles, and the investigation will focus on Ted Baker's policies and procedures.

site_title: Salesforce slides after disappointing revenue forecast
summary: Salesforce reported disappointing revenue forecasts, with projected sales of $3.67 billion to $3.68 billion for the period ending in April, missing analyst estimates of $3.7 billion. The company's profit forecast also fell short of projections. Salesforce's growth rate appears to have stalled, with a 22% year-over-year revenue increase in the current quarter being the smallest since 2010. The company's new annual revenue goal of $26 billion to $28 billion by fiscal year 2023 aims to boost growth, but investors are concerned about the pace of expansion.

images.alt_text: Salesforce.com Inc. gave a revenue forecast that fell short of estimates, stoking concern the torrid pace of the cloud software maker's growth has stalled as it matures into a larger company.

site_title: Indonesia, Australia sign long-awaited trade deal, years after talks started
summary: Indonesia and Australia signed a long-awaited trade deal after nine years of negotiations, marking a "new chapter of cooperation" between the two nations. The pact aims to eliminate Australian tariffs and 94% of Indonesian duties, improving access for Australian farmers, universities, and miners to Indonesia's 260 million people. The deal is expected to boost exports of timber, electronics, and medicinal goods, and spur Indonesia's automotive and textile industries. The agreement comes after months of diplomatic tension over Australia's plan to move its embassy to Jerusalem, which was later abandoned.

site_title: Cathay Pacific says in talks to buy stake in HK Express Airways
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd is in "active discussions" about acquiring a stake in Hong Kong Express Airways Ltd from cash-strapped conglomerate HNA Group Co Ltd. This comes as HNA unwinds a $50 billion acquisition spree amid soaring debt and government scrutiny. The airline's shares have risen 17% this year, following a surprise profit projection in February. An agreement has yet to be reached, and Cathay Pacific will issue a statement when necessary.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong flagship carrier Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd said on Tuesday it is in "active discussions" about an acquisition involving Hong Kong Express Airways Ltd, although an agreement has yet to be reached.

site_title: Sustainability central to MPA's social responsibility efforts
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) prioritizes sustainability in its corporate social responsibility efforts, aiming to foster a culture of good governance and conscientious environmental and social practices. The MPA's sustainability office focuses on prudent resource management and environmental and social responsibility. This commitment reflects the organization's dedication to making a positive impact on the community and the environment.

site_title: 8Telecom reshuffles board after directors quit; reveals changes among major shareholders
summary: 8Telecom International Holdings replaced two executive directors, Wan Guang and Liu Lu, with Shan Chuanlong and Long Hong, who have no prior experience as directors. The company also announced changes among major shareholders, including the acquisition of a 10.67% stake by Tian Di Internet for a discounted price. Private company Vok Investment Holdings disposed of 12 million shares, and it was revealed that Lan Zhihua now controls 100% of Vok, potentially changing Wang Zhejun's interest in the company. The board is now looking for a suitable candidate for an independent director position and a chairman of the audit committee.

site_title: WWE wrestlers return to Sports Hub in June
summary: WWE professional wrestlers will return to Singapore in June, nearly two years after their last performance at the Indoor Stadium in Kallang. The American sports entertainment giant will stop in Singapore on June 27 as part of a short Asia tour, alongside shows in Tokyo.

site_title: Far East Group to buy air-con engineering firm with S$7m cash, share issuance
summary: Far East Group has agreed to acquire air-conditioning company Tech Air-Con & Security Engineering for S$7 million in cash and 2.98 million shares. The share issuance represents 2.75% of existing issued shares and 2.68% of enlarged shares. The deal falls within a share mandate allowing for up to 50% new share issuance. The acquisition price will be based on the volume-weighted average price of the last market day prior to completion.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower following a fresh tariff salvo by the US on Canada. Creative Technology warned of lower-than-target H2 revenue and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing a DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: India needs land, labour, financial reforms: economic adviser
summary: India's next government must implement land, labour, and financial sector reforms to boost manufacturing productivity and economic growth. The country's manufacturing sector has seen a 1.5 percentage point growth in the last three years, and economic growth rate has decelerated to a five-quarter low of 6.6% in 2018. Despite this, the present government's economic reforms have contributed to an average annual growth rate of 7.3% over the past five years. The government faces challenges in creating jobs and shifting rural youth to urban areas, with 75-100 million young people expected to enter the labour market in the next five-year term.

site_title: As the Web turns 30, is it an 'out-of-control monster'?
summary: Tim Berners-Lee, inventor of the World Wide Web, has warned that his creation has been "hijacked by crooks" and may spell its destruction. Thirty years after its invention, Berners-Lee has launched a campaign to "save the Web" and has called for a new "Contract for the Web" that prioritizes access for all and fundamental right to privacy. He has expressed concerns over online bullying, fake news, and cyber threats, and has urged global elites to join the fight against polarization and the misuse of the Web.

images.alt_text: Mr Fluckiger (above) took charge of the Web team after Mr Berners-Lee left for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1994. Mr Berners-Lee has launched his own campaign to "save the Web".

site_title: Healthcare sector in South-east Asia ripe for lift-off
summary: The healthcare sector in South-east Asia, comprising 10 Asean countries, is ripe for innovation to address the region's pressing healthcare needs. With a population of over 600 million, the sector faces significant challenges, including a shortage of health workers, limited insurance coverage, and varying quality of care. To overcome these issues, innovative technologies and business models are being deployed, leveraging smart technology products and services to improve patient outcomes and resource productivity. However, regulatory challenges and varying market dynamics hinder the adoption of these solutions, requiring firms to adapt and innovate to meet the region's diverse healthcare demands.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 22% year-on-year fall in revenue but a 84% rise in net profit to 1.2 billion yuan in Q4, beating expectations. The company is pivoting from bulkers to tankers and LNG carriers, aiming to secure US$2 billion new orders in FY2019. Analysts have downgraded the stock, citing its high forward P/E ratio and limited growth prospects. Meanwhile, CSE Global reported a net profit of S$5.1 million in Q4, with a final dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents and a net orderbook of S$181 million.

site_title: Thakral family entity makes partial offer to increase stake
summary: Thakral Corporation received a partial offer from Prime Trade Enterprises (PTE) to buy 26.5 million shares at S$0.50 per share, increasing its stake to 50.2%. The offeror, owned by the Thakral family, has no intention to fully acquire or delist the company, and plans to expand its existing business. The offer represents an 18% premium above the volume-weighted average price. The offer is subject to shareholder approval and valid acceptances, and has been granted consent from the Securities Industry Council.

site_title: Ex-New Zealand PM to step down from China Construction Bank unit
summary: Former New Zealand Prime Minister Jenny Shipley is stepping down from the board of China Construction Bank's New Zealand unit amid controversy. She was ordered to pay NZ$6 million to creditors of failed construction company Mainzeal and faced criticism over an article praising Beijing's economic development. Shipley denied writing the article and will focus on personal and legal matters. Her role on the board has been questioned amid strained ties between New Zealand and China.

site_title: Silver linings and dark sides of the cloud
summary: Cloud-based services offer SMEs unlimited computing power at a marginal cost, scalability on demand, and reduced operational costs. However, risks include unauthorized access and modification of customer data, additional network risks, and vendor lock-in. To mitigate these risks, SMEs should research the service provider's organizational structure and risk management processes, monitor service performance and security, and consider certification standards such as Multi-Tier Cloud Security (MTCS) Singapore Standard 584. SMEs must also be aware of varying regulations and policies depending on the location of the data centre hosting the cloud-based service.

site_title: Will a big bust follow the current US big boom?
summary: US economist Alan Blinder suggests that the current economic boom, which could be the longest in American history, may be followed by a bust. Blinder cites low inflation, which has remained at 2%, as a potential indicator of full employment, and notes that the economy's annual growth rate is now limited to a modest 2% compared to the post-World War II average of 3%. He also points to potential threats such as a trade war, stock market crash, and unexpected oil price jumps, but believes that these risks are low. Historically, long expansions have been followed by tumultuous crises and subpar performance, raising concerns that a similar pattern may repeat itself.

site_title: The winners from Australia's property downturn
summary: Australia's property downturn has created winners in various groups, including first-time home buyers, renters, budget houses, small cities, and property stylists. The downturn has made homes more affordable for first-time buyers, with the median dwelling value in Sydney decreasing to A$789,339. Renters are also benefiting, with landlords offering incentives to attract applicants. Meanwhile, budget houses and small cities are seeing price increases, while the top end of the market is experiencing a decline. Property stylists are also benefiting from vendors seeking to present their homes in the best possible light to maximize sale prices.

site_title: Businesses, workers to get more help with digital economy tools
summary: Singapore has introduced new measures to support its digital economy, including digital learning guides for employers to plan staff training and an expanded TechSkills Accelerator scheme. The SMEs Go Digital scheme will offer more AI and cloud-based solutions, while the digital learning guides will be developed by public agencies to help workers adapt to digital technology. The government also plans to review the Electronic Transactions Act and Personal Data Protection Act to ensure they remain relevant and effective.

site_title: Crown Resorts' bid to extend skyscraper project date rejected
summary: Crown Resorts Ltd's bid to extend the start date for its Melbourne skyscraper project, One Queensbridge, has been rejected. The project, which includes a luxury hotel and apartment complex, was approved in 2017 but funding arrangements couldn't be reached before the construction start date. This decision comes as Australia's property market weakens, with Sydney and Melbourne accounting for 60% of the country's housing market. The company retains a 50% ownership interest in the land and is also developing a $2.2 billion casino on the Sydney waterfront.

site_title: StanChart sees more cost cuts, but plans for growth in Singapore
summary: Standard Chartered plans to cut costs but also aims for 9% annual growth in operating income in Singapore by 2021, with a goal of raising underlying returns on equity to 10%. CEO Patrick Lee outlined new targets in his first media interview since taking the helm in 2018. The bank plans to grow its affluent clientele and invest in digitalization to achieve these goals.

site_title: Jaguar's Indian revival stymied by China slowdown, quality problems
summary: Tata Motors' Indian subsidiary, Jaguar Land Rover (JLR), faces significant challenges, including a slowdown in China, quality problems, and a struggling UK market. Despite being a major luxury carmaker, JLR has reported a record loss of $5.2 billion in the December quarter, with shipments collapsing 35% in China. The company is exploring the possibility of selling part of the unit, and has cut 4,500 jobs. Quality issues have also weighed on the brand, with JLR ranking 148 problems per 100 vehicles in a JD Power survey, making it one of the worst performers.

images.alt_text: Land Rover still ranks as the most valuable of the major brands owned by Tata Group. The marque was worth an estimated US$6.2 billion last year.

site_title: Bigger, saltier, heavier: How fast food changed over 30 years
summary: A study by researchers at Boston University and Tufts found that fast food menus have grown in size and calorie content over the past 30 years, despite the inclusion of lighter options. The average entree weighed 39g more and had 90 more calories in 2016 compared to 1986, with sodium content increasing to 41.6% of the recommended daily allotment. The study suggests that despite some positive changes, overall menu changes have gotten worse, contributing to the rising obesity rate in the US.

site_title: China 'to lower VAT for manufacturing sector'
summary: China plans to lower the value-added tax (VAT) rate for the manufacturing sector by three percentage points to support its slowing economy. The move is expected to boost corporate profits and deliver a boost worth up to 600 billion yuan (S$121.9 billion) or 0.6% of GDP. This is part of broader fiscal support, with the budget deficit target widened to 2.8% of GDP and special bonds quota set to 2.15 trillion yuan. The VAT cut could be announced at the upcoming National People's Congress in Beijing.

site_title: The newfound power of tech workers
summary: US tech companies, such as Google and Microsoft, have begun to back away from government contracts due to employee opposition over ethical and technological concerns. Employees have protested and petitioned against projects involving artificial intelligence and lethal force, citing issues with bias and privacy. Former US Secretary of Defense ASH Carter praises employee involvement, saying it's a fair thing to challenge leaders. However, he also emphasizes the need for collaboration between tech companies and the government to address these concerns.

site_title: May accused of buying Brexit votes with £1.6b for towns
summary: Theresa May is offering a £1.6 billion Stronger Towns Fund to poorer areas of the UK, amid efforts to secure her Brexit deal. The fund, aimed at creating jobs and increasing opportunities, has been criticized as an attempt to "buy" votes from opposition politicians in Leave-supporting districts. May's opponents claim the fund is a desperate measure to woo Labour members of Parliament, while she promises a revised deal to the House of Commons by March 12.

site_title: DBS India to set up 100 branches, kiosks
summary: DBS Bank India, a wholly-owned subsidiary of DBS Bank, plans to establish over 100 customer touchpoints across 25 cities in the next 12-18 months. The bank will open 9 new branches and expand its presence in cities like Mumbai and the National Capital Region. DBS has been present in India for 25 years and has acquired over 2.5 million digibank customers since its launch in 2016. The bank aims to offer a more compelling proposition to customers through its mobile-only offering and data-driven lending solutions.

site_title: PSA head says Europe's CO2 cuts will threaten jobs
summary: The EU's plans to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from vehicles by 37.5% by 2030 threaten 13 million jobs in the European auto industry, according to PSA CEO Carlos Tavares. This could benefit Asia, particularly China, where PSA struggles to understand the market. To mitigate the impact, the EU plans to boost the electric car battery industry and reduce reliance on Asian suppliers. However, initial capital costs for localizing the industry are high, and PSA may be forced to rely on Asian suppliers if it does not sell enough electric vehicles by 2020, 2025, and 2030.

site_title: UK construction activity falls for first time in 11 months
summary: The UK construction industry experienced its first decline in 11 months in February, with the IHS Markit/CIPS Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 49.5 from 50.6 in January. Brexit uncertainty and a slow housing market led to delayed building projects, with builders facing long delays in obtaining construction materials. The construction sector's volatility has a significant impact on the UK economy, making up only 6% of the economy.

site_title: Businesses fear tying grants to worker outcomes could be deterrent
summary: Singapore businesses are concerned about the new condition requiring them to commit to worker outcomes such as wage increases when receiving funding support from the Enterprise Development Grant (EDG) starting April 1, 2020. They argue that this adds to business costs without guarantees of increased profits, potentially making Singapore less competitive in the long term. The government aims to encourage firms to "more intentionally translate enterprise transformation efforts into improvements in workers' livelihoods."

site_title: Elon Musk touts March 14 Model Y event as demand questions linger
summary: Elon Musk announced Tesla's Model Y crossover will be unveiled in less than two weeks, amid concerns about store closures, employee layoffs, and demand following waning US federal tax credits. The Model Y, a larger SUV, is expected to have "normal" doors and cost around 10% more than the Model 3. The vehicle's design and pricing are largely based on its battery range. This unveiling comes after Tesla's fourth-quarter earnings call and amid the company's shift towards online sales, with shares tumbling 7.8% following the announcement of store closures.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start week with fresh gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks started the week with gains, extending last week's rally, as China and the US close in on a deal to end their trade war. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.51%, the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 1.12%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index rallied 2.21%. The gains followed reports of a potential trade deal between China and the US.

site_title: Why the nuclear talks with N Korea fell apart
