In Singapore, a Q3 wave of condo launches may test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents reached a record high, with more increases expected. In other news, Goldman Sachs acquired a large hotel and retail asset portfolio in Seoul, while UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. New World Group is selling China property assets after a loan deal, and WeWork secured new tenants at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore after its bankruptcy.

site_title: Gold prices slide on better-than-expected US economic data
summary: Gold prices declined this week due to better-than-expected US economic data, which strengthened the US dollar and negatively impacted the non-interest-bearing asset. Despite slowing economic growth in Asia, indicated by weakening PMIs, gold prices remain firm due to prevailing global economic weakness and potential market risks in 2019. Investors should monitor US retail sales and global economic indicators for further signs of weakness, as safe haven assets are expected to remain firm.

site_title: Trump insists relations with Kim are 'very good'
summary: US President Donald Trump insisted that his relations with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un are "very good" despite their failed Hanoi summit. The summit ended without a joint statement, with each side blaming the other's intransigence. Trump said Pyongyang wanted the lifting of all sanctions, while North Korea's foreign minister stated that only some sanctions needed to be eased. The North's official news agency described the meeting as "successful," with Kim promising another encounter.

site_title: One of Wall Street's most popular trading strategies is now failing
summary: Trend-following quantitative trading strategies, popularized in the 1990s, are failing due to their inability to respond to market surprises and keep pace with the speed of modern markets. Despite managing over $1 trillion, these strategies have delivered average returns of only 3.7% between 2008 and 2018, underperforming the S&P 500 and other hedge funds. Critics argue that the strategy's reliance on historical data and slow adjustments to changing market conditions make it obsolete. As a result, investors have pulled billions of dollars from trend-following funds, with some prominent managers, including Franklin Templeton and Winton Fund, exiting the strategy altogether.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's Q4 profit soars 84%
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's fourth-quarter net profit surged 84% to 1.25 billion Chinese yuan, driven by favourable foreign exchange gains, lower administrative expenses, and a reversal of impairment loss. The company delivered 11 vessels in Q4 2018, with an outstanding order book of US$3.9 billion for 113 vessels. Full-year revenue rose 21% to 23.2 billion yuan, with net profit up 23% to 3.6 billion yuan. The company proposed a final dividend of five Singapore cents per share, up from 4.5 cents in 2017.

site_title: AJ Capital-backed Symbo launches online insurance broking business in S'pore
summary: Symbo Platform Holdings, backed by AJ Capital, has launched an online insurance broking business in Singapore. The startup's digital platform allows customers to purchase general life and insurance products with innovative, "context-based" policies. Symbo has formed partnerships with various companies, including Carro and Found8, and plans to expand to Indonesia, Malaysia, and broader South-east Asia. With an appointed international head and Singapore CEO, Symbo aims to offer thought-leading solutions in the region, marking a milestone in its regional ambition.

site_title: Call for inclusion
summary: Mastercard CEO Ajay Banga emphasizes the importance of financial inclusion, stating that it's a worthy investment despite not generating significant profits for the company. He believes that global inequality is surging, with 2 billion people outside the formal financial system, and that technology can be a tool to address imbalances in the global economy. Mastercard has reached 350 million people through its financial inclusion drive, aiming to reach 500 million by 2020. Banga's approach involves working with governments and technology to provide access to financial services, including social benefits, payroll systems, and digital wallets. He believes that financial inclusion can help create a growing, thriving middle class, which is in the company's enlightened self-interest.

site_title: China PMI and US growth figures buoy most Asian markets
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday, March 1, 2019, following strong China PMI and US growth figures. The Straits Times Index in Singapore increased 0.2% to close at 3,220.40, despite muted trading due to trade issues. Investors remained cautious, awaiting developments in US-China trade talks and the Trump-Kim summit. Key indices in mainland China also rose, with the Shanghai Composite up 1.8% to 2,994.00, its biggest weekly gain in nearly four years.

site_title: Razer Pay beta testing launched in Singapore
summary: Razer Pay, a unified e-payments system, has launched its beta testing phase in Singapore, following CEO Tan Min-Liang's 2017 promise to have the system nationwide in 18 months. Initially planned for April, the rollout has been delayed to end-June, with mobile payment company FOMO Pay as its official merchant acquirer at 4,000 payment points. Razer Pay users can make purchases at Dunkin' Donuts outlets and Buzz convenience stores, and the company has established a regional headquarters in Singapore's one-north district.

site_title: Chinese online lender Dianrong cutting thousands of staff, closing stores: sources
summary: Chinese online lender Dianrong is cutting thousands of staff and closing stores, reportedly laying off 2,000 employees and shutting 60 of its 90 outlets, as it tries to reduce costs and comply with authorities' efforts to shrink the online lending industry. The move follows a government crackdown on financial risk, which has led to the freezing of assets worth US$2.01 billion and the arrest of 62 suspects implicated in P2P frauds. The company has settled with unhappy former employees and is "optimising" its structure in response to regulatory policies and industry changes.

site_title: Pacific Century's FY18 net profit slides 42.7%
summary: Pacific Century Regional Developments, a Hong Kong-based company owned by Richard Li, saw its FY18 net profit slide 42.7% to S$49.96 million due to a lower share of profit from associated companies. Revenue gained 6.6% to S$15.62 million, largely from higher dividends from HKT, Hong Kong's largest telecoms company. The company proposed a final dividend of 2.4 cents and special dividend of 6.3 cents, citing a challenging global economic environment and dependence on PCCW and HKT results.

site_title: US: Wall Street rises at open following benign inflation data
summary: US stocks rose at open on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 103.67 points, or 0.40%, to 26,019.67. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the S&P 500 rising 13.73 points, or 0.49%, and the Nasdaq up 54.92 points, or 0.73%. The data showed tame inflation pressures, which supports the Federal Reserve's "patient" stance on raising interest rates further this year.

site_title: Energy, petrochemical veteran Tan Soo Koong to helm Singapore LNG
summary: Singapore LNG Corporation has appointed Tan Soo Koong as its CEO, effective April 2, 2019. Tan Soo Koong, a veteran in the energy and petrochemical sector, replaces John Ng, who stepped down in December 2018. The company's chairman, Tang Kin Fei, praised Tan's operational, technical, and commercial experience, stating that he will drive excellence in terminal operations and grow the LNG business, establishing Singapore as a regional LNG hub.

site_title: The tech way to fengshui
summary: Way Fengshui Group, a Singapore-based fengshui consulting firm, is leveraging technology to increase efficiency and expand its reach. The company has invested in digital systems, including a knowledge bank and a software program, to empower its staff and provide better services to clients. With a growing revenue and a steady supply of fengshui masters, the company is poised for further expansion, including plans to open offices in Malaysia and Indonesia. CEO Mark Tan aims to eventually list the company on the stock market, citing the importance of sustainability and a global presence.

site_title: US personal income falls; spending weakest since 2009
summary: US personal income fell 0.1% in January, the first decline in over three years, due to decreases in dividend, farm proprietors', and interest income. Consumer spending dropped 0.5% in December, the largest decline since 2009, but remains supported by accumulated savings. Inflation pressures remain tame, and the Federal Reserve's "patient" stance on raising interest rates is reinforced. The decline in consumer spending suggests a lower growth trajectory in the first quarter, but the economy is also losing momentum due to fading tax cuts and increased government spending.

site_title: Who do we really not like?
summary: A list of the most despised professions has been compiled after a series of scandals and economic crises. Initially, lawyers, bankers, and accountants were at the top, but after the 2008 Global Financial Crisis, politicians and rating agencies joined the list. The crisis was caused by poor regulation and the promotion of cheap credit, leading to widespread financial losses. The professions have since been seen as incompetent and craven, with some calling for a "top 10" list of the world's most despised groups.

images.alt_text: For a while, the three professions - bankers, lawyers and accountants - were the butt of public jokes and top of everybody's list of "people we do not like".

site_title: Tekka Place on track for soft opening by year's end
summary: Tekka Place, a new hospitality and retail integrated development in Singapore, is on track for a soft opening by the end of this year. The $400 million redevelopment, jointly developed by Lum Chang Holdings and LaSalle Investment Management, includes a 10-storey main block, 7-storey annex block, and a 320-unit Citadines Rochor service residence. Half of the net lettable retail space has been committed, with notable tenants including XinTekka, a 10,000 sq ft food hall concept. The development aims to preserve the rich historical and multicultural characteristics of the Little India heritage precinct, with a focus on the arts and engagement with the local community.

images.alt_text: Mr Iswaran at the topping-out ceremony for Tekka Place, a hospitality-cum-retail development on the site of The Verge shopping mall.

site_title: N Korea's Kim kicks off official Vietnam visit
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un began an official visit to Vietnam on March 1, 2019, following a nuclear summit with US President Donald Trump that ended in a stalemate. Accompanied by his sister and close aide, Kim Yo Jong, Kim Jong Un was received by Vietnam President Nguyen Phu Trong and inspected an honor guard. This visit marks Kim Jong Un's fourth foreign destination in less than a year, as he seeks to portray North Korea as a country like any other.

site_title: South Korea to work with US and North Korea after failed nuclear talks
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in announced plans to work with the US and North Korea to reach a complete settlement on denuclearization, following the collapse of talks between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Hanoi. The US and North Korea had failed to agree on sanctions relief in exchange for nuclear steps, with North Korea offering to dismantle its Yongbyon nuclear site in exchange for partial sanctions relief. Despite the setback, both sides expressed a desire to maintain momentum and press on with negotiations.

site_title: Transcorp gets green light to hold AGM by Mar 31
summary: Transcorp Holdings has received approval from the Singapore Exchange to hold its annual general meeting (AGM) by March 31, with the original deadline being Thursday. The delay was due to the vacant CFO position from November to December and the late appointment of executive directors, which hindered the company's ability to assess risk management and internal control systems. This has resulted in a need for more time to address material risks and provide an opinion on corporate governance in the annual report.

site_title: Singapore to buy four United States F-35 Joint Strike Fighters
summary: Singapore plans to acquire four US F-35 Joint Strike Fighters with an option to buy eight more, as part of its efforts to build the next-generation Singapore Armed Forces. Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen cited US President Donald Trump's support for the purchase and a falling unit price of the F-35. The acquisition will be part of a broader modernization plan, including the development of new ships, armoured vehicles, and cyber security capabilities. The goal is to create a "next-generation SAF of 2030 and beyond" that can defend Singapore for another generation.

site_title: CDL buys £15.4m site in Leeds to build rental housing
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) has acquired a £15.4 million site in Leeds, UK, to build a 664-unit, build-to-rent residential project. The site, with a total development cost of £140 million, is expected to be completed in 2023 and will feature a commercial area and public park. The project aims to capitalize on the UK's growing private rental sector, with a net yield of 5% annually. This expansion is in line with CDL's strategy to grow recurring income, as the UK government seeks to address its housing supply-demand imbalance.

site_title: EU banks watchdog urges protection of deposits in case of no deal Brexit
summary: The European Banking Authority (EBA) has urged EU member states to offer deposit account protection for customers of UK bank branches in the EU in case of a no-deal Brexit. This would ensure that depositors' funds remain safe, as national deposit guarantee schemes only protect deposits within the EU, not branches outside it. The EBA's call comes as Britain is set to leave the bloc on March 29, 2019.

site_title: Eric Lew appointed Y Ventures' executive chairman, director
summary: Eric Lew Chern Yong, former executive director of Wong Fong Industries, has been appointed as the executive chairman and director of e-commerce company Y Ventures. He replaces Adam Low Yik Sen as managing director and will drive the group's strategic direction and growth. Y Ventures reported a widened 2018 net loss of US$3.6 million due to increased costs and expenses. The company is also streamlining operations and focusing on online book distribution, amid concerns over accounting errors and internal controls.

site_title: Thailand defends cybersecurity law amid concerns over rights, abuse
summary: Thailand has defended its newly approved cybersecurity law, which critics say could sacrifice privacy and violate rights. The law, approved by the rubber-stamp parliament, aims to protect networks from cyber attacks but experts warn its vague language could lead to broad interpretations that infringe on rights. The government claims the law will not enable state surveillance or violate individuals' rights, but activists have called it "cyber martial law" that could drive foreign businesses out of Thailand.

site_title: ASTI Holdings nearly halves Q4 loss; proposes to pay out 0.5 Singapore cent per share
summary: ASTI Holdings nearly halved its Q4 net loss to S$3.2 million, down from S$6.3 million in the same period last year. The company proposed a 0.5 Singapore cent per share cash dividend and reported a 15.8% revenue increase to S$19.3 million. ASTI posted a full-year net profit of S$30.1 million, reversing a loss of S$4.4 million in FY2017. Despite the positive financials, ASTI remains cautious about its next quarter prospects due to market uncertainties.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Key developments include CDL's £15.4m acquisition into the UK private rented sector, Razer Pay's beta launch in Singapore, and MSCI's decision to increase weighting on Chinese A-shares. Singapore plans to purchase four F-35 jets with an option for 8 more, while Fortress Minerals seeks a Catalist listing. The Straits Times Index added 7.71 points to close at 3,220.40, driven by corporate earnings.

site_title: Green economy? Thai party campaigns on marijuana as cash crop
summary: Thailand's Bhumjaithai party is campaigning on promoting cannabis farming as a cash crop ahead of the country's general election on March 24. The party's leader, Anutin Charnvirakul, advocates for the recreational use of marijuana, citing its potential to generate income for farmers and boost the economy. Thailand legalized medical marijuana in December, and the party's proposal includes regulations similar to those for tobacco. However, experts warn that it may take time for cannabis farming to develop in Thailand, competing with established markets in the US and Canada.

site_title: Huan Hsin to delist, submit cash exit offer by end-March
summary: Huan Hsin Holdings, a Singapore-based electronics contract manufacturer, has been given until end-March 2019 to submit a reasonable cash exit offer proposal after its appeal to delist was rejected. The company had failed to meet listing requirements for profitability and market value, but narrowed its net loss to S$2.5 million for fiscal year 2018, thanks to a boost in operating income and disposal of non-performing assets. The company's current assets of S$24 million and liabilities of S$70.5 million pose a going concern issue, but management is confident in its corporate restructuring strategies.

site_title: AMP Capital's proposed sale to partner managing AA Reit did not take place on Feb 28
summary: AMP Capital's proposed sale of its 50% interest in AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit) to AIMS Financial Group did not occur on February 28 as planned. The Reit Manager cited disagreement between the parties and no certainty of the transaction proceeding. The deal, announced in November, would have given AIMS Financial Group full ownership of AA Reit's management entities. The Reit Manager stated it will make announcements when material developments occur, advising unitholders to act with caution. The transaction's impact on AA Reit's operations is expected to be minimal.

site_title: Daimler asks EU antitrust regulators to probe Nokia patents
summary: German carmaker Daimler has lodged a complaint with EU antitrust regulators against Nokia, alleging that the company is not providing fair access to essential patents for car communications. Daimler seeks clarification on licensing terms for telecommunications standards used in navigation systems, vehicle-to-vehicle communication, and self-driving cars. Nokia claims Daimler is trying to avoid taking a license, and patent disputes between tech companies could escalate to the vehicle industry. The European Commission has confirmed receipt of Daimler's complaint.

site_title: China's factory rebound eases one big fear about global outlook
summary: China's manufacturing purchasing managers index rose to 50.5 in March, exceeding estimates, signaling a stabilisation in the world's second-largest economy. This easing of concerns for the global outlook is due to China's rebound in manufacturing and exports, which had weighed on sectors worldwide. However, domestic consumption remains weak, and the economy is expected to slow further to 6.2% growth in the first quarter. The government has vowed not to overstimulate the economy and is cautious about policy measures, but a confirmed rebound could lift concerns about a downturn in China and global asset prices.

site_title: Cosco Shipping FY2018 net profit plummets 93% to S$13m
summary: Cosco Shipping International (Singapore) reported a net profit of S$13 million for FY2018, a 93% decrease from S$189.4 million in FY2017. Revenue increased four times to S$163.7 million, driven by a turnaround in logistics businesses. The company aims to expand its logistics network in South and South-east Asia through acquisitions and investments. Profit from continuing operations was S$16.9 million, reversing a loss of S$26.6 million in FY2017.

site_title: UK factories brace for Brexit, but consumers less worried
summary: British factories are cutting jobs and stockpiling goods ahead of Brexit, but consumers appear less worried, with household spending and borrowing increasing in January. The IHS Markit/CIPS Purchasing Managers' Index hit a four-month low, but consumers' focus on Brexit is expected to intensify closer to the March 29 deadline. The UK's economy has slowed ahead of Brexit, with a weakening global economy and a manufacturing index falling into contractionary territory. The Bank of England plans to resume raising interest rates if Britain avoids a no-deal Brexit.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to fresh tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2 and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing a DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, ahead of Singapore's GDP data release.

site_title: Deutsche Telekom open to data sharing to boost security
summary: Deutsche Telekom is open to sharing data with other operators to enhance network security as the industry prepares for 5G technology. This move comes amid concerns over equipment supplied by Huawei, which the US alleges could be used for spying. The decision aims to counter these concerns and improve cybersecurity.

site_title: SPH Magazines launches brand new online store
summary: SPH Magazines has launched myNEWSSTAND.online, a new online store offering print and digital editions and subscriptions of over 60 international and local magazines, including Bloomberg Businessweek and The Atlantic. The site allows readers to choose between print and digital editions, with prices starting from S$1 for single-issue digital magazines and S$10 for annual subscriptions. The launch aims to boost the digital presence of regional publishers and improve accessibility to audiences. The platform will also feature digital magazine bundles themed along lines like men, women, and business.

site_title: India's Tata Motors denies reports of JLR unit sake sale
summary: India's Tata Motors denies reports that it is exploring options for selling a minority stake in its luxury car unit Jaguar Land Rover (JLR). The reports sparked a 3.7% gain in Tata Motors shares, but the company has since clarified that there is no truth to the rumors. Tata Motors had posted its largest quarterly loss in Indian corporate history, mainly due to weak China sales, and warned that the JLR unit would likely swing to an operating loss in the year to March. The company may prefer to seek fresh equity from investors rather than divest control of JLR.

site_title: Taxpayers can't bail out Hyflux investors, Masagos tells Parliament
summary: Singapore's National Water Agency (PUB) cannot use taxpayer money to help retail investors recoup their losses from Hyflux, despite the government's efforts to ensure water security. Minister Masagos Zulkifli stated that PUB's actions on the Tuaspring desalination plant do not weaken the public-private partnership (PPP) model for critical infrastructure assets. PUB is willing to waive compensation and take over the plant at no extra cost to Hyflux, but cannot use taxpayer funds to help investors. The government prioritizes water security over investor claims, citing the need to protect Singapore's water supply.

site_title: Ryobi Kiso to potentially undergo judicial management
summary: Ryobi Kiso Holdings and its unit Ryobi Kiso (S) may undergo judicial management following an application filed by Standard Chartered Bank for interim judicial managers. DBS Bank has appointed receivers for Ryobi Kiso (S) for certain project contracts. The winding-up application against Ryobi Kiso (S) has been adjourned and will be heard on a date to be scheduled by the court. Ryobi Kiso shares are currently suspended.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Friday, closing 6.97 points down at 1,700.76 on the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index. Volume reached 2.9 billion lots worth RM2.3 billion, with 486 gainers and 460 losers.

site_title: Trek 2000 posts FY2018 net loss of S$3.8m on weaker customer demand
summary: Trek 2000, a Singapore-based thumb drive manufacturer, reported a net loss of S$3.8 million in FY2018, down from a net profit of S$8.2 million in the previous year. The company attributed the loss to weaker customer demand due to the 2018 trade war. Revenue plummeted 73.3% to S$30.1 million and gross profit margin decreased to 3.7%. Despite the challenges, Trek 2000 plans to maintain its cash reserves and invest in R&D to stay relevant in the market. The company expects the market to remain challenging in the next 12 months.

site_title: Pakistan re-starting some flights, to fully re-open commercial airspace Monday
summary: Pakistan will partially reopen four airports on Friday and fully resume commercial flights on Monday, ending a week-long closure due to military tensions with India. The airports of Karachi, Islamabad, Peshawar, and Quetta will initially operate some flights, with the remainder opening next week. Airspace for all commercial flights will reopen on March 4 at 1:00 pm GMT. The decision comes after signs of a cooling conflict between the two nuclear-armed neighbors, with an Indian pilot captured by Pakistani forces.

images.alt_text: Pakistani passengers gather outside the Jinnah International Airport as they wait for flight operations to resume in Karachi on March 1, 2019.Four Pakistani airports will begin partial operations on Friday with a full resumption of commercial flights on Monday, following their suspension after military tensions with India erupted earlier this week, the Civil Aviation Authority said.

site_title: Pacific Century FY18 net profit slides 42.7%
summary: Pacific Century Regional Developments' net profit for FY18 fell 42.7% to S$49.96 million, largely due to a lower share of profit from associated companies. Revenue increased 6.6% to S$15.62 million, driven by higher dividends from HKT, the largest telecoms company in Hong Kong. The group has proposed a final dividend of 2.4 Singapore cents and a special dividend of 6.3 Singapore cents. Pacific Century expects challenges in the global economic environment and is dependent on the results of PCCW and HKT for its results.

site_title: Oceanus Q4 net profit plunges
summary: Oceanus Group reported a net profit of 792,000 yuan (S$159,770) for its fourth quarter ended December 31, down from 222.1 million yuan a year ago. Revenue dropped 7% to 7.4 million yuan, but gross profit margins improved. The company posted a net profit of 4.9 million yuan for the full year, down 97% from the previous year. Oceanus also recorded a decrease in other non-operating income due to the absence of a compensation amount from the acquisition of Gulei Farms by Chinese authorities.

site_title: Ascott Reit buys 150-room business hotel near Sydney Airport for A$61m
summary: Ascott Reit is purchasing a 150-room business hotel near Sydney Airport in Australia for A$60.6 million, set to be rebranded as Citadines Connect Sydney Airport. The deal, completed in May 2019, marks the trust's first Australian business hotel. The freehold Felix Hotel is expected to cater to travelers and business professionals.

site_title: Release of shot-down Indian pilot delayed by hours
summary: India's captured air force pilot, Wing Commander Abhinandan Varthaman, was expected to be handed over to authorities at the Wagah border crossing on Friday but the handover was delayed by hours. Varthaman was shot down on Wednesday in a dogfight over Kashmir and was being held by Pakistani authorities. The delay was attributed to the lack of information, with both sides remaining tight-lipped about the reasons. Violence continued in Kashmir, with at least one woman killed and gunbattles between militants and security forces leaving seven dead.

site_title: WeWork faces uphill climb from Europe's lenders
summary: WeWork, a co-working giant, faces an uphill climb from European lenders due to caution over its business model and single-tenant exposure. Banks and investors are hesitant to finance WeWork-leased buildings, citing concerns over the company's high valuation and lack of transparency. WeWork's rapid expansion, with 630 locations worldwide, is a key factor in its high valuation, but also poses a risk if lenders follow the lead of ING Groep in rejecting a lease. The company must build relationships with banks and address concerns over its business model to secure funding.

site_title: British hedge fund Man Group's performance fees plunge as assets slip in 2018
summary: British hedge fund Man Group reported a 0.5% decline in assets under management to $108.5 billion in 2018, resulting in an 81% plunge in performance fees. The company suffered investment losses of $7.7 billion and currency losses of $3.7 billion, with most of its strategies losing money. Only its computer-driven trading division AHL eked out modest gains. CEO Luke Ellis attributed the challenges to "higher volatility" and "periods of market weakness."

site_title: Businesses must embrace AI and machine learning for the digital economy
summary: Singapore's government has invested S$15.5 billion to combat cyber threats, recognizing the country's rapid digitalization and increased connectivity as a target for cyber criminals. To address this, businesses must also improve their cyber-security measures, leveraging AI and machine learning to detect and respond to threats more effectively. This includes implementing predictive security, machine learning, and business intelligence to reduce the gap between compromise and detection, and improve response capabilities.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week higher, driven by refreshed hopes for China-US trade talks and improved Chinese factory activity data. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.63% to 28,812.17, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 1.80% and 1.20%, respectively. The gains followed positive news from the US, including a record-breaking S&P 500 and Nasdaq. Investors remained optimistic despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Reclaims Global launches Catalist IPO at 23 S cents per share
summary: Reclaims Global, an eco-friendly construction service provider, launches its initial public offering (IPO) at S$0.23 per share, offering 20 million shares. The IPO will debut on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board on March 11. The company plans to use the net proceeds for expanding operational capacity, expanding its recycled product range, and general working capital purposes. Reclaims Global specializes in recycling construction and demolition waste and expects growth driven by domestic infrastructure projects and government initiatives promoting sustainable building practices.

site_title: Ramping up the fight for renewable energy
summary: WEnergy Global, a company led by Asean CEO Atem Ramsundersingh, has unveiled a micro-grid hybrid project in Sabang, Philippines, aiming to electrify the city using solar, battery, and renewable energy. The project, which took six years to complete, can rely on renewable energy for half of its energy production over 20 years. The company's goal is to electrify and illuminate communities in Southeast Asia without using dirty power, and plans to collaborate with partners to accelerate the process and build a portfolio of electrification projects worth $100 million in the next four years.

site_title: Singapore shares add 0.2% on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.2% to close at 3,220.40, lifted by Chinese manufacturing data and optimistic comments from US economic adviser Larry Kudlow. However, muted trading occurred due to uncertainty surrounding the Trump-Kim summit and China-US trade talks. Gainers included media company UnUsUaL Ltd, which closed 15.4% higher after three off-market trades, and casino operator Genting Singapore, which rose 1% after 25.5 million shares changed hands.

site_title: Reits
summary: US mortgage rates rise after five weeks of decline, impacting real estate markets worldwide. A wave of condo launches in Singapore's prime projects above S$3,000 psf is expected to test demand. Manhattan rents reached a record, with more increases anticipated. In other news, Goldman Sachs acquired a South Korean hotel and retail portfolio, and UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. WeWork secured new tenants at its Singapore office after emerging from bankruptcy. These market shifts indicate a potential slowdown in real estate investment.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's economy expands in Q4 on boost from crude; non-oil growth slows
summary: Saudi Arabia's economy expanded in Q4 2018 at its fastest rate since 2016, driven by a 6% year-on-year growth in the oil sector. Non-oil growth was sluggish at 1.8%, down from 2.1% in Q3. The economy's reliance on oil output remains a concern, with growth expected to moderate in 2019 due to oil production cuts. Saudi Arabia plans to issue 118 billion riyals in debt to finance the national budget deficit, and has borrowed extensively to refill state coffers depleted by a drop in oil prices.

site_title: Ezion posts wider Q4 net loss, says potential rescue talks reach 'advanced' stage
summary: Ezion Holdings, an offshore and marine group, reported a widening net loss of US$390.8 million for the fourth quarter, with revenue plummeting 33.5% to US$29.7 million. The company is in advanced discussions with a potential strategic investor to strengthen its financial position, improve cash flow, and preserve value for stakeholders. Ezion's losses per share stood at 10.54 US cents, down from 16.06 US cents before, and the group's full-year net loss was US$344.3 million.

site_title: Jet Airways founder agrees to step down: sources
summary: Jet Airways founder Naresh Goyal has agreed to step down as chairman of the airline's board as the cash-strapped carrier struggles to finalize a rescue deal. He will also reduce his 51% stake in the airline but will remain a part of the company. The airline is in talks with Etihad and Tata Sons for fresh funds or a stake sale, but any deal would require Goyal to step down or take a less prominent role. Jet Airways is struggling with debt, fuel costs, and a weak rupee, forcing it to ground over a dozen planes.

site_title: Stolen Picasso unearthed by 'Indiana Jones of art'
summary: A stolen 1938 Picasso painting, "Buste de Femme (Dora Maar)," worth 25 million euros, has been recovered by Dutch art detective Arthur Brand, known as the "Indiana Jones of the Art World." The painting, one of Picasso's most influential works, was stolen from a Saudi sheikh's yacht on the French Riviera in 1999. Brand tracked the painting through the Dutch criminal underworld, eventually recovering it from two intermediaries who had been using it as collateral in various deals. The painting is now in the possession of an insurance company, which will decide its next steps.

site_title: Cancer immunotherapy biotech Tessa Therapeutics names industry veteran to board
summary: Singapore-based immunotherapy biotech company Tessa Therapeutics has appointed industry veteran Jeffrey Buchalter as an independent board member, its third independent director in over a year. Buchalter brings extensive experience in biopharmaceutical companies and oncology expertise, following the appointments of Goran Ando and George Sledge in 2018. Tessa's key nasopharyngeal cancer therapy, TT10, is currently undergoing a global Phase 3 trial, and the company is developing other immunotherapy treatments for solid tumours and Epstein-Barr virus-associated lymphomas.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.5% to 7,107.64 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also increasing 0.6% and 0.5%, respectively. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares, while US-EU trade talks were in focus. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq indices also edged to fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Tan Quee Lan Street site expected to grab developers' attention
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a tender for a 99-year leasehold site on Tan Quee Lan Street in Singapore's Bugis area, attracting keen interest from developers due to its prime location next to the Bugis MRT station. The site can potentially yield up to 580 residential units and 2,000 sq m of commercial space on the first storey. Analysts expect 10-12 bids, with a potential top bid of S$834 million, which works out to S$1,600 psf ppr, making it one of the most attractive sites in the area.

site_title: Yellen sees no US recession, so Fed won't cut rates in 2019
summary: Former US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen expressed confidence that the US economy won't enter a recession in 2019, citing a slowdown rather than a recession. Yellen stated that the Fed won't cut interest rates, as officials are comfortable with the current level and prepared to adjust rates based on economic developments. The Fed has marked down its economic growth forecasts to 2.1%, but Yellen believes this is not a recession. She also downplayed concerns about the inverted yield curve, which has preceded US recessions in the past, and noted that the Fed would be prepared to cut rates if there were downside surprises in Europe and China.

site_title: Thousands gather at border to welcome back Indian pilot
summary: Thousands of Indians gathered at the Wagah border crossing to welcome back Indian air force pilot Wing Commander Abhinandan Varthaman, who was shot down by Pakistan and freed as part of a "peace gesture." The move comes amid escalating tensions between the two nuclear-armed rivals over Kashmir. Abhinandan's parents were given a standing ovation as they boarded a flight to Amritsar, and thousands of people cheered as he was expected to be handed over to India at around 3:00-4:00 pm. The event has been marked by patriotic displays and messages of support for the pilot, who has emerged as a national hero in India.

site_title: Delivery app outdoes rivals by letting diners bargain on the go
summary: A Saudi delivery app, Mrsool, has outpaced rivals Uber and Facebook in the kingdom by introducing a bargaining system, allowing customers to interact with couriers through messaging and photo sharing. With 4 million registered users and 1 billion riyals in transactions last year, Mrsool has become a popular choice for food, grocery, and other delivery services. The app's success is attributed to its personal touch, cash payment options, and regional expansion plans.

site_title: India's Jet Airways founder Goyal to quit as chairman on Monday -ET Now
summary: Naresh Goyal, founder of Jet Airways, will step down as chairman on Monday, along with his wife Anita Goyal, amid the airline's financial struggles. Goyal had agreed to reduce his 51% stake earlier this month. Jet Airways is saddled with over $1 billion of debt and has delayed payments to banks, suppliers, and lessors, leading to the grounding of up to 40 planes. Chief Executive Vinay Dube is expected to stay on board. The airline's lenders may invoke Goyal's entire stake, potentially leading to a new buyer in the coming weeks.

site_title: Japan vows to raise sales tax as record budget passes parliament
summary: Japan's parliament approved a record 101 trillion yen budget for the coming fiscal year, with a planned sales tax hike to 10% in October. Despite speculation that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe may delay the tax increase, Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga reaffirmed the plan. The government has taken steps to mitigate the impact of the tax hike, including increased spending on welfare and public works. Analysts warn that proceeding with the tax hike could be risky, particularly with national elections for the upper house looming.

site_title: Apple spotlights services with TV, gaming and credit card offerings
summary: Apple has launched its streaming television service, Apple TV+, alongside a credit card, digital video game arcade, and revamped magazine offerings. The service, featuring original content from Hollywood stars, will be available in over 100 countries and will be offered through a revamped TV app. Apple has also introduced Apple Arcade, a gaming subscription service, and Apple News+, a paid-subscription version of its news app. The company's services segment, which includes App Store, iCloud, and content businesses, grew 24% to $37.1 billion in fiscal 2018.

site_title: US: Stocks bounce, shrugging off economic doubts
summary: US stocks rose 0.8% to 25,962.51, shrugging off economic doubts, with Apple leading the gain ahead of its product launch. The S&P 500 advanced 1.1% and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 1.4%. The rally came despite uncertainty over the US economy and ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Oil prices drop nearly 1% on fears recession may be looming
summary: Oil prices dropped nearly 1% on Monday due to concerns of a looming recession, despite Opec's production cuts and supply disruptions from US sanctions on Iran and Venezuela. Global economic data was disappointing, and the US-China trade war remained unresolved, leading to a risk-off sentiment that pressured commodity prices. West Texas Intermediate futures steadied after its biggest loss in three weeks, but concerns over a slowdown in global economic growth and a potential crude glut continued to linger.

site_title: Lyft's debut looks like Snap all over again, warns IPO analyst
summary: Lyft's upcoming IPO has drawn comparisons to Snap's ill-fated 2017 debut, with analyst Rett Wallace warning investors to look at Snap's IPO as a cautionary tale. Wallace, CEO of Triton Research Inc., advises investors to focus on Lyft's top line, as the company's profitability story and metrics are lacking. Similar IPOs with Triton scores below 5.5 have underperformed. However, some analysts, like Shyam Patil, believe Lyft's executives have set a low bar for financial estimates, potentially allowing for a near-term upward bias to its numbers.

site_title: Beyond the core: Singapore's office decentralisation
summary: Singapore's office decentralization efforts aim to shift office space outside the Central Business District (CBD) to create alternative options for businesses. Since 2010, developers have successfully attracted multinationals to areas like one-north, with The Metropolis contributing significantly to its annual revenue. However, industry players cite factors such as cost, occupier profile, and talent retention as concerns. Despite this, the government's plans to encourage non-office use in the CBD and new economic gateways in the east, west, and north may lead to more office decentralization. Analysts predict that decentralised areas will account for nearly 30% of Singapore's total office stock by 2023, driven by factors like the "hub-and-spoke model" and flexible working spaces.

site_title: Pacific Radiance narrows Q4 loss to US$76m
summary: Pacific Radiance reported a narrowed Q4 net loss of US$76 million, down from a net loss of US$296.5 million in the same period last year, due to lower costs and reduced joint venture losses. Revenue fell 22% to US$14.7 million, with subsea revenue declining 64% and offshore support services revenue growing 4%. The company will not pay dividends and is evaluating a merger proposal to expand its service offerings. Executive chairman Pang Yoke Min noted that the OSV sector faces challenging market conditions and subdued charter rates.

site_title: May tries to save Brexit plan ahead of EU summit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is set to write to EU President Donald Tusk with a plan to delay Brexit beyond March 29, amid a parliamentary deadlock. The plan, which could involve a 12-month extension, comes after May's divorce deal was rejected by MPs for a second time. European leaders warn that a prolonged extension could have "political and economic costs" for the remaining 27 EU states, and May's government is seeking to secure backing from the British parliament.

site_title: Finding value
summary: Singapore's private residential market has cooled down following last July's cooling measures, but analysts believe there is still pent-up demand. Despite higher stamp duties and loan-to-value ratios, property remains a key component of investors' portfolios due to its safety and security. Experts estimate 50-60 new private residential projects may be launched in 2019, and developers are positioning their products to capture buyer interest. The upcoming URA Master Plan will also shape the market's long-term potential, with regional hubs gaining importance through decentralization.

site_title: Lyft's IPO oversubscribed on road show's second day: sources
summary: Lyft's initial public offering (IPO) has been oversubscribed, indicating it is likely to fetch or exceed its target valuation of $23 billion. The ride-hailing startup has set an indicative price range of $62 to $68 per share and plans to price the IPO on March 28. Despite uncertainty over its path to profitability and autonomous driving strategy, investors are willing to overlook these concerns to participate in the IPO. This oversubscription bodes well for rival Uber, which is planning to launch its IPO in April.

site_title: Fidelity National to buy payment processor Worldpay for US$35b
summary: Fidelity National Information Services Inc (FIS) agreed to buy payment processor Worldpay for approximately $35 billion, valuing the company at $43 billion including debt. The deal, which comes two years after Worldpay merged with Vantiv, will retain FIS's name and be headquartered in Jacksonville, Florida. Upon closing, FIS shareholders will own about 53% and Worldpay shareholders will own about 47% of the combined company, with Worldpay shareholders receiving 0.9287 FIS shares and $11 in cash per share.

site_title: US: Wall St gains with tech; S&P 500 posts best week since November
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, led by technology companies, as a report on US-China trade talks lifted sentiment. The S&P 500 posted its best week since November, with the Nasdaq Composite reaching its best weekly gain this year. Chipmakers and technology stocks surged, while Boeing's shares fell 10.3% despite a software upgrade announcement. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 138.93 points, and the Nasdaq added 57.62 points.

site_title: NZ firms mull pulling ads from social media after mass shooting
summary: New Zealand companies are considering pulling their ads from social media platforms due to concerns over content moderation. Following the Christchurch mass shooting, two industry groups urged advertisers to reconsider their association with platforms unable or unwilling to take responsibility for hate content. State-owned Lotto NZ has already pulled its ads, and ASB Bank is in talks to do the same. The Association of New Zealand Advertisers and the Commercial Communications Council challenged Facebook and other platform owners to take steps to moderate hate content, citing the need for greater accountability.

site_title: Oxley receives S$1.025 billion offer for Chevron House
summary: Oxley Holdings has accepted a S$1.025 billion offer from US-based real estate fund AEW to acquire Chevron House in Raffles Place, a Grade-A office building. The purchase consideration works out to about S$2,739.43 psf on the increased NLA. The building has a total net lettable area of 261,280 sq ft and a 99-year leasehold tenure. Trading in Oxley shares will resume on Friday after a 3.13% gain on Wednesday.

site_title: Moinian gets US$595m loan to take back 3 Columbus Circle
summary: New York developer Moinian Group secured a $595 million loan from JPMorgan Chase & Co and Deutsche Bank AG to refinance 3 Columbus Circle, a Manhattan office tower. The loan replaces a $350 million loan and includes 10 years of interest-only payments at a 3.9% rate. Moinian, which had previously partnered with SL Green Realty Corp, now has full control of the property after buying out SL Green's 48.9% stake for $223 million. The 26-story building is fully leased and anchored by marketing agency VMLY&R.

site_title: China will allow cities to set their own property taxes
summary: China will allow cities to set their own property taxes, following the huge price differences between top-tier cities and hinterland cities. The move aims to address the challenge of creating a single tax regime for all markets. The decision is seen as a response to China's deeply segmented and polarized residential property market, with prices varying significantly between cities. This change is expected to give cities more flexibility in setting property taxes.

site_title: Emerging Asia's top bonds get fresh impetus from new governor
summary: Philippine central bank governor Benjamin Diokno is expected to implement looser monetary policies, potentially rewarding local-currency bond investors with bigger gains. The country's peso bonds have seen significant profits in global emerging markets, with yields reaching 6.6% this year. Diokno has suggested reducing the reserve ratio by 100 basis points every quarter for four quarters, and cutting the policy rate, which could support the rally in bonds. However, some analysts warn that the potential for looser monetary policy could also lead to a weakening of the peso.

site_title: Latest deals at the Fair
summary: The article discusses the latest deals at the Fair, specifically at the Takashimaya booth, which features golf apparel and equipment. However, the provided article does not contain information about the fair or deals. The article actually appears to be a collection of news summaries, covering various topics such as food, politics, economy, and business, including US jobless claims, China's efforts to aid employment, and Reliance Jio's delayed India IPO.

site_title: Divestment intent remains near record levels in region: poll
summary: South-east Asian companies are planning to divest at near-record levels, with 85% of firms in the region aiming to sell assets within the next two years. This is a significant increase from 2018, when only 26% of firms in the region had divestment intentions. Companies are driven by a desire to streamline their operating models, address geopolitical shifts, and capitalize on technology-driven changes. Industry consolidation and the need for agile management are also major factors. Experts warn that companies are leaving money on the table due to poor exit management and a lack of preparedness.

site_title: Fat cats or top dogs: Is the Singapore CEO overpaid?
summary: A recent controversy surrounding Hyflux's CEO compensation has sparked debate about whether CEOs in Singapore are overpaid. According to a Korn Ferry Hay Group study, the median total pay for CEOs in Singapore-listed companies was constant at S$625,000 in 2016. However, CEOs of large companies received a median remuneration of S$3.41 million, while those of small companies received S$375,000. The study found that long-term incentives (LTIs) make up 30-35% of total compensation for CEOs, but the LTI component is "quite modest" compared to other developed countries. Despite this, only 48% of performance share plans granted three years ago met threshold performance conditions, suggesting that the link between pay and performance may be weaker than initially thought.

site_title: Informatics Education proposes S$10.5 m rights issue
summary: Informatics Education plans to launch a renounceable non-underwritten rights issue to fund a business expansion. The issue, which may yield up to S$10.51 million, will see the company issuing up to 216.6 million new shares at S$0.05 apiece. The funds will be used for expansion, including online courses and licensing, and possibly awarding degrees to its British subsidiary. The issue must be approved by shareholders at an extraordinary general meeting, and major shareholders may be required to provide irrevocable undertakings to subscribe for rights shares.

site_title: Blackstone-backed firm seeks 47.5b rupees in India's first REIT
summary: Blackstone-backed Embassy Office Parks REIT plans to raise 47.5 billion rupees in India's first real estate investment trust (REIT) listing, with anchor investors subscribing to 8.76 billion rupees. The REIT, which includes Embassy Group properties, aims to open a fund-raising avenue for cash-starved property companies. A successful listing, expected by April 3, could attract more REITS to the market, potentially easing the sector's struggles with sluggish sales and price declines.

site_title: Asian markets rally in risk-on mood
summary: Asian markets rallied on Tuesday, driven by renewed optimism over the UK's revised Brexit deal and further progress in US-China trade talks. The Singapore Straits Times Index rose 0.65% to close at 3,212.25, while Tokyo's Nikkei index gained 1.8% to 21,503.69. However, Australia's ASX 200 edged lower due to losses in financials. The rally was also fueled by a Wall Street tech-led rally and higher crude oil prices.

site_title: Providing connections
summary: Orange Business Services CEO Helmut Reisinger emphasizes the importance of data in today's digital economy, stating that it enables "invisible empowerment" to companies. As the CEO of Orange's business services arm, OBS, Reisinger highlights the company's focus on data-driven solutions for businesses, including providing a global wide area managed network service to companies like Siemens. Reisinger notes that the telecommunications industry is at a crossroads, with the intersection of IT and telco worlds leading to a need for end-to-end enterprise-level IT communications services. He believes that data is the fourth factor of production, similar to land, labor, and capital, and that it can result in positive, creative destruction. Reisinger also emphasizes the importance of data privacy, citing the European General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) as a model for a strong approach to data protection. Despite challenges, Reisinger believes that trust is critical and that OBS is committed to making data available in a way that benefits both enterprise customers and consumers.

site_title: Trump team has no plan to go to China for trade talks: official
summary: The US and China have made progress in trade talks, but no plans have been made for a team to visit China for face-to-face negotiations. White House trade adviser Clete Willems stated that daily communication with Chinese officials continues, but no trip plans have been set. Despite concerns that President Trump may accept an agreement short of addressing key structural issues, Willems pushed back, saying a "bad deal" is "totally inaccurate." A meeting between Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping has yet to be scheduled.

site_title: Oil prices end mixed after US crude stocks build sharply
summary: Oil prices ended mixed on Wednesday after US crude inventories rose 7.1 million barrels, exceeding analysts' expectations. Brent crude futures rose 13 cents to $65.99 a barrel, while US crude oil futures fell 34 cents to $56.22 a barrel. Gasoline stocks dropped 4.2 million barrels, supporting prices. The mixed results were influenced by surging US crude production, which has undermined supply cuts led by OPEC, and the US equity market slump. The US President's trade talks with Beijing also contributed to the price volatility.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower; select aviation shares drag
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index ended down 8.77 points, or 0.41%, on Wednesday as investors cautiously watched US-China trade talks. Aviation shares, particularly those of T'way Air and Korean Air Lines, were affected by the crash of Boeing's 737 Max 8 jet. Foreigners were net buyers of 102.0 billion won worth of shares. The won fell 0.25% against the US dollar, while the benchmark bond yield fell by 1.4 basis points.

site_title: Hanoi summit debacle: Peace deal trumped by 2020 election prospects
summary: US President Donald Trump abruptly ended the Hanoi summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un due to domestic politics and differing ideas on "denuclearization". Trump's former lawyer Michael Cohen testified before Congress about Trump's involvement in the 2016 presidential election and warned of a potential non-peaceful transition of power if Trump lost re-election. National Security Advisor John Bolton persuaded Trump to demand North Korea dismantle all nuclear capabilities, leading to the collapse of the summit and no deal. The failure will have significant regional implications, particularly for South Korean President Moon Jae-in, who will now have to stick with US sanctions policy.

site_title: Hard drive for success
summary: Neelam Dhawan, a 36-year IT industry veteran, remains highly driven and passionate about her career, despite being recognized as one of the most powerful businesswomen worldwide. She attributes her success to her ability to think critically and lead teams, skills she developed in her early career at IBM, Microsoft, and HP. Dhawan emphasizes the importance of self-assignment, goal-setting, and delegation to achieve work-life balance. She advises women to prioritize their careers and be bold in speaking their minds, while also appreciating their progress and accomplishments. With a long career ahead, Dhawan remains committed to her work, seeking new challenges and opportunities to give back to the industry she has learned from.

site_title: China's local govt financing vehicles are now darlings of bond market
summary: China's local government financing vehicles (LGFVs) have become popular in the bond market, with yields decreasing to below those of corporate bonds. The surge in LGFV bonds is driven by the government's easing measures and investors seeking high-yield assets, as the private sector faces rising defaults. However, experts warn that the government's continued support may lead to moral hazard, and the rally in LGFV notes may be short-lived and volatile. The government has acknowledged the need for market-based solutions to address LGFV debt problems, but has yet to take decisive action.

site_title: Singapore top in Asia-Pacific for quality of living and personal safety: survey
summary: Singapore has ranked as the top city in Asia-Pacific for quality of living and personal safety, according to Mercer's 2019 survey. The top five cities are Singapore, Tokyo, Kobe, Yokohama, and Osaka. Hong Kong and Seoul rose two places from last year. Singapore's high ranking is attributed to its continuous improvement in standard of living, connectivity, and sustainability. Notable cities in South-east Asia include Kuala Lumpur, Bangkok, and Jakarta, while Phnom Penh ranks lowest for personal safety.

site_title: EU could impose more sanctions against Venezuela's Maduro: Germany's Maas
summary: Germany's foreign minister Heiko Maas stated that the European Union will respond to further developments in Venezuela and may impose additional sanctions against President Nicolas Maduro. The EU has already recognized opposition leader Juan Guaido as interim president and increased pressure on Maduro to step down. Maas said the EU will monitor developments and may consider further sanctions, which would target the Maduro regime. This move comes as the US and other countries, including Germany, have recognized Guaido as interim president and increased pressure on Maduro to step down.

site_title: China's customs is said to lift suspension on Tesla Model 3 imports
summary: China's customs has lifted a suspension on imports of Tesla's Model 3 sedan, a move that affects over 4,600 cars that may have misprinted or missing local-language labels. Tesla is fixing the labels under customs supervision and will resume clearances after they pass review. The company initially stated that it had reached a resolution with Chinese customs and that Model 3 sales in China aren't affected. The move comes after a previous suspension due to label issues.

images.alt_text: China's customs has lifted a suspension on imports of Tesla Inc's Model 3 sedan, a person familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Singapore business sentiment slips for 3rd straight quarter
summary: Singapore businesses show decreasing optimism for the second quarter of 2019, marking the third consecutive quarter of waning sentiment. The Business Optimism Index fell to +5.08 percentage points, down from +7.19 in Q1 2019. Financial and services sectors remained optimistic, while manufacturing and wholesale saw downward moderations due to weaker external demand and a slowdown in China. SCCB chief Audrey Chia attributed the decline to external factors, but expects the services and financial sectors to drive growth in the first half of 2019.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Far East Orchard, OUE Lippo Healthcare, OUE
summary: Far East Orchard has acquired three British student housing properties for £55 million (S$98.7 million), expanding its portfolio to 2,091 beds across eight properties. OUE Lippo Healthcare's subsidiary had its claim against a former legal representative dismissed by a Shanghai court. OUE has picked up food and beverage outlet operator Superfood Retail for S$7.53 million, valuing it at 6.9 times earnings. These developments may affect trading of their shares on Monday.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks plunge on China's weak export data; won hits 4-month low
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index plummeted 1.31% to 2,137.44 points, its lowest trading level since January 24, due to China's weak export data and concerns over a global economic slowdown. The won hit a 4-month low, falling 0.63% to 1,136.2 per dollar. European policymakers slashed growth forecasts, and the benchmark bond yields fell. The Kospi has lost 2.6% this week, its biggest weekly loss since October 2018.

site_title: Malaysia plans to halt all expansion of palm oil plantations
summary: Malaysia plans to halt the expansion of palm oil plantations this year, capping the area at around 6 million hectares, in an effort to dispel the oil's reputation as a driver of deforestation. The move comes as the European Union considers a delegated act classifying palm oil from large plantations as unsustainable. Malaysia's Minister of Primary Industries, Teresa Kok, aims to boost productivity and yields of existing palm trees, while also launching a "Love My Palm Oil" campaign to promote the industry and gather support at home.

site_title: Legaltech and the law: How tech will change the practice
summary: Lawyers are embracing technology, with 88% of decision-makers believing it improves the delivery of legal services and 82% seeing technology adoption as crucial for firms to stay competitive. However, technology is also threatening junior lawyers' work and law firm structures. Alternative legal service providers (ALSPs), enabled by technology, are giving lawyers a run for their money, with 23% of large law firms surveyed losing business to ALSPs. To address these challenges, initiatives such as the Singapore Academy of Law's Legal Technology Vision and Future Law Innovation Programme aim to help lawyers integrate technology into their processes and encourage an exchange of ideas between the tech and legal sectors. Despite the benefits, many law firms remain "old school" in practice, and a change in mindset is needed for lawyers to fully harness the power of technology.

site_title: Oil little changed as market awaits US-China trade deal
summary: Oil prices held near flat on Tuesday as investors awaited a potential US-China trade deal. Brent settled at $65.86 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude settled at $56.56 a barrel. The market wavered on Opec-led supply cuts and Libya's restart of its largest oilfield, but was also influenced by concerns over China's economic slowdown, which may lead to weaker fuel demand. The US government's official crude inventory data is due on Wednesday.

site_title: The capital conundrum
summary: Singapore's tax policy is seen as pro-business, with low corporate taxes and no capital gains tax, making it an attractive destination for foreign investments. However, experts argue that this approach may not be equitable, as it favors capital over labor and contributes to rising income inequality. To strike a better balance, some propose introducing a low tax rate on capital gains and increasing the top end of the individual tax scale. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat has suggested targeting wealth taxes on fixed assets like property, but experts caution against this approach due to its potential impact on lower- and middle-income households.

images.alt_text: Are we doing enough to reward labour?
As of May 2018, Singapore maintained its World Bank ranking as the second-best country in terms of ease of doing business, behind New Zealand and ahead of Denmark and Hong Kong.

"While further taxes on real property ownership may be easy to administer, they would likely affect this segment of the population the most. Individuals who are better off have the ability to diversify their investments and even to move them elsewhere if need be." - PwC Singapore tax leader Chris Woo.
Singapore's tax rate, at 17 per cent since 2010, compares favourably to other financial hubs, says Head of tax at Ernst & Young Solutions Soh Pui Ming.

"The most sustainable way to achieve a fair distribution of society's resources is to ensure a strong and resilient economy." - Harvey Koenig (above), head of Asean Incentives Advisory at KPMG Singapore.

site_title: Deutsche Bank setting up a bad-loan buying unit in India: sources
summary: Deutsche Bank is setting up a unit in India to buy and reorganize soured debt, following the country's rules that restrict overseas investors from directly buying bad loans. This move comes as India has one of the world's worst non-performing loan ratios. The German bank aims to profit from the bad-loan clean up, similar to Bank of America Corp, which is also considering setting up a similar unit. The move is a response to the 2002 law allowing overseas investors to fully own asset reconstruction companies, but with current rules still limiting their direct involvement.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank AG is setting up a unit in India to buy and reorganise soured debt as it seeks to profit from an unprecedented bad-loan clean up in the nation with one of the world's worst non-performing loan ratios, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Top-ranked Osaka one of new Barbie 'Sheroes'
summary: Naomi Osaka, world number one tennis player, has expressed her surprise and gratitude to be part of Mattel's new 'Sheroes' series of Barbie dolls, joining gymnast Laurie Hernandez and Olympic fencer Ibtihaj Muhammad. Osaka, who won her second straight Grand Slam title at the Australian Open, sees this as an opportunity to represent people who may not think they can be represented. She also acknowledges the responsibility that comes with being a role model, reflecting on her own childhood and aspirations.

images.alt_text: World number one Naomi Osaka said Thursday she finds it "a little bit surreal" that there's a new version of the iconic Barbie doll in her likeness.

site_title: Plans in place for homegrown cyber security skills and tools
summary: Singapore is taking steps to boost its cyber security industry, with measures to develop homegrown talent and products. Senior Minister Janil Puthucheary announced plans to certify cyber security products to international standards, allowing local companies to save time and money. The government will also support on-the-job training for the private sector and develop cyber security specialists for the public sector. This is part of Singapore's goal to become a regional hub for product evaluation and certification, attracting global evaluation laboratories and innovative solutions.

images.alt_text: Dr Puthucheary says Singapore's status as a certifier of cyber security products to international technical standards is a building block for the industry.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit 5-month high on trade war resolution hopes
summary: European shares hit a 5-month high on Monday, rising 0.2% as investors hopeful for a US-China trade deal, which could end uncertainty and boost riskier assets. The Stoxx 600 index is up 11% this year, with cyclical stocks outperforming defensives. Weaker-than-expected US construction data weighed on the session, but hopes for a trade deal lifted shares in companies like IAG, Daily Mail & General Trust, and Interparfums.

site_title: MSCI EM Index's A-share boost to drive portfolio rebalancing
summary: MSCI is increasing the weighting of Chinese A-shares in its benchmark indices, giving global investors more investment opportunities. Analysts predict active and passive funds will rebalance their asset allocation, with China A-shares expected to reach 3.3% of the MSCI EM Index by 2020. This move is seen as a step towards China's full integration into the global market, offering diversification benefits and deeper investment opportunities for global investors.
